HEADLINE: Bush Orders Quicker Expenditure Of $9.7 Billion to Aid Economy

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5

 BODY:
President Bush issued orders today to speed up the spending of $9.7 billion of Federal money in an effort to kick life into the nation's listless economy.
The announcement followed months of assertions by Democrats and some Republicans that Mr. Bush was neglecting the nation's economic problems. 
 Some economists welcomed Mr. Bush's action as a modest step in the right direction. Others said the accelerated spending would have a small effect in a nation that produces goods and services worth more than $5 trillion a year.
The $9.7 billion, already appropriated by Congress, will be spent within the next four months rather than later in 1992, as originally planned, the White House said.
 
Loans and Construction Money
 The money is earmarked for uses like rural housing loans, farm loans, conservation programs, construction of sewage treatment plants, construction of runways at airports and payments to military contractors. "We're also considering additional spending accelerations that may be possible," the President said at a news conference today.
Moreover, Mr. Bush said, "I intend to propose a new package of programs that will stimulate growth in the economy for both the short and the long terms." He declined to give details today, saying he would announce the proposals in his State of the Union Message next month.
Mr. Bush said the accelerated spending of $9.7 billion would provide a "shot in the arm" for the economy. But Rudolph G. Penner, who served as director of the Congressional Budget Office from 1983 to 1987, said, "A small amount like that would clearly not have a lot of economic effect."
Mr. Penner said the acceleration of spending "won't do any harm and might do a very little bit of good in creating some momentum for an economic recovery that doesn't have much momentum."
In annual appropriations for Federal agencies, Congress makes money available for a specific fiscal year. The President and his budget director have some discretion in apportioning the money over the course of the year. To stimulate the economy, Mr. Bush said he was ordering the "earliest possible expenditure" of the $9.7 billion.
 
'Steps in the Right Direction'
 Irwin L. Kellner, senior vice president and chief economist at the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, in New York, said: "The steps announced by the President today are steps in the right direction. I would call for an even bolder program in which the Government hires unemployed construction workers and puts them to work on highways, bridges, tunnels and water and sewer systems. Once you hire an unemployed person, that person will spend every dollar you give them."
The biggest item in the list of accounts designated for accelerated spending is $3 billion in grants to states for construction of sewage treatment plants. The list also includes $1.9 billion for airport construction and $1.9 billion in loans to help farmers purchase and operate farms.
The Pentagon expects to speed up the spending of $1 billion by signing military contracts sooner than planned and by paying contractors more promptly.
Robert D. Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office, said that despite Mr. Bush's action, there would probably be a lag in the actual use of some of the $9.7 billion. For example, he said, after the Federal Government makes money available, the sponsors of a construction project may still need to sign contracts, obtain permits or get approval from local environmental protection officials. So the accelerated disbursement of money may mean that the project begins nine months, rather than 12 months, from now.
Moreover, Mr. Reischauer said, because of harsh weather in many parts of the country, it is usually difficult to start construction of highways and other projects in the winter months.
Paul Craig Roberts, a supply-side economist who served as Assistant Secretary of the Treasury in 1981 and 1982, said the accelerated spending might help some Government contractors. "But then again," he said, "it could have a bad impact if people are looking for decisive action and see a warmed-over New Deal approach."

HEADLINE: Factory Orders Rose 1.9% in October

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5

 BODY:
Orders for American manufactured goods rose by 1.9 percent in October, the Government said today in a report that left analysts generally unimpressed.
The Commerce Department said orders for durable and nondurable goods climbed to a seasonally adjusted $242.12 billion in October, as a huge surge in demand for military hardware offset weakness in areas like automobiles. 
 But without the big rise in military orders, total orders would have actually been up by a smaller amount in October, six-tenths of a percent.
The 1.9 percent rise was the first since July, but it failed to make up for declines of 2.3 percent in September and 2 percent in August.
 
Weak Consumer Spending
 Manufacturing had been one of the few bright spots in the economy earlier in the year, as order books filled up and factories rehired workers.
But consumers have since failed to respond with increased spending, especially for big-ticket items like cars.
Analysts said they expected further setbacks in orders in the months ahead, and they said that would translate into further production cutbacks and layoffs.
The manufacturing weakness is one of the reasons many analysts are raising the odds that the fragile recovery will topple back into a full-fledged recession.
"Manufacturing generally leads the country out of recession and is one of the major sources of growth, and that is clearly not happening this time," said Mark Zandi, an economist at Regional Financial Associates, a consulting firm in West Chester, Pa.
 
Growing Concerns
 John Silvia, an economist at Kemper Financial Services Inc. in Chicago, said concern was growing that the overall economy would begin shrinking again in the final three months of the year.
He said business inventories had risen rapidly in the third quarter and unless those were reduced by strong holiday sales, American industry would be forced to cut back on production in the coming months.
That, Mr. Silvia added, would translate into further declines in the gross domestic product.
The report on manufacturing orders said demand for durable goods, items expected to last three or more years, climbed by 3 percent, to a seasonally adjusted $123.75 billion in October. The figure was essentially unchanged from an advance report a week ago.
Orders for nondurable goods climbed by seven-tenths of a percent, to $118.37 billion, after a drop of one-tenth of a percent the previous month.
Much of the strength in October came in demand for military hardware, which shot up 55.5 percent after having fallen 48.9 percent the previous month.
Orders for transportation equipment posted the biggest increase during the month, rising by 12 percent, to $32.9 billion.
But the rise came from higher demand for military aircraft, ships and tanks. Orders for motor vehicles and parts fell, as the auto industry continued to experience weak sales.
Shipments of factory orders, a gauge of current production, rose by 1.1 percent, to $244.9 billion. It was the seventh straight increase, putting shipments at their highest level since November 1990.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Posts Are Consolidated At American National

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON

 BODY:
The American National Can Company announced yesterday that Jean-Pierre Ergas, chief executive since 1989, had been named to the additional post of chairman.
As producer of cans for Coca-Cola, toothpaste tubes for Colgate-Palmolve, bottles for Oil of Olay and other products, the $4.7-billion-a-year company says it is the world's largest maker of beverage cans and plastic-based tubes. 
 Mr. Ergas, 52, replaces Jean Gandois, who will remain as chairman of the parent company, the Pechiney Group of France, a state-owned packaging and metals concern.
"It was a natural step to take," Mr. Ergas said. "It was the plan all along." He added that Mr. Gandois no longer needed to be chairman "of both mother and daughter companies."
"My close personal involvement is no longer necessary," Mr. Gandois said in a statement.
American National Can was formed in 1987 in a merger of the American Can Company and the National Can Company. It was purchased by Pechiney a year later.
Sales volume this year is expected to grow by 3.5 percent, to $4.7 billion, which Mr. Ergas called "not too bad in this economy." He predicted above average growth in 1992.
Under Mr. Ergas's direction, American National Can has taken advantage of Pechiney's expertise in metallurgy by marketing a fluted can that is easier to grip.
Of the approximately 90 million beverage cans that will be produced in the United States this year, 500 million, or less than 1 percent, are fluted. American National produced about 25 million cans this year.
Mr. Ergas is also supervising the company's international expansion in Europe, with operations scheduled to open in Barcelona, Spain and Dunkirk, France.
When Mr. Ergas arrived at American National in 1989, he stressed his personal commitment to the company by moving to Chicago from Paris and putting his children into local schools.
"To be successful in the United States, you have to be a strong professional and a good citizen," he said yesterday. He is still a French citizen.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Rates Rise Ahead of New Jobs Data

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Interest rates rose slightly yesterday in quiet trading as investors and securities dealers digested new issues and waited for today's report on November employment to provide new clues to future rate changes.
Many analyts expect a weak employment report to be the catalyst for another move by the Federal Reserve to push short-term rates lower. 
Although long-term bond yields are unusually high compared to short-term rates, two of the nation's largest corporations -- A.T.& T. and General Motors -- have decided that conditions are favorable for large new long-term issues.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company offered $676 million of 40-year debentures with a yield of 8.65 percent yesterday, while G.M. plans to offer $1 billion of preferred stock with a yield of 9.125 percent today.
 
First Sale Since 1986
 The A.T.& T. sale was its first public offering of long-term debt since 1986. It was handled by Morgan Stanley & Company, which offered the 8 5/8 percent debentures at 99.716. A.T.& T. intends to use proceeds of the sale to redeem 8 3/4 percent debentures due in 2000, which it issued in 1970.
"We thought interest rates were favorable at current levels, and we did not want to wait until later in the year when it can be more difficult to sell large issues," said Peter M. Sperling, a director of corporate finance in the treasurer's office at A.T.& T.
The General Motors preferred stock has no maturity but is protected from early retirement by the company for seven years rather than five as initially planned. Merrill Lynch & Company handled the issue.
 
$500 Million G.E. Issue
 Other large corporate offerings yesterday included a $500 million issue of two-year notes by the General Electric Company with a yield of 5.91 percent through underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company.
A Merrill Lynch group also offered $100 million of 10-year notes for the Republic New York Corporation with a 7.95 percent yield.
While securities dealers in the corporate market were distributing new offerings and planning for several more corporate issues before the holidays, dealers of Treasury securities said trading and investor demand were quiet in advance of the Commerce Department's November employment report to be issued today.
 
Jobs Decline Expected
 Many economists expect the report to show a decline of about 30,000 workers in non-farm payrolls -- another sign that the economic recovery that began in the spring is slowing. That decline in jobs would be far less than the monthly average decline of 200,000 workers during the October 1990 to April 1991 recessionary period, but many economists expect it will be large enough to cause the Federal Reserve to ease monetary policy another notch and push short-term interest rates lower.
Prices of Treasury bonds were little changed, with the bellwether 30-year Treasury bond rising by about 1/8 point, or $1.25 per $1,000 bond, to 100 7/8 to yield 7.84 percent.
Among shorter-term note issues, which offer lower yields but less risk of loss when interest rates begin rising, the 5 1/2 percent Treasury issue due in November 1993 was offered at 100 14/32, down 3/32, to yield 5.27 percent. The 6 1/2 percent Treasury notes due in 1996 were offered at 100 24/32, down 5/32, to yield 6.32 percent.
 
Growth in Money Supply
 Although the Fed's moves to reduce interest rates earlier this year have not prevented the economy from stalling, there are signs that the Fed has succeeded in stimulating faster growth in the nation's money supply -- a precursor, some economists say, to a stronger economy.
Including a $2.1 billion increase in the M-2 money supply measure for the week ended Nov. 25, the money supply measure is now within its 2.5 percent to 6.5 percent growth target for the year. Earlier this month, it was below the growth target.
Although recent Fed moves to lower short-term interst rates have not brought long-term bond yields much below the levels reached in February, some analysts still foresee lower bond yields as investors buy longer issues in order to earn a yields.
"Another Fed easing move could help the bond market, if Fed officials do a better job educating the market and explaining that inflation will remain low," said Victor Chang, president of the VC Management Company, an economic advisory firm. "Earlier this year, the Fed overemphasized the inflationary threat, and that has led to unrealistic fears among long-term bond investors."
Another idea for lowering long -erm rates -- reducing the amount of new bonds issued by the Treasury -- is under consideration, the Secretary of the Treausry, Nicholas F. Brady, said yesterday. He noted, however, that the Treasury already did most of its borrowing in the short-term markets, and that 30-year bonds accounted for only about 7.5 percent of net new Treasury borrowings.

HEADLINE: Chrysler to Pay Bonuses To 19,000 of Its Workers

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, Dec. 5

 BODY:
The Chrysler Corporation, financially the weakest of the Big Three, said today that it would pay holiday bonuses to 19,000 white-collar workers. The bonus amounts to $600 for most workers, meaning an outlay for Chrysler of almost $12 million.
The decision comes less than a week after the General Motors Corporation, the nation's largest auto maker, elected to forgo bonuses for its 107,000 salaried employees. The Ford Motor Company said today that it had decided to forgo a bonus, which would have been paid in the spring. Ford did not pay its bonus last spring either. 
 Lee Sechler, a Chrysler spokesman, said, "We decided to pay because of the many sacrifices made by the salaried group." Mr. Sechler said that over the last few years, cost-cutting measures that had reduced salaried benefits had also been hard on workers.
"As the staff gets smaller, the work load doesn't get any smaller," Mr. Sechler said. Chrysler's securities are rated the lowest among the Big Three, making it difficult to borrow money or sell debt securities. But the auto maker is hopeful that several new models set to make their debut in 1992 and an uptick in the economy might bail it out.
 
Salaried Workers' Bonus
 The bonus for salaried workers was first paid last year, following a new contract by the United Automobile Workers that provided for a similar amount for all hourly workers.
Like G.M., Chrysler had asked the union to consider forgoing the bonus this year in light of the deep losses being suffered by the industry and persistent weak demand for vehicles. The union said no to both auto makers. Auto makers have typically kept parity between wage and benefit increases for salaried and hourly workers to prevent low morale or provide inroads for futher union organization efforts.
Since the first of the year Chrysler has lost $892 million, G.M. has lost $2.2 billion and Ford has lost $1.78 billion. Among the belt-tightening measures have been dividend cuts, worker buyouts and price concessions from suppliers. At each auto maker the top few thousand executives are normally eligible for large annual bonuses, which may constitute half of annual compensation. But last year, and probably this year, bonus-eligible executives are not being paid bonuses.

HEADLINE: Dow Off 22.58, to 2,889.09, As Trading Volume Falls

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks closed lower yesterday, with a growing number of investors taking to the sidelines ahead of today's November employment numbers. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 22.58 points, to finish at 2,889.09.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was a moderate 166.4 million, compared with 187.9 million on Wednesday. Losing issues outpaced gainers by 1,037 to 619. 
 The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fell by 2.68, to 377.39, while the Big Board composite slipped 1.17, to 208.96. In American Stock Exchange trading, the composite was down 0.52, to 371.80.
 
Small Stocks Slip Too
 In over-the-counter trading the Nasdaq index was down 1.25 points, to 534.03, and the Russell 2,000 index, a barometer of small company issues slipped 0.60 points, to finish at 177.23.
Harry W. Laubsher, a senior vice president and market analyst for Tucker Anthony Inc., said: "Whenever you have investors moving to the sidelines, you always open the market up to increased volatility. If recent support levels can hold, then a 5 to 10 percent rally should occur and carry over into January. An employment number taken more positively than negatively could begin the rally early, but if it is taken adversely, the market could move quickly to test the support level of 2,850 on the Dow."
Wall Street stocks were mixed in early trading, and with few buyers participating the market moved lower. A 1.9 percent increase in factory orders for October, compared with a forecast of 1.5 percent, had little impact.
 
Awaiting Unemployment Data
 Ricky Harrington, a technical analyst for Marion Bass Securities, said the employment numbers scheduled for release today would be significant, because the market is more focused on the economy than on interest rates. As a result stocks are not likely to rally if the Federal Reserve Board eases interest rates after the jobs data are released.
Blue chip issues fell throughout the trading session, with futures related program selling contributing to yesterday's decline. Birinyi Associates, a research firm which tracks program trades tracked eight sell programs and one buy program yesterday. The combined impact pulled the Dow lower by 29.97 points.
Boeing stock rose 3/4, to 42 1/8 after declining the previous day. Analysts said the previous day's decline was an overreaction by the market to comments by the company's chief executive, Frank Shrontz, that Boeing would not be able to sustain planned production levels if the airliner market did not improve.
 
Recommendation Improved
 Genetics Institutes, a biopharmaceutical company, rose 1, to 38 1/4, as Robert S. Kupor, an analyst at Kidder, Peabody, adjusted his rating on the company to a "trading buy" from a "hold."
Shares of Lotus Development rose 2, to 20 3/4, in active trading after an announcement that it plans to cut costs aggressively. The computer software company said it would trim its work force by almost 10 percent and exert tighter controls on discretionary spending.
Richard R. Stover an analyst at Alex. Brown & Sons said his rating change on Upjohn, to "hold," from a "buy," was purely a precautionary move ahead of next week's meeting of a European regulatory committee regarding Upjohn's Halcion, a drug for insomnia. The stock closed down 1 5/8, to finish at 38 3/8.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Chief of Lukens Quits Before Planned Date

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
Lukens Inc., a big steelmaker embroiled in a two-month-old strike, said yesterday that its chairman and chief executive, William R. Wilson, resigned six months before his previously announced retirement date.
His duties will be assumed by R. William Van Sant, who has been president and chief operating officer since October. 
 The company had announced Mr. Van Sant's promotion months ago. But Mr. Wilson's retirement was not expected until he reached age 65 next May. W. Evelyn Walker, a spokeswoman for the company, said the resignation was not related to the labor dispute, though she added that the reason for Mr. Wilson's early departure was unclear.
Lukens, based in Coatesville, Pa., is the nation's third-largest producer of plate steel used in construction, shipbuilding and transportation. While other steelmakers were battered by the recession, Lukens remained strong because of its niches in highly profitable corrosion-protective steel and high-quality steel. The company also developed a growing business in highway products and in goods and services for the mining and energy industries.
Mr. Van Sant, 53 years old, has been a director of Lukens since 1988. He has extensive experience in manufacturing, aerospace and construction. He rose to vice president for manufacturing and engineering at Deere & Company, where he worked for 26 years. Then he served as president and chief operating officer of the Cessna Aircraft Company.
He joined Blount Inc., a Montgomery Ala., construction company, in 1987 and had been president and chief executive since 1990.
Mr. Van Sant holds bachelor's and master's degrees from the University of Iowa. He is married and has three sons and two daughters.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Copper Hits 15-Week Lows On London Market Easing

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
Copper prices fell to their lowest levels in 15 weeks yesterday, as the market responded to a relaxation of what several analysts viewed as an artificially tight supply situation on the London copper market.
Earlier this week, the London Metal Exchange placed limits on the price premium paid for the nearest delivery month over the succeeding month, in order to defuse what some traders viewed as an attempted supply squeeze. 
 A Japanese concern, Sumitomo, denied that it was hoarding supplies, which are fairly plentiful worldwide, and futures prices fell this week in London and on the Commodity Exchange in New York.
The Comex December copper contract lost 2.05 cents a pound yesterday, to 98.50 cents.
Analysts said a sluggish recovery from recession in the United States and weak growth elsewhere were limiting industrial demand for copper.
"A balanced market is projected in 1992, which will lead to generally stable prices," Fred Demler, a metals economist at Paine Webber Inc., said at an industry conference yesterday.
On the New York Mercantile Exchange, crude oil for January delivery fell 37 cents a barrel, to $20.39.
On the New York Cotton Exchange, cotton prices dropped to a new three-year low, with the March delivery down 0.89 cent, to 58.57 cents a pound.
Traders said the Agriculture Department was expected to again cut a critical price marked to keep American cotton exports competitive on the world market.
"That is weighing on people's minds, as well as a potential cut in exports in next week's U.S.D.A. report," said Sharon Johnson, an analyst with Cargill Investor Services.
On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, feeder cattle contracts plunged in line with a recent tumble in fully fed live cattle prices, and wheat prices edged up again.
The March feeder cattle contract plummeted 1.35 cents a pound, to 77.575 cents, as operators of cattle feedlots lowered their bids for unfed cattle because of poor profit margins.
February live cattle edged down 0.45 cent, to 73.65 cents a pound.
At the Chicago Board of Trade, wheat futures again posted new highs, but some analysts said the market might be running out of steam.
March wheat rose 1.75 cents a bushel, to $3.85 1/4, after the Soviet Union tendered for 500,000 metric tons of American wheat. The Soviets will use the first installment of loan guarantees recently granted by the Bush Administration to make the purchase.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Full-Price Brands Fighting Off Assault by Cheaper Rivals

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
AS the souring economy spurs shoppers to buy lower-priced products, some marketers of full-price packaged goods are fighting back.
Consumers "still want to buy a name brand, but they don't want to pay a big price," said Deepak Raj, an analyst who follows household and personal-care products for Merrill Lynch Research in New York. "That puts pressure on the manufacturers." 
 Typifying the way companies are seeking to reverse buyers' switching to lower-priced goods, which advertising and marketing executives call "trading down," are television commercials sponsored by Procter & Gamble for its Dawn dishwashing liquid. In the spots, created by D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles in New York, a woman recounts her decision to switch from Dawn to a "value brand," which, she says, provided less effective grease-cutting power.
"Will I switch again?" she asks. "I'm thrifty, not crazy." The spots, which have been running since August in 15- and 30-second versions, end with the usual Dawn slogan -- "Takes grease out of your way" -- plus an additional line, "And that's the real value."
The current economic climate provides "as good a time as any to convey the outstanding performance and real value that Dawn provides to consumers," said Chris Burbank, a P.&G. spokeswoman in Cincinnati. But she added that the company considered the spots, which have been appearing in addition to the old Dawn commercials, to represent no departure from Dawn's basic advertising theme, which has been running since 1976.
The counterattack against lower-priced products is similar to what occurred during the late 1970's and early 1980's. Then, the target was "no name" generic products, which came in plain wrappers and were priced below name brands and store brands.
Now, the target is what the Dawn spots refer to as value brands, which are priced below full-price brands, but above generics and private labels. An example of a value brand is Suave, a line of hair-care and personal-care items made by Helene Curtis Inc. and priced less than P.&G. brands like Prell shampoo and Sure deodorant.
The counterattack also mirrors recent developments in the fast-food industry. Last year, the McDonald's Corporation introduced an upbeat, image-oriented campaign, by Leo Burnett U.S.A. in Chicago, that carried the theme "Food, folks and fun." But when sales growth stalled, in large part because of lower-priced menu items introduced by rivals like Wendy's International and Taco Bell, McDonald's regrouped; a revamped campaign, called "McDonald's today," has been presenting what the company considers the values that customers can find under the Golden Arches.
If consumers believe there is "not that much difference" between a full-price brand and its lower-priced competitor, "then today, you're in trouble," said D. Frederick Baker, senior vice president and director of market research at McCann-Erickson New York.
As a result, he added, makers of full-price products "have to protect, nurture and expand their emotional ties with the consumer." And one method of achieving that, he continued, is "to be associated with delivering quality at a level" that consumers would perceive to be unmatched by lower-priced competitors.
Some packaged-goods companies are not participating in the trend. "Our strategy really hasn't changed," said Sharon Morganstern, director of consumer affairs at the Lever Brothers Company in New York.
Rather than run advertising that pummels lower-priced brands, Lever is instead continuing to distribute what she termed tons of cents-off coupons, redeemable on purchases of its full-price brands like Wisk detergent.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
The First Draft of I.B.M.'s Future

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
Just how far I.B.M. is prepared to go to free itself from the large-system computer business that has been its bread and butter became obvious yesterday when it separated a $2 billion printer company and its $11 billion disk drive business from its mainframe division.
"By freeing these individual companies we are establishing competition, and that's healthy," John F. Akers, chairman of the International Business Machines Corporation, said in a telephone interview. 
 I.B.M. said it would establish the Pennant Systems Company to develop and manufacture advanced printers and related software and services. The company will be a wholly owned subsidiary run by James T. Vanderslice, an I.B.M. vice president who will report to Terry R. Lautenbach, a senior vice president.
Mr. Vanderslice has been senior managing director of manufacturing and development for the company's Asia-Pacific region. The new company will be based in Norwalk, Conn.
 
New Data Systems Unit
 I.B.M., whose headquarters are in Armonk, N.Y., also established its data systems division as a new line of business, known as Storage Products, to be run by Ray S. AbuZayyad, who was named general manager. He will also report to Mr. Lautenbach.
"It's the end of the mainframe hegemony," said Rick Martin, a Wall Street financial analyst at Prudential Securities and a former product manager for one of I.B.M.'s mainframe computers.
I.B.M. also provided fresh details on new management and financial measurement systems designed to build independence and accountability into each of its business. It said it would establish systems of reporting and measuring financial results and tie compensation to performance.
Mr. Akers also said the company was planning, perhaps as soon as its 1992 annual report -- which will be released in February 1993 -- to give a never-before-public look at the details of the company's financial performance, giving performance data on each of its businesses.
Until now, I.B.M. has given revenue data only on major business categories like mainframe processors, personal computers, work stations and software; it has not broken down data on each operation's profitability.
Mr. Akers also said that decisions on selling equity in I.B.M.'s newly independent businesses would not be made quickly. "We're not going to wake up next spring and do something," he said. "We are establishing an environment."
"Our intention is to go public with all the financial results of these businesses," he said. "We want these businesses to be publicly visible and publicly measurable and publicly accountable. You have to do that first before you can deal with the equity issue."
Since the mid-1980's, the fastest- growing segment of the computer industry has been personal computers and more powerful computers known as work stations, both of which are increasingly linked by office networks.
Mr. Akers bridled at the suggestion that I.B.M. had not pursued opportunities in personal computers and work stations for fear of competing with its more profitable but slower- growing large-systems business.
"I think that is a bunch of baloney," he said. "In the final analysis, the customer has something he wants to do. If he wants to do it with a mainframe, we'll sell those to him. If he wants a local area network, we can provide that as well."
Mr. Akers identified software and services as two businesses where high growth is expected and said the changes the company was making should help it pursue those opportunities. He said that next year he expected the company's newly formed services business to have $5 billion in revenue and a 30 percent annual growth rate.
 
Memo to Employees
 In a memo describing the changes, which was distributed yesterday to its 350,000 employees, I.B.M. reassured its workers that it was not ending its no-layoffs policy. But in an unusual caveat at the end of the document, the company noted that full employment was not a guarantee at I.B.M. and depended in part on the health of the economy. It also said it was "impossible to predict" what actions the independent businesses will take as they evolve.
The company has reduced its employment by 65,000 through voluntary departures and retirements between 1986 and 1991.
The company yesterday also made several management changes affecting both its Personal Systems and Applications Business Systems businesses, which sell personal computers, work stations and more powerful minicomputers. In Personal Systems, an executive board was established, composed of marketing executives from I.B.M.
I.B.M. also established a new group called the Employment Solutions Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary that will provide hiring and recruiting services to I.B.M. in the United States and market those services to other companies. Each I.B.M. business will still do its own recruiting and hiring, while the new company will help schedule interviews and test and screen applicants.
On the New York Stock Exchange, I.B.M. stock gained 25 cents a share, closing at $90.25.

HEADLINE: Layoffs in the Auto Industry Send Jobless Claims Higher

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 5

 BODY:
Seasonal layoffs in the auto industry and other industrial cutbacks threw nearly a half-million workers into the jobless ranks in late November, just weeks after factory orders registered the first increase since July.
The Labor Department said today that 471,000 people filed initial unemployment claims for the week that ended on Nov. 23, up 57,000 from the previous week. 
 President Bush, at a news conference, conceded that "economic growth is sluggish at best."
He added, "People are out of work, and we need to get this country back on its feet, people back on the job." Mr. Bush said he would make several major economic proposals in his State of the Union Message in January.
The President also said he would speed up about $9.7 billion in Government payments and benefits to help spur the economy.
 
Evidence Increases
 The Labor Department's jobless claims report provided further evidence that the economy is at a standstill or is sinking back into recession.
"It's not a death spiral," said David Rolley of DRI-McGraw Hill. "It just means we're on the bottom. We've stalled out."
Robert Dederick of the Northern Trust Company said, "The economy is rapidly spinning its wheels, trying to make up its mind whether its going to gather strength or slide back."
The jobless claims report all but erased the previous week's decline of 80,000, to 414,000. That was seen as a fluke, because it reflected a week in which unemployment offices were closed on Veterans Day.
Over the last month, jobless claims, a good but not foolproof gauge of how many people have been laid off in a given week, have averaged 458,000 a week, analysts said. That is a worrisome number, they said, especially when compared with the four-week average of August and September, when it was a much more moderate 400,000.
 
7% Rate Predicted
 Many economists predicted, before the Labor Department's report on Friday on the unemployment rate, that the rate will have climbed to 6.9 percent or 7 percent, from 6.8 percent in October. If the rate hits 7 percent, that would match the highest level of the recession, when unemployment hit a five-year high of 7 percent in July.
Economists also think Friday's report will show that companies are still cutting their work forces. The number of payroll jobs could tumble by up to 75,000, analysts said.
If the news is as weak as expected, some analysts said, the Federal Reserve might be prompted to provide new cuts in interest rates to try to prod the economy.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off on Expectations Of More Interest-Rate Cuts

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar slumped yesterday on foreign exchange markets on expectations that interest rates here might continue to fall.
Gold prices rose in New York after falling earlier in Europe. Republic National Bank quoted gold at $366.50 an ounce at 4 P.M., up $1.60 from Wednesday's late bid. 
 Traders said worries that interestrates might be headed lower and that November unemployment data to be released today would show more weakness kept pressure on the dollar. Falling rates make the dollar less attractive to foreign investors.
At the same time, analysts said it appeared the currency market had overreacted a day earlier to the Soviet Union's plans to halt payments for a year on the principal portion of its foreign debt.
Some traders sold German marks on Wednesday because of the potential impact of that development on German banks and the German economy. But Jeffrey Mondschein, managing director of foreign exchange at the Continental Bank in Chicago, said traders reconsidered the situation yesterday and bought marks once again.
Germany left its interest rates unchanged, and Mr. Mondschein said traders still believed German rates would hold steady or move higher.
With expectations of further rate declines, he said those developments would widen the difference between rates in Germany and the United States, making the mark more appealing and the dollar less attractive.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 128.85 yen, down 0.40 yen from Wednesday's finish. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 128.65 yen. In New York, the dollar fell to 128.70 yen from 129.10 yen late Wednesday.
In London, the pound was quoted at $1.7935, compared with $1.7730 late Wednesday. In New York, the pound rose to $1.7965 from $1.7835.
Late dollar rates in New York compared with late rates on Wednesday also included: 1.5885 German marks, down from 1.6015; 1.4050 Swiss francs, down from 1.4160; 5.4315 French francs, down from 5.4750; 1,202 Italian lire, down from 1,210; and 1.13795 Canadian dollars, up from 1.13715.
Silver for current delivery rose 2.2 cents an ounce to $4.026 on New York's Comex.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Why Fiscal Policy Has to Have Soul

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
IS the United States economy in worse shape than the official statistics disclose? Or is the national mood simply a lot worse than the economic data warrant?
The Commerce Department's shift this week to a new set of figures for tracking the United States economy is intended to put the economy into sharper focus, even though it may muddy the waters for people accustomed to thinking in the old terms. The new approach focuses on gross domestic product -- or what is produced within United States borders -- rather than gross national product, which included income earned by Americans companies and individuals abroad as well as at home. In addition, the department moved to 1987 prices from 1982 prices. 
 Whichever figures are used, there is an undeniable disparity between the pattern showed by the statistics, of a recovery, albeit sluggish, following a short recession, and the deep anxiety that people have been expressing at the ballot boxes, in consumer surveys, in the marketplace and to each other. It is an anxiety deeper than in the recession of 1981-82 or earlier postwar recessions.
One source of the gap between economic data and people's perceptions may be their sense that the morning in America of the Reagan years did not turn everything around, but left the nation and its businesses and people with a pile of debts that will take years to pay off and that could breed a financial catastrophe.
There is widespread awareness that living standards for most people have been stagnating and that life is harder for the young than it was for their parents. With the increase in many social problems -- ranging from crime to health care to homelessness to urban decay -- growing, many blame the politicians for offering no public philosophy or believable solutions. And, on this 50th anniversary of Pearl Harbor, many fear the United States is losing out to Japan economically.
Economics is not just about production data, money and prices; it is also about people. A Stanford economist, Tibor Scitovsky, in his 1976 book "The Joyless Consumer," sought to link motivational psychology to economics. Work means more to most people than just a way of getting income; it may be the core of their life. Unemployment, and fear of unemployment, can undermine their confidence in themselves and their society.
Conversely, hope is energizing. In the current issue of the Quarterly Journal of the Banca Nazionale del Lavoro, published in Rome, Mr. Scitovsky wrote, "Needless to say, I was not the first economist to realize this and try to distinguish the different sources of human satisfaction." He notes that Joseph A. Schumpeter spoke of the entrepreneur's creative urge and John Maynard Keynes spoke of his animal spirits.
The standard cures for depressed spirits are based on money; tax cuts or expenditure increases. President Bush's chief economist, Michael J. Boskin, this week hinted that a sizable, temporary tax cut may be offered by the President if the economy does not rally in the coming months. Yesterday, President Bush, calling the economy sluggish at best, said he was speeding up $9.7 billion in various Government payments and benefits to help "get this country back on its feet."
Democratic politicians are discussing such stimuli as reshuffling taxes to the rich from the middle class and poor, temporary tax cuts for all and expenditure increases.
But the polls are showing that many ordinary people oppose further tax cuts in the face of the swelling budget deficit. And some conservatives, in both parties, are concerned about the long-run consequences on savings, investment and economic growth of deepening the huge structural budget deficit. They know the Keynesian arguments for ignoring the deficit for short-term stimulative purposes. But they also know the difficulty of increasing taxes when the need for tax cuts is past and or of slashing spending programs once they are undertaken.
The people's concerns may be rational, but not conventionally rational, in the economist's meaning of rationality as a narrow calculus of self- interest. They see genuine reasons for concern about where the nation and their own lives are going, and they are looking for leadership. A revival of animal spirits would help, but they are not just animals out there.

HEADLINE: The Art Market

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel

 BODY:

Mystery Cabinets
Almost as quickly as Sotheby's issued the catalogue of its Dec. 13 London sale of French and Continental furniture and tapestries, tongues began wagging. One of the sale's star offerings -- a pair of Louis XIV ebony cabinets decorated with Boulle ormolu marquetry -- looked awfully familiar. Experts in the rarefied world of fine French furniture believed the cabinets had been among the most prized pieces in the celebrated Patino Collection. Sotheby's sold this collection of furniture and decorative objects, which had belonged to Antenor Patino, the Bolivian tin magnate, to an unnamed buyer on Nov. 1, 1986, for $797,500. 
 A Sotheby's spokesman said that the auction house could not divulge a purchaser's name without permission. But insiders in the art world are convinced that the 1986 buyer was Basia Piasecka Johnson of Princeton, N.J., who is the widow of J. Seward Johnson of the pharmaceuticals family. Mrs. Johnson, through a spokesperson, declined to comment.
Two questions arise. Why is the pair of cabinets back on the block five years later without a mention of the Patino provenance and with a significantly lower estimate? (In the 1986 Patino sale, Sotheby's experts were quoting a figure of between $400,000 and $600,000. Today, it expects to sell the pieces for between $354,000 and $530,000.)
And why, according to the most recent catalogue description, has a large front mount been replaced when they were all listed as original five years ago?
A source at the auction house who would speak only on condition of anonymity said that this is what happened: Mrs. Johnson made the purchase, but soon afterward she began questioning the authenticity of the cabinets. (Sotheby's acknowledges only that a question of authenticity arose.)
Three experts chosen by mutual agreement were then called in to look at the pieces, said Matthew Weigman, manager of auction information at Sotheby's, and all three said the pair of cabinets was authentic.
But Mrs. Johnson no longer wanted the cabinets, sources said. And since she had never paid her bill, Sotheby's kept the pieces in storage. Eventually the auction house decided to ship them to London for its December furniture sale. "During the process of shipping, one of the mounts was lost," Mr. Weigman said. "Restorers replaced it, which accounts for the lower estimate."
On the question of omitting the Patino provenance, Mr. Weigman said: "It was an oversight. But it will be corrected during the exhibition."
 
Against Sell Offs
 Last month the Rose Art Museum of Brandeis University in Waltham, Mass., sold 11 Impressionist and modern works by such artists as Renoir, Toulouse-Lautrec and Vuillard at Christie's in New York for a total of $3.65 million. The museum said the money would help pay for conservation and educational expenses as well as for future acquisitions.
Other institutions, including the Barnes Foundation near Philadelphia and Westbrook College in Portland, Me., have taken similar steps recently to cope with rising operating costs.
But not everyone thinks these new financial strategies are a good idea. The Association of Art Museum Directors, based in New York, has now issued a code of ethics stating that any museum that sells, or deaccessions, works of art from its collection for any purpose other than buying art will no longer be able to participate in loan exhibitions with any of the association's 160 museum members.
Millicent Hall Gaudieri, the executive director of the association, said the board voted unanimously for the change.
Phillipe de Montebello, the director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art and an association member though not a trustee, said that "to use proceeds from deaccessioned works of art for anything other than acquisitions is condemnable.
"People give works of art for augmenting a museum's collections," Mr. de Montebello said, "and it is our responsibility to respect our donors' intentions."
The directors are also expected to issue a policy statement before February that describes the proper use of funds by its membership. "This is an issue of considerable importance, and Brandeis is just one of a growing number of cases," said Mary Gardner Neill, the president of the Association of Art Museum Directors and director of the Yale University Art Gallery.
"There are always alternatives to deaccessioning," she added. For example, Ms. Neill cited the Brooklyn Museum and the Metropolitan Museum, both of which now rotate the hours at their galleries, rather than keeping all of them open full time. These museums have also made staff cuts recently. "It's time to be more imaginative financially," Ms. Neill said.
But David Rosen, a vice president for public affairs at Brandeis, maintains that the museum had few options and that the money raised selling the art was not used for "heat and electricity." He explained that he did not consider the money going to conservation or education as operating expenses. "They don't take into account institutions like ours where education is crucial to our existence," Mr. Rosen said.
 
Disappointment in London
 Results of this week's auctions of Impressionist and modern paintings, drawings and sculpture at Sotheby's and Christie's in London indicate that the art market is still soft. The patterns in London were a replay of last month's auctions in New York where private collectors dominated the buying and seemed reluctant to spend more than $1 million for any work of art. And works that did sell, generally went for the low estimates.
At Christie's evening sale, 24 works were sold and 24 did not find buyers. The total was $12,746,624, well below Christie's projected $22 million to $35 million estimate. Sotheby's sale fared a bit better, bringing in a total of $18,254,000. But this figure was also much lower than its $35 million to $45 million estimate.
"It was a hit-and-miss sale," said James Roundell, the director of Impressionist and modern pictures and drawings at Christie's in London. "There were no wild-card bids. The dealers were there, but they were just watching. As usual in a market like this, 90 percent of those who attended were just watching." Leading the sale was Pissarro's "Gelee Blanche, Femme du Bois," which was sold for $3,291,200.
At Sotheby's, David Nash, who heads its department of Impressionist and modern art worldwide, also confirmed that the London sales echoed what the auction house experienced in New York. "But in London I was encouraged by the popularity of works on paper, because the amount of money needed to buy them is not astronomical," he said. The first part of Sotheby's sale, offering 19th-century French paintings and drawings from a European private collector, proved his point. A Millet drawing was sold to a Japanese dealer for $1,014,000, a record for a drawing by the artist. Another record for a drawing was Daumier's "Parade," which was sold for $682,000. Also from that collection was the evening's top lot, Delacroix's "Tete d'Etude d'Une Indienne," which was sold for $1.4 million, just under the low estimate.
One big disappointment and an interesting indicator of where the market is today was a Monet "Nympheas," which failed to sell. "In 1986 before the Japanese entered the market it was worth $1.5 million," Mr. Nash said. "In 1990 it soared to $10 million. Now in 1991 bidding stopped at $5 million."
 
High Hopes for Berlin
 With the economy depressed in the major art centers -- London, Paris and New York City -- dealers and auction houses are looking to Berlin as the next area of expansion. Sotheby's and Christie's have both opened large Berlin offices in the past year, and major art galleries both here and abroad are rushing to find space in the city's prime neighborhood, the area bound by Fasanenstrasse and Kurfurstendamm. Karsten Greve, a contemporary-art gallery, for example, is closing its Paris house and moving to Berlin. Eric Franck, a Geneva-based contemporary art gallery, is opening a Berlin branch. Even German galleries like Wolfgang Wegner, from Bremin, and Wolfgang Wittrock, based in Dusseldorf, are opening there.
"Berlin is a city poised for growth," said William O'Reilly, a co-owner of the Manhattan-based Salander-O'Reilly Galleries, who opened a branch in Berlin this fall. "When we were looking for a European location, we chose Berlin because we think it will reclaim the rich cultural heritage it once had."
Mr. O'Reilly, like many other players in the art world, is also banking on the strong interest in fine arts among the Germans, the country's relatively stable economy and Berlin's rising real-estate market. They are also riding on the coattails of many big banks who are establishing German bases. "The German market has enormous growth potential," said Michael Ainslie, president of Sotheby's Holdings.
So firm is Sotheby's belief in the Berlin market that it has begun holding auctions there. The first, on May 30, was a sale of German 20th-century art. It totaled $4.3 million, and 28 percent of the works failed to sell. Just last week, on Nov. 28, the house held its second Berlin sale of 20th-century German art, which did badly -- the auction totaled only $1.8 million, and 46 percent of the works did not find buyers. These poor results don't seem to bother Sotheby's. "We see this as a long-term strategy," said Mr. Ainslie.
Christie's, on the other hand, has no plans to hold auctions in Berlin, but they are hoping to attract German sellers. "We don't want to weaken London and New York," said Francois Curiel, president of Christie's in Europe. "But right now Germany is one of the most active countries in the art market and one that has not been affected by the recession. In fact, Paris and Berlin are competing to become the art capital of Europe by 1993. And from the way things look now, Berlin may well be the winner."

HEADLINE: On Stage, and Off

BYLINE: By Alex Witchel

 BODY:

Of Bookings and Possible Bumpings
If you haven't noticed the vultures circling Broadway lately, look again. There is a booking crunch for the second half of the season, when activity traditionally picks up. That means there are too many shows for the theaters available. And finding the right home for a show can mean its life or death, both artistically and at the box office. 
 The unspoken rule is never to talk about booking a theater that has a show running, lest you invoke any evil spirits for your own. But with the stakes high in this recessionary economy, people seem willing to take their chances.
One of the biggest questions is where Jerry Zaks's highly anticipated revival of "Guys and Dolls" will go. He has been paid a salary by Jujamcyn Theaters for more than a year, and this show is an opportunity for that investment to pay off. Although the idea was to put it into Jujamcyn's Martin Beck Theater, no one counted on the longevity of its current occupant, "Grand Hotel." And though the show's gross for the week of Nov. 18 (printed in Variety this week as $248,233 of a potential $485,000) would seem to cast doubt on its ability to pull through the tough weeks before Christmas, and the annual January slump, Marvin Krauss, a co-producer and general manager, says that Cyd Charisse has just been signed and will play her first performance on New Year's Eve.
"I told Jujamcyn my estimate on when 'Grand Hotel' will run is at least until Labor Day," he says. "Last week and this week are blockbusters. And Jujamcyn is a major investor in this show. Who even knows if 'Guys and Dolls' will work?"
But Rocco Landesman, the president of Jujamcyn Theaters, doesn't quite see it that way. "What if 'Grand Hotel' runs through March and as a result we lose 'Guys and Dolls' and have an empty theater for nine months to a year," he says. "That is not a prospect I welcome."
Still, for safety, "Guys and Dolls" sets are also being designed for the Marquis, the Gershwin and the Virginia. (Only the Virginia is a Jujamcyn house; the two others are Nederlanders.) "City of Angels" is at the Virginia, and Mr. Landesman says it remains unclear how it will fare in January. In any case, another musical, "Jelly's Last Jam," starring Gregory Hines, also wants the Virginia. Michael David, a co-producer of "Guys and Dolls," says the Gershwin may prove to be too large. The Marquis's availability will be determined after "Nick and Nora" finally opens on Sunday.
And what about next fall's booking, already in place at the Marquis, of "The Goodbye Girl," the Neil Simon movie turned musical with a score by Marvin Hamlisch? Whichever show is there, chances are it will have to move, says Arthur Rubin, the executive vice president of the Nederlander Organization. Its commitment to Mr. Simon, he says, is solid. And why not? Mr. Simon's "Lost In Yonkers" is playing at the Nederlander-owned Richard Rodgers Theater, and his new play, "Jake's Women," will open at the Nederlander-owned Neil Simon Theater next spring.
Then there's the Brooks Atkinson, now dark, another Nederlander house, which may or may not have Mike Nichols's production of "Death and the Maiden," an Ariel Dorfman three-character play starring Gene Hackman and Richard Dreyfuss and maybe Juliet Stevenson, the British actress. The maybe is pending approval by the Actor's Equity Alien Committee. And if "Maiden" goes to the Atkinson, it will bump "Redwood Curtain," a new Lanford Wilson play directed by Marshall Mason. Their alternative, says its co-producer Tanya Berezin, might either be the Nederlander Theater or the Lunt Fontanne, a large Nederlander house usually reserved for musicals on the scale of "Peter Pan." Its current tenant is the comedy revue "Catskills on Broadway." "Redwood Curtain" is a three-character drama. Stay tuned.
 
A Leap Into the Lap of Stardom
 If you can't stand to hear one more thing about Asta, try this heartwarming cat tale. Casey, who co-stars in Israel Horovitz's "Park Your Car in Harvard Yard," with Jason Robards and Judith Ivey, was rescued from the pound by a friend of the show's stage manager. He auditioned, but lost the part. Then in a stunning show-biz twist, the cat who had been cast didn't work out (you know, artistic differences) and Casey replaced him.
Since then, he has become such a favorite of the Broadway show's stagehands that he was recently given a lifetime membership card to Local 1, their union. And since everyone in the theater knows that stagehands are better paid than playwrights, Mr. Horovitz might want to sit up and take notice. He has personally been paying a few hundred dollars a week to have his name included on an extra line in "Harvard Yard's" ABC ads. Shirley Herz, the show's press agent, says the producer, Robert Whitehead, "had contractually agreed to run Mr. Horovitz's name in those ads three times a week, because every day was too expensive." When Mr. Horovitz insisted, Ms. Herz says, Mr. Whitehead arranged to deduct the money from the playwright's royalties.
Does Mr. Horovitz feel that his name sells the show? "I pay because I am proud of the play," he says. Maybe Casey could arrange a loan.
 
Hall of Fame for Bancroft and Adler
 Roger Stevens and Earl Blackwell, the co-chairmen of the Theater Hall of Fame, have announced its inductees for 1991. They are the actors Anne Bancroft, Stella Adler, Gene Kelly, and posthumously, Charles Gilpin, who first played Othello on Broadway; the composers Cy Coleman and Harold Rome; the director Gene Saks; the costume designer Patricia Zipprodt; the choreographer Hanya Holm, and, also posthumously, the producer Theresa Helburn of the Theater Guild.
The ceremony will take place at the Gershwin Theater on Jan. 27. The theater owner and producer James M. Nederlander will receive the Arnold Weissberger Award for Outstanding Contribution to the Theater, and special tributes will be paid to Joseph Papp and Colleen Dewhurst.
 
For Sunday Nights, a Variety Show

Something to ease the pain on Sunday nights: Rainbow and Stars has started "Varieties," a revue that will run through Dec. 29. A performing ensemble appears weekly, including Jason Graae, Adam Green and Douglas Bernstein. On Dec. 15, one guest act will be a duet with Rita McKenzie, an Ethel Merman impersonator, and Carole Shelley, as Mary Martin. They will sing a famous medley that Merman and Martin did for the Ford 50th Anniversary Special, broadcast in 1953. On Dec. 29, Chris Durang and Dawne will be there.


GRAPHIC: Shirley Knight has been cast in the American premiere of Edward Albee's "Marriage Play," which is to open at the Alley Theater in Houston in January and move to the McCarter in Princeton, N.J., in February. Mr. Albee will direct the two-character play, co-starring Tom Klunis, about the end of a 23-year marriage. It is his first new work to be produced in this country since 1983.

HEADLINE: Review/Theater;
Borscht Belt Humor Goes to Town

BYLINE: By MEL GUSSOW

 BODY:
The title of the show "Catskills on Broadway" deserves a truth-in-advertising award. With these four stand-up comics at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater, you pay your money and you get the jokes, unless you happen to miss the punch lines because of the laughter.
Appropriately, the show begins with a quick, clever montage of photographs of celebrities and guests enjoying themselves at diverse hotels. The song "Comedy Tonight" is heard in the background. For receptive theatergoers, "Catskills on Broadway" offers something familiar, and something entertaining. Is Broadway ready for the Catskills? Do Catskill hotels serve too much food? 
 One-liners and ethnic wisecracks speed by as these jokesmiths offer their shtick in trade, just as they would if they were performing their routines in a nightclub. Despite the presence of a director, Larry Arrick, there is no special adaptation to the Broadway stage. Expect no newness here, although there are updated variations on old themes. The comics, three men and a woman, deliver a spritz of recognition.
Freddie Roman, who conceived the show and is the opening act, reflects on his boyhood in Queens. After knocking today's cinderblock cineplexes, where if you leave a theater to go to the bathroom "you forget which movie you're seeing," he remembers the grandeur of Loew's Valencia. The mere mention of that palace evokes an audible sigh from theatergoers. Responding to nostalgic references, the audience becomes an integral part of the show, so much so that Mr. Roman is forced to interrupt and comment, "Who's working here?"
His effervescence becomes infectious as he shifts targets from the Catskills to Florida. He pinpoints the problem of retirees living in perpetual sunshine until their grandchildren arrive for their annual holiday visit, when it rains every day. By his own description, Mr. Roman is a semi-chubby man in the midst of a midlife crisis, and he is as personal as his medical report. "I took a cholesterol test," he says. "My number came back 911."
Finishing his finely honed routine, he introduces Dick Capri, followed by Marilyn Michaels and Mal Z. Lawrence. Mr. Capri, who adds an Italian-American note to a mostly Jewish field of humor, is the most predictable of the four comedians. But he serves at least one useful purpose: He lets the audience catch its breath between laughs.
Then Ms. Michaels appears, backed by a band, to deliver deft and often daft imitations. Of the comics, she has the most individualized talent. The objects of her mimicry are so instantly identifiable that there is no need for her to introduce them by name.
Her booming version of Ethel Merman imperils the chandelier, and her Elizabeth Taylor assumes a tremolo. After raining on Barbra Streisand's parade, she tosses off a passing impression of Jackie Mason, who, of course, is the role model for the current entertainment. Ms. Michael's chef d'oeuvre is a three-minute version of "The Wizard of Oz," in which she imitates Judy Garland, Bert Lahr, Toto, the witches and the munchkins, one of whom sounds suspiciously like Dr. Ruth.
Mr. Lawrence, who has a ponytail and the manner of a Borscht Belt hipster, winds up the show with a rapid-fire monologue that races from the mountains to the shore, in this case Atlantic City, which he says is not a city but a bus terminal. Proving his point, he takes the audience aboard a bus dense with geriatric gamblers.
"Catskills on Broadway" manages to reproduce the ambiance of the Catskills. The basic difference is that on Broadway there is not a nosh in sight. But there is a groaning board of jokes about eaters and stuffers. As Mr. Lawrence observes, everyone in the Catskills wears warm-up suits. Warming up for what, he asks, sumo wrestling?
After every comic has had a 30-minute spot, the show ends with a chorus of one-liners as each tries to top the others. They could keep going for hours. Catskill resorts may be fighting the recession, but Catskill comedy has not lost its flair.
 
Catskills on Broadway
 
Conceived by Freddie Roman; entire production supervised by Larry Arrick; sets by Lawrence Miller; lighting by Peggy Eisenhauer; sound by Peter Fitzgerald; musical director, Barry Levitt; opening musical sequence arranged by Donald Pippin; projection design by Wendall Harrington; associate producer, Sandra Greenblatt; creative consultant, Richard Vos; technical supervisor, Roy Sears. Presented by Kenneth D. Greenblatt, Stephen D. Fish and 44 Productions. At the Lunt-Fontanne Theater, 205 West 46th Street, Manhattan.
 
WITH: Mr. Roman, Marilyn Michaels, Mal Z. Lawrence and Dick Capri.

HEADLINE: Trenton Panel Supports Plan For Welfare

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Dec. 5

 BODY:
The New Jersey Legislature took a significant step today to advance a controversial plan for revising the welfare system by, among other things, trying to discourage welfare mothers from bearing more children.
A pivotal committee of the Legislature today approved a package of bills that would drastically revise New Jersey's welfare system, among other things barring additional benefits to any welfare mother who gives birth to another child while receiving benefits. 
 The six-bill package, written and strongly supported by the Assembly's Democratic majority leader, Wayne Bryant of Camden, is intended to break the cycle of welfare dependency. It also includes provisions intended to encourage employment and education as well as a stipulation that benefits could continue even if the recipient married a wage-earner.
 
A Senate Pledge
 The approval of the package by the Assembly's Health and Human Services Committee means that the bills can go to the Appropriations Committee, which is expected to approve them. The package is likely to come to the floor of the Assembly for a vote sometime before the Democratically controlled lame-duck session of the Legislature ends in January and a solid Republican majority takes control.
The Senate President, John A. Lynch, a New Brunswick Democrat, has pledged to bring the bills to a vote in that house.
Privately, legislative leaders say the package has a good chance of being approved in toto despite opposition by church groups and others who fear that the denial of benefits for additional children in a welfare family would serve only to hurt the children. Gov. Jim Florio has not committed himself on the Bryant proposals, but he has said he would welcome changes that would break the cycle of welfare dependence, the pattern in which the children and even the grandchildren of welfare recipients remain in the system. The Bryant bills have also undergone revisions, including amendments attached today, and may undergo further changes before they reach the Democratic Governor, if they do.
Mr. Bryant, who said he discussed his proposals at a White House meeting with Bush Administration aides last month, said he knew of no other state considering such sweeping changes in the welfare system.
In public hearings across the state, witnesses have generally accepted the premise of the welfare revision package but have questioned whether it might ultimately hurt children cut off from welfare funds by the fact that their mothers were in the system when they were born.
 
A 'Punitive' Provision
 That objection was raised again at the committee session today by Cecilia Zalkind, associate director of the Association for Children of New Jersey. The cutoff provision, she maintained, "is punitive and directed toward the most vulnerable segment of our population, the children."
"I think we should not lose sight of how difficult it is for poor families to live as it is," she said.
But Mr. Bryant, representing Camden, the poorest city in the state, where a majority of the residents receive some form of public assistance, argued that the system did not encourage parents to take responsibility for their children.
"If you decide to enlarge your family," he said, "that is great. But if you do, you should do as I do -- get a job and earn more money."
Mr. Bryant, who is black, maintains that the welfare system is particularly injurious to poor blacks and has called it "a modern form of slavery."
The pending legislation seeks to encourage welfare parents, particularly those who have additional children while in the system, to seek employment by allowing recipients to earn as much as 25 percent of their monthly grants without losing any grant money.
The system, Mr. Bryant said, breeds both irresponsibility and criminal behavior. "Sixty-four percent of the welfare population comes from three counties in the state, and 50 percent of the jail population comes from the same three counties," he said. The counties are Essex, Hudson and his own Camden County.
 
Incentives in Package
 But while the ban on increasing aid to a mother who gives birth to another child while on welfare has received the most attention, Mr. Bryant's package also includes incentives intended to encourage education and preservation of the family.
One provision, for example, would allow continued benefits for the children of a mother who marries, even if the husband is employed, so long as the family's total annual income does not exceed 150 percent of the official poverty level.
Mr. Bryant argues that the present system discourages a man from marrying a woman with children receiving assistance through the Aid to Families With Dependent Children program because that assistance would be cut off or reduced and he would have to support the family.
"The promotion of two-parent families among A.F.D.C. recipients," the pending legislation maintains, "should enable more recipients to become economically self-sufficient."
 
Employment Incentives
 A central part of Mr. Bryant's welfare revision program is called the Family Development Act. It would provide incentives to welfare recipients to seek employment and assistance, like training and transportation, in doing so.
An able-bodied welfare recipient whose youngest child was older that 2, for example, would be required to participate in an educational program, vocational assessment and training or some form of employment, or have their benefits reduced for refusing to do so without good reason. Day-care services, to be bought through a voucher, and other assistance, including transportation, would be part of the program.
The family development program would intitially be limited to the counties of Hudson, Essex and Camden and would be phased in statewide over the next two years.
Mr. Bryant acknowledged that putting into effect some provisions of the legislation, like denial of benefits under certain conditions and the changes in allowable earned income levels, would require waivers from existing Federal regulations.

HEADLINE: Border War on Lake Champlain Waste

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TICONDEROGA, N.Y.

 BODY:
Hostilities have erupted between New Yorkers and Vermonters over the operation of a giant paper mill here that discharges waste into Lake Champlain.
In a charge led by Vermont's Governor, Howard Dean, Vermont environmentalists are demanding that New York State officials force the International Paper Company mill to use oxygen instead of chlorine to bleach its paper products. They contend that the byproducts of the chlorine process are carcinogenic. 
 "I don't view I.P. as the bad guys, but we have to ask them to use the best technology available," the Governor said.
But officials and employees of International Paper, the area's largest employer, argue that the chemicals discharged by the mill have not been proven to cause cancer, and that switching technologies would price their products out of the market.
 
'A Cost Disadvantage'
 "For this mill alone to have to convert would put us at a cost disadvantage," said Jill Kurtz, a spokeswoman for the mill. The company also argues that there is no guarantee that the new technology works.
At issue are chemicals known as organochlorines, which are byproducts of chlorine bleaching. Of all the organochlorines, dioxin has become the most feared, partly because it is a chemical name the public has widely come to associate with cancer.
International Paper contends dioxin levels are undetectable in the water of Lake Champlain, which is used for drinking water by some communities. There is no third-party study of the dioxin level of the lake, which is the northeast boundary of New York and the northwest boundary of Vermont.
Tension between the two states came to a head in mid-November at a New York Department of Environmental Conservation hearing to take testimony on a new discharge permit for International Paper, which releases 18 million gallons of waste water a day into the lake.
 
Wrong Arrowsw and Vandalism
 On the way to Ticonderoga for the hearing, members of the Vermont delegation said, they were purposely misled by handmade road arrows and greeted with signs like: "Environment Yuppies Leave Mill-Worker Jobs Alone, Our Mill Does Not Pollute." Afterward, Elizabeth McLain, Vermont's Commissioner of Environmental Conservation, discovered her car had been splashed with yellow paint.
In the hearing, Ms. McLain was criticized by Thomas C. Jorling, head of the New York Department of Environmental Conservation, who told her he found it "disconcerting to hear that we should do more from a state that's not doing as much as we are doing." This apparently was a reference to Vermont's water-quality standards not meeting the Federal requirements for toxin substances, while New York's do.
"My understanding is that Tom Jorling used to be an environmentalist," Governor Dean said in a later interview. "He clearly is not the same person now."
Ms. Kurtz said the draft of a new discharge permit includes more stringent requirements for pollution control and monitoring than the one issued in 1984. The draft sets a dioxin discharge limit of 18 parts per quadrillion, about 36 tablespoons for the entire lake; before that number was a guideline. The proposed permit also requires more frequent testing and for more substances. A final version of the permit is due in early March; the draft has not satisfied the delegation from Vermont.
Because no one has demonstrated that dioxin causes cancer in humans, International Paper officials say the worrying is excessive. But Alan McIntosh, a specialist in water toxicology at the University of Vermont, said he believes there is sufficient evidence for concern.
"Based on tests on rats and fish, there is experimental evidence to show that organochlorines are carcinogenic," said Mr. McIntosh, who will head up a two-year Government study of toxins in Lake Champlain.
Mill workers and townspeople demonstrated for the company at the hearing, fearing that a mill producing paper neither white enough or nor cheap enough to compete in the marketplace would soon be out of business.
 
Big Employer in Hard Times
 International Paper employs 850 people, 75 percent of whom live in Essex County, where the unemployment rate in October reached 9 percent, compared with the state average of 6.9 percent. The mill also provides a large amount of business to loggers on both sides of the lake.
Patrick Robins, a Burlington businessman who sits on the Lake Champlain Management Conference, said, "It all seems to be a green agenda over here, green as in environmentalist. There's a green agenda over there, but there it's about green dollars."
Governor Dean, a doctor, said that Vermont has "never wanted to ask I.P. to shut down, just to change technology." He also said that Vermont is prepared to provide a market for paper bleached through oxygenation.
"We intend to put our money where our mouth is," he said.
