HEADLINE: Shoppers Jittery Over Gunfire Threats

BYLINE: By ROBERT HANLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ROXBURY TOWNSHIP, N.J., Dec. 5

 BODY:
Christmas and commerce at the Roxbury Mall are mixed this year with threats of sniper fire, extra police patrols, bitter merchants, jittery shoppers and the angry residue of financial trouble.
Someone shot out at least 14 windows at the mall late one November night and -- a few days later -- left on car windshields, in neighborhood mailboxes and at the Shop Rite supermarket about 100 hand-lettered fliers warning shoppers of sniper fire during business hours. "Your life will be in danger," the leaflets said. "This is your only warning!" 
 The police say the shootings and the leaflets are the work of one or two among the 100 or so subcontractors who helped enlarge the mall from 14 to 46 stores 15 months ago and have not been paid for about $5 million worth of work and material.
 
No More Gunfire
 No one has been hurt so far, and there has been no more gunfire in the night. But an edgy mood prevails among shoppers and store managers, part bravado and defiance and part anxiety.
"No way I'm saying anything," said the owner of a card shop. "This is the time of year that makes or breaks us for the whole year, and it's lousy that this is coming up now."
"We're just sitting here like dead ducks," said another shopkeeper who sought anonymity. "Some of us are afraid, some not. These idiots are going around hurting the small merchant, and that's very unfair because we're already struggling with the economy. If I had somebody's gun, I'd know what to do with it."
At the Continental Hair Salon, Lee Pozar said business had not slipped because of the incidents, adding: "Actually, we're busier at night than in the day. It's like a serious threat that's not being taken seriously."
 
Parking Lots Filled
 At first glance, the threats seem to have had little impact on shopping. At lunchtime today, the 3,200 spaces in the mall's parking lots were filled. Shop Rite was bustling, and 6 of the 14 cash registers at Caldor's were open, each with two or three customers waiting in line.
Nancy Eden, 30 years old, and her boyfriend, Joe Henriquez, 25, emerged with a bag of toys and two children's sleeping bags. "I don't think fliers will stop people from shopping at Christmas," Ms. Eden said. "But if something happens . . ."
"They should picket or boycott or set up stands and do a protest," Mr. Henriquez said of the subcontractors. "Violence and sniper fire with kids around at Christmas is ridiculous. It's the same as them reducing themselves to gangs fighting over crack in New York."
Two women in their 20's, Arlene Liquori and Ida Robak, came to the mall together. "When I first heard about this, I didn't come," Ms. Robak said. "But this week, I'm coming with friends during the day. I wouldn't come at night; I wouldn't feel safe."
 
Business as Usual
 A prime target of November's gunfire was an unfinished three-story office building at the mall's entrance. Three windows at the ground-floor Liberty Travel Agency and two in an adjacent branch of the National Westminster Bank were shot out, Detective Sgt. James Simonetti said.
Michelle Varga, operations supervisor of Liberty Travel, was upbeat. "I honestly don't think it has had any impact on business," Ms. Varga said. "We're open 9 to 9, and people are always coming in and out, just like nothing happened. It's not our fault. We're not involved. We feel sorry for the subcontractors, but they shouldn't be shooting out windows."
November's round of vandalism is the mall's second since its expansion. About a year ago, a small fire was started on a shelf in Caldor's, the police said, and soon afterward tar was poured in air-conditioning ducts. The culprits were never found.
A $10,000 reward has been posted for information leading to the arrest and conviction of those responsible for the fliers and the shooting, the police said.
 
Dispute Over Payment
 The principals involved in the expansion project disagree on why the subcontractors were not paid. The mall's owner, Salvatore Davino, head of the Fidelity Land Development Corporation of Chatham, said his company had paid the general contractor, Modular Structures Inc., of North Branch, $15.7 million, of which $10.5 million was paid to subcontractors.
Richard Greene, head of Modular, which has filed for bankruptcy, said of Mr. Davino's figures: "I can't say they're accurate or not accurate." But in a telephone interview he said the mall's owner had failed to pay some requisitions from subcontractors after Modular's contract was terminated when the project fell behind schedule. Mr. Greene declined to provide the amount of the disputed requisitions.
Many of the subcontractors are puzzled. "The subcontractors have no idea why they got stuck," said Robert Kerris, vice president of the Marchelle Corporation, a construction company in West Caldwell. "Nobody really knows what happened." Mr. Kerris said the company had lost about $500,000 on the Roxbury project. "There's a whole lot of people in the middle who got hurt dramatically," he said. "I believe a lot of people lost their companies and their homes. In the 90's, this shouldn't happen. Somebody, somehow, should protect the guy who does all the physical work on a job and then gets stuck. It's always the little guy who gets hurt."
The biggest loser on the job, Gene Smith, who did the mall's masonry and cement work, said he lost $1.2 million. "It's expensive to pursue a suit," he said. "There's not much hope of getting my money out. I might have to go bankrupt myself."

HEADLINE: In New York, the Doctor Is Out

 BODY:
New York State suffers from a surge of public health problems, yet the crucially important posts of State Health Commissioner, New York City Health Commissioner and president of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation remain vacant.
Mayor David Dinkins may be forgiven for not having filled the Health and Hospitals post. Dr. J. Emilio Carrillo resigned only recently. But the jobs of City and State Health Commissioners have remained unfilled for months. Dr. Woodrow Myers resigned the city post in May; the state job has been vacant since February, when Dr. David Axelrod suffered a stroke. 
 City officials say good health commissioners are hard to recruit because first-rank physicians and health system managers usually take a big pay cut when they accept public service. Yet the state's search committee found a promising candidate in Dr. Mark Chassin, a former Federal Medicare administrator and Rand Corporation researcher who was nominated by the Governor this summer.
The problem in Albany is the State Senate, which has neglected its duty to hold confirmation hearings. Senator Mark Tully, the Long Island Republican who heads the Senate's Health Committee, now says he won't even call a hearing until January. That would be nearly a year after Dr. Axelrod's departure, even though the prospect of a special budget session this month provides the chance for immediate action.
Meanwhile the state's health problems multiply: tuberculosis, measles, AIDS and drug abuse are epidemic. Medicaid costs have exploded alarmingly. New York City's staggering public hospitals are locked in bruising negotiations with private affiliates -- a problem that underscores the need to appoint a new H.H.C. president.
Mr. Tully says he wants to postpone hearings until the full Senate reconvenes because these issues are so complex. On the contrary. The health urgencies make it imperative to confirm the new commissioner as soon as possible.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Thank Them Not

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
Now that the last American hostage is free, so is the Government of the United States. It is free at last to use a political weapon that might prevent other Americans from being taken prisoner and held captive year after foul year.
The weapon is the truth -- the truth about the terrorist organizations that took the Americans prisoner, about how the terrorist states organized them, paid them, how they kept them in guns, Mercedeses, safe houses and money, and how they could have stopped the kidnappings almost as soon as they began, quite possibly before. 
 Until Terry Anderson was "liberated" by the kidnappers and their masters, a privately spoken case was sometimes made by Washington for holding back on the truth. The argument was that speaking candidly would have meant a political indictment of Iran, the country that inspired, organized and maintained the various Holy War gangs, and Syria, the country that allowed them to operate their prisons and dungeons on Lebanese territory controlled by Syrian troops and police.
That kind of honesty might have made it more difficult for Syria and Iran to carry out their cynical end-game charade of suddenly discovering that after all they did have enough influence with the kidnappers to open the cell doors.
It was a decent case, but it had great weaknesses. It permitted hostage-taking to go on for seven years and it provided no credible threat of penalty either for the kidnappers or their sponsors. And it led the U.S., its Western allies and Israel into one devious deal after another with the criminal nations.
But those years have already been lost, those tears already all shed, except of course by relatives of hostages who are in their graves. Two questions now must be faced -- punishment and prevention.
Don't hold your breath until the terrorists pay any sort of price for chaining men to walls, torturing them and their families -- or until the terrorist states are held to payable account for not ordering them freed.
Iran and Syria are safe from retribution. Teheran offers economic deals. Syria protects itself simply -- with the Western illusion that it is the great hope for Mideast peace. Syria, imagine. The Western and Israeli landscape is littered with the careers of diplomats who thought they could outmaneuver Hafez al-Assad.
But still we can hope that Washington will at least find the courage to tell the truth. Iran and Syria could have freed the prisoners years ago, and ended hostage-taking as a strategy of Mideast terrorism, had they so wished. But they so wished only when in their own sweet time they decided the hostages were squeezed dry and that it would be more profitable to release them than have them kept, or killed.
And for that, the U.S. thanks the Syrians and Iranians. Hostages are paraded in front of a portrait of Hafez al-Assad -- as that little British boy was forced to stare terrified into the face of Saddam Hussein and suffer his touch.
But this time our own Ambassador is there. Standing among the smirking Syrian diplomats and police agents he has to utter some unctuous blather. I hope that he longed to raise his finger and point it straight at them.
Hostage-taking would never have started had not Iran shown the way by capturing the American Embassy staff in Teheran. And it is a fantasy, a lie, that once kidnapping started in Lebanon neither Syria nor Iran or both together could persuade kidnappers dependent on them for their very lives to release the prisoners.
Daniel Pipes, a top American specialist on Syria, puts it clearly: Without Syria and Iran the kidnappers are orphans. These Holy War gangs, he says, are not simply allied to Damascus and Teheran -- they were created by them, for them.
President Bush and the State Department have worked hard for the release of the hostages. But morally, politically and legally Syria and Iran are parties to a series of sickening crimes against Americans.
It is in American interests for Mr. Bush to say so in this moment of his own freedom. That will not be a guarantee against more abductions. But it will make them more difficult -- because those who bear the real guilt will be walking around with a brand on their foreheads.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: CHANCES FOR END TO YUGOSLAV WAR SEEM TO BE FADING

BYLINE: By STEPHEN ENGELBERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Dec. 6

 BODY:
Although Western nations have dramatically stepped up the economic and political pressure against Serbia in recent days, the prospects for a quick end to the war in Yugoslavia remain tenuous at best.
Cyrus R. Vance, the United Nations envoy trying to broker a durable cease-fire and deployment of peacekeeping forces, acknowledged as much today as the 14th truce in the Yugoslav conflict fell apart after several days of increasingly violent clashes. 
 At the close of a week that took him from the battlefields to the capitals of the warring parties, Mr. Vance, a former American Secretary of State, appeared to pour cold water on the possibility of stationing United Nations forces in Yugoslavia anytime soon.
 
Vance Protests Shelling
 "It makes it much harder to even consider it," he said of the reports of widespread fighting in Croatia today. During a visit to Sarajevo, the capital of the ethnically mixed republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina, he said he had sent a protest letter to the Yugoslav Defense Minister over the renewed shelling.
"I was outraged to receive news of the shelling of Osijek and Dubrovnik," he said. "It is appalling to think this was going on."
"I will continue to do what I can, but this certainly makes it very difficult," Mr. Vance told reporters.
 
Few Other Options
 European diplomats say that if Mr. Vance's mission fails, the West has few other realistic options to stem a conflict that has already driven 500,000 people from their homes and left thousands of soldiers and civilians dead.
[Citing the shelling in Croatia, the United States announced economic sanctions against Yugoslavia. Page 7.]
Diplomats say Serbia and the Serbian-dominated Yugoslav Army are comparatively immune to economic sanctions, which in recent days had been expanded to include a ban by Bonn on air and truck traffic between Germany and Yugoslavia. Hundreds of thousands of Yugoslavs work in Germany, and the air route had been among the Yugoslav national airline's most profitable, carrying 170,000 passengers last year. Serbia also relies on German companies for spare parts in various industries.
European Community members have removed preferential tariffs for textiles from Serbia and Montenegro, another Yugoslav republic, and urged the United Nations to impose an oil embargo.
Serbian officials say that they have already drawn up plans to sidestep the sanctions, and that they have already secured supplies of crude oil. Gasoline lines nonetheless persist in regions near the battlefields.
"There is nothing prouder that resisting pressure that is improper, and this is improper," Brana Crncevic, a Serbian writer said this week in a televised panel discussion aimed at explaining "what Serbia wants."
Sanctions have some chance of succeeding over the longer term. Yugoslavia's central bank is furiously printing money to finance the war -- prices rose close to 20 percent last month -- and foreign businesses have suspended investment. Diplomats say economic hardship could eventually kindle popular revulsion against the war and the leaders responsible for prolonging it.
 
An Unproductive Step?
 As for Germany's announced plans to accord diplomatic recognition by Christmas to the breakaway republics of Croatia and Slovenia, many analysts in Belgrade believe it would have the opposite of its intended effect.
Recognition of Croatia, which is strongly opposed by the United States, could well spur the national army to step up its offensive before Croatia can import more powerful weapons from Western nations. The Yugoslav Army is in little danger of running out of armaments, because Yugoslavia's extensive domestic arms industry is mostly in Serbia.
Franjo Tudjman, the Croatian President, assailed Washington today for its refusal to endorse recognition.
Yugoslavia is now under a European Community arms embargo. Some figures in Europe, notably the former British Prime Minister, Margaret Thatcher, have backed recognition as a means of giving Croatia the weapons needed to counter the Yugoslav Army.
A report by exasperated European Community observers in Yugoslavia, disclosed this week, accorded most of the blame for the war to the Serbian-dominated army. It asserted that the generals were waging a cowardly struggle to preserve their perquisites and pensions.
The report raised the possibility of deploying Western military forces -- presumably from air and sea -- to attack the army whenever it indiscriminately shelled civilian areas. But few experts believe that this idea is technically or political feasible in the jumbled battlefields of Yugoslavia.
Mr. Vance's mission has been widely portrayed here as the last real chance for securing peace in Yugoslavia. He has made it clear repeatedly that United Nations peacekeepers will be placed between the two sides only if the fighting stops. This in effect leaves the various military forces in the field, regular and irregular, with veto power over any truce arrangement.
The Croatian radio reported today that 14 people were killed and 71 wounded Thursday in shelling of Osijek, in eastern Croatia. The Associated Press quoted hospital officials as saying that 6 died and 15 were wounded there today.
There were also reports of renewed fighting in the port of Dubrovnik, although the circumstances were unclear. The Croatian radio even reported fighting among rival Croatian units.
 
Memories of World War II
 Belgrade television reported tonight that Croatian forces had opened atank-backed attack against army positions in Lipik, a central Croatian town.
Serbian officials said this week that the war would continue as long as the two million to three million Serbs living outside the republic's borders feel under threat from a Croatian government routinely characterized in Belgrade as "fascist." In nearly every conversation, the Serbians refer to World War II, when the Nazi-installed puppet government of Croatia killed hundreds of thousands of Serbs, Jews and gypsies.
Croatia, which has lost one-third of its territory to the combined forces of the national army and Serbian irregulars, contends that it is the victim of a blatant land grab.
"I've been here for three and a half years," a European envoy said. "I've gotten gloomier and gloomier about our ability to coerce, pressure, guide or direct these people to our way of thinking, particularly when it comes to this matter of ethnicity."

Mr. Vance was accompanied by a soldier early this week as he toured the besieged city of Osijek. (Agence France-Presse)(pg. 7)

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 3; Metropolitan Desk

HEADLINE: The New Immigrants: Reshaping the Region/A special report;
Wider Mosaic: Suburbs' Jobs Lure Immigrants

BYLINE: By LISA W. FODERARO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS, Dec. 6

 BODY:
They still come for all the things that enticed their predecessors: economic opportunity, freedom, a better life for their families. But unlike earlier immigrants, today's new arrivals often bypass New York City, settling in the towns and cities that dot the metropolitan region.
Quickly but quietly, areas that not long ago were fairly homogeneous have changed. Indian saris swish down sidewalks in Edison, N.J. Pastors deliver sermons in Portuguese and Spanish in North Tarrytown, N.Y. Vietnamese restaurants and markets are springing up in the West End of Hartford. Iranians are becoming homeowners in Great Neck, L.I. 
 Some of the new immigrants have tapped an extensive network of friends and relatives already living in communities outside New York City. Others have had the money and savvy to establish themselves in desirable suburbs. Almost all were attracted by job markets that expanded far more quickly in the 1980's than did employment opportunities in the city.
"Traditionally, immigrant groups started out in sizable city enclaves and gradually -- across generations -- fanned outward into the suburbs," said Dr. Richard D. Alba, professor of sociology at the State University of New York at Albany. "Now we have groups that are leapfrogging over the early stages of that process."
In a recent New York Times Poll of the entire New York metropolitan region, 48 percent of those questioned in the suburbs around New York City, as well as in the five boroughs, said their communities were more racially mixed than they were five years ago. Of those who lived from one to two hours from the city, 43 percent said their communities had become more diverse. Just how diverse should become evident early next year when the Census Bureau releases 1990 data on immigrants' country of origin.
"Until the 1980's, a lot of these places saw themselves as completely white, and they were," said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, Regional Commissioner of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics in New York. "But immigrants tend to be young, innovative and entrepreneurial, and they moved to where the action was."
For the immigrants and for the communities where they move, the changes, while often beneficial to both, have been tinged with bitterness. The newcomers appreciate the jobs, housing and educational opportunities available where they live. They are proud, too, of the businesses that they have established. But they voice frustration over their lack of political influence, obstacles toward advancement in the work place, resentment in some schools and scattered bias attacks.
 
Education
Schools Speak With Many Voices
 The experiences of new arrivals in the region are as diverse as their cultures.
The Japanese executive in Scarsdale, who will probably be returning to Japan in a few years, has a vastly different view of -- and impact on -- the region than, say, the Salvadoran peasant struggling to stake out a new life as a landscaper in Hempstead, L.I.
But one common flash point is the public schools. The rise in bilingual education and special instruction for children for whom English is a second language have strained school districts at a time of intense financial pressures.
In Stamford, Conn., which saw tremendous economic growth in the 1980's, some 30 foreign languages, from Laotian and Russian to Urdu and Creole, are spoken by the students in the 17 public schools. The district now has 20 instructors teaching English as a second language, which is mandated by the state for those whose native language is not English.
Along the Hudson River in Westchester County, the Tarrytown school district is now 40 percent Hispanic, with large numbers of Dominicans and Cubans.
"There is resentment on the part of some parents simply because they know that a very large part of the budget has to be spent getting these children up to speed," said Betsey Hardeman, a former deputy superintendent in Tarrytown. "The basic prejudice comes out when people are dealing with their pocketbooks."
The same tensions, though perhaps more muted, are present in the wealthiest suburbs where many Japanese families have settled, like Scarsdale, in Westchester County, and Greenwich, Conn.
"They create, at the very least, a situation where huge numbers of people need remedial work in English," said John Wheeler, vice president of the Japan Society, a private educational organization promoting United States-Japanese relations. "You also have students worrying that the Japanese are taking their place in terms of test scores."
 
'Work at Integration'
 In Fort Lee, N.J., 688 Korean students and 357 Japanese make up 36 percent of the enrollment in the public school system.
But Dr. Alan W. Sugarman, Superintendent of Schools in the middle-class community overlooking the George Washington Bridge, said social interaction between Asian students and whites -- and even between Japanese and Koreans -- is lacking. "We have to constantly work at integration," he said.
While public schools struggled with the social tensions and educational burdens accompanying the influx of newcomers, the mood in the work place, especially among employers, is one of gratification.
 
Employment
The Willing Hands Of Varying Ability
 "Immigrants in Westchester fill the jobs that Americans disdain," said Luis Andrew Penichet, a lawyer in White Plains and chairman of the county's Hispanic Advisory Board. "They are gardeners, cooks, dishwashers and domestics, and they work like dogs."
That view is supported by the recent New York Times Poll of the metropolitan region, which found that 63 percent of those questioned, both in the city and the suburbs, believe that immigrants take jobs that United States citizens do not want. And about two-thirds in both places said that today's immigrants work harder than people who were born in the United States.
The rapid growth of the region's economy during the 1980's provided employment for many of the new immigrants, whose numbers swelled during that period.
 
Eased Restrictions
 Westchester's Hispanic population rose by 89 percent in the last decade, to 86,000, according to census data, and leaders of the Hispanic community say that illegal aliens probably bring the total number of Hispanic residents to around 120,000.
Changes in United States immigration laws that lifted restrictions from East Asian countries and loosening emigration policies abroad have also brought more skilled workers and professionals to the region, like doctors and computer programmers from Korea, mathematicians and pharmacists from India, translators and theatrical producers from the Soviet Union.
The new arrivals took advantage of the region's economic expansion. Between 1980 and 1990, 660,000 jobs, an increase of 17 percent, were created in the 18 counties of northern New Jersey, the mid-Hudson Valley and Long Island that sweep around New York City. In the same period, jobs in the city increased by 212,000, or 6 percent.
Yet some immigrants believe that their prospects are limited, and they blame discrimination. "The concern of the upper-middle-class Chinese scattered throughout the suburbs is very much the 'glass ceiling,' " said Peter Kwong, the author of "The New Chinatown" and a professor of political science at the State University of New York's College at Old Westbury on Long Island.
"In corporations, in computer firms and engineering firms," he said, "they can be the senior engineer but they can't be the manager. It's a frustration commonly shared by Chinese."
And not all new arrivals slip easily into the work force. In Hartford, for example, some Vietnamese immigrants who arrived without professional skills are struggling. "We put them into vocational courses, but we're not lucky with everyone, and some go on welfare," said Hai Nguyen, a 47-year-old counselor for Catholic Charities Migration and Refugee Services who is herself a former "boat person" plucked from the sea in 1975. "Once they are on welfare, even though it's just a little money, they're pleased since they had even less before."
Mrs. Nguyen lives in Manchester, a suburb of Hartford, with her husband, a senior analyst for an insurance company, and their two youngest children. A third child is in college. A month ago, after a 10-year campaign, she welcomed her mother, father and brother to the United States.
 
Politics
Struggle to Develop Government Role
 If economic gains have been uncertain, those in the political arena have been more elusive still. Typically, immigrants are not concentrated enough to elect, say, an Indian or Korean, leaders of those groups contend.
"What Koreans really feel is that the history of immigration is short, and we don't have any assemblymen, senators, Congressmen or judges," said Dr. Richard S. Rhee, a neurologist in Rumson, N.J., and past president of the Federation of Korean-American Associations of New Jersey. "There is no political clout, no one to turn to with a problem."
Though they have yet to field a candidate, Indians who have settled in Edison, N.J., have begun to organize, outlining agendas and supporting candidates sensitive to their needs. Edison, with a population of 89,000, had 6,000 Indian residents last year, up from only 900 in 1980, according to the Census Bureau.
As their numbers have grown, so have their incomes. "When you're self-sufficient and have money, you have time to get involved in politics, and that time for us has come," said Pradip Kothari, a travel agent and president of both the Indo-American Cultural Society of Edison and the Indian Business Association.
Hispanic people, who are the largest ethnic group in the region, have also made the greatest strides politically. In Hempstead, L.I., where bodegas, video stores and restaurants cater to the island's largest Hispanic community, there is excitement among the village's Salvadorans, Hondurans and Guatemalans about their rising political prospects. Recently, some of them gathered to discuss the formation of a political action committee to mobilize Hispanic voters in local elections.
"For the first time we have an Hispanic member on the school board," said Rafael Picon, a civic leader who migrated to Hempstead in the 1950's from Puerto Rico. "That will be only the beginning."
Frank Rey was elected mayor of North Tarrytown last spring, becoming the first Hispanic leader in the history of the village, which is 34 percent Hispanic. North Tarrytown's 2,776 Hispanic residents "are better represented because I'm Spanish," said Mr. Rey, whose mother emigrated from Spain 51 years ago, just before his birth.
 
Opportunity
As Diversity Rises, Options Expand
 More than anything else, one has only to walk down the street -- looking and listening -- to realize the growing diversity of the region.
In North Tarrytown, a video store rents tapes translated into Spanish while a Chilean bakery offers traditional pastries like milhojas and meringues. In the same tiny business district are a Cuban-owned laundromat, a Dominican-owned stationery store, an Argentine-owned television repair shop, a Puerto Rican-owned grocery store.
Two years ago in Great Neck, the Colbeh restaurant opened to serve the growing Iranian community, now estimated to be a few thousand strong. The restaurant offers the only glatt kosher Persian cuisine on Long Island, and also features a traditional dish called Chelo-Kabab, a mix of grilled and barbecued chicken, salmon and beef.
In Edgewater, N.J., one of the most striking retail additions in the region is the Yaohan shopping plaza, a three-year-old complex of Japanese businesses, including a bookstore, golf shop, beauty salon, pharmacy, travel agent and bonsai tree outlet. There is also a giant supermarket, where Elvis Presley croons over aisles brimming with thousands of Japanese products, from rice crackers and dried seaweed to Japanese-brand condoms.
 
Divergent Reception
 Elsewhere in New Jersey, three Hindu temples in Middlesex County draw worshipers from the Indian community while around the state some 100 churches, most of them Protestant, provide services in Korean. A handful of churches in Elizabeth and East Orange hold Mass in Creole for the growing Haitian population.
Some longtime residents see such "foreign" influences as an intrusion in their communities; others welcome them. In Larchmont, N.Y., for instance, many residents feel that the French community of some 400 families in the area lends a certain cachet to their village, one of the most expensive suburbs in Westchester.
Not so in the comfortable neighborhoods surrounding the more working-class village of Mount Kisco in northern Westchester. In the last decade, the Hispanic population there has risen to 1,100 from 400, with many Guatemalans and Salvadorans crowding into apartments. Some residents have organized to expel illegal aliens.
"People keep calling the Immigration and Naturalization Service and telling them to make raids on Mount Kisco," said Joseph A. Sena Jr., a lawyer who counts many Hispanic immigrants among his clients. "If Hispanics live in west Yonkers in the slums, they don't attract too much attention. But if they live in affluent northern Westchester, it's a different story."
Welcome or not, the immigrants now living in the region make it likelier that their numbers will grow, thanks to the networking phenomenon, immigration specialists say.
"The new immigrant whose cousin is in Mount Kisco doesn't need to settle in New York City," said Jeffrey S. Passel, director of the program for research on immigration policy at the Urban Institute in Washington. "He can live with his cousin until he finds a job in Westchester. Those informal networks are very strong."
Mr. Kothari, a leader of the Indian community in Edison, N.J., said the special stores and services catering to ethnic communities in the region were also a strong pull. "Twenty years ago, there was no alternative," Mr. Kothari said. "If you were an immigrant from India, you went to Queens. Now you can move to Jersey City or Middlesex County, where everything is available."

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 6; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1207 words

HEADLINE: BLEAK JOB REPORT SHOWS EMPLOYERS SLASHED PAYROLLS

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6

 BODY:
In an unexpectedly grim report, the Labor Department today found that employers slashed payrolls by 241,000 in November, the biggest drop in jobs since late last winter, when the economy was mired in recession.
The nation's unemployment rate remained at 6.8 percent last month -- and did not rise slightly as had been widely predicted -- but economists took little comfort from any part of the report, which now shows 8,499,000 unemployed. The report is the first comprehensive gauge of the economy's performance last month. 
 In hopes of heading off a new downturn, the Federal Reserve moved swiftly to cut yet again the interest rate on overnight loans among banks, carrying the Federal funds rate to 4 1/2 percent, the lowest since mid-1972. [Page 37.]
 
Greenspan Cites Slowdown
 Bond prices rallied and yields fell on expectations that the weak economy would force further cuts in rates, and the stock market, which has benefited from the diminishing appeal of competing investments, also rose on the news, although it lost the gains by the end of the day.
The Federal Reserve, as is usual, did not explain its action, which consisted of temporarily injecting money into the banking system by purchasing Treasury securities. But Alan Greenspan, its chairman, observed to a trade group meeting in Florida, "The economic recovery, which seemed to be gathering momentum and spark during the summer, more recently has shown signs of faltering."
Analysts said consumers would enjoy no immediate benefits of today's interest-rate cut. But the belief spread today that perhaps by Christmas, the Federal Reserve, which has reduced rates repeatedly to help the sputtering economy, would cut its discount rate by another half-point and that banks would then cut the prime rate further.
 
Shrinking Labor Force
 The discount rate, now at 4 1/2 percent, is what the Fed charges on loans to financial institutions, and the prime, currently at 7 1/2 percent, is the benchmark rate for consumer and business loans. A cut in the prime rate would reduce the cost of various consumer and business loans, including home equity mortgages, that are tied to the prime.
The steadiness in the unemployment rate in the last two months, averaging 6.8 percent for both the second and third quarters, reflected a sharp 292,000 shrinkage in the size of the labor force that was roughly equal to the job losses. Since a person must be seeking work to be counted as unemployed, those who stop looking are not included in calculating the unemployment rate.
Lane Kirkland, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., noted that the official jobless rate would have climbed to 7 percent had the labor force not shrunk, part of the evidence in the report that he said "clearly documents the need for programs to get people back to work."
Jobs in construction and retail trade were particularly hard hit last month, with construction, down by 95,000, suffering from unusually severe weather in various areas as well as generally weak conditions in the industry.
In retailing, hiring for the holiday season was well short of normal, with the result that jobs fell by 111,000 on a seasonally adjusted basis.
The 241,000 jobs lost represent the largest total since 258,000 jobs were cut in both February and March.
"This is a very discouraging report," asserted Norman Robertson, chief economist for Pittsburgh-based Mellon Bank. The number of payroll jobs, he noted, is now lower than in May, and since April the increase is a meager 66,000. By contrast, during the first seven months of the recoveries of 1961, 1970, 1975 and 1983 payroll gains averaged nearly 900,000.
"You can't describe this as a recovery anymore," Mr. Robertson concluded.
 
A Mitigating Factor
 Labor Department and other analysts did point to one mitigating factor: the introduction of updated, semiannual seasonal adjustment factors that, had they been applied to the October data as well, would have produced a decline for November of about 170,000 jobs instead of 241,000. Most predictions, however, were for a decline of 50,000 or less.
Factory jobs fell by a more moderate 33,000, the third straight decline, with most of the contraction in the durable goods and primary and fabricated metals industries. Automobile jobs rose enough to offset declines in September and October.
There was some employment growth in the service industry although it was less than in the three preceding months. Gains in health services were nearly offset by declines in business and other services.
 
More Factory Overtime
 Other negative elements of the department's survey of payrolls were that the proportion of industries shedding jobs rose for the third straight month and that the index of aggregate weekly hours edged down one-tenth of a point, to 121.4, below the August level. The length of the average private-sector workweek expanded by six minutes, to 34.4 hours, and factory overtime climbed by the same amount.
Janet L. Norwood, the Commissioner of Labor Statistics, said in response to questioning before the Joint Economic Committee of Congress, that it was not possible to determine from employment data alone whether the increasingly feeble economic recovery was becoming a new contraction. But she said that "November certainly shows some deterioration and sluggishness; there's no doubt about that."
This was the 137th and final time that Dr. Norwood, who is to retire at the end of the year, appeared before the committee to interpret the monthly figures. She first testified in 1978 when she was acting commissioner.
According to the Labor Department's survey of households, on which the unemployment rate is calculated, there were 209,000 jobs lost last month, somewhat fewer than in the separate survey of establishment payrolls, which counts jobs, rather than people with jobs. With the total labor force shrinking by 292,000, however, the ranks of the unemployed actually declined by a statistically small 83,000 and the unemployment rate remained unchanged.
Among the 11 biggest states for which job data were published today, the biggest change was for Texas, where the unemployment rate fell 1.3 points, to 6.6 percent. The rate for Michigan jumped nine-tenths of a percentage point, to 9.7 percent, while the rates for New York and Illinois rose eight-tenths of a point, to 8 percent and 8.5 percent, respectively.
State figures, the department cautions, however, are highly erratic because they are based on far smaller samples than the national data.
The various population groups showed relatively little change last month, although since midyear the jobless rate for adult men has receded a bit, to 6.3 percent, while the rate for adult women, now 5.9 percent, has been on a gradual upswing.
The proportion of the working-age population with jobs eased to 61.3 percent from 61.5 percent in November, about 14 1/2 points below its level of July 1990, when the economy slipped into recession.
Today's report also showed that while the number of newly unemployed -- those out of work less than five weeks -- was about unchanged, the number out of work 27 weeks or more jumped by 180,000. Benefits for the long-term jobless were recently extended.

NEW IMMIGRANTS, NEW DESTINATIONS
They still come for all the things that enticed their predecessors: economic opportunity, freedom, a better life for their families. But unlike earlier immigrants, today's new arrivals often bypass New York City, settling in the towns and cities that dot the metropolitan region. Quickly but quietly, areas that not long ago were fairly homogeneous have changed. Indian saris swish down sidewalks in Edison, N.J. Pastors deliver sermons in Portuguese and Spanish in North Tarrytown, N.Y. Vietnamese restaurants and markets are springing up in western Hartford. Iranians are becoming homeowners in in Great Neck, L.I. Page 1.

RISING DEMAND FOR AIDS TESTS 
 In the month since Magic Johnson announced that he had the virus that causes AIDS, the number of people seeking tests for the virus has nearly doubled in New York City. The demand has increased the waiting time for the tests and put a strain on the laboratory that processes them. Page 1.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
 Payrolls were slashed by 241,000 jobs in November, the Labor Department said, the biggest drop since late last winter. The Federal Reserve moved swiftly to cut again the interest rate on overnight loans among banks, making the Federal funds rate 4 1/2 percent, its lowest level since 1972. The nation's unemployment rate remained at 6.8 percent last month, but economists took little comfort from any part of the report. [Page 1.] With the recession biting deeper into New York's most important businesses, the city's unemployment rate climbed to 10.2 percent in November, the highest since the summer of 1984. [25.] President Bush told workers at a flashlight factory in California that he knows "people are hurting." [47.] 
 The differences in the way Democrats and Republicans view tax policy was highlighted during the second day of hearings about the economy. Democrats focused on tax plans that would let middle-income taxpayers keep a few hundred dollars more a year. Republicans offered a package of tax cuts for individuals and businesses that they said would create millions of jobs. [37.]
Consumers have reversed course and again began taking on debt, including a 1.3 percent increase in October, the steepest jump in six months, the Government said. [47.]
 
Companies
The selloff of the Maxwell empire began in earnest, and employees of Mirror Group proposed to buy the 51 percent stake in the company held by two family companies. Pearson, which owns The Financial Times and the Viking Penguin publishing house, said it might be interested in making an offer. [37.] Kevin Maxwell, the publisher of the Daily News, pledged to keep the paper operating and invited unions to help decide how to cut costs. [49.]
A committee of Pan Am creditors sued Delta for backing away from a reorganization plan that might have saved the bankrupt airline from having to shut down earlier this week. [41.] American Airlines refused to add flights on routes to Brazil and Argentina after the Transportation Department gave it the right to do so only temporarily when Pan Am shut down. [41.]
McDonnell Douglas Helicopter said it might sell parts of its business and lay off up to 1,000 workers. [39.]
 
 International
Europe's leaders seem ready to give up control of their economic fate in return for a unified monetary policy when they meet tomorrow in the Netherlands. Despite Britain's objections, the European Community is moving forward with its plans for a common currency. [37.] Germans are balking at bidding farewell to their beloved mark. [38.]
The U.S. imposed economic sanctions on Yugoslavia's republics in an attempt to end the undeclared war. [7.]
 
Markets
The Federal Reserve eased monetary policy another notch, pushing down short-term rates in response to a much larger-than-expected decline of 241,000 jobs on corporate payrolls in November. The Fed's chairman, Alan Greenspan, said the economic rebound of the summer months "has shown signs of faltering." [37.]
Stocks closed mixed for the day after a volatile trading session. The Dow Jones industrial average ended down 2.69 points, at 2,886.40. For the week, it dropped 8.28 points. [40.]
The dollar slid after the release of the Government's jobless report and a subsequent easing of interest rates by the Federal Reserve. [45.] Wheat futures prices closed lower. [45.]
 
Today's Columns
A cheaper way to produce natural vanilla, using cell culturing, has been developed. Edmund L. Andrews: Patents. [38.]
People making gifts to avoid estate taxes may be overlooking a way to save on income taxes, too. Jan M. Rosen: Your Money. [38.]

HEADLINE: Theory and Practice Are at Odds in New Proposal on Minority Scholarships

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA

 BODY:
Education Secretary Lamar Alexander's proposal for settling the legality of minority scholarships enables the Bush Administration to have it both ways on the issue of race.
The stand outlined by Mr. Alexander last week played to conservative concerns by striking down, in theory, scholarships that are based solely on race. But then, almost in the same breath, Mr. Alexander reassured many minority students, and the college administrators who want to attract them, by doing almost nothing that would eliminate any of the 45,000 race-based scholarships now available. 
 While little may have changed in a practical sense, to some people the Education Department's actions send a disturbing message, one that echoes similar sentiments of division and resentment in debates over other civil rights issues, especially those involving affirmative action.
"This may represent the neo-racism of the 1990's," said Anthony James Catanese, president of Florida Atlantic University in Boca Raton, a public university of 13,800 students whose minority scholarships have been under review by the Education Department. "This says that neo-racists are not illiterate Southerners in hoods and sheets trying to burn crosses, but people who are well-educated, wearing three-piece suits, who are raising questions obscured in issues of legality and constitutionality when in fact they are trying to say the same thing as old-time racism -- that the economic and social problems of this country are due to giving minorities an even chance."
 
Race-Neutral Guidelines
 At his news conference Wednesday to discuss the new policy, Mr. Alexander did not mention affirmative action or use any other political code-words that might play to conservative causes. He insisted that the new guidelines were intended to be race-neutral, and would not deprive minority students of opportunities for scholarships. "What we're trying to do is solve problems," the Secretary said, "not create them."
As college officials try to clarify which scholarships remain legal and which can be made legal by a few changes in wording or bureaucratic procedures, many said they thought the final word will eventually have to come from the courts.
But in the meantime they said the confusion over the new policy would make disadvantaged minority students think that opportunities for them to advance have been shut off. It may also make some administrators reluctant to seek out minority students with assistance programs that could end up being challenged in court.
"Many of us are very much afraid that the Secretary's decision will put a chill on inititatives to recruit minority students," said H. Patrick Swygert, president of the State University of New York at Albany.
Part of the confusion stems from the fact that, after seven months of study, Education Department officials have arrived at seemingly contradictory conclusions. In essence, they say that scholarships granted exclusively on the basis of race violate provisions of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, which prohibits acts of racial discrimination. Yet, they go on to say that most of the 45,000 such scholarships now awarded on the basis of race can probably continue to be awarded, if certain technical changes are made.
The new policy will not be adopted until after a 90-day period of public comment, which extends to March 9.
In question are about 45,000 race-exclusive scholarships, about 3.5 percent of all scholarships awarded to minority students. Generally, according to the policy guidelines issued by the Education Department, such scholarships are discriminatory because they deprive non-minority students of an equal chance at receiving the assistance.
But Mr. Alexander said the department realized the importance of such scholarships in helping disadvantaged youngsters and wanted to see them continued. He said race could be used as a factor, rather than an obligatory condition, to determine eligibility for scholarships aimed at increasing racial, ethinic and cultural diversity on college campuses, and that would be in keeping with the law.
Such a definition is considered so broad that almost any minority scholarship now offered could continue to be offered, provided the eligibility criteria were slightly altered. Although this, in effect, would open such scholarships to non-minority students, universities could continue to give preference based on race.
The Education Department also has outlined several broad exceptions for minority scholarships. These include scholarships created by Congress and race-exclusive scholarships sponsored and paid for by private sources.
Last December, Michael L. Williams, Assistant Secretary of Edeucation for civil rights, declared in a letter that a $100,000 scholarship fund for minority students set up by the sponsors of the Fiesta Bowl college football game in Phoenix was illegal. Under the new interpretation of the law offered by Mr. Alexander, the Fiesta Bowl scholarships would be considered legal because the money to support them came from private sources giving it for that purpose.
 
Past Discrimination Cited
 A third broad category of permissible scholarships based on race covers those used to overcome past discrimination as determined by the courts or by Federal agencies like the Education Department.
The Martin Luther King Jr. Scholarship Program at Florida Atlantic University, for example, has given just over 100 scholarships to black students since 1984 as a way of raising the minority enrollment there. Of the university's 13,800 students, 6.7 percent, or 928, are black.
Officials at Florida Atlantic believe the scholarships will be allowed to continue because all Florida universities have been under pressure from the courts and from the Education Department to remedy past discrimination.
But lawyers at the Washington Legal Foundation, a conservative public interest and policy center that filed a complaint with the department about the university's scholarships several years ago, contend that Florida Atlantic is too new a university to have established any record of discrimination.
Dr. Catanese, the university's president, said there was far more doubt about the status of special scholarships offered by the State of Florida that are open only to direct descendants of Confederate Army veterans.
"That says about everything you can without saying it's for whites only," he declared.

HEADLINE: In Congress, Miles Apart On Tax Issue

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6

 BODY:
The stark differences in the way Democrats and Republicans in Congress view tax policy, the economy and politics was highlighted today on the second day of hearings about what to do next year to speed recovery from the recession.
The solutions put forward by Democrats in testimony before the House Ways and Means Committee focused almost entirely on tax plans that would let middle-income taxpayers keep a few hundred dollars more a year from what they earn. 
 "A proposal to cut taxes on middle-class individuals, paid for by the very rich, must be a centerpiece of whatever we come up with," said Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader.
 
The Republicans' Proposal
 Republican leaders, by contrast, offered a package of tax cuts for individuals and businesses, and said the measures would create millions of jobs. These measures should be enacted "for the sake of the unemployed and the country," said Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the House minority whip.
The lack of common ground illustrated how difficult it will be to reach a consensus next year when the lawmakers begin to vote on legislation.
No action will come in Congress until after President Bush offers his State of the Union Message late next month. It was apparent from the testimony Thursday of the President's top economic advisers that the Administration has not decided what to propose.
Economists disagree on whether tax cuts for capital gains, savings, small businesses and real estate investment, like those the Congressional Republicans propose, would be good for the economy.
But hardly any economist argues that the Democrats' main plan, which would give middle-income families a tax reduction of up to $400 a year financed by higher taxes on the wealthy, would do much for the overall economy. The less than $8 a week in new spending money for families that qualify for the tax cut would hardly be enough to give the economy a big kick, especially since the money would come directly out of the pockets of wealthier taxpayers.
What happened today in the Ways and Means Committee's large, windowless hearing room across Independence Avenue from the Capitol was largely a made-for-C-Span spectacle.
 
'A Season of Anxiety'
 Mr. Gephardt sat in the witness chair for two hours this morning, beginning at 9 o'clock sharp, while he and his fellow Democrats blamed Mr. Bush and former President Ronald Reagan for the sorry state of today's economy. In one speech after another the Democrats complained about how rich a few people had become while the poor and middle class became worse off.
"This is a season of anxiety, worry and great hurt," Mr. Gephardt said at one point. "The nation's longest peacetime expansion was certainly that, if you're talking about the incomes of our most fortunate citizens."
It sounded a bit like the way the Prime Minister of Britain is questioned by members of his own party in the House of Commons.
At one point, for instance, Representative Michael A. Andrews, a Texas Democrat, asked Mr. Gephardt "for the benefit of the committee, to reiterate two or three specific things that you think we've got to do to increase our savings rate."
That gave Mr. Gephardt the opportunity he had clearly been waiting for to talk about the American rate of savings and investment and productivity compared with that in Japan.
Then Mr. Gingrich and Representative Mickey Edwards of Oklahoma, chairman of the House Republican Policy Committee, were called to testify, and they said basically that there was no tax cut they did not like.
 
Tax Credit Plan Favored
 For example, after presenting the 12-point plan that House Republicans had agreed to two weeks ago in the last days of the Congressional session, Mr. Gingrich embraced two new ideas: a $2,000 tax credit for first-time home buyers, and the abolition of the capital gains tax altogether for families with incomes below about $35,000 a year.
After the party leaders presented the proposals that are likely to be the starting point for the deliberations in the House next year, about two dozen other lawmakers offered their own pet tax plans. They varied in the particulars. In general, the Democrats offered what they called middle-class tax relief, to be financed either by tax increases on the wealthy, cuts in military spending or both. The Republicans for the most part sought tax cuts, especially on capital gains, in which better-off taxpayers would be the main beneficiaries.
Representative Bill Gradison, an Ohio Republican, said he saw an "obvious compromise": both a capital gains tax cut and lower income taxes for the middle class.
"The rich folks, who realize most of the capital gains, will realize more and pay more revenue to the Treasury," Mr. Gradison said. "Plow it back into middle-class tax relief. Why does it take so long to do it?"
To the Democrats, that sounded like another free lunch.

HEADLINE: November Jobless Rate in New York City Jumps to 10.2%

BYLINE: By MARIA NEWMAN

 BODY:
With the recession biting ever deeper into New York City's most important businesses -- from retailing to publishing to Wall Street -- the city's unemployment rate jumped to 10.2 percent last month, the first time the November jobless rate hit double digits since 1977, the Federal Government reported yesterday.
Unemployment rose from 8.5 percent in October and now stands at the highest level since the summer of 1984. 
 The figures are particularly troubling, economists said, because employment generally rises in November as retailers begin gearing up for the busiest shopping season of the year.
The unemployment rate was 7.4 percent in November 1990.
"It does reflect fundamentally that New York City is in the grips of a long and severe and unusual downturn that took another turn for the worse in November," said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
The news was also grim for the state overall, as unemployment increased to 8 percent, the highest level in more than seven years, up from 7.2 percent in October. New Jersey's unemployment rate was 7.1 percent, up from 6.8 percent the previous month. Figures for Connecticut are not yet available for November, but in October unemployment was 6 percent, down from 6.4 percent the previous month.
There were 339,000 unemployed New York City residents in November, up from 279,000 in October and 248,000 a year ago, according to the Federal figures.
Nationally, the unemployment rate remained at 6.8 percent. The problem is more severe in New York City, Mr. Ehrenhalt and other analysts said, because the anchors of its economy all seem to be suffering at once.
Many of the businesses hardest hit by the recession, like banking and advertising, are concentrated in New York, and many are in the process of paring down their budgets or merging with other companies, which often results in layoffs.
 
Defining New York
 "The industries that define what New York is all about are in the process of re-inventing themselves, of sorting out what's out there," Mr. Ehrenhalt said.
One of those is the airline industry. And to employees of Pan American, which announced this week that it was shutting down, the new unemployment data came as no surprise. Even before the shutdown, the airline was cutting jobs. In September, for example, Pan Am laid off 900 flight attendants.
"We're not at the point where we're dealing with statistics," said Brian Moreau, president of the Independent Union of Flight Attendants for Pan Am. "I know them by names. To us it's Ms. Smith and Mr. Davis and Mr. Jones. It's a lot more painful than 10.2."
Michelle N. Coffman, 26 years old, an inflight purser for Pan Am, was filing for unemployment benefits yesterday in Jamaica, Queens, and wondering when she might find work again.
"I worked part-time selling Christmas trees, and that's what I'll do to get me through the holiday season," she said. "When Pan Am goes out of business one day, and the next The Daily News files for Chapter 11 -- they are the mainstays in New York. It makes you wonder what big corporation is going next.
"When the big names start going, it really makes people insecure."
 
More to the Story
 Some analysts said that the Federal statistics may not be telling the whole story of workers' discouragement with the economy.
Isaac Lagnado, a principal in the firm Tactical Retail Solutions, which studies retail trends, said many people have stopped looking for the jobs they were trained for, and instead are taking any job to avoid being unemployed altogether.
"I've just run a small ad for a very junior position in my firm, and I had over 100 inquiries in a couple of days," he said. "I am shocked at the qualifications of many people who wanted this position, which is really a junior position that doesn't pay that much."
At the Jamaica unemployment office, Robert A. Rogers, 54, had a similar story. A security guard for 11 years, he was laid off in April. He worked for 13 days in June as a doorman during the doorman's strike but has been unemployed ever since.
"I've been to factories and everything. You can't find nothing anywhere," he said. "They keep saying that the recession is over, but I can't see it."
For New York City, things may get worse before they get better. The city's Deputy Mayor for Finance and Development, Sally Hernandez-Pinero, said that the effects of layoffs announced months ago are just now being felt. "You remember the announcements of Citicorp, New York Telephone, I.B.M., the Chemical Bank-Manny Hanny merger," she said. "In many of those instances, it was a multi-year process. Unfortunately, the numbers were in the thousands. We had been saying that it would not be until the end of 1992 that we thought we'd be hitting bottom.
"It just happens that the service industries that are restructuring to insure their long-term competitiveness are concentrated here. I think we're going to be feeling this for awhile longer."
 
Layoffs at Banks
 New York City's banks, which employed about 240,000 at the end of 1990, will lose another 15,000 to 20,000 jobs during 1992 and 1993, said Thomas Hanley, a bank analyst for Salomon Brothers.
"Banks have been cutting back on their staffs perhaps at an accelerated rate thus far this year," Mr. Hanley said. "As we look ahead, and the merger process unfolds over the next couple of years, I would think the staffing levels would be reduced even further."
And this is not expected to be a strong holiday season in terms of retail sales. Mr. Lagnado of Tactical Retail Solutions said a study by his firm was forecasting that retail sales during November and December of this year would be 6 percent less than the year before, while nationwide, sales are expected to increase by 1.5 percent.
"It's a chicken and egg problem," Mr. Lagnado said of the relationship between employment and the overall economy. "High unemployment leads to an erosion of the economic base and hence affects the retail industry, which unfortunately provokes more unemployment."

HEADLINE: President Tours Successful Factory

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ONTARIO, Calif., Dec. 6

 BODY:
President Bush toured a flashlight factory today and told the workers that he understands that "people are hurting."
Mr. Bush's political strategists said that the Mag Instrument factory in Southern California was chosen for the trip because it was a success story and the President wanted to show, as one White House official put it, that "all the news isn't bad." 
 The company was also chosen because it donated 40,000 flashlights to serve as "points of light," in Bush argot, at the inaugural celebrations in Washington.
Mr. Bush's tour of the factory and speech to the local Kiwanis and Rotary clubs here were part of his accelerated effort to show that he is sympathetic to the problems of average Americans hurt by the recession.
Bush strategists said that the President had no plan to meet with unemployed Americans right now, and that the White House was trying to accent the positive in Mr. Bush's picture-taking sessions at factories around the country.
Asked by a local reporter at the Mag factory if he planned to stop by a nearby General Dynamics plant where there had been recent layoffs, Mr. Bush demurred, replying: "I'm having a good time. I'm learning a lot here."
The President told the lunch of business executives that he would have a health care proposal ready to deliver in his State of the Union Message in late January. Mr. Bush has been under a lot of political pressure to come up with such a program.
"So we've been concentrating on prevention," he said. "But I do think the time has come for the Administration to come forward with a comprehensive program."
Mr. Bush also praised the Federal Reserve for taking "the constructive step" of easing the Federal funds rate by a quarter of a point today, to 4 1/2 percent.
"And even now, this percentage drop in the Fed funds rates, I think, will help the economy along," he said.
 
'Message to the Democrats'
 Mr. Bush was asked about a report that Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas, a Democratic Presidential candidate, had held a fund-raising breakfast in Southern California today that was attended by major Republican contributors seeking to send the President a warning on the economy.
"Interesting," Mr. Bush replied, shrugging his shoulders, adding later, "I want to send a message to the Democrats."
He said that the proposed free trade agreement with Mexico would not cost American jobs. "No, create jobs," he said.
On Saturday, Mr. Bush will speak at the 50th anniversary marking the attack on Pearl Harbor.
At the White House this morning, Mr. Bush said that he would offer his regrets about the United States internment of Japanese-Americans during the war.
"I will point out that was, on our side, one of the tragic things that happened and, of course, it will never happen again," he said. "But it was a very shameful chapter in an otherwise glorious achievement, you might say, the total victory over imperialism and totalitarianism."

HEADLINE: Conyers Journal;
Veteran Touches Raw Economic Nerve in Georgia

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CONYERS, Ga., Dec. 6

 BODY:
When Bob Mensinger, a World War II veteran, decided that he wanted to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the attack on Pearl Harbor by burning a replica of a Japanese battle flag on public property, he touched an economic nerve here.
And for good reason: Conyers, a city of 9,000 people 22 miles east of Atlanta, has shared in that city's growing international profile and become home in recent years to four Japanese companies whose payrolls provide more than $6 million annually to the city. 
 Robert Kitchens, a maintenance supervisor at the Japanese-owned Maxell Corporation plant here, called the idea "stupid" and said publicity about it had caused tension among his Japanese co-workers.
But even among those not directly affected by the Japanese presence, the Japan-bashing implicit in the idea seems alien to anything remotely felt in Conyers and amounts to just plain bad manners. Mr. Mensinger's flag-burning act is scheduled to be held in the city's Pine Log Park at 7:55 A.M. Saturday, but most people here are betting he will be pretty much alone.
"He has no community backing," said James Proxmire, a veteran and member of the Atlanta chapter of the Pearl Harbor Survivors Association. "You know, he spent time as an M.P. in the Army Air Corps stationed in England, while I spent 52 months at Pearl Harbor and in the Pacific. What he is doing just doesn't make sense."
News of Mr. Mensinger's unusual observance led the Rockdale-Conyers Chamber of Commerce to visit each one of the Japanese companies here to reassure them that the enmity implied in Mr. Mensinger's act was not generally shared.
"The incident has brought out support for Japanese-owned companies here, and many have spoken to us to encourage us," said Seiji Omahsu, general manager of Takahashi Works Inc., which moved to Conyers a year ago and makes cabs for heavy equipment.
Seiji Ogasawara, the manager of Liochem Inc., a division of Toyo Ink, which has been here for three years and manufactures printing inks, said, "We have strong relations here, but I hope nothing happens."
There is more than $26 billion in Japanese direct investment in the United States, according to the economic affairs office of the Consulate General of Japan in Atlanta. About $12 billion of that is scattered among 321 manufacturing companies in the Southeast and 512 other Japanese-owned business outlets. A total of 85,000 people are employed at these businesses, including 20,000 each in Georgia and Tennessee.
Last year, when Toshiki Kaifu, then Prime Minister, became the first Japanese chief executive to visit Atlanta, the event was intended to highlight the significance of this region as the focus of so much Japanese investment and manufacturing activity, a spokesman for the consulate said.
Maxell, the audio and video tape manufacturer, is a subsidiary of Hitachi America Inc. It is the oldest Japanese-owned company in Conyers, arriving 10 years ago and initially employing 50 people. There are now 220 workers at the plant and distribution center here, said Tony McGiboney, assistant manager of the plant.
Besides Liochem, which employs 28 people, and Takahashi, with 33 workers, there is one other Japanese-owned company here: Hokushin, which makes parts for fax machines and copiers, and employs 100 people.
Mr. Mensinger, who is 69 years old, said in an interview that his planned observance of Pearl Harbor was not aimed at arousing anti-Japanese feelings in the area, but was intended only as a way of honoring the American soldiers and sailors killed in the attack 50 years ago. He noted that he was not planning to burn Japan's national flag with its red sun on a white field, but a battle flag with a red sun and red rays emanating from it.
He conceded that the flag burning might be considered to be in bad taste, but added, "We have freedoms in this country, and I have the right to show bad manners as long as I don't break the laws."
Acting City Manager Roland Vaughn said that city officials had granted Mr. Mensinger permission to hold his observance, but not on public property in the heart of downtown Conyers as he had originally requested. They have allowed the observance to be held at a park just outside the city and at 7:55 A.M. on Saturday. Mr. Vaughn said the time was chosen partly because it is the exact time the attack began, but mostly because it was when city and county police officials could provide protection and other services.
Mr. Mensinger said he believes the permit's requirement that it be held at the early hour, while symbolic, was intended mostly to cut down on the number of those who might want to join the observance.
Local pressure and opposition had forced three of six veterans who had initially planned the observance to drop out, Mr. Mensinger said, but he added that he had received telephone calls of support from others who promised to attend.
"Seven fifty-five wasn't too early for the Japanese to come bomb us at Pearl Harbor," he said, "but I guess some people won't come because of the early hour."

(Alan S. Weiner for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Paterson to Monitor Dig at Burial Ground

 BODY:
To insure that archeologists not be hurried in digging an 18th-century burial ground for blacks in lower Manhattan, State Senator David A. Paterson said yesterday that he would form a team to monitor the work.
The cemetery, known in the 1750's as the Negros Burial Ground, was discovered at a construction site on Broadway, between Duane and Reade Streets, where a 34-story Federal office tower is planned. More than 90 skeletal remains have been unearthed there since October and there may be dozens more. 
 Senator Paterson, a Democrat who represents Harlem and the Upper West Side, had expressed fear that the Government would put economy ahead of archeology. Construction delays from a painstaking dig may cost up to $6 million.
The New York Times reported in some editions yesterday that the project manager, John Rossi, was considering quicker excavation. But after learning of the article, the regional administrator of the General Services Administration, William J. Diamond, said on Thursday night, "There will be no speeding up that will endanger the artifacts."
While acknowledging that assurance, Mr. Paterson said he would nonetheless gather preservationists, elected officials and concerned citizens to keep watch on the dig.
Mr. Diamond said yesterday, "We welcome any and all serious oversight, as we will go to all appropriate lengths to assure the community that their ethnic and social heritage is being well protected."
Senator Paterson said he would take Mr. Diamond's word that it was now his intention to give archeologists first priority. "But I'm not assured that this was the original intention," he said.

HEADLINE: New Move On Rates By the Fed

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve eased monetary policy another notch yesterday, pushing down short-term rates in response to a much larger-than-expected decline of 241,000 jobs on corporate payrolls in November.
The most recent move by the Fed is the latest in a series of adjustments to reduce interest rates that began in early 1989 and accelerated in the last few months. The Fed's chairman, Alan Greenspan, noted in a speech yesterday that the economic rebound of the summer "has shown signs of faltering" and that there was enough uncertainty about the future to make lenders, consumers and businesses more cautious. 
 David Jones, an economist at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, a government securities firm, commented: "This was a devastatingly weak employment number, and I doubt it is the last move by the Fed to ease. Later this year, or more likely early next year, the Fed will probably move again to cut rates again."
 
Unnoticed by Consumers
 Yesterday's actions did not greatly affect consumers, but Mr. Jones said he expected an additional move by the Fed in the next month. If it cuts the discount rate to 4 percent from 4 1/2 percent, that may well produce a reduction in the prime lending rate charged by banks, which is now at 7 1/2 percent.
Yesterday's decline in payrolls was roughly the same size as monthly declines during the recessionary months of October 1990 through April 1991, and led many economists to predict flat growth for the economy during the current quarter and perhaps a small decline in the first quarter of next year.
 
To Encourage Spending
 The Fed is cutting interest rates to try to stimulate a weak economy by encouraging more borrowing and spending. According to the theory, as rates come down, borrowers pay less for loans, and consumers become more willing to spend as the interest rates on savings decline.
The starting point for the process of declining interest rates is the Treasury securities market, where the Fed signaled its desire for lower rates about 11:30 A.M. when it temporarily purchased securities for the account of its foreign customers. Traders and economists quickly concluded that the Fed was aiming to provide enough credit to the banking system that overnight bank loans in the Federal funds market will average about 4 1/2 percent, down from 4 3/4 percent since early November and 7.3 percent in December 1990.
While the Fed has succeeded in pushing down short-term rates, long-term bond yields have been slower to drop.
Interest rates on Treasury bills quickly dropped a tenth of a percentage point or more, with the three-month issue ending the day at about 4.24 percent, down from 4.34 percent.
Among the longer-term notes and bonds, prices rose modestly and yields declined for most issues, but not all the change could be attributed to the Fed's move. A comment by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady late Thursday that he was considering reducing the Treasury's quarterly sales of $12 billion of 30-year bonds caused many firms to buy bonds to offset positions taken earlier in a trading strategy involving the sale of borrowed bonds.
 
Yield on 30-Year Bond
 By late in the day, the 8 percent Treasury bond due in 2021 was offered at 102 10/32, up 1/2 point, to yield 7.80 percent. Earlier in the day the 8 percent bonds traded as high as 103 1/4, to yield 7.75 percent. The yield on the 30-year bond, a benchmark for home mortgages and corporate bonds, was 8.14 percent in December 1990.
Selling by securities dealers and other speculators was enough for the 7 1/2 percent Treasury notes due in 10 years to fall 1/32, to 101 29/32, to yield 7.23 percent. The 6 1/2 percent notes due in 1996 rose 6/32, to an offered price of 100 30/32, to yield 6.28 percent.
Although the Fed's moves have not prevented steep declines in consumer confidence or a slowdown in the overall economy, analysts note that the effects of monetary policy are always felt later.
 
Support for Policy
 Hugh L. McColl, chairman of the NCNB Corporation, the nation's seventh-largest banking company, said earlier this week that the economy needed lower interest rates and added that consumers and businesses were benefiting from lower rates even if their spending remained subdued.
"When we refinance somebody's mortgage at today's lower rates, that leaves more money in their wallet available for spending on other things," he said.
The refinancing of old high-rate mortgages has been a booming business and one of the most visible ways in which some consumers are benefiting from lower rates. For every eighth of a percentage point reduction in mortgage rate, the monthly payment on a $100,000 mortgage declines by nearly $10. For example, replacing a 10.5 percent $100,000 mortgage with a new loan, which could carry a rate as low as 8 1/2 percent, would reduce the monthly payment by $145.83.
Jerry Baker, a managing director at the Countrywide Funding Corporation, which is based in Pasadena, Calif., one of the nation's largest mortgage lenders, said that declining interest rates had stimulated heavy demand for mortgages. "The demand is not just from homeowners looking to refinance at a lower rate; we are beginning to see more by home buyers," he said, noting that demand is about evenly split between those categories.
