HEADLINE: Consumer Borrowing Jumps 1.3%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 6

 BODY:
Consumers reversed course this fall and again began taking on new debt, including a 1.3 percent increase in October, the steepest jump in six months, the Government said today.
The Federal Reserve said consumer credit advanced a seasonally adjusted $802 million in October after a sharply revised gain of one-tenth of a percent a month earlier. The September estimate originally had been a 2.5 percent drop in debt. 
 They were the first gains since installment debt jumped 1.9 percent in April.
Still, some analysts said the increases could be revised downward in subsequent months.
"Even if they're not revised, November and December certainly will be more in line with the economic state and we'll see falling consumer credit again," said Jean Sundrla of Evans Economics, a Washington forecasting service.
"There's no reason for these figures to be increasing," Ms. Sundrla added, pointing to falling consumer confidence, a continued loss of jobs and an uncertain political climate.
Consumer credit includes all consumer loans except mortgages and home-equity debt. It helps finance much of overall consumer spending, which represents two-thirds of the nation's economic activity.
The increased debt was all charged on credit cards. Revolving credit advanced 6.9 percent, or $1.3 billion, in October. Still, that was slower than the 13.7 percent jump in September.
"Any purchases on credit cards at this time, beyond normal holiday spending, are being made for absolute necessities" that consumers cannot otherwise afford, Ms. Sundrla said.
Consumers continued to pay off their bills in other areas faster than they took on new debt.
Automobile credit in October dropped eight-tenths of a percent, or a seasonally adjusted $173 million. But that was much slower than the 7.4 percent drop in September and the 7.3 percent decline in August.
Bank and credit union loans not secured by real estate fell 1.4 percent, or $240 million, nearly matching the 1.7 percent decline in September.
Borrowing for mobile homes plummeted 8.1 percent, or $128 million. Still, that was not as sharp as the 37.1 percent plunge a month earlier.
The changes left consumers holding $730.4 billion in installment debt at the end of October.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
McDonnell Helicopter Plans Major Cutbacks

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: MESA, Ariz., Dec. 6

 BODY:
The McDonnell Douglas Helicopter Corporation, a unit of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, said today that it might sell portions of its business and lay off up to 1,000 workers because of what it called "rigorous cuts in defense spending."
Based in Mesa, Calif., the helicopter company said it was also exploring options for joint ventures. 
 It said it plans to cut its work force by 800 to 1,000 in 1992. "The rigorous cuts in defense spending coupled with a sharp economic downturn forces us to take action," Tom Gunn, company president, said in a statement.
The layoffs will be accomplished as existing contracts are concluded and will be done via normal attrition and the elimination of less essential positions, the company said. McDonnell Douglas Helicopter has 5,200 employees, including 4,000 in Mesa, Ariz., and 1,200 in Culver City, Calif. The cuts will be made in both locations, the company said. It said it would also consolidate internal divisions and reduce spending in all areas.
McDonnell stock was down $87.5 cents today, to $66.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.
The company said it did not have any estimates on how much it would save from the work force reduction.
Ken Jensen, a spokesman for McDonnell Douglas Helicopter, said, "We're exploring everything, product lines included."
 He said the helicopter unit was profitable and was expected to remain profitable in the future.
The cuts come just days after the St. Louis-based parent company, the nation's largest military contractor, said it would slash up to 3,800 jobs at its Douglas Aircraft Company unit in the next 18 months because of a slowdown in jetliner production and cost-cutting efforts.

HEADLINE: Stocks Close Mixed; Dow Is Off 2.69

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks closed mixed for the day, after a volatile trading session that saw the Dow Jones industrial average swing 50 points before finishing down 2.69, at 2,886.40. For the week, the index fell 8.28 points.
Despite the Dow's loss yesterday, gainers led losers by 874 to 775. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was heavy at 199.2 million shares traded, up from 166.4 million on Thursday. 
 The market rallied after the Federal Reserve lowered the Federal funds rate to 4 1/2 percent, indicating an easier credit stance. By the afternoon, however, "as the bond market became disappointed that the Fed did not follow up with a discount rate cut, bonds sold off and stocks similarly reversed field, coming back down from the high on the Dow and slowly giving it all back," said Anthony Ludovici, a senior vice president and senior investment analyst at Tucker Anthony.
 
'Still on Unsteady Footing'
 "The fact that the market's breadth was so narrow, evidenced by the closeness between losers and gainers, demonstrates that the overall market is still on unsteady footing," he added.
Among other indexes yesterday, the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 1.71 points, to 379.10, as the American Stock Exchange index gained 0.83 point, to 372.63. The Big Board's composite index rose 0.78 points, to 209.74.
Trading on the Nasdaq pushed the composite up 2.27 points, to 536.30, while the Russell 2,000 index gained 0.31 point, to 177.54.
Mr. Ludovici said market activity yesterday was punctuated by program trading that saw it begin the day with a selloff, following disappointing November employment data that showed non-farm payroll down sharply.
Birinyi Associates, a research firm that tracks program trading, said the impact on the market was heavy on both sides of trading, with 11 programs adding a cumulative 13.85 points to the index throughout the day.
 
The Big Movers
 According to the research firm, the big movers on the Dow that were off more than a point included International Paper, I.B.M., Caterpillar and Sears, Roebuck. Stocks up more than a point included General Electric, Merck and Texaco.
Elsewhere in the market, shares of Alpine Lace Brands jumped 3 1/2, to 7 1/2, as the food-processing company declined to comment on market speculation stemming from an article in the Dec. 16 issue of Business Week magazine. The article said that there was fresh takeover speculation about the company and that one investment manager said RJR Nabisco Holdings headed a list of three companies interested in Alpine.
Xoma released some favorable data on Thursday about a protein in development for bacterial infection. The stock rose as much 1 1/2 yesterday, to 20, before finishing at 19 1/2. Traders said Robert Kupo, an analyst at Kidder, Peabody, increased his rating on the biotechnology company to "hold" from "underperform."
Other stocks receiving favorable ratings yesterday from analysts included the Gap and the Limited. William N. Smith, an analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham, repeated his buy rating on both retailers after they reported sales gains in November. The Gap rose 1 1/2, to 52, and the Limited rose 1 1/8, to close at 26 3/4.

HEADLINE: European Monetary Union: Now Much More Than Talk

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, Dec. 6

 BODY:
After years of talk, European Community governments seem set to relinquish control over their monetary policies and form a landmark monetary union that will include a common central bank and a single currency.
Despite Britain's objections, the plan calls for setting up a common currency in several European countries, perhaps as soon as 1997 and no later than 1999. 
 If all goes according to plan, the European Currency Unit, or ECU, will become the currency of hundreds of millions of Europeans -- and could someday rival the dollar in importance. European officials say the plan will bolster growth and investment, push down inflation and interest rates, and improve Europe's competitiveness versus the United States and Japan.
Over time, there will be trade-offs for countries that join the monetary union. For example, they will relinquish sovereign power over their money supply. Each nation will stop issuing its own money and forfeit control over the setting of interest rates, since those powers would go to a common central bank.
These countries will still influence overall monetary policy because they will have representatives on the board of the common central bank. Member countries will also give up the power to devalue their currencies. Many European countries with competitiveness problems and trade deficits have devalued their currencies, because it raises their exports by making them cheaper abroad.
Also, countries will no longer have full freedom over their budget policies. Concerned that large deficits can push up inflation and interest rates, the community plans warnings and even fines against countries with deficits that exceed 3 percent of their gross domestic product.
Still, every community member except Britain insists that the benefits of monetary union will outweigh any of the losses.
Although the decisions taken next week in Maastricht, the Netherlands, will not have overnight repercussions, monetary union will ultimately have far-reaching effects on people and businesses both here and in the United States.
Germans who travel to France and the Netherlands will no longer have to worry about changing their marks to French francs and Dutch guilders; all three countries will have the same currency. Similarly, vacationing Americans who travel from Nice to Florence will not have to fret about their leftover francs.
And businesses will be able to end the bothersome and costly practice of preparing invoices in separate currencies for different countries. Companies will also save money by eliminating the European currency-hedging operations they use to protect the value of shipments against currency fluctuations.
American banks and manufacturers doing business in Europe strongly support monetary union, saying it will lower costs and, they hope, stimulate the Continent's economy.
"Imagine what it would be like operating our business in the United States with 12 different currencies," said Ursus Jaeggi, director of government affairs for Du Pont in Europe. "It would have a hell of a negative impact on our bottom line, because our costs would go up significantly.
"As soon as these European currencies can be replaced by a single currency, we can simplify internal administration. It would help our costs, our bottom line, and our ability to compete."
 
Builds on Existing System
 The plan for monetary union will build on the existing 10-nation European Monetary System, which pegs exchange rates among the community nations. Monetary union will improve on this by creating a large currency zone that raises investors' confidence by eliminating the threat of devaluations and exchange-rate fluctuations.
It is unclear now how many nations will join a common central bank and use a common currency. After bitterly fighting monetary union to preserve its own currency and sovereignty, Britain is likely to opt out. Several other nations may also be excluded if they do not rein in their inflation rates and budget deficits. Many European officials predict that seven nations, including France and Germany, will make up the first group to use a common currency and form a joint central bank.
Since July 1, 1990, when the first stage of the monetary union plan took effect, community nations have sought to make their economic policies and performance converge by lowering inflation rates and budget deficits. Europe's currencies can only be fused together if community members bring down their inflation rates so that they are in a narrow range, European officials say. These officials add that community members need to slash their budget deficits to ease pressures on inflation and interest rates.
 
In 1994, a Second Stage

The second stage of monetary union -- which begins on Jan. 1, 1994 -- calls for an embryonic European central bank, known as the European Monetary Institute, to guide and put pressure on the 12 nations to bring their inflation rates, interest rates and budget deficits into line.
"Monetary union will not only create certainty, but it will create a better consensus on economic policies over all that are strongly influenced by the idea of lowering inflation," said Jean-Louis Beffa, chairman of Saint-Gobain, the French glass and packaging company.
By the end of 1996, the community's members plan to vote on a third and final stage of monetary union -- to create a common central bank and set permanent exchange rates. These moves require unanimous approval. Officials from several nations hope a decision to form a single currency will also be taken then.
Worried that a lack of unanimity would cause a single currency to fall by the wayside, France won a compromise from other nations this week that aims to insure the creation of a single currency. A new vote is to be taken by late 1998, and according to the compromise a simple majority of nations will suffice to form a common central bank and currency.
 
Similar to Fed System
 Once a common central bank is formed, the central banks of France, Germany and other nations will take on functions not unlike the role of the regional Federal Reserve Banks in the United States.
France, Spain and Italy want a communitywide central bank because they are frustrated that Germany's Bundesbank so dominates the European Monetary System. These countries contend that the German central bank, with its high interest rates, too often favors fighting inflation over promoting economic growth.
"You won't have a policy that is totally influenced by the specifics of one country," said Mr. Beffa of Saint-Gobain. "It could be a little more growth-oriented. It could take into account a little more the situation of other countries."
 
Germans Are Wary
 President Francois Mitterrand of France persuaded Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany to go along with monetary union after Mr. Kohl sought to dispel fears that his nation would dominate Europe as a result of German reunification. But in exchange for agreeing to abandon the Deutsche mark, Mr. Kohl insists on making the community's institutions more democratic, partly to reflect the population of a united Germany.
Many Germans are wary of embracing the ECU, which they fear will be weaker than the mark. The ECU's value will be based on a weighted "basket" of community currencies.
"Some people feel this is a very unique opportunity, and we shouldn't let it slip by," said Ulrich Schroeder, an economist with Deutsche Bank. "But others say we should proceed a little more cautiously, that we shouldn't commit ourselves right now."
The Germans insist that the new central bank be independent of government pressure, which would allow it to concentrate on keeping prices stable rather than on easing credit, as many politicians want. They also fear that if community members fail to bring down inflation, the common currency will prove far flimsier than the mark.
 
Conditions for Joining
 The plan sets several conditions that a nation must satisfy to join the monetary union:
*Its inflation rate must not exceed by more than 1.5 percentage points the average rate of the three community nations with the lowest rates.
*Its budget deficit must not exceed 3 percent of its gross domestic product and its overall Government debt must not exceed 60 percent of G.D.P.
*Long-term interest rates must not exceed by more than 2 points the average interest rate of the three countries with the lowest inflation rates.
*Its exchange rate must not fall, for two years, more than 2.25 percent below the average of the European Monetary System.
Currently, only France and Luxembourg meet all of these criteria. Even Germany does not meet all of them, because the costs of reunification have pushed its budget deficits to 5 percent of G.D.P.
Italy does not meet any of the conditions. Its deficit is about 10 percent of G.D.P., and its overall debt is more than 100 percent of G.D.P.

HEADLINE: Maxwell Says The Daily News Still Has Several Weeks of Breathing Room

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES

 BODY:
Kevin Maxwell, the publisher of the bankrupt Daily News, pledged again yesterday to keep the paper operating and invited unions to help decide how to cut costs, almost certainly including labor concessions.
"We have the cash to meet any obligation that may fall due in the foreseeable future, and the paper is not for sale," Mr. Maxwell said, responding to two of the most urgent concerns of the paper's employees. 
 On Thursday, the board of Maxwell Newspapers filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code, which shields an unprofitable company from creditors while it tries to reorganize. While Mr. Maxwell said the situation called for speedy action, he seemed to suggest that The News had some breathing room, perhaps several weeks or more, to become self-sustaining and emerge from bankruptcy.
 
Effort to Begin Soon
 Federal Bankruptcy Judge Tina L. Brozman is expected to set a hearing in 20 to 40 days to bring all parties involved together for the first time. But a reorganization effort is expected to begin in earnest next week.
After meeting with union leaders at the paper yesterday morning, Mr. Maxwell appeared at a news conference with union leaders and announced a partnership with them in the effort to save The News one more time. After a devastating five-month strike, the late Robert Maxwell won significant concessions from unions and kept the paper alive by acquiring it from the Tribune Company.
Mr. Maxwell said all financial information would be shared with the unions and two people chosen by the unions would join a working party of advisers who will prepare a reorganization plan for The News. John Campi, a News spokesman, said the advisory group would include the paper's management, creditors and union leaders and would probably be organized next week.
 
Board Seats for Unions
 Should the paper emerge from bankruptcy, two union representatives would be placed on the board.
Mr. Campi said the paper cost about $1 million a day to operate and had about $8 million in cash on hand. Another $20 million to $25 million is in accounts receivable, mostly for advertising, and he said normal collection rates were about 90 percent. He added that the paper generated more than $2 million each week in circulation revenue.
Mr. Maxwell also said The News would investigate borrowing against assets like its Brooklyn printing plant and a truck garage, which Mr. Campi said had been appraised at about $7.5 million.
John S. Reidy, a stock analyst who specializes in newspaper companies at Smith Barney, Harris Upham in New York, said yesterday that The News could probably operate through Christmas with little difficulty. After that, he said, it could face a substantial decline in revenues. While advertisers would find it very difficult to withdraw from the paper shortly before Christmas, January is traditionally a poor month for advertising, and this year's advertising climate is especially poor over all because of the recession.
 
Effect on Advertisers
 "The bankruptcy will definitely have a dampening effect on advertising in a very damp market," Mr. Reidy said.
Les Goodstein, vice president for advertising at The News, said many leading advertisers had been contacted since the Chapter 11 filing and all had expressed support. He said no advertisers had said they wanted to withdraw or reduce advertising.
If advertising revenues decline from pre-Christmas levels, pressure will increase to make significant cuts in costs.
While relations at present between unions and the paper's management appear cordial, that could change should an effort be made to cut the paper's work force drastically or to void the current contract and change work rules and salaries.
 
Opportunity in Adversity
 Indeed, James P. Willse, editor of The News and a member of its board, said a reorganization would be "an opportunity to set right what needs to be set right about the structure of the paper," which has been shorthand for significant reductions in areas like the number of people needed to operate presses. For instance, during the five-month strike that ended in March, the paper's presses were operated by about half the number of people now operating them.
No member of the paper's management would elaborate on what changes would be sought in a reorganization plan.
George E. McDonald, president of the Allied Printing Trades Council, the umbrella organization for the paper's unions, said Theodore W. Kheel, a lawyer who acts as unpaid adviser to the unions, would be one of the unions' representatives on the advisory board.
Union leaders are scheduled to meet Tuesday to discuss who the other representative should be. That person will be expected to do a financial analysis on the unions' behalf.
 
Willing to Help
 While Mr. McDonald expressed his willingness to help with the reorganization effort, he said he was concerned that the unions might make one set of concessions to make the paper profitable and then be called upon to make more concessions by a buyer if it was put up for sale.
The Maxwell family's private companies were put in bankruptcy in London on Thursday and the British court appointed four partners of Arthur Andersen & Company, the accounting firm, to be administrators of the various businesses, which include The Daily News through various holding companies.
While filing for Chapter 11 protection in the United States offers The News some protection from immediate sale, the ultimate power over its fate lies with the administrators in Britain because they have the power to replace The News's management, including Mr. Maxwell.
 
Control Lies in London
 The administrators issued a statement yesterday saying they were "working with the board and management of The Daily News to protect The Daily News so that it continues as a viable newspaper."
But the administrators have repeatedly said they would sell whatever assets were necessary to satisfy creditors. That could well include The Daily News, especially if it becomes profitable through a reorganization plan.
Yesterday, David Cornstein, president of Finlay Enterprises, a company that sells jewelry through department and other stores, said through a spokesman that The News was too important to be allowed to die. The spokesman, Gary Lewi of Howard J. Rubenstein Associates, a public relations firm, said Mr. Cornstein was investigating whether a consortium of businessmen might invest in the paper.
 
Potential News Buyers
 Mortimer B. Zuckerman, a real estate developer and owner of U.S. News & World Report, and Peter S. Kalikow, also a developer and the owner of The New York Post, who is also in personal bankruptcy, have also expressed some interest should The News be put up for sale.
Mr. Maxwell said his family had invested $20 million to $25 million in The News, in addition to the $60 million it received from the Tribune Company for taking over the paper in March.
About $7 million of the Maxwell investment was in cash, Mr. Campi said, the rest in debt to other Maxwell companies.
Mr. Maxwell declined to address questions regarding the source of the money he had used to subsidize The News's operation.
Robert Maxwell, his late father, apparently transferred millions of dollars from pension funds of the Mirror Group Newspapers in Britain to shore up his private companies. Mr. Campi said he could not say whether this was the source of funds that came to The News.
Mr. Maxwell and union leaders said The News's pension plan was intact.

HEADLINE: ABOUT NEW YORK;
From Sotheby's High Gloss To Filth of Calcutta's Slums

BYLINE: By Douglas Martin

 BODY:
The auctioneer cut an imposing figure, nearly six feet tall in heels, her English-accented contralto crisply authoritative. "We're going to dash right in and start," she announced Wednesday evening.
In less than an hour she would sell Keith Carradine's lucky cowboy boots, Dorothy Hamill's favorite skates, Nolan Ryan's no-hit cleats, Ivana Trump's mules and the used footwear of more than a dozen other famous people as part of a benefit staged by the Fashion Footwear Association to help AIDS patients. 
 The auctioneer waved her pen like a conductor's baton, shushed gigglers, noticed bidders' slightest twitches. A pro. Almost like old times, when she was not just doing this for charity but was on top of the auction world.
That began for Lorna Kelly in 1976, when she became an auctioneer at Sotheby's in New York -- the first woman to do so and one of the first women to become a fine arts auctioneer in America. Over the next six years she conducted nearly 50 auctions, yielding some $50 million a year. Her achievements were chronicled in The New York Times and other publications.
She lived on the Upper East Side, dined at the best restaurants, wore elegant clothes, adored the power that comes from orchestrating the sale of a Picasso. She says she gave it all up for God and humanity -- albeit with a little push from Sotheby's.
Her ever-strengthening religious convictions left no doubt that her dismissal served larger purposes. "God did for me what I couldn't do for myself," she declared.
Ms. Kelly made a tiny West Side apartment a base for soothing God's scattered children. She journeyed to Calcutta to work in Mother Teresa's House for the Dying, worked as an AIDS volunteer at St. Clare's Hospital in Manhattan, personally vaccinated 2,000 children in West Africa, ministered to the needs of garbage-dump residents in Cairo, fed the homeless on 42d Street, spent 100 days at an upstate Buddhist retreat in complete silence.
And now Lorna Kelly -- who at 46 years of age has been to the top of many mountains, at times feeling "a sibling rivalry" with Jesus -- wants the simplest of things. "I want a job, not a career," she said. "I want to get back in the mainstream of life. I want to get up, put on my pantyhose and go to work."
Ms. Kelly regards New York as a calling as much as a city. Growing up in London, she daydreamed about New York's adrenalin and sophistication. She first visited as a strong-spirited 15-year-old on her way to catch a liner home after spending a year in Toronto living "a Dickensian life with a tyrannical aunt."
She vowed to conquer Gotham. At age 18, she returned as an au pair to care for four children, all under 7. "The price of admission," she calls this domestic bedlam.
Shorthand, typing and sheer drive fueled her survival. She thrived after becoming an expert in tiny Japanese objets d'art at Sotheby's. Her decidedly nervous request to auction was greeted with a decidedly immediate yes. Her confidence grew to that of the prototypical New Yorker.
Ask Mother Teresa. Ms. Kelly first arrived at her mission wearing designer clothing, perfect makeup and very long, Cadillac-red fingernails. Mother Teresa grabbed a hand and demanded, "Why do you wear that stuff?" She suggested her money might be better spent on the poor.
Ms. Kelly shot back that Jesus had repudiated Judas's suggestion that He ask Mary Magdalene to stop annointing His feet for similar reasons. Mother Teresa had clearly not expected somebody with fingernails like Ms. Kelly's to fire off scriptural retorts. They stared at each other.
"I was trying to put her down," the visiting New Yorker acknowledged. Mother Teresa just laughed.
The result was that Ms. Kelly visited many more times, coming to feel at home sleeping on straw pallets full of bugs that she calls "God's beloveds." She spent days cleaning maggots off people. In turn, she says, Mother Teresa made a point of seeing her on visits to New York.
"I think she was as fascinated with me as I was with her," Ms. Kelly ventured.
However, New York ultimately became more affecting for her than the slums of India or other distant hells. Ms. Kelly was more personally involved here, particularly with AIDS victims she cherished. And her life traversed valleys familiar to many: a decade-long failed marriage, apartment moves, periods of economic uncertainty, lost loves.
These days, she works on an autobiography, gives speeches, conducts auctions for good causes. Her goal, as always, is to seek new horizons -- not necessarily to do extraordinary things, but to do "the next thing."
Yet surely they will be extraordinary. You should have seen the way she toyed with the crowd to draw a bid of $5,250 for Madonna's only slightly used sneakers.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls on Jobless Data; Gold Is Higher Worldwide

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar slid yesterday after the release of an extremely disappointing jobless report and a subsequent easing of interest rates by the Federal Reserve.
Gold prices advanced worldwide. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery gained $2 an ounce to settle at $369.40. The Republic National Bank quoted a late bid for gold of $368.75, up $2.25 an ounce. 
 The dollar was pummeled by a Labor Department report showing non-farm payrolls tumbled a steep 241,000 last month, despite an unemployment rate that remained unchanged.
Soon after the report was released, the Federal Reserve lowered a key interest rate in yet another attempt to revive the economy. The central bank trimmed the Federal funds rate -- the rate on overnight loans between banks -- by 1/4 percent, to 4 1/2 percent.
"It was a very, very tough day," said Randolph Donney, research director at the Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J. With the cut in the Fed funds rate, "there is the expectation we will see an even more aggressive lowering of interest rates in the next week or two," he added.
Lower interest rates are bearish for the dollar because they make dollar-denominated securities less valuable for investors.
Marc Chandler, an analyst with the advisory firm IDEA, noted that economists used the unemployment report, one of the earliest bits of economic data from the previous month, as a base for their projections of other November data that have yet to be released.
 
Lower Dollar Expected
 "This will force people to reassess the economy," he said. "It looks like the dollar is poised to continue to slide."
In Tokyo, the dollar fell 0.15 yen, to a closing 128.70 yen. Later, in London it was quoted at 128.00 yen. In New York the dollar settled at 127.95 yen, down from 128.70 yen on Thursday.
In London, the pound was quoted at $1.8095, compared with $1.7935 late Thursday. In New York it cost $1.8167 to buy 1, more expensive than Thursday's $1.7965.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's rates, included: 1.5675 German marks, down from 1.5885; 1.3845 Swiss francs, down from 1.4050; 5.3590 French francs, down from 5.4315; 1,187.00 Italian lire, down from 1,202.00, and 1.1364 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1380.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Thursday's rates, included: 1.5710 German marks, down from 1.5880; 1.3885 Swiss francs, down from 1.4065; 5.3720 French francs, down from 5.4280; 1.7700 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7895; 1,188.50 Italian lire, down from 1,200.75, and 1.1363 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1366.
In London gold rose to $367.90 an ounce, from $364.15 late Thursday. In Zurich the bid was $367.75, up from $364.25. Earlier, in Hong Kong gold rose $1.91 an ounce, to $368.18.

HEADLINE: Waiting to See if 'Hook' Will Fly

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Dec. 6

 BODY:
Even before it opens next week, "Hook," Steven Spielberg's update of "Peter Pan," has become a symbol of all that is right and all that is wrong with the movie business.
With its magical special effects and its all-star cast -- Robin Williams as the grown-up Peter Pan, Dustin Hoffman as the pirate captain and Julia Roberts as Tinkerbell -- "Hook," from the Sony Corporation's Tri-Star Pictures, is the kind of big-screen spectacle that even competing studio executives say should rekindle the excitement of moviegoers. 
 The industry desperately needs some excitement. Although several new releases, including the Paramount Pictures Corporation's "Addams Family" and the Walt Disney Company's "Beauty and the Beast" are proving to be big hits, this year has been one in which box-office results and the bottom lines of most studios have been battered.
Part of the problem, industry executives and analysts say, has been the recession, which for many people has made a trip to the movies a luxury. But they also blame the movies themselves, which with a few exceptions have left reviewers and audiences yawning or deciding to wait for the home-video releases.
No one in Hollywood is yawning about "Hook," if only because it is one of the most expensive movies ever made. While most studios are preaching the virtues of cost-cutting, Sony's two studios, Columbia Pictures and Tri-Star, have been spending freely to re-establish themselves as major forces in the business.
To some industry executives and Wall Street analysts, "Hook" is evidence of how Hollywood will never really learn to control production costs or hold the line against soaring salaries. Even if it is successful, they say, it will hurt the business by encouraging other studios to take huge risks in the pursuit of the next blockbuster instead of concentrating on movies with more modest aspirations -- and budgets.
 
$62 Million for Production Alone
 Some people in Hollywood who have seen the film say it may not live up to its hype. Sony and Tri-Star executives say they are confident, however, that "Hook" will pay off in the long run and that every penny they have spent has been worth it. But even they acknowledge that the movie will have to be a big hit before the studio can turn a profit.
People involved in the film said the initial $48 million production budget for "Hook" started swelling even before shooting began, first to $52 million and finally to a little more than $62 million by the time the film was completed.
At that level "Hook" was three times more expensive to produce than the average studio picture -- placing it in a league with "Terminator 2: Judgment Day," the big hit of last summer but among the costliest productions in Hollywood history. And the $62 million does not include $20 million or so to advertise the film and distribute it to theaters, or the tens of millions of dollars to be paid to its stars and director, under a deal that gives them a hefty cut of the studio's revenues.
 
Other Studios Becoming Thriftier
 The finances of "Hook" stand out in part because such lavish spending comes when most studios are actually making some progress in holding down their costs. After years of bemoaning rising costs and then rushing to bid for the next high-priced deal, studio executives seem to be looking for ways to hold down costs, especially for stars and scripts.
At Disney, Jeffrey Katzenberg, the company's studio chief, has reduced the average production budget this year to $16.3 million from $24.1 million last year. In large part, the decrease came from Disney's unwillingness to sign big stars to expensive contracts or to cast more than one big star in a movie.
At Paramount, executives are scrutinizing deals and scripts more closely than ever in an effort to avoid movies that do not make economic sense.
"When you get into those high-octane ventures you have to look deep into the remains of your soul and ask if it is something audiences really want to see," Brandon Tartikoff, Paramount's new studio chief, said several months ago. "There have been pictures offered to us that were so expensive we'd never get the money back."
Agents report that all but the biggest of stars are being forced to cut their asking prices, although most continue to earn hundreds of thousands of dollars per film, if not millions.
 
'Event' Movies Considered Viable
 A few studios, including 20th Century Fox, are still making many expensive movies. And almost all studios are continuing to make at least one or two very expensive movies a year on the theory that properly conceived and executed, "event" movies can still make economic sense. "Terminator 2" turned out to be very profitable for its producer, Carolco Pictures Inc., and for Tri-Star, which distributed it to movie theaters in the United States. Indeed, some Hollywood executives argue that the most expensive of movies are actually less risky than those with moderate budgets because they offer jaded audiences something out of the ordinary.
"Hook" is just one of two high-priced Tri-Star movies opening this month, the other being "Bugsy," the story of the gangster Bugsy Siegel, starring Warren Beatty and Annette Benning.
Earlier this year, the studio suffered through the spectacular flop of "Hudson Hawk," starring Bruce Willis, another high-priced movie. Mike Medavoy, Tri-Star's chairman, is clearly under pressure to start generating some returns for Sony, whose multibillion-dollar investment in Hollywood has so far yielded the Japanese company little other than a reputation for profligacy.
 
Ingredients for Success
 Mr. Medavoy said that he preferred not to make big-budget movies but that "Hook" combined all the ingredients for success: a director, Mr. Spielberg, who was behind five of the 10 biggest hits in Hollywood history, including "E.T.: The Extra-Terrestrial"; proven box-office draws in Mr. Williams, Mr. Hoffman and Ms. Roberts, and a story derived from one of the most successful plays of all time, J.M. Barrie's "Peter Pan.".
"It's obvious that there are certain circumstances when event-type movies, while risky, are worth making," Mr. Medavoy said.
Much of "Hook's" costs will be visible in special effects and dazzling sets, including a life-size pirate galleon built on a huge sound stage on the lot shared by Tri-Star and Columbia Pictures. The invisible costs include a reported $1 million-plus settlement with the film's original director.
But no element of the movie has raised more questions and eyebrows in Hollywood than the deal that brought Mr. Spielberg, Mr. Williams, Mr. Hoffman and Ms. Roberts to the film. Brokered by Michael Ovitz's powerful Creative Artists Agency, the deal gives the director and stars a hefty portion of the film's revenues before Tri-Star gets its investment back.
So-called gross deals are not uncommon for Hollywood's biggest stars, who usually find it more profitable to take a percentage of a film's gross box-office receipts than a flat salary. Jack Nicholson earned tens of millions of dollars with his gross deal to play the Joker in "Batman."
But the total size of the deal for "Hook" dwarfs any prior previous film arrangement. People familiar with the deal said the director and the three stars will split 40 percent of the studio's initial $50 million in worldwide revenues, meaning they will receive $20 million and Tri-Star $30 million.
Since a studio's revenues typically are slightly more than half of the box-office gross, with the rest kept by theater owners, the first $50 million in studio revenues corresponds to about $100 million in ticket sales -- a level that only a handful of films reach each year.
 
The Break-Even Point
 After the studio's first $50 million in revenues, the deal calls for Tri-Star to keep all the proceeds up to $120 million, giving the studio a chance to recoup its costs. At $120 million in studio revenues, or a block-busting $240 million in ticket sales, Tri-Star would keep $100 million -- enough, its executives calculate, for the film to break even.
After revenues reach $120 million, the director and stars again keep at least 40 percent of each additional dollar.
In Tri-Star's favor, the movie will generate considerable revenues from sources other than domestic box-office receipts. Foreign box-office receipts are likely at least to match receipts in the United States. Home-video sales, broadcast and cable-television fees and product licensing deals will all help.
Many industry executives agree that "Hook" will ultimately make money. But they question whether it will ever be profitable enough to justify the studio's investment and risk.
"The real problem with a movie like 'Hook' is that it's indicative of how the industry is giving away an increasing portion of the profit from its hits without remembering that you also have to cover your failures," said an executive at a rival studio. "It's not enough to prove that a winner is a decent investment. The winners in this business need to be fabulous."

HEADLINE: Bottled Suffolk Water? County Thinks It'll Sell

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HUNTINGTON, L.I., Dec. 6

 BODY:
Perrier, Poland Springs and Great Bear may soon be making room on supermarket shelves for Pine Barrens Pure, bottled and marketed by the Suffolk County Water Authority on eastern Long Island.
Michael LoGrande, chairman of the Suffolk County Water Authority, thinks there's a big market out there for the 10,000-year-old glacier water pumped daily from the pristine aquifer beneath the sands of Suffolk's pine barrens. He envisions sales of more than $80 million a year in Suffolk County alone, but he has a ways to go to convince shoppers to put down money for something they can get out of their own tap. 
 "How could I serve that to my guests?" asked Miriam Skells, loading a six-pack of Evian into a shopping cart filled with snacks for her husband's 50th birthday party.
"It's probably all the same stuff, but I like the little bottles," she said as she hurried on down Aisle 13 at Waldbaum's supermarket here.
 
Started With a Joke
 Shoppers are now paying about $1 per gallon for bottled water, which represents one of the fastest-growing consumer markets in the United States, with consumption of about 2 billion gallons in 1990, more than double the volume since 1986. Mr. LoGrande said that he and the authority's controller, Charles Stein, were talking one day about the increase in the consumption of bottled water and speculated, at first jokingly, about bottling county water.
"But he said, 'Look, don't laugh, it may be a good source of revenue,' so I agreed to give it some thought. It was never our intention to bottle the water per se, but we have a very extensive testing system that enables us to provide unchlorinated water for bottling," he said.
"And at $1.18 cents per thousand gallons, it's the best deal in the county," he added. "But we're always looking for ways to hold that rate down, and bottling water would help."
Dr. James Pierson, a consultant for the authority, concluded that sales of bottled water in Suffolk, with its population of 1.3 million, should number 12 million gallons in 1992. His study also determined that by 1999, sales of the water in the entire metropolitan area could possible reach 300 million gallons.
Only one other municipality in the United States sells its own water in bottles -- Memphis Light, Gas and Water, in Tennessee.
Pure Memphis, advertised as "the flavor of the South," went to market in October 1990 and has been so successful that several private companies are now bidding to acquire the bottling rights, said Tommy Jackson, supervisor of energy services for Memphis Light, Gas and Water, a city agency.
"We sell it in upscale-looking packages of blue-tinted plastic," he said. "We started by giving it away to promote our water quality for economic development purposes. But the novelty caught on and we began marketing it."
Geary Campbell, a spokesman for the International Bottled Water Association in Alexandria, Va., said there were 475 private bottling plants in the United States and 600 different types of brand labels.
And that means a lot of competition for a new product whose working name is Pine Barrens Pure. Sarah Kearny, for one, would need convincing.
"It's exciting to drink water that comes from Ireland," she said, putting two liters of Tipperary into her shopping cart at Waldbaum's. "Drinking Suffolk water would be like never leaving home."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Tenneco Names Head Of Its J. I. Case Unit

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER

 BODY:
Tenneco Inc. said yesterday that Edward J. Campbell, president of its Newport News Shipbuilding unit, had been named president of its troubled J. I. Case unit, effective Jan. 1. Based in Racine, Wis., Case is the world's largest maker of small and medium-size construction equipment, like bulldozers and backhoes, and the second-largest maker of farm equipment in North America, behind John Deere.
As president, Mr. Campbell, who is 63 years old, succeeds Robert J. Carlson, who will continue as Case's chairman and chief executive. A 30-year employee of John Deere, Mr. Carlson joined Case in July from BMC Industries, a Minneapolis electronics and optical company, where he was chairman and chief executive. Mr. Carlson filled a position left vacant last March by the resignation of James Ashford. 
 Tenneco said it was strengthening the management team at Case as part of its program to return the unit to profitability. Stung by the recession and the sliding demand for farm equipment, Case took a $461 million special charge in the third quarter in connection with plant closings, contributing to a record loss for Tenneco of $693 million.
Case itself had a $169 million operating loss, and earlier this month said it would eliminate 4,000 jobs by the end of 1992, bringing its worldwide total to 21,000. The unit has already cut 5,000 jobs this year.
"Ed Campbell is a highly experienced, proven executive who has demonstrated his leadership many times," Michael H. Walsh, Tenneco's president, said in a statement. "He and Bob Carlson give Case two very experienced leaders in the equipment industry. They're a very good team, with well-matched skills, and both are dedicated to returning Case to profitability."
Mr. Campbell previously worked at Case from 1968 to 1978, last as an executive vice president, before moving to Newport News. While he was president of Newport News, its sales rose from $700 million a year to more than $2 billion, and operating income improved from $13 million to more than $200 million, Tenneco said. At Case, he will be responsible for worldwide operations. A successor to Mr. Campbell at Newport has not been named.
Mr. Campbell received a B.S. degree in mechanical engineering and an M.B.A. from Northwestern University.

HEADLINE: Many Reasons Prompt Donations to Neediest

BYLINE: By J. PEDER ZANE

 BODY:
Although lagging behind last year's pace, The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund is receiving more than one hundred donations every day as the 80th annual appeal closes out its first week.
In the short notes and spirited letters accompanying their checks and money orders, donors have detailed a wide range of reasons for giving. "We are the parents of a beautiful healthy girl," wrote Jill and Tim Stoller of Cedar Grove, N.J., who gave $384. "We hope this money can be earmarked for less fortunate children, especially those infected with the H.I.V. virus." 
 Alexandra Werner of Manhattan, who gave $300, also wrote in celebration of life. "On the eve of my 92d birthday, being in reasonable good health and comfortable financially, I am sending the enclosed check."
Janice Gorn of Manhattan sent $50 in remembrance "of Lion Albert Gorn who perished in the North Sea 29th November, 1943."
 
Windfalls Passed to Others
 Last year more than 15,000 individuals and organizations contributed a record $4.4 million to the Neediest Cases. Since it was founded in 1912 by Adolph S. Ochs, who was then publisher of The New York Times, the Neediest Cases has raised money for New York's sick, poor and disabled.
The New York Times covers all of the campaign's overhead so that every dollar collected is passed on to seven charities. The money buys food for the hungry, shelter for the homeless and clothing for those without. It also provides Hanukkah and Christmas presents for thousands of New York City children.
Several donors have contributed because of a windfall, including Michael Damelin of Great Neck, L.I., who donated $75 from his office baseball pool, explaining that the participants "wanted to share the spoils with the less fortunate."
Another winning bet prompted Mr. Damelin to send $25 more. He and two friends were playing golf and, he explained, "As golfers sometimes do, a small wager was negotiated on the first tee.
"After we completed the 18 holes and the debts were settled, we said to one another how lucky we were to have enjoyed the others' company and the beautiful day. Then we started talking about those less fortunate and decided to send the winnings to the Neediest Cases."
Reflecting the tough economic times, many people said they have donated despite personal financial worries. "I don't know what my own finances will look like next year," wrote Kirsten Kirby of Pleasantville, N.Y., who gave $125, "but I am sending a little extra this year, while I still can. Surely the need has never been greater."
Patricia S. Bridges of Flushing, Queens, said that money problems forced her to end a long string of contributions last year. Her family's situation has not improved but she sent $100 because, "We're still better off than so many New Yorkers."
"I wanted to send this in as soon as possible," she wrote, "partly to relieve my guilt about not doing so last year, and, as you say: 'To delay may mean to forget.' "

HEADLINE: Former Museum Head Named to Culture Post

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN

 BODY:
Luis R. Cancel, a former executive director of the Bronx Museum of the Arts, was named New York City's Commissioner of the Department of Cultural Affairs yesterday by Mayor David N. Dinkins.
The post had been vacant since Sept. 6, when Mary Schmidt Campbell left to become dean of the Tisch School of the Arts at New York University. 
 The appointment comes at a time of stress for the city's arts institutions. In its recession budget adopted last July, New York City reduced its allocation for the arts by 28 percent, or $24 million, from a proposed budget of $87.1 million, which does not include mandated expenses. As a result, numerous productions and exhibitions have been canceled, visiting hours curtailed and jobs eliminated.
Even in the best of times, the Culture Commissioner has so little discretionary money to spend that the job is considered largely symbolic.
In addition, the Department of Cultural Affairs is under pressure from the City Council. On Nov. 12, Herbert E. Berman, a Brooklyn Democrat who is chairman of the Finance Committee, introduced a proposal to merge Cultural Affairs with the Parks Department. The two departments were one agency before 1977.
 
Accustomed to Austerity
 When asked what he could realistically hope to accomplish, given the city's lack of money, Mr. Cancel said, "Part of my mandate will be to make people aware of the integral part the arts play in the economic life of this city." He referred to "the disastrous consequences to the city if the arts continue to take a beating."
Mr. Cancel, who is 39 years old, also pointed to his experience at the Bronx Museum as valuable training for tough times. "I am accustomed to working in austere situations," he said. "This is no news to me."
Under Mr. Cancel, who directed and managed a $6.5 million capital campaign and renovation project that was completed in 1988, the Bronx Museum's operating budget grew from $125,000 in 1978 to its present level of $1.7 million. He left the museum in October, saying he wanted to pursue other career opportunities.
Before arriving at the Bronx Museum, Mr. Cancel was director of the Cayman Gallery in SoHo, which specialized in Latin American art. He has a Bachelor of Fine Arts degree from Pratt Institute and master's degrees in museum management and public administration from, respectively, New York University and the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University. Mr. Cancel is also a painter and has exhibited his work in several group shows in New York.
The selection of Mr. Cancel, who was born in Puerto Rico, comes at a time when Mayor Dinkins's relations with the city's Hispanic groups are rocky, particularly since Dr. J. Emilio Carrillo's stormy resignation as head of the Health and Hospitals Corporation in October. The Mayor recently appointed Cesar A. Perales to be deputy mayor for health and human services.
Mr. Cancel said, "The Mayor's selection of me was in part an opportunity to send a signal that for this city and this administration, access to the arts is a particular concern. He explained that in his tenure at the Bronx Museum he had paid special attention "to engaging citizens who have not traditionally been involved with the arts."
Mr. Cancel will take office immediately at an annual salary of $97,000, minus the 5 percent pay cut imposed on all city managers earning $70,000 or more.
Mr. Dinkins also announced the appointment of three new members to the city's Art Commission: Vivian Millicent Warfield, who was named executive director; Lo-Yi Chan, and Barbaralee Diamonstein-Spielvogel. Ms. Warfield, who served on the Mayor's Advisory Commission on Cultural Affairs from 1979 to 1990, has been interim executive director of the Art Commission since July. Mr. Chan is a partner in the architectural firm Prentice & Chan Ollhausen. Ms. Diamonstein-Spielvogel is a writer and television interviewer who has served on a number of boards, including the Landmarks Preservation Committee and the Municipal Art Society.

HEADLINE: Hellinger Theater Sold To Church

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS

 BODY:
The Nederlander Organization has sold the Mark Hellinger Theater to the Times Square Church, the Rev. Donald W. Wilkerson, a pastor of the church, said yesterday. The Hellinger has long been considered one of the best and most beautiful theaters for presenting Broadway musicals.
Mr. Wilkerson said the 1,600-seat theater at 217 West 51st Street had been sold "during the last few weeks." He would not disclose the purchase price, but others knowledgeable about theater property values estimated it at $15 million to $18 million. 
 The last production in the theater was "Legs Diamond," which closed in February 1989. Before "Legs" closed, the Nederlander Organization, saying there were no new musicals around, leased the Hellinger to the church for five years, at more than $1 million a year. Previously the church had leased the smaller Nederlander Theater on West 41st Street since January 1988.
"I'm a theater person and I hate to see any theater go," said Arthur Rubin, executive vice president and general manager of the Nederlander Organization. "It's a question of economics. We can't fill the theaters we have, and the city has not given us tax abatements when the theaters are dark."
 
3,500 Attend Services
 Mr. Rubin said he did not know the purchase price of the theater. Robert Nederlander, president of the Nederlander Organization, did not return a telephone call.
Mr. Wilkerson described the Times Square Church as an evangelical pentacostal church headed by three pastors: himself, his brother, the Rev. David R. Wilkerson, and the Rev. Robert Phillips. Although the church has no formal membership, the Rev. Donald Wilkerson said 3,500 people regularly attended services.
The Hellinger Theater originally opened as a movie house, Hollywood Theater, in 1930 and became a legitimate theater four years later. In 1949, after several name changes, it became the Mark Hellinger in honor of the Broadway columnist.
In 1956, Alan Jay Lerner and Frederick Loewe's "My Fair Lady," starring Rex Harrison and Julie Andrews, opened and stayed for six years. Among the other shows to have played there are "On a Clear Day You Can See Forever," with Barbara Harris; "Coco," with Katharine Hepburn; Andrew Lloyd Webber's "Jesus Christ Superstar," and "Sugar Babies," with Mickey Rooney and Ann Miller.
The Times Square Church will not alter the theater. "The theater is landmarked and it will remain the same," the Rev. Donald Wilkerson said.

HEADLINE: Ball's Dropping for a New Year's Sitter

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
Finding a baby sitter for New Year's Eve is an inevitable struggle. Now is not too soon to line one up.
Educators, parents and baby-sitting agencies in New York, Connecticut, New Jersey and on Long Island say they expect the demand to be high despite the recession. "We're already getting calls," said Lucille Warrington, owner of the Service, a baby-sitting agency in Larchmont, N.Y. Conspicuous spending is in disfavor, but people still plan to celebrate. 
 The experts say baby sitters are always scarce for New Year's Eve and that parents should offer a nonfinancial incentive, extra pay or both.
With that in mind, it is worth determining whether the cost is worth it. If you are indifferent to New Year's Eve parties, you might be happier at home with a midnight toast. It would certainly be less expensive.
 
Double Time Plus
 Many professional baby-sitting agencies will be charging double time. The minimum number of hours is likely to be higher, a nonrefundable deposit or cancellation fee may be required and there could be additional charges for transportation.
The Baby Sitters' Guild, a Manhattan agency that serves many of the larger hotels, is doubling its normal fee of $10 an hour. Charges will also vary depending upon the number of children being tended and whether a foreign-language speaker is needed.
The guild is also asking for a nonrefundable deposit of $50, an extra $7 for transportation and a minimum charge of five hours. For this amount, the parents will be provided with an adult female ("no teen-agers," said Heidi Ball, the guild's director) and no limit on the number of hours. Visitors to the city can make a reservation through their hotel concierge.
Ms. Ball recommends that vistors call before arrival, even if the concierge says it is not necessary.
Parents who use neighborhood teen-agers will also be expected to provide something extra. "You're going need an incentive to get anyone good," said Steffani Cohen, a mother of two in Scarsdale, N.Y., who runs parent-education programs for the Edgemont School District's Parent-Teacher Association.
Mary Kay Wallace, an executive member of the Parents' Council, an umbrella group of 10,000 families in Nashville, said it was customary in her area to offer time and a half, dinner of something like an "extra special pizza," and even to permit the sitter to bring along a friend.
"You might want to rent a couple of movies, too," she said, "something suitable for the kids for early in the evening and something selected by the sitter for herself for later on." Even if the sitter does not want to make an immediate commitment, it is worth mentioning the extras.
Dawn Svenson, executive director of the Mother Connection of Montrose, N.Y, a parent-support and education group, said she favored inviting a baby sitter to sleep over on New Year's Eve, especially if the parents expect to be drinking or unsually late and the sitter is a young teen-ager.
The protocol, she said, is to suggest the idea to the sitter and then confirm the offer with the sitter's parents. "Some parents will not let their children baby sit on New Year's Eve because they're so worried about what might happen on the way home," Ms. Svenson said. If the sitter is staying over, it's customary to work out a flat fee instead of an hourly rate.
Parents who have been invited to a private New Year's Eve party might also consider organizing a cooperative. One favored by a growing number of parents who give parties in their homes is to encourage guests with small children to bring them along and let them sleep in a bedroom during the party. Couples with older children might think about organizing a supervised slumber party for their youngsters while the grown-ups celebrate in another part of the house.

HEADLINE: Decorative Arts Sale Defies Auction Slump

BYLINE: By CAROL VOGEL

 BODY:
The sale of French furniture and decorative objects from the Keck collection on Thursday night at Sotheby's proved that in this depressed auction season a touch of gilt and lacquer goes a long way. Many pieces sold for more than their high estimates, a far cry from the disappointing results in last month's auctions of paintings, drawings and sculpture. Of the 55 objects on the block on Thursday, only six failed to sell. The auction's total, $10,212,400, confirmed what the art market already knew: fine French furniture appears to be recession-proof.
"It just doesn't fall," Jean-Marie Rossi, a Paris-based dealer, said after the sale. "This is still a serious market." And that was exactly what Sotheby's was banking on. With the auction house's bread and butter -- Impressionist, modern and contemporary paintings -- bringing in far less revenue, it is counting on the decorative arts to make up much of the difference. 
 As a result, Sotheby's treated Thursday's sale with the importance it accords a sale of major paintings. It was at night, the first time a furniture sale in New York has not been held during the day, and the house presented the Keck collection in an elaborate hard-bound catalogue. The auction house also guaranteed the seller, Howard B. Keck, an undisclosed sum, which some experts estimated was as low as the sale's low estimate of $8,189,000 and others estimated was as high as $19 million. (A guarantee is a minimum price that the auction house promises the seller regardless of the outcome of the sale.)
 
Small but Potent Turnout
 Still, the turnout seemed small compared with the crowds that attend the major paintings auctions, although all the major decorative-arts dealers from New York and Paris were present. In the front row were the Antiquaires a Paris, five French dealers (including Mr. Rossi) with their own Paris galleries who hold joint exhibits and often buy pieces together. There were also several private collectors visibly bidding. And a great deal of business was done on the telephone.
The collection was from La Lanterne, the Bel Air mansion in Los Angeles belonging to Mr. Keck, the son of William M. Keck, the founder of the Superior Oil Company; most of it was acquired within the last 10 years. The sale was forced by a divorce.
"It's an outstanding collection," said Thierry Millerand, who heads the French furniture department at Sotheby's, "one that covers the scope of French furniture."
Highlighting the sale was a Louis XVI ebony and Japanese lacquer commode and secretary, both by Adam Weisweiler, a well-known 18th-century furniture maker. The pieces fetched $2,860,000 and the final bid was made by Mr. Rossi, who was buying the piece for the Antiquaires a Paris.
"Highly unusual pieces are what people were after tonight," said Mr. Millerand. A pair of blue-and-white marble Jardinieres, expected to sell for $250,000 to $350,000, sold for $825,000 to a private collector bidding on the phone. A rare Louis XVI stained horn, mother-of-pearl, stone and brass marquetry writing table, estimated to bring $400,000 to $500,000, was sold for $962,500 to a dark-haired man wearing dark glasses and identified only as a European private collector. A Louis XVI ormolu and hard stone-mounted ebony cabinet brought $572,000, well above its projected $350,000 to $450,000 estimate; it went to the Paris-based dealer Maurice Segoura, who said he was bidding for a client from Monte Carlo.
 
A Disappointment
 The evening's one major disappointment was a Louis XV desk attributed to Joseph Baumhauer that was estimated to sell for $1 million to $1.2 million. Bidding stopped at $675,000. "It was one of the most distinguished pieces in the sale," Mr. Millerand said. "Maybe the problem was that it was too distinguished. Tastes tonight ran toward the more exotic."
Indeed, rare works of French furniture, no matter how recently they have been on the market, are a strong commodity these days. Another sale of a major collection of French furniture assembled in recent years, the Roberto Polo collection, auctioned Nov. 7 in Paris, also brought top dollar. Estimated to bring $10 million, the final total of the Polo sale, held at the French auction house Ader Tajan, was $17,422,271.
Surprisingly, none of these prices seem the least affected by the recent 18.6 percent tax that the French Government recently imposed on the purchase and importation of French antiques. While the French dealers who were buying in New York are thought to be shipping their goods to Geneva, such arrangements are more difficult for private French collectors. "There was a noticeable absence of French collectors bidding tonight," said Mr. Millerand of Sotheby's. "But for a number of years now, because of the economy, the French have been sellers on the auction scene rather than buyers."

HEADLINE: OLYMPICS;
Quick Leap From Dominance to Disarray

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY

 BODY:
The president of the International Olympic Committee said yesterday that the decision of the Soviet Government to withdraw support from its central sports agency would lead to a sharp decline in performance by Soviet athletes in future Olympics.
"In Albertville and Barcelona, the Soviet Union will be No. 1," Juan Antonio Samaranch, the I.O.C. president, said from Lausanne, Switzerland, referring to the sites of the 1992 Winter Games and Summer Games, in France and Spain, respectively. "After Barcelona," he added, "the Soviet team will be weaker." 
 Samaranch met earlier in the day with Vitaly Smirnov, the president of the Soviet Olympic Committee, who told him that the Government had shut down the ministries for many aspects of Soviet society, including Gossport, the agency responsible for all aspects of sports, everything from the upkeep of facilities to the salaries of coaches to apartments for athletes.
 
Twenty Years of Success
 In short, this was the organization that for more than 20 years made the Soviet Union into the leading medal winner in the Olympics, the various world championships and other major international competitions. It had already been weakened by the fact that independence was granted earlier this year to the Baltic republics of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania.
Just how debilitating the elimination of the centralized system will be to Soviet sports in the 12 remaining republics is impossible to gauge quickly. The agency's strength was organization across the country, the ability to spot exceptional talents in 10-year-old children and nurture them through a network of 40 sports schools and 50 sports colleges.
Now, like so many other changing facets of life in Soviet society, the responsibility for maintaining the programs is being left to the individual republics.
While many sports officials interviewed yesterday agreed with Samaranch that the Soviet performance was more likely to suffer in the long run, a dissenting view was proposed by Tom Kelly, the president of the Goodwill Games, which were first held five years ago in Moscow and again last year in Seattle as a joint venture between the Turner Broadcasting System and Gossport.
 
New System Coming?
 Kelly, who speaks with his Soviet colleagues on a regular basis, said that senior Soviet officials had known for months that the ministry would be eliminated. As a result, he said, they expected that a new system would emerge quickly, led by officials from the Russian republic and possibly modeled after Britain's and designed to embrace Western-style marketing concepts.
In some events, like soccer's World Cup, British athletes represent England, Scotland and Wales. In the Olympics, they compete together.
"I think that soon, we're going to see an interrepublic confederation of sports in the Soviet Union," Kelly said from Atlanta. "They're not going to let the sports system simply dissolve. It means too much to the country."
And if that's true, he said, the new model could eventually produce stronger and more solvent Soviet Olympic teams than those in place for 1992. Just last week, Soviet Olympic officials said they had sufficient funds to send a team to Albertville but not yet enough to send one to Barcelona. The 1996 Summer Olympics will be held in Atlanta.
Samaranch acknowledged the Soviet Union's financial pinch but could offer no additional assistance from the I.O.C. beyond the amounts of money that flow normally to all countries through the sale of Olympic television rights, marketing agreements and other commercial deals.
"We cannot fund the Soviet Union; it would be too expensive," he said. "We have no money, but we can help in other ways, like with marketing seminars that teach them how to get money."
But just how much does success in the Olympics mean now to the average Soviet citizen? With the current economic crisis, it's a safe bet that it's not as much as before.
"I don't think the Soviet people are looking at medals as recognition of their country," said Mike Jacki, the executive director of the United States Gymnastics Federation. "Recognition of their country is a stable economy and food."
 
The Talent Drain
 Jacki said the migration of expert coaches and teachers might have a more profound impact on the Soviet sports system than reduced funding. As the economy has soured in recent years and immigration laws have been relaxed, many of the Soviet Union's leading coaches have left, some for the United States.
Aleksandr Gomelsky, who coached the national basketball team for many years, now lives in Chicago. Vladimir Artemov, the all-around champion in gymnastics in the 1988 Olympics, is coaching in San Antonio. One of his teammates, Vladimir Gogoladze, is coaching in Houston.
Athletes, too, have left, although they retain the right to represent the Soviet Union or a republic. Last summer, Sergei Bubka, a Russian who is the world's best pole vaulter, moved to Berlin to train with a club, but he intends to represent the Soviet Union in Barcelona.
"I think the real hazard is in their development programs," said Ray Essick, the executive director of the United States federation for swimming. "Mom and Dad aren't used to paying X number of rubles for coaching or pool access. Those kinds of costs can be considerable. I think their current swimmers will be O.K. But what about the 14-year-old kid preparing for 1996?"

HEADLINE: Patents;
New Process Cuts Cost of Real Vanilla

BYLINE: By Edmund L. Andrews

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Vanilla, with its smooth facility for blending with other tastes and fragrances, eclipses even chocolate as the most heavily consumed flavor. Despite that, most people rarely taste the real thing.
The reason is its expense. Natural vanilla, extracted from the bean, costs about $1,200 a pound. The beans themselves are $35 a pound, but only 3 percent is usable for the extract. By contrast, flavoring made from synthetic vanillan costs only $7 a pound. 
 Using a relatively new technology called cell culturing, however, a small California company has patented what it says is a much cheaper way to produce natural vanilla. The result, it said, is a richer, more complex flavor than the artificial product most people have come to know.
"You have a much fuller-bodied, rounded flavor, rather than the sharp chemical aroma," said Raymond J. Moshy, president of the Escagenetics Corporation in San Carlos, Calif.
The difference, Mr. Moshy said, is that the natural extract contains more than 200 trace compounds that add subtle overtones that enhance the basic flavor of vanilla. By contrast, he said, synthetic flavorings consist entirely of the chemical vanillan and have none of the subtle shadings of the real extract.
Cell culture techniques represent a relatively new way to produce plant products without growing the whole plant. In this case, tissue samples from the vanilla plant are transplanted into a laboratory dish, where they are induced to multiply into a large colony of cells. By manipulating the nutrients, the company said, the cells can be made to secrete the vanilla components for "harvesting."
The process can cut the cost of flavoring to less than $200 a pound, which may make it economical for use in premium ice creams, baked goods and other foods. Quest International, a division of the Unilever Group, is preparing a pilot plant and plans to run market tests on food products containing the flavor.
Om Sahai and Mark E. Kanuth, researchers affiliated with Escagenetics, received patents 5,057,424 and 5,068,184.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: OLYMPICS;
Soviet Union Shuts Down Its Sports Ministry, Ending Financial Support for Olympic Effort

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Dec. 6

 BODY:
The Soviet Union's state sports agency announced today that it was being closed down because of the Government's crushing financial problems, raising doubt about the nation's ability to field a competitive Soviet Olympic team in 1992.
The organization, Gossport, was shut down as part of the Soviet Government's efforts to shrink a bloated bureaucracy. 
 Leonid Drachevsky, first deputy chairman of Gossport, told the Soviet news agency Tass that Gossport could no longer meet its payroll to keep the state system of 25,000 athletes and 12,000 coaches working toward the Winter Games in Albertville, France, which start in February, and the Summer Games in Barcelona, Spain.
"If our athletes are not able to take part in the Olympic Games, it will damage the prestige of our country," he added.
Even though Gossport said it had to shelve plans to field competitive teams in the 1992 Olympics, sports officials in Russia, the Soviet Union's dominant republic, announced that they were making an attempt to maintain the national Olympic effort by enlisting support from the other 11 Soviet republics that now exercise separate forms of sovereignty.
In making its announcement today, Gossport joined a chorus of once-powerful bureaucracies that are experiencing the end of Kremlin-controlled financing. They have been lobbying for fresh support with some cataclysmically worded cries for help, with thus far mixed results.
The sports agency was richly supported throughout the Cold War. Athletes enjoyed privileges and comforts normally experienced only by ranking Communist careerists, and for its investment the nation reaped prestige and often the lion's share of Olympic medals. Since 1972, the Soviet Union has won far more medals than any other nation, accumulating 674, as compared with the United States' 500.
But now the Government's financial crisis extends to all aspects of Soviet life, with the 12 republics intent on establishing their own sovereignty and controlling the amount of money they devote to national endeavors.
The three Baltic republics of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia, which reclaimed their independence after an attempted coup in the Soviet Union last summer failed to reassert a hard-line Communist dictatorship and brought down the centrally controlled and financed system, have indicated they will send their own teams to the Olympics.
There is a proposal that the 12 remaining republics commit themselves to a single Olympic team, according to Vladimir Vasin, the chairman of the Russian republic's own Olympic committee.
Vasin said today that Boris N. Yeltsin, the Russian President, and others had expressed preliminary interest in creating some sort of an interregional center for preparation for the Winter Olympics. Vasin had no specific commitments to report but said that further discussions would be held.
"It would be a tragedy for sports if the best athletes wound up making cigarette lighters rather than doing what they do best," Vasin told the Russian Information Agency news service.
The disbanding of Gossport may not be the last word on Soviet state support for the Olympic teams. Last weekend, after dire warnings similar to those of Gossport, the government of the Russian republic stepped in at the last minute and agreed to help the central Soviet Government avoid imminent bankruptcy and to meet some Kremlin payrolls.
There was no sign today that this might happen as well for the Olympic payroll. But here, as everywhere, sports are far more popular than run-of-the-mill bureaucracies, and republic leaders, now popularly elected, are likely to be more mindful of the public's interest in Olympic competition.

CORRECTION-DATE: December 9, 1991, Monday

 CORRECTION:
A sports article on Saturday about reaction to the shutdown of the Soviet Union's Olympic effort misidentified the president of the Goodwill Games. He is Jack Kelly, not Tom Kelly.
