HEADLINE: With No Frills, New Bush Chief Signals Changes

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Dec. 6

 BODY:
Samuel K. Skinner, who will take over as the new White House chief of staff this month, flew here today from Washington to give a luncheon speech. By commercial airline. In coach class.
The no-frills travel was only one of several signals Mr. Skinner sent on the first day after being named to the post that he planned to use a different style, political agenda and perhaps a different staff at the White House than John H. Sununu, whose manner, imperial tastes and economic and political judgments all led this week to his resignation. Until the White House restricted Mr. Sununu's travel this year, he often used Air Force planes for business and personal trips. 
 In an interview on the way to Chicago and in a speech to the Illinois Manufacturers Association, Mr. Skinner made clear that he intended to make the economy and domestic policy the focus of White House attention, and to help President Bush overcome Democratic criticism that he has neglected the home front to concentrate on foreign policy issues.
"The baton has been passed," Mr. Skinner said, from Mr. Bush's foreign-policy and military advisers to himself and other domestic advisers, who will work to make the health of the American economy match the new world order developing in the cold war's aftermath.
Mr. Skinner said he had a short list of priorities to address upon taking over from Mr. Sununu on Dec. 16. "The economy, the economy, the economy. And then behind that, the economy and domestic policy, because they've got to work together," he said.
Mr. Skinner, who professed in an interview to be "kind of awed" and nervous about becoming Mr. Bush's chief aide, said he expected to make few changes in Mr. Sununu's staff or operations -- for at least two weeks.
But in a clear sign that he intends to make the staff operation his own, Mr. Skinner said he had asked John Croisant, a friend who heads human relations at RJR Nabisco, to review Mr. Sununu's operation. Mr. Croisant, a customer of Mr. Skinner when he was a salesman for I.B.M. in the 1970's, worked closely with Mr. Skinner when he became Transportation Secretary. Virtually every important appointment at the department was overseen by the two men.
Mr. Bush "has given me a mandate to move as fast as I can," and he met with the President early this morning to discuss the economy, Mr. Skinner said. But first, he continued, "I want to make sure I know how the operation works now, in detail, and who the players are." Not until Mr. Sununu's staff members have been interviewed to get their views on the office will any reshuffling take place, he said.
He said Mr. Bush, who was insisting two weeks ago that any new economic stimulants could wait until his State of the Union Message in late January, was now "singularly focused" on economic policy and would take regular and frequent steps to speed a recovery.
Asked later to explain his and Mr. Bush's apparent conversion to believers in economic stimulus, Mr. Skinner said that politics had nothing to do with it. "What obviously happened is that the economy is changing somewhat," he said, adding that the Administration had seen an "almost overnight" drop in consumer confidence that it now believed warranted stronger action.
Some of Mr. Skinner's remarks appeared to reflect his reputation as a team player who, in this case, was on the hustings pitching the Administration's most recent version of its political message on the economy.
But Mr. Skinner is also an acute politician, schooled in Chicago-style electioneering, who could not have helped but know that he would be closely watched in his debut for signs of change at the White House. Although Mr. Skinner took pains at every stop in today's five-hour blitz of Chicago to lavish praise on Mr. Sununu, his words and actions nevertheless were billboards that sometimes seemed to shout "new and improved."
 
Return Flight to Capital
 Self-effacing and indefatigably upbeat, Mr. Skinner worked the friendly crowd in this, his hometown, with abandon. In his speech, a news conference, and a stop to christen a new Federal office, he pumped strangers' hands, cracked jokes and handed out praise like political buttons." His mission completed, he boarded another commercial jet and returned to Washington tonight.
Mr. Skinner said in an interview that the Administration was now fully aware that "people vote their pocketbooks, they vote the economy, and in the economy, obviously, we have a lot of challenges." One of his primary duties, he said, will be to insure that Mr. Bush keeps more in touch with the economy's effects on average Americans, largely by taking him out of the White House on whistle-stop tours.
One of Mr. Skinner's first jobs will be to help Mr. Bush find replacements for himself as Secretary of Transportation and for Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher, whom Mr. Bush named Thursday as his 1992 general campaign chairman.
Administration officials said today that the President had not yet settled on any nominees for either post, but names of likely contenders were already circulating in the White House and the agencies involved.
Among the contenders for Commerce Secretary is Kenneth Lay, chief executive of Enron Corporation, a natural gas company based in Houston; John D. Macomber, a friend of Mr. Bush who has been head of the Export-Import Bank since 1989 and was chief executive of the Celanese Corporation; Bill Frenzel, a former Minnesota Congressman who is an expert on trade issues; Maurice Greenberg, head of the American International Group Inc. of New York, an insurance concern, and Barbara Franklin, a Washington businesswoman and former White House aide.
Possible contenders for Transportation Secretary include Wendy Gramm, chairwoman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, who is married to Senator Phil Gramm, the Texas Republican, and Deputy Transportation Secretary James B. Busey 4th. Roger Porter, Mr. Bush's domestic policy adviser, has been angling for a Cabinet post and has his sights on the transportation job, officials said.

HEADLINE: New Orleans Weighs Anti-Bias Law on Carnival

BYLINE: By FRANCES FRANK MARCUS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 6

 BODY:
A law has been proposed that would ban discrimination of any kind in clubs that sponsor Mardi Gras, but opponents of the proposal say such a measure could mean the death of this city's famous festival.
The proposal, which was introduced in the City Council last week, is the latest chapter in the politics of race here. Last month, State Representative David Duke, a former Ku Klux Klan leader and neo-Nazi, lost a race for Governor in which he ran a racially divisive campaign. 
 During Mardi Gras's seasonal brawl of parades and partying, the city is virtually a hostage to fun. But behind the fun is a tradition that is laced with prejudice in many forms.
The 27 private clubs, known as "krewes," that sponsor the glittering parades which are Carnival's centerpiece discriminate widely: against women, against men, some against Jews, blacks and Italians. Among the most prominent of the parade sponsors are elite white male non-Jewish clubs that make up the core of New Orleans high society.
 
Killing Mardi Gras?
 The law,introduced by a black City Council member, Dorothy Mae Taylor, would deny city services and parade permits to clubs that discriminate. The city pays $3.5 million for the extra police protection and garbage cleanup needed for the festival, but a University of New Orleans study found that the 1990 Carnival pumped $480 million into the local economy.
City Council Member Jackie Clarkson, who represents the French Quarter, where the celebration is wildest, complained that the proposal would "kill Mardi Gras."
And the Mayor's Mardi Gras representative, Maureen Detweiler, said the proposed law could "do away with parades" in the city. Some parades have already been moved to the suburbs, following whites who used to live in the city.
She said that the clubs "will not change overnight; they will change with time," and that some of the popular newer clubs are already racially mixed. In addition, New Orleans has one predominantly black, all-male krewe and at least one krewe with both men and women members.
Ed Muniz, the leader of Endymion, a 1,250-member krewe, questioned the need for the law and said the clubs were changing without the ordinance. Of his own krewe, he said, "We have never refused a black who was interested in joining."
Blaine Kern, a float builder who is part of an all-male krewe with some black members, said he favors racial integration, but as for women, "We don't want 'em, pure and simple." Mr. Kern says he sees the all-male krewes as "just a bunch of guys getting together and raising hell," while women would "pay serious attention to costumes, frills, froufrou and sequins."
Mr. Kern said, "Most krewes are opening up" without city laws "because it's normal and the natural thing to do and with the economy, krewes need members." The krewes charge dues and members must sometimes spend lavishly on costumes and other expenses.
 
Modeled on New York Law
 Mrs. Taylor's proposal is modeled on a New York City law banning discrimination in business-oriented private clubs that was upheld by the United States Supreme Court in 1988. The City Council on Thursday deferred action on the ordinance until Dec. 19, responding to a request from Carnival leaders and Mayor Sidney Barthelemy.
Councilman Lambert Boissiere Jr. said today, "I'm hoping we'll work out a compromise" between the krewes and Mrs. Taylor. Mr. Boissiere, who is black, said Mardi Gras is "a special day" and "you don't want to lose that. Millions of people come here every year to enjoy that free-spirited day. You don't want to tone that down."
But Dr. Dwight McKenna, who is black and the chairman of the New Orleans school board, says Mardi Gras has long had "a plantation mentality" and that "no tradition or economic loss is worth more than my dignity."
Nonetheless, nine of 10 letters in The Times-Picayune newspaper on Thursday criticized the proposal, emphasizing the possible economic harm to the city.
Arthur Hardy, who publishes the "New Orleans Mardi Gras Guide," said, "the talk in the street" is that 5 of the city's 27 Carnival krewes would not parade if the law is passed, "and that would mean 5 nights without parades." During Carnival there are 10 days and nights of parades leading to climax of the festival on Mardi Gras, March 3 next year.
"Mardi Gras sets the whole tone for our economy and our spirit," said Mr. Hardy, who is white. "We're all recipients of the money the people on the floats are spending, no matter what color they are."
Mr. Hardy said his family has been in New Orleans since the 1830's but has not been invited to join Carnival's most exclusive club. "That doesn't bother me. I'm excluded because my family didn't know their great-grandparents. I never even think about it."

HEADLINE: Pay-per-Minute Phone Advice Gets Personal and Professional

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE

 BODY:
The pay-per-call services -- 900 telephone numbers -- that dispense advice of all kinds are reaching out again, expanding to include insurance assistance and legal information.
Now you can dial a 900 number from anywhere in the country and talk to an insurance consultant or a lawyer. What's next? Financial services: there are plans to put financial planners, bond specialists and other experts at the end of new 900 lines. 
 Consumers are expected to spend $1.2 billion on calls to 900 numbers this year, according to Marketing Logistics, a consulting business in Lincolnshire, Ill. The growth of live professional consulting services on 900 lines comes as new restrictions are being placed on the pay-per-call industry by the Federal Communications Commission.
Starting this week, all such calls must begin with a preamble disclosing the price and the provider's identity, and offering callers a chance to hang up without charge. In addition, consumers must be offered the ability to block 900 calls from home telephones at no charge, and telephones cannot be disconnected for failure to pay for calls to a 900 number.
The essence of live 900 services, which grew out of services that offered recorded advice on a variety of subjects, is that callers can ask personal questions and receive informed answers from a specialist. Some are open only during business hours, while others are open evenings as well. And since the caller is paying a high price -- usually from $1 to $3 a minute -- an integral part of the arrangement is that the person on the other end will give advice, but should not try to sell the caller anything.
"The primary advantage is that it is an easy way to get information from a third party who doesn't have a vested interest in your being a client," said Bruce Kushnick, president of Strategic Telemedia, a New York market research company. "And it's good for people who have a desire to find out information late at night."
 
Sometimes, All That's Needed
 Gene Chamson, president of Intermedia Resources, a consulting company in San Francisco, said: "You can talk directly to an expert who you might not otherwise have any access to. Obviously, you can't have as complete a consultation as you could in somebody's office, but in many situations that's not necessary."
Still, just because a 900 service exists does not mean that its promoters are qualified to provide help or that the information is not available free elsehwere.
"I sometimes wonder who is accrediting them," said Linda F. Golodner, executive director of the National Consumers League. "Treat it like any other purchase you make."
Insurance Information Services in Simi Valley, Calif., recently began a 900 service for all kinds of insurance, including life, health, automobile and homeowner. By dialing (900) 776-7103 and paying $2.50 a minute, callers can get facts and figures about personal insurance problems.
"We'll explain how to lower insurance costs, what liability means, what benefits you have and many other things," said Bill Steiger, a veteran insurance agent who founded the service. "And the client will never be referred back to us for insurance."
A similar $3-a-minute service is Tele-Lawyer, begun two years ago by Michael A. Kane, a lawyer in Huntington Beach, Calif. Callers can get legal advice by dialing (900) 370-7000 and tax advice from (900) 835-3829. "An advantage is the convenience of being able to pick up the phone for information and not having to wait for an appointment," Mr. Kane said. "A lot of people are using us as a second-opinion source."
Similar professional consulting services are planned. Dale B. Krieger, president of the Carnegie Hill Company, an investment adviser in Princeton, N.J., plans to start an information service on municipal bonds, Munichek, early next year. It will be operated in cooperation with Kenny S. & P. Information Services.
And Laura Adams, a certified financial planner on Hilton Head Island, S.C., said she plans to start a 900 service for financial advice early next year. The service, which will cost $3 a minute, will "offer people, who are very often intimidated by the process of seeking out an adviser, low-cost, effective advice and information," Ms. Adams said.
The reaction of professional groups to these telephone services is mixed. For example, William E. Hornsby Jr., staff counsel of the American Bar Association's special committee on delivery of legal services, said: "It's nothing you are going to want to use as a substitute for a lawyer when you need a lawyer. You have to be very careful."
But Sean F. Mooney, senior vice president and economist of the Insurance Information Institute, said, "If the person on the phone has the expertise, it would be very useful." And Madeline I. Noveck, president of the Institute of Certified Financial Planners, said, "You can certainly give helpful information if you ask the key questions and get the circumstances of the particular person."
 
 
ABOVE ALL, KEEP IT SHORT
 There is a charge for all calls to 900 numbers. The amount varies, depending on the service. To avoid problems, here are some tips from the National Association for Information Services, a trade group for companies in the 900 business.
*Don't stay on a 900 call unless you are willing to pay the price disclosed at the start of the call.
*Don't call a 900 number if you are unsure what information it supplies.
*Call the billing inquiry number on your phone bill if you think the 900 service did not deliver what was promised.
*Insist that children ask permission before making any 900 calls.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Mobil Reduces Spending Budget

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: FAIRFAX, Va., Dec. 6

 BODY:
The Mobil Corporation, the nation's second-largest oil company, behind the Exxon Corporation, said it had cut back this year's spending budget by $500 million, or 10 percent, from what it had originally planned because of the recession. The company, based in Fairfax, Va., also said it had deferred some investments until business conditions improved.
 "These are difficult times for the oil industry as the pace of economic recovery is slower than expected," said the company's chairman, Allen Murray. He said that the recession in the United States and in key markets abroad was having a significant impact on demand for Mobil's petroleum and chemical products. A Mobil official declined to disclose the actual level of the 1991 capital budget, saying the data are strictly for internal use.

HEADLINE: Grandpa Was a Cowboy

BYLINE: By Susan Allen Toth; Susan Allen Toth's memoir about England will be published in 1992. Her other books include "Blooming: A Small-Town Girlhood" and "A House of One's Own," written with her husband, James Stageberg.

 BODY:

ALL BUT THE WALTZ
Essays on a Montana Family.
By Mary Clearman Blew.
Illustrated. 223 pp. New York: Viking. $19.95. 
 A cold, sharp prairie wind blows through "All but the Waltz: Essays on a Montana Family," Mary Clearman Blew's haunting memoir of life on the high Montana plains. It is a wind that quickly disperses any wisps of lingering romanticism in either author or reader about the glamour of ranching in the old West. As Ms. Blew pieces together her family's hundred-year history in central Montana, she writes with sadness, fierce pride and an unforgettable clarity of their struggle to survive drought, disaster and economic depression. These are people who struggled on slipping ground: "One foot after another, falling back with every step they took, scratching not to get ahead or even to stay abreast but only to keep from sinking for as long as they could."
Beginning with Abraham Hogeland, her great-grandfather, who came from Pennsylvania in 1882 to establish a ranch "on the very ground where I played among the willows along Spring Creek and tried to imagine my way past the river bluffs," Ms. Blew explores her connections to the earlier settlers of this lonely prairie. In loosely related essays, she describes, among others, her grandfather Albert, a renowned cowboy who died at the age of 33; Albert's widow, Edna, who took over the grinding work of the ranch; grandmother Mary, who taught into her mid-70's in isolated country schools; Jack, Ms. Blew's father, who drove away from his ranch one day in 1983, deliberately lay down on a distant hillside and died of exposure.
As Ms. Blew, born in 1939, cuts back and forth in time, she includes snippets of her own personal history. We learn how her father tried to bring her up as the son he never had. "We'll be Jack Hogeland and Daughters," he promised his family. But Ms. Blew fled the rigors of ranch life, first to the university, teen-age marriage and motherhood, and finally to a Ph.D. and teaching career. She is now an associate professor of English at Lewis-Clark State College in Lewiston, Idaho, with two books of short stories and a byline as co-editor of an anthology of writings about Montana, "The Last Best Place," to her credit.
"All but the Waltz" is not a memoir that tries to win the reader with humorous or ingratiating anecdotes. What we hear of Ms. Blew's own story is brief and stark. In her almost unbearably moving last essay, Ms. Blew sketches the downward lurch of her second marriage. Her husband, Bob, a lighthearted man who wooed her with his generosity, audacity and "his grasshopper's delight in the sunlit present," leaves the oil fields where he made his money. He buys farmland north of Havre "and gambled all over again on the weather." In Montana, the reader now knows, this is a losing bet.
When Bob contracts a fatal lung disease, he slowly disappears into a dream world that dissolves around him. The farm succumbs to drought and neglect. Ms. Blew finally takes their small daughter and leaves. She imagines the voices of those who see his last days in the Havre Hotel: "He's a walking skeleton. He has nothing to do, nothing to look forward to -- How could she have done it to him?" Her readers, who understand that she learned survival from her ancestors, see how she could have done little else.
The price of survival on the Montana prairie has always been high. Once when Ms. Blew's grandmother Mary had not seen another woman for 18 months, she began to hallucinate and see the beckoning shapes of women when she went to draw water at the spring. Mary, a schoolteacher, was one of "those armies of women of all ages in their dark rayon print dresses, heavy from their starchy diets, graying as the years passed, weather-beaten and cranky, moving from school to school, year by year, in their tenureless quest for a bare living, for an independence of sorts." In their remote one-room "teacherages," these women lived in constant fear of rape. Imogene, Mary's daughter, was given a rifle by a beau to defend her teacherage. When a gang of young men approached one night, they saw her pile of tin cans, used for target practice, and reluctantly withdrew.
Behind Ms. Blew's tales of hardscrabble living, the Montana prairie always looms, a "fearful vacancy" that nonetheless attracts and fascinates her. "I am bone-deep in landscape," she admits, and in prose with a shining edge she etches short, stunning vignettes of this bleak yet beautiful country. Its spaces are often heavy with silence: "The air grows colder as he [a neighbor] rides out of the gully and emerges from the bare black branches of hawthorns and chokecherries into the undeflected wind on the slope that leads higher into the bluish-dark stain of pines. No movement in the empty, heavily grazed grass. Not a magpie flaps across that gray snow-laden sky, not a calf bawls, though the signs of cattle are plentiful on the trail and scattered through the bunchgrass."
The compressed vigor of Ms. Blew's prose enlivens her narrative, and so does her spare but telling detail. In lives bare of luxury, she evokes the power of essentials: "A ladder nailed against the wall led through a trapdoor to the suffocating heat of the attic, where my aunt Imogene used to sleep in the summertime. She could look out the tiny window and see bunchgrass blowing in the yard and tumbleweeds ragging at the barbed-wire fence and the two tracks of the road." Here, as elsewhere, Ms. Blew opens an unexpected window onto a scene that might otherwise fade into overwhelming space and silence.
It is this intense observation, an insistent vitality, that lifts Ms. Blew's stories out of mourning into a kind of affirmation. She seizes the unchronicled lives of those who have gone before her and rescues them from oblivion. The spirit of these essays is perhaps best caught in a poignant memory of the author's father. The winter winds blew long and hard at the grassland cattle ranch, but in time, they ceased: "The first sign of spring would be the night he rode in with the pale wet lavender of the first wild crocus, the pasqueflower, in his hatband."

SECTION: Section 7; Page 32; Column 3; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1134 words

HEADLINE: CRIME

BYLINE: By Marilyn Stasio

 BODY:
Wise men know that "murder and embezzlement, like the promise of youth, are ephemeral." Wily businessmen like John Putnam Thatcher, the executive vice president of Sloan Guaranty Trust, also understand that "the gross national product of Japan is not." So don't expect any big fuss to be made in EAST IS EAST (Simon & Schuster, $19), Emma Lathen's 21st mystery to feature the distinguished Wall Street banker as sleuth, when a minor functionary with Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Investment is murdered during tense negotiations between an American steel company and the giant Japanese trading corporation that wants to acquire its English robotics affiliate. The crucial thing is that the deal should go through, come hell, high water or murder.
Ms. Lathen, a pseudonym for the writing team of Mary Jane Latsis and Martha Henissart, has a wonderful knack for turning the driest, most complicated corporate maneuvers into high drama, and occasionally burlesque. Shuttling her high rollers from Japan to Alaska to England, she drolly observes them trying to conduct delicate business while such land-mine scandals as industrial sabotage and wholesale government corruption burst all around them. 
 Although they play fast and hang tough, the more broadly satirized Americans look like klutzes compared with the crafty elder statesmen of the Japanese business world, whose glacial formality bespeaks to the ever-alert Thatcher the understanding that "with experience comes the ability to display, not real feelings, but those that are useful." What is most useful here is a rich sense of humor.
Pity young Simon Bradshaw, traumatized into manhood, in B. M. Gill's cunningly twisted suspense mystery THE FIFTH RAPUNZEL (Scribners, $19.95), following the death of his parents in a car crash. The 18-year-old naif is shocked to learn that his artist mother, whose nursery-story illustrations always gave him bad dreams, was more than a little mad, and that his pathologist father kept mistresses, including the woman Simon falls in love with. No wonder the lad is spooked by threats from a man his father's testimony helped put away for murdering five prostitutes.
High-strung minds that snap under stress are the special province of Ms. Gill, whose ambitious scheme here is to ensnare an entire English village in her sticky web of abnormal psychology. "City crime was anonymous," muses one of the few locals who manage not to lose their marbles in this Grand Guignol plot. "Village crime was like that poisonous plant that opened wide its petals and engulfed everyone."
This morbid perspective encourages some farfetched acts of depraved lunacy from the wretched villagers. In temperate doses, however, the Welsh author's dark craft yields subtler horrors, from a disturbed artist's view of the world ("an extraordinary place in which the centuries merged and the past became a grotesque, fairy-tale present") to the even more troubling vision of a healthy mind like Simon's, trapped in its nursery of nightmares.
Don't know what's got into Shifty Lou Anderson. For a professional magician who can do a classic version of three-card monte, he keeps losing sight of where his best tricks are at. In William Murray's comic mystery I'M GETTING KILLED RIGHT HERE (Perfect Crime/Doubleday, $18.50), this inveterate horseplayer also sits out most of the races at Del Mar, and he spends more time pitching woo than cutting cards -- or solving murders.
The structural problem is easy to spot. Shifty's newly acquired Thoroughbred, a spirited filly by the name of Mad Margaret, has sore shins, which puts her owner at loose ends. But instead of filling in the waiting time with some fast track action or a mystery worth its salt, he gets involved in a dull love affair with a drippy married woman who constantly whines about her mug of a husband.
Shifty's garrulous pals come through with their usual pearls of turf wisdom, and Mad Maggie eventually gets her run for glory. But since this one never really breaks out of the gate, it's good we can cling to that bit of racing philosophy that says: "At the race track, it's always tomorrow."
Any author who takes an entire chapter to explicate the phrase "shuck and jive" overestimates the charm of her narrative voice. Sarah Shankman allows herself so many self-indulgences of this nature in SHE WALKS IN BEAUTY (Pocket Books, $20) that the reader has a stiff job finding the story line of the whodunit she has set at the Miss America Pageant in Atlantic City. Something about a lubricious contest judge who is missing, only nobody cares, and about Miss New Jersey's stolen gown, which elicits more concern from this crowd.
This is not to say that Ms. Shankman's glib prose isn't amusing to read -- she's a bundle of fun on such fascinating pageant lore as bugle beads and rhinoplasty -- just exhausting. More detrimental to the author's light style, her amateur sleuth is hard to take, seriously or otherwise. A reporter for The Atlanta Constitution, Samantha (Sam) Adams has smarts to spare, but as Ms. Shankman once wrote about another manic character, she also has a "mouth going one hundred twenty-two miles per hour" and the notion that every time she opens it she has to say something adorable. You can almost sympathize with the serial murderer who belts her in the mouth -- especially when the spunky Sam snaps back with a wisecrack about orthodontia.
"Wasn't something new, something different and unexpected supposed to happen at Carnevale?" Edward Sklepowich teases the reader in his second Venetian mystery, FAREWELL TO THE FLESH (Morrow, $19), whose title is a literal translation of the pre-Lenten street festival observed with spectacular abandon in the serene city. "Wasn't it when anything could happen?" Including murder, as it turns out.
Under cover of Carnevale, someone has crept down a dark and narrow alley to murder an English photographer. Dragooned into conducting a discreet investigation, an agreeable American dilettante by the name of Urbino Macintyre soon discovers that the victim had connections, mostly unsavory, with members of Macintyre's international set. With a superb sense of timing, the urbane Urbino unmasks the villain on the stroke of midnight, at a gala ballo in maschera given by his friend and patron, the Contessa da Capo-Zendrini, at her splendid palace on the Grand Canal.
Mr. Sklepowich's animated scenes offer an enchanting spectacle of Venetian street life. But for all this descriptive glitter, the author is too much the sophisticate to neglect the intriguing, even sinister history of the festival. Writing with somber grace, he also takes care to end his tale in the spirit of "silence, ashes, and repentance" that descends on the revels come Shrove Tuesday.

PUB-DATE: December 8, 1991

SECTION: Section 6; Page 46; Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 4495 words

HEADLINE: A Fight To the Death

BYLINE: By Trip Gabriel; Trip Gabriel is a frequent contributor to this magazine.

 BODY:
THE BAREFOOT WOMAN IN faded jeans and a pink turtleneck is curled in a chair in her Oregon farmhouse. Ann Humphry, 49 years old, is an attractive blonde whose hair is knotted above her head Katharine Hepburn-style. She doesn't look like a woman who, for two years, has waged a fight against breast cancer.
"You know, I'm tough," she says. "I can look after myself." The words and the image of Humphry have been preserved on a grainy, amateurish videotape, which was made on Oct. 1. The next day Humphry trailered a horse into the Oregon wilderness 100 miles from the farm, watched the sun set over the blue-gray peaks of the Cascade Range and swallowed an overdose of barbiturates. 
 Ann Wickett Humphry was a co-founder of the Hemlock Society, a group whose how-to books about suicide for the terminally ill and 11-year campaign for the liberalization of euthanasia laws have helped put this emotional issue on the national agenda. Last month, when voters in Washington State became the first in the world to decide whether dying patients should be allowed to commit suicide with the help of doctors, it was Hemlock Society signature-gatherers who helped get the initiative on the ballot and Hemlock members around the country who flooded the campaign with $313,000 in contributions. Although the measure narrowly failed, its strong support was seen as a critical first step to possible victories in other states.
But what Ann Humphry is saying in her pre suicide videotape is that she had developed strong doubts about the right-to-die movement and about one of its leading crusaders, her former husband, Derek Humphry, the well-known author of the best-selling suicide manual, "Final Exit." Since the couple formed the Hemlock Society 11 years ago, Ann's own experiences -- as a cancer patient and also as someone who assisted in the double suicide of her aged parents -- had given her second thoughts about euthanasia.
"I've thought, 'What's the answer?' " Humphry says on the tape, which was recorded at Windfall Farm, her 42-acre property in Monroe, Ore., in the rain-drenched western part of the state. "I've got my own supply of barbiturates because I was lucky enough to get them when I was in the middle of Hemlock. Should it be as easy as that? I think the legislation is simply too dangerous."
Humphry had come to believe that if doctor-assisted suicide were legalized, then euthanasia might become more and more involuntary. Poor people or those without medical insurance, for example, might be influenced to accept a fatal drug dosage. Or regardless of their economic means, the feeble and the sick might feel subtle pressures to relieve their families and friends of the emotional burdens of lingering death. On the videotape recorded the day before she died, Ann accuses her ex-husband of applying unwelcome pressures during her cancer. She describes a conversation with Derek in which she told him she'd prefer suicide if her cancer was terminal.
"I remember saying, 'If anything were to happen, if the cancer were to metastasize, I'm getting out of here,' " Ann says. "And I remember how relieved he was. I said, 'No hospital beds for me in the middle of the living room, no puking my guts out . . .' And I remember feeling really chilled to the bone because now it was my life and my dying and it was kind of like 'Good, get out of the way as quickly as possible.' There was none of this 'Jesus, hang in there, I want you to be here for me!' . . . I knew I was being pushed out of the picture."
The reasons for Ann Humphry's suicide are not simple. She was not terminally ill -- her cancer was in remission -- and she was not, by most accounts, clinically depressed.
In addition, there have been questions about the purity of her motives in attacking the Hemlock Society. She had stopped working for the 46,000-member organization, headquartered in Eugene, Ore., following an angry and much-publicized divorce from Derek, who contends that all of his ex-wife's criticisms are outgrowths not of their philosophical differences but of their marital clashes.
Nevertheless, Ann Humphry's negative views of life in the Hemlock Society illuminate a darker side of the right-to-die movement than is generally known, even among its followers. In the videotape, Ann accuses Derek of having become "an agent of death and dying." At one point, she describes how he had learned that a strong barbiturate could be ordered without prescription from a Swiss pharmacy, bought 500 tablets of the drug and distributed them to some Hemlock members. "I began to feel really uncomfortable with this," Ann says, "and I began to feel I'm getting much deeper into something I'm not clear about at all."
ANN HUMPHRY'S STORY really begins with Derek Humphry and his first wife, Jean, in England. In 1971, Jean was found to have breast cancer. Anticipating a painful death, she asked Derek, a reporter for The Sunday Times of London, to be prepared to help her end her life. When the time came, he brewed a mug of coffee laced with Seconal and codeine, which she drank. Jean died in 1975 at home in the Cotswolds with Derek beside her.
A year later, Derek Humphry married Ann Wickett, a 33-year-old American student of Shakespeare he met through a personals ad she'd placed in a newspaper. Moved by the tender story of his first wife's death, Ann persuaded Derek to write about it in "Jean's Way," which, when published in Britain in 1978, stirred much controversy and strong sales. Since aiding a suicide is a crime in Britain, as it is in the United States, Humphry was investigated by the police, but no charges were ever brought. In the meantime, the Humphrys moved to Los Angeles, where Derek had found a job as a feature writer with The Los Angeles Times.
Soon, interest in "Jean's Way," which was published in America in 1979, and the topic of euthanasia overwhelmed Derek's reporting career. He was invited to address medical schools and other groups throughout the United States, Canada and Australia. The size and enthusiasm of the crowds astonished him. "My journalistic antenae told me this was going to be a big subject," Derek Humphry recalled a few weeks ago, sitting on a couch in his office in Eugene. He gave up journalism in 1980, and, together with his wife, formed the Hemlock Society.
After the appearance of "Jean's Way," Humphry had received scores of letters pleading with him to disclose what drugs he'd used to ease his wife's dying and how he'd acquired them. A sympathetic doctor had given him the pills, but at the time Humphry had decided not to ask what they were. "Secretly," he wrote in a subsequent book, "I was glad that I did not know, for how could I have, with good conscience, sent the fatal formula to people whose true medical and psychological condition I had no knowledge of?"
On this point, Humphry was to change his mind -- provoking a public outcry. In 1982, he authored "Let Me Die Before I Wake," a book of anecdotal accounts of assisted suicides but with drug information embedded in the text. Then, in May of this year, through the Hemlock Society, he published "Final Exit," which describes in stark detail, without the nuance of narrative, how to take one's life. The book includes a table of prescription drugs and their fatal dosages. In a chapter entitled "How Do You Get the Magic Pills?" it tells how to fool doctors into prescribing lethal quantities of drugs. On page 112, Humphry suggests Dramamine to prevent vomiting the suicide drugs, and on page 95, he recommends pulling a plastic bag over the head as a backup to the sleeping pills.
Humphry, a man of restrained but not humorless mien, says the information was gleaned from 12 years of research and conversations with pharmacists, physicians and "many hundreds" of informants who've assisted loved ones to die. "Nobody else could have written 'Final Exit,' " he says proudly.
The book, which has already sold 520,000 copies in North America, is one of the most unlikely success stories in publishing history. The 61-year-old Humphry, whose nearly bald dome and wide sideburns have become familiar to talk-show viewers, expects to earn about $1 million in royalties from the book and says the society will reap $2 million more. Numerous Hollywood producers have even sought the film rights -- apparently without bothering to read the book, which has no characters, scenes or dialogue.
Yet some experts on medical ethics and even laymen who favor liberalizing the euthanasia laws were shocked by the content of "Final Exit." The book has been boycotted by some booksellers and the target of protests -- all of which only fed its sales. "I defended the book massively," says Humphry, who clearly relishes the public debate as well as the personal attention. "I think I did a good job. I was spending 18 hours a day on radio and television."
In addition to book sales, the Hemlock Society is kept afloat by some $500,000 a year in membership fees. Today, in a converted white clapboard house, recently expanded, Humphry, whose annual salary as executive director is $66,000, heads a full-time staff of 11. His latest plans are to open Hemlock Society field offices around the country and to become more active in political races.
Perhaps the most common criticism of Derek Humphry is that troubled individuals will be tempted to use "Final Exit" in a moment of passing depression. Its shop-manual approach, critics say, just makes suicide too effortless. And indeed, copies of the book have been found near the bodies of several victims who suffered from depression and who apparently carried out Humphry's instructions. "I'm concerned about giving an easy approach to people who otherwise would not commit suicide," says Alan L. Berman, director of the National Center for the Study and Prevention of Suicide in Washington. "Why is there a need for this book?"
Humphry's response is that if the nonterminally ill kill themselves with his book, that's an abuse. He contends that anything -- guns, rope, a gas oven -- can be abused. "This cry went up when we published 'Let Me Die Before I Wake,' " Humphry recalls. "But the suicide rate did not alter. It'll be intersting to see if the rate in America alters now. I doubt it."
But what about the ethics of providing recipes for self-annihilation to people without knowing how sick or mentally unstable they are? Humphry himself had once opposed this, finding it repugnant to send drug information indiscriminately through the mail to inquiring readers of "Jean's Way." Asked what had led to his conversion, he replies, "I changed my mind."
One casualty who unquestionably used the pharmaceutical advice disseminated by the Hemlock Society and who was not terminally ill was Ann Humphry. The powerful prescription pills she ingested came from a cache she had hoarded in anticipation of the day she might need to seek "self-deliverance" (as is advised on page 70 of "Final Exit"). Although Ann had recently quit drinking, a bottle of Chivas Regal was found beside her body, suggesting she'd heeded the information on page 112 that certain drugs, when combined with alchohol, are 50 percent more toxic.
On Oct. 14, Derek Humphry took out a half-page advertisement in The New York Times, which, to the casual reader, might have seemed like a heartfelt eulogy to his former wife. "Sadly, for much of her life Ann was dogged by emotional problems, and . . . her life was a series of peaks and troughs," the ad said. "Suicide for reasons of depression has never been part of the credo of the Hemlock Society."
Asked recently why he had placed the ad, Humphry said flatly: "Damage control."
WHAT DAMAGE WAS Derek Humphry trying to control? The chain of events that led to the acrimonious split -- both personal and ideological -- between the co-founders of the Hemlock Society and that finally drove Ann Humphry to kill herself were set in motion two years ago. In September 1989, for the second time in Derek's life, a wife of his was found to have breast cancer. Three weeks after surgery to remove the cancerous lump, and just four days after Ann had started chemotherapy and radiation treatment, Derek phoned from a business trip to say he was walking out of the marriage. He conveyed his intentions in a message left on their telephone answering machine.
Ann was shattered. According to friends, she concluded that Derek was fleeing the prospect of having to watch a second wife wither away from cancer. But facing months of treatment and a winter alone at Windfall Farm, she could not forgive Derek for withdrawing emotional support just when she needed it most. Ann suffered a nervous breakdown and checked herself into a psychiatric ward for eight days.
Derek Humphry tells a far different story. He says his home life had long been a shambles. The cancer, he maintains, was a crisis that hastened the inevitable. "It was terribly bad luck," he says in his clipped British accent. "I felt bad, but I did not run away."
According to Derek, Ann, at first refused to talk to him about her cancer. But then she began making self-pitying comparisons with his first wife. "She kept saying, 'You don't love me like you loved Jean,' " Derek says. " 'You're not crying for me like you cried for Jean.' I would say, 'Ann, I don't think you're dying.' "
After Ann's lumpectomy, Derek recalls, the oncologists pronounced her cancer-free -- a fact Ann never disputed. But she continued to fear that the disease would return and that it would one day kill her. "I snapped and walked out," says Derek. "I knew it was the worst possible moment to walk out. I just could not take it anymore."
Because of the sharp contrast with his handling of his first wife's illness, the couple's breakup became more than a private dispute. Accusing Derek of violating the principles of compassion that are part of the Hemlock Society's credo, Ann wrote in December 1989 to her fellows on the seven-member board of directors to urge that he be sacked as executive director. Meanwhile, Derek barred her from Hemlock's offices and changed the locks on the doors.
Early last year, both parties went public with their differences. Ann talked volubly to newspapers and on the Sally Jesse Raphael and Larry King shows. Derek issued a four-page statement entitled "Why My Marriage to Ann Wickett Failed," which managed both to elicit sympathy and to showcase an almost clinical detachment. He wrote of "the unacceptable way" Ann had handled her cancer. Today, he says that he never wanted to make their problems an open book, but that once Ann had lashed out, he felt constrained to "counterattack."
Most of Hemlock's officials sided with Derek, accepting his explanation that his wife's depression had caused their marriage to unravel and his denial that he had compromised any of the society's articles of faith. Yet one dissenting voice, Henry Brod, the president of the Oregon chapter, issued a news release accusing Derek and the other board members of acting "despicably."
"I thought Hemlock was all about compassion and decency towards people desperately ill," Brod said. "But Hemlock is, after all, Derek Humphry -- and that is not good enough any more."
HER OWN experience with cancer produced in Ann Humphry a growing skepticism toward the gospel of assisted suicide, which she had preached enthusiastically for years in books and speeches.
One sign of her disaffection was a friendship she entered into with Rita L. Marker, the head of the International Anti-Euthanasia Task Force and a former debating adversary of Derek Humphry. "Ann called me in December 1989, not too many weeks after she'd lost her husband, her health and her job," Marker remembers. Four or five months into their friendship, according to Marker, Humphry expressed misgivings about her old ideology. "She said until she developed her cancer, she had not known what subtle and not so subtle pressures could be put on people to get out of the way."
Ann also came to be troubled by the 1986 double suicide of her parents, 92-year-old Arthur Kooman, a Boston banker, and his 78-year-old wife, Ruth. The couple had been among Hemlock's charter members. Then one day they called and asked their daughter for help in dying. While neither was terminally ill, they were "affronted and humiliated by the growing indignities of their deterioration," Ann wrote in "Double Exit." The book was her thinly veiled account, complete with pseudonyms, of how she and Derek had flown in from California with a lethal supply of Vesparax, the barbiturate Derek had obtained from the Swiss pharmacy.
In separate bedrooms, Derek helped Arthur Kooman ingest the drugs in a mixture of applesauce and 7-Up, while Ann assisted her mother. When it was all over, the book suggests, Ann's conscience was clear. "They actually did it," she writes. "And they did it right."
But in ensuing years, Ann seemed increasingly burdened by ambivalence. "She felt guilty and remorseful," her closest friend, Julie Horvath, says. "At the same time she'd rationalize, saying, 'I'm proud of what I did.' But then she'd start to cry, saying, 'All I wanted to do was help my parents.' She went back and forth. It ate away at her."
In the videotape from Windfall Farm, Ann identifies some of the memories that haunted her. Her mother's suicide, she had come to believe, was not entirely an act of free will, but subtly coerced. "I knew my mother was not ready to die," Ann says. "I knew she felt pressure and that she couldn't survive without my father. I never forget that."
She also confesses on the tape that her mother's death was not as antiseptic as portrayed in "Double Exit." After swallowing the barbiturates, Ruth Kooman had begun choking. "I got really scared," Ann says, her voice catching. "Derek had always said to me, 'Just use a plastic bag or a pillow.' And so there was a plastic laundry bag with her linen in it, and I took the bag and I very gently held it over her mouth." There is a long pause. "She died very peacefully. But I walked away from that house thinking we're both murderers."
By contrast, according to Ann, Derek took his in-laws' double suicide in stride. "He could walk away from it and within 24 hours he was back again mowing the lawn," she says. Perhaps, she surmises, that is when the couple's marriage began to crack.
Ann's friends say she made the confession about her mother's death to blunt charges that her criticism of the Hemlock Society was inspired by a personal vendetta against her ex-husband. And on the tape she goes on to voice an even more startling claim: that Derek had used a pillow to smother his first wife, Jean, after she'd started to regurgitate her suicide drugs in her sleep.
If true, it would mean Derek Humphry had not simply assisted a suicide, but had, under the law, committed murder. Derek, who adamantly denies smothering Jean, says he is shocked by Ann's accusation. Where is the evidence, he asks? Why is the charge being leveled now, he argues, when for 13 years Ann let her name appear on the cover of "Jean's Way" as its co-author? "Even in the weeks before her death," he says, "she was taking money for 'Jean's Way,' which, if it was untrue, would have been terribly dishonest."
IT IS DEREK HUMPHRY'S contention that his ex-wife's suicide and her antagonistic behavior toward him over the last two years -- including the charge he suffocated Jean -- were the result of mental illness. He claims Ann attempted suicide once before in the early 1970's, after the breakup of her first marriage. Ann suffered "huge depressions," Derek says, in which she could be reduced to a "catatonic" state. "Sometimes she was the most beautiful person to live with," he says. "Other times she was hell on earth."
Humphry alleges that Ann was a heavy Valium user who had spent much time in therapy. In several public statements he described her as "a borderline personality," given to sudden mood swings and dark rages. Marion C. Freeman, a longtime friend of the Humphrys, recalls that on a weekend visit to Windfall Farm, which Ann had bought in 1988, Ann exploded with startling anger during a minor disagreement with her. "She came up to me practically nose to nose and screamed in my face," says Freeman. "She had so much rage in her that never got out."
In her most virulent moments, Ann accused Derek of waging a premeditated campaign to drive her to the brink of suicide. In October of last year, three months after their divorce became final, she filed a $6 million lawsuit against him and the Hemlock Society, contending that Derek had libeled her in his public statements about her emotional instability and that he'd harassed her to impede her cancer recovery. On her videotape, Ann lobs accusations against virtually everyone prominently involved in the Hemlock Society, reeling off a list of names of people who are, she says, "trying to kill me."
The depth of Ann's anger and hurt on the tape raises the question of whether her suicide might have been an act of revenge. In leaving her, Derek had obliterated not just their marriage but, in the subsequent shakeout within the Hemlock Society, the status and identity she'd enjoyed for almost a decade as its deputy director. The videotape may have represented an honest expression of her doubts about euthanasia and the Hemlock Society, but it may also have been Ann Humphry's way of paying back her ex-husband.
"Derek," begins the suicide note Ann left for him. "There. You got what you wanted. Ever since I was diagnosed as having cancer, you have done everything conceivable to precipitate my death. . . .
"You will have to live with this until you die. May you never, ever forget."
In response to Ann's note, made public by her friend, Rita Marker, Derek accuses his ex-wife of "trying to lay a guilt trip on me," adding: "I felt terribly sad and I feel pained and I've cried about her death. But I know how ill she was."
IT IS UNCERTAIN what, if any, fallout there will be from Ann Humphry's death for either the Hemlock Society or the broader euthanasia movement. Derek claims to have noticed no discernible upsurge in membership defections after the sordid publicity surrounding the divorce, and he doesn't expect any now, in the wake of Ann's electrifying videotape, which was given to this reporter by a friend of hers.
Jack Nicholl, director of the campaign to place an aid-in-dying initiative before California voters next year, also predicts the controversy will have little impact on public opinion. But, he adds, "For the insiders, it's hard. They're fighting from the grave now. Who knows what to believe? Obviously, they were very angry at one another."
Ann's friends contend, however, that although she was emotional, she was never consumed with anger, and they dispute Derek's claim that she was mentally ill. They describe a woman who was rational and actively engaged in life. In the last year, they say, Ann had learned to fly-fish, taken a five-day river rafting trip and trained for an airplane pilot's license.
In her last eight months, Ann had also become romantically involved with Dr. Rick Urbanski, a 41-year-old emergency-room physician in Eugene. "I'm used to looking for suicidal depression, and I didn't see it," says Urbanski. "A person like that creates so much havoc around them, I wouldn't have allowed them in my life. Ann and I had a wonderful relationship."
Yet despite the bright spots of her final months, Ann also had to endure a series of sharp setbacks. There were complications from reconstructive breast surgery, and a second operation led to an infection that damaged her liver. She'd hoped to write a book about her struggles with her disease, according to her friend Julie Horvath, but her proposal was turned down by publishers who told her the woman-with-cancer story was overdone. "That really took a lot out of her," Horvath says. "She used to call and be really upset." The book rejections came at the very time "Final Exit" was becoming the top-selling nonfiction title in the country.
Friends say a great weariness came over Ann in September. When she visited Rita Marker, the subject of suicide arose. "She had really been through an awful, awful lot in the last two years," Marker says.
In late September, Ann called Horvath, a helicopter flight instructor in Los Angeles, and invited her to Windfall Farm. "She was planning on 'checking out,' as she termed it, and the purpose was to say goodbye," says Horvath, who arrived on a Sunday with a sense of dread but also a conviction that Ann was sound of mind. On Monday night and off and on through Tuesday, the two recorded the videotape, which was meant to be a record of Ann's story though not necessarily her last statement.
On camera, Ann says: "It bothered me that when I die I might slip through the cracks, and I thought, 'Well, that's just the way it is.' You live in the country and life is cheap. . . . And maybe you finally have to accept the fact that you did slip through the cracks. . . . I just want to get out of here and go to sleep and just be left alone."
Ann goes on to say there are two things she would like to live for: to continue speaking out about her misgivings about euthanasia and to see through to the end her lawsuit against Derek, a conclusion she expects will fully vindicate her.
When Horvath left with the videotape on Tuesday night, Ann seemed in no immediate danger. She had weekend plans with Rick Urbanski to drive one of her steers to a cattle auction. But suddenly her plans changed. At 12:30 Wednesday afternoon, Horvath received Ann's call:
"She said, 'Julie, I'm checking out.' I said, 'What happened?' She said, 'My attorneys dropped the lawsuit. They said they've already given the papers to Derek to say he's won.'
"She said, 'I'm so tired. I can't go on.' I said, 'Anna, let me come up.' She said, 'No.' I said, 'Anna, then come down here and I will support you, get you back on your feet.' She said, 'I'm just too tired.' "
Horvath began to cry. "I said, 'I love you so much.' She said: 'I love you, too. I'll see you wherever.' "
Hastily, Ann scribbled a few farewell notes, including the letter to Derek. Then she hitched a horse trailer to her Chevrolet pickup and set off east, for the four-hour drive into the mountains. Turning up a rough road into the Three Sisters Wilderness, she headed for one of her favorite places, Park Meadow -- driving fast, trying to make it by nightfall.
At a trailhead, she saddled up and cantered out to the meadow, a large clearing amid the tall pines with a view of the mountains. Her friends are certain she arrived in time to watch a gorgeous sunset. Then she rode 200 yards off the trail, removed her horse's tackle so it wouldn't snag once the animal was free and sat down with her back to a tree. "She apparently just lay down," said the head of the search team that found her six days later, "and went to sleep."

HEADLINE: FILM;
A 'Peter Pan' for the 90's

BYLINE: By HILARY DE VRIES; Hilary de Vries writes about the performing arts for The Los Angeles Times and other publications.

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
The pirate extras are milling about the deck of the Jolly Roger, a coal-black galleon the size of a Episcopal church. A Japanese television crew, filming a commercial, hunches over a treasure chest, debating the number of doubloons that should appear in the frame, while the actors, bedecked in the requisite eye patches and earning tidy per diems, take time out from their attempts to appear craven.
The site is Stage 27 of the Sony Pictures lot. For "Hook," Steven Spielberg's $60 million-plus updating of J. M. Barrie's classic "Peter Pan," it's all over but the shooting of this commercial. 
 Mr. Spielberg is nowhere to be seen, but a reverential hush hangs over the proceedings. Up on the poop deck of the Jolly Roger, an earnest press aide leans forward and whispers to a visitor: " 'Hook' isn't really about pirates. It's about Steven's views of modern parenting."
The film, which opens Wednesday, is considered the big movie in a season crowded with nearly a dozen big films opening within the same two weeks -- among them Barbra Streisand's "Prince of Tides," Oliver Stone's "J.F.K." and Barry Levinson's "Bugsy." "Hook" has generated more than usual interest largely because it represents a watershed in Mr. Spielberg's career -- a return to the themes that have made him the industry's No. 1 practitioner of fantasy film making. As such, the movie marks another potential blockbuster for the director as well as for Sony Pictures Entertainment, the Japanese owners of Tri-Star Pictures, the studio releasing the movie. "Hook" is expected to bolster Sony's future in Hollywood as well as the recession-battered American film industry.
For Mr. Spielberg, the director of such hits as "Jaws," "E. T., the Extra-Terrestrial," "Close Encounters of the Third Kind" and the Indiana Jones series, "Hook" is the movie he said he would never make, and it is one influenced as much by pop psychology as by Barrie's quirky views of child rearing.
In the film, Robin Williams plays an overweight, middle-aged man who leaves the world of corporate raiding to return to Neverland on a mission to rescue his own two children, kidnapped by his arch-foe Captain Hook, played by Dustin Hoffman. Clearly, this is a New Age Peter Pan for the 90's.
"Peter has grown up into a Type-A personality who is fairly unlikable as a modern parent," says the 43-year-old Mr. Spielberg (father of "four with one on the way"). "He is a workaholic like a lot of us -- I can relate to that -- but he evolves into this wonderful man-child."
For years, the conventional wisdom in Hollywood has been that no one was better equipped to bring Barrie's puerile sprite to the screen than Mr. Spielberg, himself dubbed Hollywood's Peter Pan because of his ability to tell children's stories that appeal to young and old alike. And perhaps it was only a matter of time before Barrie's Victorian tale of childhood in extremis met its match in the psycho-speak of John Bradshaw, another firm believer in extended childhoods, who coined the mantra for the 90's -- "the child within."
Mr. Spielberg's preoccupation with Peter Pan dates back several years to a time when he worked on his own screen adaptation of the Barrie tale about a boy who prefers the pirate-infested Neverland to puberty. The story first saw life as a play at the Duke of York Theater in London on Dec. 27, 1904, and was reworked into a best-selling children's book in 1991. Of the many versions of the story, the 1953 Disney animated film and the 1954 Broadway production, starring Mary Martin and directed by Jerome Robbins, remain perhaps the best known.
In his initial flirtation with his own film version, Mr. Spielberg went so far as to woo Mr. Hoffman for a role, but the venture became mired in script difficulties, and Mr. Spielberg went on to shoot "Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade," the 1989 film that completed his trilogy about the archeologist-adventurer.
"I will never direct 'Peter Pan,' " he said at the time.
"Did I say that?" he says now. "I guess I had to get a little older to see that I wasn't done regressing. I've given up trying to be Martin Scorsese, Kurosawa or David Lean. Maybe this film is about my finally growing up. I guess I've given up avoiding me."
Anthony Powell, the costume designer for "Hook" who has worked with Mr. Spielberg on the Indiana Jones films, says: "The whole premise of this version is Peter Pan finding himself, and Steven is fascinated by that idea."
Mr. Spielberg brings many "I gotta be me" sentiments to "Hook." With a tone bereft of irony, he describes the film as "Peter's journey backward to reclaim his own childhood." In Mr. Spielberg's hands -- and with a script by Jim Hart and Malia Scotch Marmo, based on a Nick Castle story -- Barrie's narcissistic protagonist is transformed into a far more laudable individual, even a role model for a middle-aged man.
To the suggestion that Barrie's Peter was often a less-than-admirable hero, Mr. Spielberg replies deadpan: "He was? That's Barrie's idea. I think we go in the other direction."
Kathleen Kennedy, Mr. Spielberg's longtime associate and one of the producers of "Hook," elaborates: "What is unnerving in Barrie's story is its focus on regression. Steven is not making a movie about regression, but he is tapping into that child-as-adult theme.
"Unlike 'E. T,' he is telling this film from an adult, not a child's, perspective."
As this New Age revision goes, the middle-aged Peter (renamed Peter Banning) goes up against a Captain Hook played by Mr. Hoffman with a kind of campy villainy that owes much to William F. Buckley Jr. Julia Roberts flutters in and out as a decidedly androgynous Tinkerbell, a cantankerous aide de camp on this journey toward the center of self. Wendy (Maggie Smith), Barrie's other major female character, has been consigned to the sidelines as a 90-year-old plot device.
Indeed, this has become a story of middle-aged men in search of themselves. Mr. Spielberg even calls Captain Hook "a grown-up Lost Boy -- the biggest boy with the most toys." And in discussing the film, most of the principal actors sound as if they had just finished a seminar by the pop-psychology guru of inner maleness, Robert Bly.
"I can't remember a film of this ilk; it's not just a job, it's extraordinary," says Mr. Hoffman, who was less entranced with his heavy costume, which included a yak's-hair wig, a five-pound steel hook and an air-conditioning hose running up the back of his velvet waistcoat.
"Hook," explains the 54-year-old actor, "is about killing off a part of yourself when you grow up. God knows, I'm not a feminist, but I do think women understand the idea more than men. As a rule, women can sit on the ground with the kids and just get lost for hours; and for men it's work. The child is still alive in the female more than the man."
Mr. Williams, 40 years old and a father of "two with one on the way," suggests that "Hook" "is about growing up, the good and the bad -- the joy of seeing an uptight workahaolic get back his imagination and make him magical again.
"Fight, fly and crow," says the actor, who spent two weeks of the filming strapped to an elaborate cable and camera system being flown around the sound stage 60 feet in the air. "Those are the things needed to get back to childhood, and in order to fly you have to have one happy thought. And 'they didn't audit me' doesn't count."
It is gently suggested that a post-Victorian audience might find it hard to believe that a grown man, even one as playful as Mr. Williams, would crow as a sort of whimsical primal scream. In response, he launches into an impression of President Bush. " 'Well, gotta ooooh! Gotta do it, gotta make it happen, gotta fly. Gonna work together, people.' Yeah, wouldn't that be great."
Probably Mike Medavoy, the chairman of Tri-Star Pictures, would be equally ecstatic if "Hook" turns out to be the hit of the holiday season. When he was handed the script shortly after his arrival at Tri-Star last year, he swiftly jettisoned the original and less-experienced director, Nick Castle, and signed Mr. Spielberg. Mr. Castle received a $500,000 kill fee, a story credit on "Hook" and a promise to direct another Tri-Star film. Mr. Medavoy then went after Mr. Spielberg, who "committed in two weeks," says Mr. Medavoy.
And Mr. Spielberg, whose reputation had suffered when he tried to make what he called "grown-up stories" like "Always" (1989) and "Empire of the Sun" (1987), got to make the movie that many in the industry thought he was destined to make.
At Mr. Spielberg's insistence, all the film's sets -- ranging from the Jolly Roger and the teeming Pirate Town to the Lost Boy's treehouse and Tinkerbell's dollhouse -- were built in the "timeworn Hollywood tradition" of artificial sets photographed realistically.
"We are trying to be less cutesy than the Disney version and go back to Barrie's darker original, which was more about unleashed devilment," says the set designer John Napier.
Adds Mr. Spielberg: "Neverland is not a cartoon world. It is a real place."
 
 
 
HOOK'S DREAM BOAT
 When filming of "Hook" began in Hollywood last February, the set -- considered lavish even in an industry inured to fiscal excess -- proved to be one of the biggest draws in town. The A-list of visitors to the Culver City studios included royalty (Queen Noor of Jordan), ex-wives (Amy Irving, formerly married to Steven Spielberg) and actors from competing films (Warren Beatty of "Bugsy").
Most of the film's $60 million-plus budget went into the production (director and stars are receiving percentages of the gross); $1.5 million went into Captain Hook's pirate ship, the Jolly Roger, whose sheer size -- 170 feet long, 35 feet wide and 70 feet high -- made it the most expensive prop ever used in a Spielberg film, along with the mechanical extra-terrestrial in "E. T.," which also cost $1.5 million.
The Jolly Roger was designed by John Napier, the man behind the helicopter in the Broadway musical "Miss Saigon," and it took 15 weeks to build. The ship is a combination of a Spanish galleon and a 17th-century English frigate with a skull-like protrusion on the bow that "came to me in a dream," Mr. Napier says. "This is the ultimate pirate ship -- bleak, tough, but with an element of romance."
Norman Garwood, the film's production designer, was responsible for translating Mr. Napier's designs into a wood-and-steel structure surrounded by 400,000 gallons of water. Then there was the question of painting it. "With a ship this size, the temptation was to paint the whole thing pink to make it look ominous and regal," says Mr. Garwood, who opted instead for a traditional color scheme of black, gold and crimson. Except for the rigging (designed by British nautical experts) and the cannons (replicas of those on the real H.M.S. Bounty), which can fire plastic cannonballs, nothing on the Jolly Roger actually moves. "Basically," Mr. Napier says, "this is just big scenery."
Maybe not. Plans are under way for a Peter Pan theme park in Orlando, Fla., which may be why Tri-Star spent $500,000 to dismantle and store the "Hook" sets rather than destroy them.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 30; Column 1; Arts & Leisure Desk

HEADLINE: POP VIEW;
Should Ice Cube's Voice Be Chilled?

BYLINE: By Jon Pareles

 BODY:
Ice Cube must be pleased about the reception for "Death Certificate." In the last month, the album of angry raps zoomed up to No. 2 on Billboard's album chart and brought denunciations from groups that believe Ice Cube's virulent diatribes are racist: proof that he's not only popular but important.
Welcome to the bitterly contested zone of hate speech, which can lead to disciplinary action on some college campuses, arrest in some states and, now, a best-selling album that some people want to squelch. In the past, rockers who slipped into bigotry accused their accusers of nit-picking a line or two. Ice Cube devotes long stretches of his album to knee-jerk racial and class prejudices. 
 Hate speech is hard to define but disturbing and threatening to many of its targets, and it has become a major battleground in constitutional law. On Wednesday, the United States Supreme Court heard arguments over whether a St. Paul law against cross-burning violates the First Amendment.
"Death Certificate" offers more complex (and sometimes contradictory) messages than a cross-burning, but it's not subtle. Ice Cube knows who he hates, and his raps bluntly insult and threaten violence against homosexuals, women, whites who exploit blacks, whites who covet black women, blacks who date white women, Korean shopkeepers, rappers who cross over to pop, the Los Angeles chief of police, self-destructive ghetto blacks and more.
The album is divided into "the death side" -- purportedly ironic gangster raps about gunplay and sex -- and "the life side," which reduces politics to grudge matches, often defined on racial lines. On the life side, Ice Cube is serious. Clearly influenced by the Rev. Louis Farrakhan's Nation of Islam, which he endorses in liner notes, Ice Cube favors black separatism, although he doesn't want his black nation to include homosexuals ("true niggers ain't gay") or yuppies. In his opposition to miscegenation, he probably has a lot in common with the pre-campaign David Duke and his notions of racial purity.
The Simon Wiesenthal Center, a Jewish human-rights group, urged four major record-store chains to stop selling the album, calling it a "cultural Molotov cocktail." The center had previously protested songs by Public Enemy, Guns 'n' Roses and Madonna, but has not called for an album's withdrawal.
It singled out "No Vaseline," a put down of Ice Cube's former group, N.W.A. The main metaphor is a homophobic one, and at one point Ice Cube envisions hanging and burning N.W.A.'s Eazy-E. The center cited Ice Cube's references to the group's manager as a Jew and his suggestion that N.W.A. "put a bullet in his temple/ You can't be the nigga for life crew with a white Jew telling you what to do." (N.W.A.'s current album is called "Efil4zaggin," intended to be read backward.)
The center also cited "Black Korea," in which Ice Cube rails against "Oriental one-penny countin' " shopkeepers who "follow me up and down your market." The song threatens a "nationwide boycott" and continues: "Pay respect to the black fist or we'll burn your store right down." The Korean-American Coalition has also condemned that rap. The British album will delete "No Vaseline" and "Black Korea," although the album will still include inflammatory material.
In a rare editorial about an album's contents, Billboard magazine described "Death Certificate" as "the rankest sort of racism and hatemongering." The editorial specifically rejected the Wiesenthal Center's request for removal of the album, but concluded, "Each of us must decide whether or not Ice Cube's record is fit to sell or purchase."
A response by James Bernard, senior editor at the rap magazine The Source, said Billboard's conclusion favored censorship because the magazine's editors "are too dainty and thin-skinned to hear the anger and rage and frustration that many people are forced to deal with every day."
The rage and frustration are real; so is the demagoguery that would exploit them, and the stupidity of some who are enraged. Ice Cube has decided that his people have been bullied too long, and that the appropriate reaction, as it would be in a gang war, is to identify the enemy and perpetrate vengeance. It's an ugly, simplistic reaction, an escalation rather than a solution. If Ice Cube were running for political office, seeking the power to realize his fantasies, he'd most likely be defeated as decisively as David Duke was.
By not only replying to Ice Cube's ideas but urging that he be silenced, the Wiesenthal Center handed him a tactical bonanza. Now he has opposition, white and Jewish to boot, that's out to muzzle him, proving that even paranoids have real enemies. The issue becomes not whether Ice Cube's raps are worth heeding, but whether they can be heard at all. When Jesse Helms and George Bush win elections with racially divisive commercials, Ice Cube's supporters can easily charge that the censorship is selective. As for hype, many rappers and rockers would give up their drum machines to be perceived as "a cultural Molotov cocktail."
Why are people buying "Death Certificate"? Most, I suspect, are not endorsing its racism; they're savoring the action-movie thrills of Ice Cube's dirty words, his machismo, his gift for violent imagery and his general anger -- N.W.A.'s formula. While Ice Cube has said that album is addressed to black listeners, and others don't matter, it's unlikely that "Death Certificate" reached No. 2 solely through sales to blacks; whites are buying it, too, and are probably not persuaded to see themselves as "the devil."
This year, N.W.A., Guns 'n' Roses, Metallica and Skid Row have all hit No. 1 because, doctrines aside, they're mad as hell and ready to profit from it. The recession has left young people un- and underemployed, disillusioned and seething. Some will fall under the sway of political demagogues, some will join gangs; Ice Cube didn't invent us-vs.-them thinking. A far larger audience, however, will just play loud music.
None of Ice Cube's ideas -- some half-baked, some arguable and some pernicious -- will surprise anyone who is aware of the racial rhetoric of American cities. Ice Cube is not the most responsible voice; someone who calls himself "the nigga you love to hate" doesn't pretend to be. Ugly as some of his thinking is, however, he has a right to be heard by those who are curious about his message -- and, then, to be challenged for his prejudices.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ice Cube performing at the Apollo -- insults and threats of violence. (Darcy Padilla for The New York Times)
