SECTION: Section 10; Page 1; Column 4; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 2209 words

HEADLINE: Time for a Change in Builder Incentives?

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
UNDER the combined weight of budget deficits, a deep recession and a surplus of new buildings, New York City officials are facing off against the construction industry in an attempt to overhaul the city's generous incentives for real estate development.
The incentives include tax breaks for developers and have become a fixture of New York construction over the last 15 years. Beginning in 1976, a time of fiscal crisis, they were created, modified and layered in an attempt to foster new construction, steer it to the commercial backwaters of the five boroughs and keep big business from leaving the city. 
 Now, in the aftermath of a development wave gone sour, there is almost universal agreement that changes in the incentives are needed.
Can the city afford to subsidize new development when there is already too much space to fill? And can it afford to stop, thereby dealing a further blow to construction, which grew in the 80's into New York's largest industry, but is now floundering?
"Times have changed," said Sally Hernandez-Pinero, the Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development. Although the incentives "generated numerous benefits for the city in the real estate market of the 1980's," she added, "we require a redirection to focus on the problems of the 1990's."
The debate in some ways echoes another in Washington, where Congress and the Bush Administration are grappling with what tax incentives to enact to jump-start a national economy mired in recession. New York's economy also is in recession, and the construction industry, after losing more than 20,000 jobs since 1989, is considered by some to be in depression.
"It is precisely because New York City is under fiscal constraints that it needs incentives for development," said Louis J. Coletti, president of the New York Builders Congress, a trade group. "Until we get the real estate design and construction industry moving again, the city will not regain its luster."
Ms. Pinero spoke before a City Council committee that is due in January to recommend revisions or elimination of one of the largest of the development incentives, the Industrial and Commercial Incentive Program, which since 1976 has provided tax benefits to developers across the city. Because of a sunset provision, it is scheduled to end this month.
The program, known in the shorthand of City Hall as "I.C.I.P.," postpones property taxes for up to 23 years on new and renovated commercial buildings and is available to anyone building outside the best blocks on the East Side and in the Wall Street area.
IN an analysis last week, Cushman & Wakefield, a commercial real estate firm, found that 20 large commercial buildings have been completed over the last decade with I.C.I.P. benefits. They include office towers on Broadway, the Hotel Macklowe on West 45th Street and the Holiday Inn Crowne Plaza in the theater district.
Ms. Pinero said all I.C.I.P. benefits should be eliminated for new construction everywhere south of 96th Street in Manhattan. But she did not recommend ending the program, saying new tax breaks should be extended to those who renovate old office space in lower Manhattan, where vacancies are the highest in the city and many buildings are technologically ill equipped.
Her proposal did not go far enough for many construction-industry executives.
A study commissioned by the New York Building Congress, released last week, analyzed the spillover effect of construction as it benefits other businesses and concluded that it had grown during the boom of the 80's to account for 23.4 percent of the city's economic output.
But now, the group said, cutbacks in construction spending have created a "reverse ripple" affect, in which jobs are being lost across a spectrum of related businesses. What the builders need, it maintained, is more, not less, help from City Hall.
Among the recommendations of the builders is that the I.C.I.P. program be renewed and extended, providing its tax benefits to anyone who builds anywhere in the city. The group also proposes that $1 billion in the city's capital budget, raised through the Municipal Assistance Corporation, be spent entirely on the repair of roads, sewers and public buildings.
Other real estate executives said the city's efforts to revive the construction industry should be more narrow, and targeted to areas most in need of development.
"We don't need subsidies for new buildings, but we do need to enhance existing resources," said John E. Zuccotti, chief executive officer of Olympia & York of Toronto, owners of the World Financial Center in lower Manhattan. He also serves as president of the Downtown Lower Manhattan Association, a group advocating renovation and development below Chambers Street.
Mr. Zuccotti said the city "needs a bundle of subsidies" to retain and attract corporate tenants, but that the inducements should be offered directly to the tenants instead of to their landlords or developers.
He also said incentives for development should be designed exclusively for lower Manhattan and include tax abatements for those who renovate old office and loft space into other uses, particularly housing.
Any new incentives would come at a time when developers, contractors, architects and building trades people are desperate for work. In one small example of the industry's plight, Der Scutt, the New York City architect, placed a "help wanted" advertisement in The New York Times on Oct. 20 for three entry-level architects in his firm. He was overwhelmed by 1,100 applications. The three positions were quickly filled, but not before the mailman serving Mr. Scutt's Manhattan office asked if he was running a sweepstakes.
Still, some analysts of City Hall and the New York economy say that reviving development now is at best wishful thinking, and at worst a serious waste of tax revenues.
"The 80's may have been wonderful for the construction industry, but we can't recreate the past and shouldn't try," said Mitchell Moss, a professor of urban planning at New York University and co-author of a report on prospects for the city's economy entitled "Reinventing New York."
Mr. Moss and Hugh O'Neill, a New York University professor of economics, said the objective of financial incentives and tax policy should now be people rather than real estate. Any subsidies the city can afford, they said in the report, should go to schools, libraries, the arts, parks, job training and other programs that would reinforce its position as a center of "intellectual capital."
"We should be creating incentives for job creation, not space creation," Mr. Moss said.
New York was far from alone among American cities in the 1980's in providing incentives for development. In Houston, Los Angeles, Boston and many other cities, zoning inducements and tax breaks led to a surge of building that was faster and more exaggerated, and led to office gluts that are now more severe than the one in New York.
"New York City has spent a boatload on its real estate incentives, but it has done better than most cities in monitoring what incentives were appropriate," said Margaret Sowell, director of real estate advisory services for Coopers & Lybrand, the Manhattan accounting firm.
Another lure to development in all cities in the early 80's were Federal tax shelters used by wealthy people who financed or built real estate. The tax breaks, allowing people to sharply reduce their taxes by declaring "passive losses" on real estate, were largely eliminated with the 1986 revision of the tax codes, but not before drawing vast investments into development that was not completed until later in the decade.
For New York, one competitive fact of life remains, even though the real estate boom has turned to bust: New, lower-cost office space beckons business from Jersey City, Stamford, White Plains and other suburban corporate centers. Without tax breaks from City Hall, Manhattan real estate executives say they would be out of the game.
"WE think it sends the wrong message to foreign companies and big corporate tenants when the Dinkins administration talks about scaling back" development incentives, said Steven Spinola, president of the Real Estate Board of New York City. "It says the city does not want growth."
The costs and benefits of development incentives are impossible to measure. While it is simple to calculate how much tax money is lost if property taxes on a new building are temporarily deferred or eliminated, it cannot be known how much more would be lost if the building were not constructed at all.
This becomes a classic chicken-or-egg question for planners and historians. Without incentives, how much would be built?
"There is just no way to know," said James P. Goonan, a partner in Deloitte & Touche, a New York accounting firm, which tried in vain in the 80's to measure the fiscal impact of the city's J-51 program, which eliminates property taxes for 10 years for owners who renovate apartment buildings.
Still, experts say there is no question that the large menu of incentives promulgated by New York City were an important spur to developers. Besides the I.C.I.P. program and J-51 -- both still being offered -- other initiatives led to bursts of building just as these initiatives were taken off the city's books.
One was the 421a program, which offered tax abatements to builders of new luxury housing. Designed to alleviate the city's severe housing shortage in the early 80's, it was eliminated below 96th Street in Manhattan in December 1985, thereby creating a deadline for builders to put in foundations.
The result was a construction spree from 1986 to 1988, with more than 20 huge condominium and rental buildings rising from the posh avenues of the Upper East Side to the far reaches of Clinton, formerly known as Hell's Kitchen. Many of the new condominiums, priced from $200,000 to over $1 million, were completed just as the city's residential market began to slump after the stock market collapse in 1987.
Another deadline was created at the end of 1987 under a program of zoning bonuses for commercial developers who built offices and hotels in the western half of Midtown Manhattan. The developers were allowed to put up taller and bulkier towers than would otherwise have been permitted.
The deadline led to a fresh surge of development from 1988 to 1990, with more than a dozen commercial buildings and 9 million square feet of new offices rising in West Midtown, mainly around Times Square. When they were completed, the urban economy was already slumping, and some of the new towers at still begging for tenants.
"While it is true that some of these building are in deep trouble attracting tenants, the program accomplished its goal of attracting development from east to west" in the nation's most heavily developed commercial district, said Robert Flahive, director of the Manhattan office of the New York City Department of Planning. He added that the new West Side buildings will "prime the pump" for more development in the neighborhood when the real estate slump ends.
Perhaps the most important development incentives since 1988 have been incorporated in what City Hall calls its "other-boroughs strategy." The incentives include the biggest tax breaks allowed under I.C.I.P., other tax credits for each employee, subsidized energy and moving expenses. They go to developers who build, or business that move, above 96th Street in Manhattan or in any of the other four boroughs.
Real estate executives say the program has been instrumental in a development surge in downtown Brooklyn. More than 15 million square feet of office space is being completed there and almost all has been leased to an assortment of Wall Street firms, other private companies and government agencies.
DESPITE that apparent success, some critics say the other-boroughs strategy, like other incentives, is an idea whose time has passed. "Manhattan is, and always will be, the epicenter of commerce," for the New York region, said Mr. Moss of New York University, adding that whatever incentives remain in place should not be designed to draw development elsewhere.
Mr. Moss's proposals for the city have little else in common with those of the real estate industry, but he concurred on that point, which was put this way by Mr. Spinola:
"We need to protect the city's core and build on it."
Whatever the outcome of the debate over incentives, New York City has already lost huge numbers of jobs and much needed tax revenue, at least compared to the peak years of the construction boom from 1985 to 1987.
Construction itself has fallen off sharply. In 1987, the peak of the boom, more than 11.3 million square feet of new office space was started in the city, according to F. W. Dodge Company, a research concern. Last year there were starts for only 4.3 million square feet, and for the first ten months of this year, the total is only 700,000.
Employment in construction has also plummeted. Since 1989, when construction industry employment averaged 120,800 jobs, the highest ever in New York City, it has fallen to an average of 99,500 jobs so far this year, according to the Federal Department of Labor.

HEADLINE: Talking: 2-Families;
Bias Now Prohibited In Rentals

BYLINE: By ANDREE BROOKS

 BODY:
TRADITIONALLY, the rental apartments in two-family houses in New York City have been exempted from the laws that prohibit racial and other forms of discimination in housing, provided the owner or a member of the owner's family lived in the house.
While owners of two-family houses could not publicly advertise that they would accept only, say, a white Christian family, they were able to legally make such a distinction when an applicant called at the door. The rationale was that renting the second unit in a two-family house was like bringing someone into one's home and thatcontrols would be an unfair restriction on private property rights. 
 Although not every landlord discriminated, the exemption meant effectively that more than 100,00 apartments were not available to families of some ethnic or religious groups.
But now an amendment to New York City's fair-housing regulations that took effect Sept. 16 has brought owner-occupied two-family houses under the antidiscrimination regulations. This means that owners may no longer refuse to rent on the basis of race, color, creed, national origin, citizenship status, occupation, children, sex or sexual orientation, age, disability or marital status. An owner can still refuse someone who has a poor credit or employment history, insufficient income to pay the rent or a criminal record.
Lonnie Soury, director of public information for the New York City Human Rights Commission, said the commission had sought the change to eliminate "major sources of weakness where discrimination could freely flourish."
Keeping owner-occupied two-family houses outside the purview of the law was viewed as having major implications. The 1990 census showed that the city has 188,474 two-family houses: 82,170 in Brooklyn, 70,448 in Queens, 17,135 in Staten Island, 16,864 in the Bronx and 1,857 in Manhattan. Not all are owner-occupied, but most probably are, say housing observers, and two-family houses contain some of the largest and most economical apartments in the city.
Moreover, New York City was recently cited in a Federal study as having the worst record for housing discrimination in the country.
The new antidiscrimination amendment applies to units offered publicly for rent. The only exclusion is "if the available housing accomodation has not been publicly advertised, listed (with a real estate broker), or otherwise offered to the general public" -- the actual amendment's words.
Harvey Fisher, assistant deputy commissioner for law enforcment for the city's Human Rights Commission, said this means that "if the landlord puts up a notice on a church bulletin board or in the laundromat or tells a real estate broker or even puts it a small ethnic newspaper, the apartment would be subject to the new amendment."
Phyllis Spiro, director of the Open Housing Center, a nonprofit group in Manhattan that helps victims of discrimination gather evidence against landlords, added that it could also mean a notice in a window or in a private-membership newsletter.
But there could be exceptions. Ms. Spiro gave as a hypothetical example two white friends in an office who talk about such an apartment at the water cooler. If a black colleague overhears and applies and is turned down, he might not have a legitimate right to complain.
But Mr. Fisher of the Human Rights Commission further warned that even under those conditions the owner may no longer have a right to discriminate. When the two-family-house amendment was approved, he said, the regulations were also modified to broaden the definition of "publicly assisted housing," another category of housing covered by the law.
PUBLICLY assisted housing now includes any two-family house built after July 1, 1950, that might have been bought with the help of a Goverment-subsidized financing program such as a Sonny Mae mortgage, a loan from the Veterans Administration or even a mortgage insured by the Federal Housing Administration. Provided the loan was taken out after July 1, 1955, the house will now be subject to the law even if the second unit is not publicly offered.
Normal Siegel, a lawyer and executive director of the New York Civil Liberties Union, said that as a result it would be prudent for any owner of a two-family house to check with a lawyer before making any attempt to rent. The owner should also double-check the nature of the financing to see if it might be deemed "publicly assisted" under the widened definition.
He also said that owners who have a family member living in one of the units -- rather than themselves -- should also be cautious before assuming that the family member qualifies under the amendement. It would proabably have to be an immediate family member like a child, a parent or a sibling, said Mr. Fisher.
Mr. Siegel further warned that the city's Human Rights Commission has been gradually strengthening the penalties likely to flow from any violation of the fair housing law. Fines up to $100,000 can now be imposed if the commission is able to prove "willful, wanton or malicious" dealings.
Even so, tenants should not expect those practices to disappear overnight. Roberta Bernstein, president of the Small Property Owners of New York, expects some of the strongest resistance to come from owners who have tradionally preferred to rent only to members of their own ethnic group, she said.
Also, many owners may not yet be aware of the change. "I only just found out myself," said Ms. Spiro of the Open Housing Center. She suggests that any applicants suspecting discrimination should call the owner's attention to the new amendment.
While that may not save the apartment for them -- applicants rarely move in even if they win a case or an argument, she said, because they fear retaliation -- it could help save the day for another family. The commission is already prosecuting its first case under the new amendment but would not release details.
Tenants who need advice or suspect discrimination when applying for an apartment in a two-family house should contact the Open Housing Center (941-6101) or the Human Rights Commission hot line (306-7500). They should not contact any of the state or federal anti-discriminaton agencies since the new amendment has not been adopted into state or federal law. It applies only to New York City properties.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: Grand Central;
Adding to the Area Where Air Rights Can Be Used

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
HOW far will city planners go to find development sites where Grand Central Terminal's air rights can be used?
East 48th Street, it would seem. 
 Tomorrow, the City Planning Department is to issue a report on a proposed zoning subdistrict from Madison to Lexington Avenues, 41st to 48th Streets, that would expand by 15 blocks the area to which the unused development rights -- some 1.7 million to 1.9 million square feet -- can be transferred.
The question of which sites are eligible has bedeviled developers, owners, city planners and preservationists ever since the United States Supreme Court upheld the landmark designation of Grand Central in 1978.
That decision effectively barred Penn Central from building a 55-story tower over the terminal itself, given that there were other sites in the vicinity on which Grand Central's development rights might be used.
However, without a subdistrict, the only eligible sites are those adjacent to the terminal, across the street or connected through a chain of lots under common ownership.
City planners have been working since 1989 on the subdistrict proposal, which is to be reviewed next year by Community Boards 5 and 6, Borough President Ruth W. Messinger and the Manhattan Borough Board, after which it must be voted on by the City Planning Commission and City Council.
In the core of the subdistrict, planners would allow buildings with floor-area ratios of 21.6; that is, having floor space 21.6 times greater than the lot size. Such a floor-area ratio, or F.A.R., would yield a 432,000-square-foot building on a 20,000-square-foot lot. On the district's edges, the F.A.R. would be 16.
To qualify for the 21.6 F.A.R., a builder would have to provide major improvements to the pedestrian circulation system around Grand Central and contribute to the maintenance of the landmark.
The director of the Manhattan office in the City Planning Department, Robert E. Flahive, explained, "We are trying to provide a mechanism, on sites where appropriate, to allow transfers to occur but at the same time to impose additional controls."
Within the Grand Central subdistrict, planners have identified 15 potential development sites. Some are under single ownership but others would require laborious assemblage.
Under current zoning, the F.A.R. is 15, before bonuses. An increase in allowable bulk of more than 40 percent might make it economical -- in an improved market -- to attempt an assemblage or tear down a large building to be able to capitalize on the zoning. Planners have cited these structures:
* Graybar Building, 420 Lexington Avenue, between 43d and 44th Streets; -- "1927 building with outdated systems; not first-class office space; prime location; large lot."
* 250 Park Avenue (former Postum Building), between 46th and 47th Streets -- "1924 building on prime Park Avenue location."
* Roosevelt Hotel, Madison Avenue and 45th Street -- "Old hotel in single ownership; easy site for redevelopment."
BUT new construction is out of the question today. As a practical matter, a possible enlargement of Manufacturers Hanover Plaza may provide the first opportunity to draw down the air rights, which are owned by the Penn Central Corporation of Cincinnati, corporate successor to the New York Central Railroad.
The question of space is particularly relevant for Manufacturers Hanover, which is to merge next month with Chemical Bank. Chemical's headquarters are to move into Manufacturers Hanover Plaza, which occupies the whole block between Park and Madison Avenues, 47th and 48th Streets.
Under the subdistrict proposal, the bank headquarters would be eligible to receive 353,000 square feet of air rights from Grand Central. These could be used to add 11 or 12 floors to the Madison Avenue annex, which is only 12 stories high, as opposed to the 52-story tower on Park Avenue.
Such an addition could not be constructed today because the headquarters is larger than zoning permits, with an F.A.R. of 17.2. It was built in 1960, for Union Carbide, before the current Zoning Resolution.
Moreover, even if there were a higher cap on bulk, Manufacturers Hanover Plaza is too far from Grand Central to be eligible for its air rights under current zoning rules, although it would qualify under the subdistrict, whose northwest corner it occupies.
In 1989, the City Planning Commission rebuffed an effort by a developer, G. Ware Travelstead, to establish a "chain of common ownership" along the subsurface lots of the rail yard running from Grand Central to his property, 383 Madison Avenue, between 46th and 47th Streets.
The commission's denial was upheld last August in State Supreme Court in Manhattan. Mr. Travelstead is planning an appeal.
Mr. Travelstead is under contract to buy 1.5 million square feet of air rights from Penn Central. He hoped to use more than half of those rights to build a 1.45 million-square-foot tower (roughly 650,000 square feet as a matter of right, supplemented by 800,000 square feet from the terminal).
UNDER his contract with Penn Central, Mr. Travelstead must close on the air rights within a year of the end of his lawsuit -- he plans to go to the United States Supreme Court, if necessary -- or, under any circumstance, no later than November 2004. Penn Central is not a party to the suit.
Aside from Mr. Travelstead's portion, it is not clear how much square footage there is in air rights. Penn Central says the total is 1.966 million square feet. Even subtracting the air rights under contract, that leaves more than enough to sell to Manufacturers Hanover.
But Frederick W. Rovet, the general counsel and managing director of the Travelstead Group and a former Penn Central executive, said he "did not believe that Penn Central has 353,000 square feet to give to Manny Hanny, in addition to the 1.5 million it has under contract to us."
He said Penn Central controlled 100,000 square feet free and clear. It owns another 100,000 square feet that are subject to use by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority if it chose to add floor space to the terminal.
Then there is an unusual lot at 416 Lexington Avenue, sandwiched between the Graybar Building and the Grand Hyatt Hotel. On it is a three-story building with a tunnel-like passage to a loading dock at Grand Central.
If the parcel at No. 416 is considered part of the terminal's zoning lot -- because it functions as a driveway to Grand Central -- it yields 270,000 square feet more of air rights for Penn Central. But it also might be considered a separate lot, like the adjacent Graybar and Grand Hyatt parcels.
Penn Central includes the 416 Lexington Avenue lot in its calculations. City planners neither concede nor dispute the point, referring to it instead as an "open issue."
Robert W. Olson, senior vice president of Penn Central, said he would not comment on "any discussion I may or may not be having" with the city and Manufacturers Hanover.
Should all other efforts fail to draw down the air rights, Penn Central is still prepared to propose a tower directly over Grand Central, perhaps using as a model the plans drawn in 1910 by Warren & Wetmore, architects of the terminal itself.
Mr. Olson said Penn Central had engaged the architect Hugh Hardy, of Hardy Holzman Pfeiffer Associates, "to research how the Warren & Wetmore Beaux-Arts building works and how it relates to the terminal." For example, there are already banks of elevators at the corners of the terminal that were designed to serve a building overhead.
Hardy Holzman Pfeiffer designed the comprehensive exhibition "Grand Central Terminal: City Within the City" at the New-York Historical Society in 1982.

HEADLINE: IRT Power Plant

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I was outraged to read in your article on Nov. 17 titled "The Power of Design vs. Con Ed Power" that the Landmarks Preservation Commission is going to try again to designate the IRT power plant at 59th Street and 11th Avenue -- an incredibly ugly building that, as your story points out, was obsolete when it opened in 1904. 
 The commission will spend badly needed tax dollars on hearings and court proceedings, and Con Edison will fight designation and add the costs to what we pay for electricity.
How can we expect anyone to take the city's needs seriously when we engage in this sort of insanity in the middle of a recession?
 
LEE LEVITT
Manhattan

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: Perspectives: A Converter Looks Back;
Recasting Rental Apartments as Co-ops

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
PEOPLE have the wrong notion of Francis Greenburger if they think of him as a co-op converter. He says he hasn't been in that business for five years.
Being in that business means being a buyer of rental property for conversion into co-ops. The downturn in the market for New York City co-ops, a series of New York State regulatory steps, and tax policies, not to mention the Tax Reform Act of 1986, soured Mr. Greenburger's taste for acquisitions. He hasn't bought a building for conversion since 1986. 
 "But for seven to nine years I spent two or three nights a week negotiating with tenant groups," he said in the soft-spoken and thoughtful, almost grave, tone he sometimes adopts, "and I would spend three to five days negotiating with owners."
All those negotiations led to the conversion by Mr. Greenburger and his company, Time Equities, of about 100 buildings with 10,000 apartments, making him one of the city's leading conversion sponsors. He did only noneviction plans. About 6,000 apartments were sold for owner-occupancy. Of the remaining 4,000, mostly renter-occupied, 80 percent have been turned back to his lenders. Half of the rest are owned by former partners. The other half, about 400 apartments, Mr. Greenburger still owns.
Now he is reflecting on the conversion years, which were sandwiched between periods of buying Manhattan residential real estate for investment and, after 1986, industrial and commercial buildings around the country. Time Equities was formed in 1968 and it owned 25 buildings with 1,000 apartments even before the first conversions began in 1979.
"We all paid too much in hindsight," he said of his mid-80's rental purchases for conversion, "what with tax reform, the increase in the tax assessed on capital gains, the expensive incentives we had to give in order to sell, and the economy going to hell. No one who bought a building after 1985 to convert made any money, and the more you paid the more you lost."
Other losers in the market's downturn, which cut values sharply, have been some of the purchasers of converted apartments, particularly outside buyers who paid market prices for their units in the mid and late 80's. If they need to resell in the current market, many will have to accept losses.
Beyond that, the flood of conversions has left a series of problems. The worst have been caused by the handful of sponsors who collected rent payments on renter-occupied apartments in co-ops but failed to make maintenance payments to the co-op corporations.
Or in some cases, sponsors collected payments on new mortgages that encompassed the building's existing underlying mortgage, but then failed to make debt payments on the underlying mortgage.
Mr. Greenburger, for his part, kept up his maintenance payments or turned over his shares to lenders who have done so. The publicity given to his early acknowledgment to the state's Attorney General that he foresaw problems in meeting his obligations to his lenders sent tremors through the co-op market and may have helped depress sales of vacancies in co-ops with renter-occupied apartments.
"He should be commended for not waiting to bring the problems to everyone's attention," said Frederick K. Mehlman, the assistant Attorney General in charge of the Bureau of Real Estate Finance. Subsequently Mr. Mehlman required far more detailed sponsor disclosures.
IN Mr. Greenburger's opinion, the new requirements created a "crisis atmosphere" in the name of full disclosure. "They made you present information that was overbiased negatively," he said. "It made you present the worst case possible and that panicked the market. It was like requiring a sign that says 'There may not be enough exits in this theater if there's a fire."'
The more rigorous reporting procedures instituted when sponsor difficulties began to emerge three years ago grew out of longstanding policies of the Attorney General's office. Its narrow goal -- some, including the Attorney General, have tried to get the Legislature to widen it -- in regulating conversions is to make sure sponsors provide "full disclosure."
Thus, acceptance of a plan by the Attorney General never meant that the plan offered buyers a good deal in an economic sense; it meant only that the sponsor had given buyers the information they needed to make an intelligent decision. Beyond that it was essentially "let the buyer beware."
Documents notwithstanding, many tenants organized to negotiate better prices and terms from converters, who were hoping for large sales to the tenants, called insiders. Other sponsors tended to be less concerned about insider sales. There were conversions with so few insider purchases that the converted building hardly seemed like a co-op at all. Only 15 percent of the apartments must be sold for a noneviction conversion. Some of the buyers were people who moved into vacancies as renters before conversion, planning to buy, rather than long-term insiders.
Mr. Greenburger said he typically obtained 40 percent of sales to long-term tenants before converting. Many current co-op officers remember him well as a negotiator.
"WE found him fair," said Ira Mothner, president of the 55-unit building at 309-317 West 93d Street. Mr. Greenburger still owns a handful of shares in the building; others that he owned are now held by an institution. Mr. Mothner suspects that these holdings increased the building's difficulties when it set out to refinance the underlying mortgage over a year ago.
In the end, the director of funding for Time Equities, Stuart Bruck, succeeded in finding the co-op a lender. The loan provided "excellent rates in a tough lending environment," said Ira Stein, treasurer of the co-op, in a thank-you letter.
Mr. Greenburger, who will be 43 next month, also runs a literary agency, Sanford J. Greenburger Associates, which his late father founded in 1932. With Time Equities it operates on a floor of 55 Fifth Avenue, at 12th Street, an office building that Mr. Greenburger bought in 1984.
His entrepreneurial tastes developed early. While still in high school he established a book export business, buying English-language books wholesale from an American publisher and selling them to a German book club to be retailed to English-speaking Germans at a 50 percent mark-up. "I made $15,000 to $20,000 a year as a 14-year-old," he says.
Later, he had an office on 59th Street, and sublet half the space at a rent that covered his own. His real-estate career was born.
The value of the 400 renter-occupied apartments he still holds has slipped with the market's decline. In 1988, Mr. Greenburger figured the average value of his apartments, when they are vacated by rent regulated tenants, at $100,000 a unit and their value if occupied at 25 percent of that. "Today people often say they are worth 12 to 15 percent of their vacancy value," he says.
His policy on apartments that are vacated is to rerent them at market rates if they can earn 8 to 10 percent of their vacancy value, but to sell if they would earn 7 percent or less. If an apartment with a sale value of $75,000 can produce income of only $4,800 a year, or 6.4 percent of the value, he would sell. But if the sale value of that apartment was $50,000, he would retain it beause the annual earnings would be 9.6 percent of the value.
He advises buyers to look at the size of a building's underlying mortgage in relation to the building's value before making a purchase. Assuming there is no commercial space in the building, if the loan-to-value ratio exceeds 25 percent it would suggest the maintenance is not competitive in the marketplace. Nowadays, the building's mortgage will typically be 15 to 25 percent of the total value of a building's shares, he said.
The co-op conversion boom in New York City was an aberration tied to rent regulation, Mr. Greenburger said. It represented a "political compromise" -- a way to deregulate housing but divide the financial benefit between the owners of buildings and their renters.
"The rental value of buildings had been driven into the ground," he said. "Conversions attracted new money to fix buildings up, and they created a tax base. Now there are not many buildings left to be converted. Even if the market strengthens, you won't see massive conversions again."
But he does expect to see higher prices. "My feeling is that we are at a bottom now," he said. "I don't expect prices to get worse, but over two to five years they will get better."

HEADLINE: In Search of the Perfect Christmas Tree

BYLINE: By HAROLD FABER

 BODY:
THE best-looking blue spruce in the United States was grown last year in Connecticut, on Ski's Christmas Tree Farm in Lebanon. A blue ribbon on the wall of the office of the farm's operators, B. John and Mary Skawinski, attests that their tree was judged the top prize winner for spruces by the National Christmas Tree Growers Association at its annual convention in Anaheim, Calif.
"It was the first time that anyone from Connecticut ever won a blue ribbon for Christmas trees in a national competition," Mr. Skawinski said. 
 Mr. Skawinski, a retired civilian employee of the Navy at Groton, has been growing Christmas trees for 28 years. "I love growing trees," he said. "They don't talk back and they don't argue."
 
Big Business in Trees
 The Skawinskis grow nine varieties of Christmas trees on their seven-acre farm -- white pine, Fraser fir, Scotch pine and various spruces. The farm opened on Friday for the annual choose-and-cut tree season.
Between now and Christmas Eve, the Skawinskis' farm and 200 others in Connecticut will be open, usually from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. daily, though a few may be open only on weekends.
Growing and selling Christmas trees is a big business in the United States, with sales of 36.5 million trees for $1.2 billion forecast this season by the national association, which has its headquarters in Milwaukee.
The 500 Christmas tree growers in Connecticut are expected to sell 350,000 to 400,00 trees this year for $7 million, according to the executive director of the State Association of Christmas Tree Growers, John Olsen. Most of the trees are sold at wholesale prices by the growers to retailers who sell them to the public at corner lots or garden centers.
But more and more people in Connecticut and other states are turning to the choose-and-cut method of obtaining a tree. For many suburban and city residents, it is not only a chance to buy a tree cheaper than pre-cut ones but also an opportunity to make an expedition to the countryside.
"The kids just love it," Mr. Skawinski said. "It's a real happy occasion."
 
Prices Haven't Risen
 He gives lollipops to children, but other Christmas tree farmers also dispense hot chocolate and doughnuts and offer hayrides in an effort to make tree cutting a more pleasant experience. At Bishop's Orchards in Guilford, for example, patrons receive hot mulled cider.
Despite inflation, the price of a choose-and-cut tree has not changed appreciably in the last few years. The range, $20 to $40, is about the same as last year.
At the Skawinski farm, the price is $20 for a budget tree, $25 for an average tree, $30 for better trees marked with a yellow ribbon, and $35 for top-of-the-line trees.
In New Hartford, Laura M. Auburn sells blue spruce, Norway and white spruce and Douglas fir trees at about $20 a tree. At Bishop's Orchards, the price for Fraser fir, Douglas fir and spruce is about $30 a tree.
At the Jones Tree Farm in Shelton the price varies by the day of the week in an attempt to attract more customers on weekdays. The price is $35 a tree from Monday to Friday but $40 on Saturdays and Sundays.
Before setting out, call to find out precise directions, days and hours a farm is open, weather conditions and whether or not to bring your own saw. (Most farms will furnish a bow saw.) In addition, the farmers suggest that you dress warmly, wear gloves and boots, and bring rope to tie the tree to the top of your car or to tie the trunk lid down for the trip home.
 
Care Prolongs Trees
 To preserve the tree before it is set up inside the house, put it in a pail of water outside, but not under cover. Before bringing it in, cut off an inch from the bottom to permit it to take up water more easily, thus prolonging its life.
Once the tree is inside the house, place it in the coolest part of the room, away from heat-producing equipment, like radiators or television sets. Set the tree in a stand that holds at least a gallon of water and replenish the water as needed, and unplug lights before going to bed, to minimize fire hazard. And, when the holiday season is over, do not burn the tree. Instead, the association suggests, put it outside as a feeding station for birds or chop it up for mulch.
Following is a list of farms, arranged by county and town, where Christmas trees are available for those who want to choose and cut their own, prepared by Connecticut Christmas Tree Growers Association in cooperation with the State Department of Agriculture:

HEADLINE: Grass-Roots Goal: Rebuilding a City

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

DATELINE: CAMDEN

 BODY:
IN some parts of Camden, abandoned, crumbling houses dominate neighborhood blocks, the remnant of the city's industrial decline when thousands of people moved away.
The vacant properties are eyesores for residents, targets for arsonists and havens for drug dealers. More than 3,500 such properties are scattered around the city. 
 As this city of 87,500 residents tries to revitalize its faltering economy, grass-roots groups are trying to rebuild their neighborhoods block by block. The task is enormous in a city where more than 10 percent of the housing units are vacant.
 
'It's a Challenge'
 "It's a challenge," said Sister Peg Hynes, managing director of the Heart of Camden, a nonprofit housing group in South Camden. "But we realize we can make a difference."
An outgrowth of the Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church, the volunteer group has rehabilitated more than 50 homes since 1984. The Heart of Camden is among a half-dozen groups that have begun rehabilitation projects in neighborhoods around the city.
"It's a very monumental task to revitalize the neighborhoods of Camden," said Thomas A. Roberts, executive director of the city's Redevelopment Agency. "They're very tough, but they can be brought back."
The neighborhoods began their downward spiral in the 1950's as white residents started moving to the suburbs. Between 1950 and 1980, the city lost nearly one-third of its population.
"We had a lot of vacant buildings left," Mr. Roberts said. "They were eventually abandoned, and the city came to own them."
 
Extensive Repairs Needed
 Using volunteers from churches, schools and civic groups, the Heart of Camden is slowly refurbishing a five-block area in South Camden. Most of the houses, vacant for a number of years, require extensive repairs.
"We really have to gut them and start all over again," Sister Peg said. "It takes a lot more muscle and a lot more time."
It takes months for crews to refurbish the houses, replacing walls, installing sprinkler systems and upgrading the properties to meet current building codes, she said. Residents say the effort is making a difference.
Freshly painted row houses now line Holcain Street, a narrow alley that was once filled with trash. A neighbor lovingly cares for a fenced-in garden park.
"Nobody would have thought these houses could be brought back," said Herb Clayton, who has lived on nearby Jackson Street for 14 years. "They were empty, almost ready to fall down."
 
Properties Acquired From City
 The Heart of Camden acquires the abandoned properties from the city and sells the rehabilitated homes to low-income families at minimal cost.
"We're not in this to make money," Sister Peg said, noting that the annual income for most families is under $10,000. "We're in this to help families find homes."
Eligible families receive interest-free mortgages with no down payment required, Sister Peg said. The average monthly mortgage payment is about $200 and includes taxes, she said.
At one time, there were nearly 200 abandoned houses in the neighborhood near the Delaware River, Sister Peg said.
 
City Is Criticized
 Despite the scattered success of grass-roots organizations, critics say the city should play a larger role in rebuilding neighborhoods and demolishing vacant, dilapidated houses.
"They say we are building Camden block by block, but I think we are losing this city block by block," said Maribel Roman, a member of Camden Churches Organized for People, which has asked the city to demolish or rehabilitate 58 abandoned properties by the end of the year. "We need help and we need it fast," she said.
Mayor Aaron A. Thompson, who coined a slogan, "Camden's on the Move -- Rebuilding Neighborhoods Block by Block," said the city could not afford to demolish all the abandoned properties. The city is giving priority to razing buildings left in ruins after a Halloween Mischief Night arson spree.
Though the city has concentrated on a $500 million waterfront revitalization project, including a state aquarium, Mayor Thompson says neighborhoods will not be overlooked.
"For us to grow on our waterfront and not in our neighborhoods would be a tragedy," said Mr. Thompson, a lifelong Camden resident. "I firmly believe that we must build in our neighborhoods."

HEADLINE: Speed-Up of Fiber-Optic Network Debated

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
A $1 BILLION plan by New Jersey Bell to make New Jersey the first state to have fiber-optic communications available to virtually every household and business has provoked an intense debate between proponents of the plan and a powerful coalition of forces opposing it.
With fiber optics, New Jersey Bell officials say, they can create a vast network of high-speed audio, video and data services that will revolutionize the way residents and businesses in the state communicate. 
 In what the company calls a "fully fibered state," homebound students can attend school by using their television sets, doctors can read CAT scans taken in hospitals miles away, businesses can market products over an interactive two-way video network and residents can dial up virtually any cable television program offered anywhere in the state.
But critics, including the cable television industry and the New Jersey Press Association, say that New Jersey Bell's elaborate plan is excessive, expensive and unnecessary and that it will result in higher rates for consumers. They say most residents will neither need nor want many services that may become available but will nevertheless end up paying the plan's $1 billion price tag. They also criticize company plans to run fiber "to the curb" and then charge consumers extra to connect it to their houses.
The debate is gathering steam as the lame-duck Democratic-controlled Legislature contemplates a controversial telephone rate freeze and deregulation legislation that New Jersey Bell says is necessary before it can proceed with its plans.
"The network that we see and we feel is so close at hand is going to impact on the lives of every consumer," said Dennis M. Bone, director of regulatory planning for New Jersey Bell in Newark.
The company's plan, Mr. Bone said, involves rewiring the entire state by replacing 56.3 million miles of copper wire with fiber-optic cable -- a finger-thick flexible cable made of hair-thin strands of glass. The plan would push forward by 20 years, to the year 2010, a previous date for completing the conversion.
"With fiber going into every single home and business in the state, there will be all sorts of capabilities for everybody to use that simply do not exist today," Mr. Bone said.
A fiber-optic network, he said, will require less cable and will be far superior to the copper cable network that now connects the company's 3.2 million customers. Fiber, he said, can handle thousands of two-way voice, data and video transmissions, compared with hundreds of one-way transmissions that can be made over copper wire. Fiber is easier to install and maintain, provides clearer transmissions, is immune to electromagnetic interference and does not corrode.
Mr. Bone said a "fully fibered network" would provide consumers with unprecedented access to information and entertainment services and would encourage economic development as well.
"If we develop this capability first, there's going to be a rush of information service providers coming here to set up shop," Mr. Bone said. "We're going to be the best test-bed in the world for this stuff."
Among the advantages that a fiber network would offer, he said, is the ability for students to communicate with schools both visually and aurally. A student in a school in Trenton, for example, could participate in a class offered in a school in Woodbridge. And a homebound student could keep up with his class -- even participate in class discussions -- while sitting in his living room.
Mr. Bone said that with fiber optics, residents could have electronic access to libraries and "read" books, complete with photographs and graphics, on video monitors in their homes.
Medical specialists, he said, could read diagnostic tests like CAT scans and MRI's without leaving their offices, and would be able to examine the results of the tests with consulting experts merely by dialing a telephone number.
And consumers, Mr. Bone said, would benefit abundantly from the new technology. For example, grandparents in Toms River would be able to see their grandchildren as well as talk to them through a telephone call. Home shopping would take on a new dimension with buyers and sellers communicating "face to face" though miles away from each other.
And cable television programming, which is now provided by individual cable operators serving specific geographic areas, would be available on an almost unlimited basis, with a viewer in Port Jervis, N.Y., having access to programming from a cable provider in Cape May.
"Some of our adversaries say that we shouldn't be putting fiber out there because consumers don't need it," Mr. Bone said. "But we're going to put fiber out there anyway -- every telephone company in the country is going to put fiber out there anyway. The question is whether we should accelerate it."
Under existing plans, the state's telephone network would be completely converted to fiber by the year 2030. Under the new proposal, New Jersey Bell would accelerate the replacement program -- at an additional cost of $1 billion through 1999 -- and complete the conversion by 2010. The total cost of the accelerated program has not yet been determined by the company.
The linchpin of the New Jersey Bell plan is the passage of pending legislation that would freeze telephone rates at existing levels through 1995. Then, from 1996 through 1999, rate increases would be limited to a percentage of the Consumer Price Index, with a maximum increase of 25 cents a month each year on basic exchange services.
In addition, the legislation would enable the State Board of Regulatory Commissioners to deregulate New Jersey Bell services that the board determines are competitive services, like the Yellow Pages. The legislation would also allow the board to regulate equal access to the Bell system.
"Everybody can say that this new technology investment is going to cause rates to go up, and our answer to that is, No, it won't," Mr. Bone said.
 
New Business Expected
 The investment will be paid for, he said, by retained earnings, growth in existing competitive and regulated services and new business that will be generated as customers take advantage of the new services that will be offered.
"We're betting the ranch on that," Mr. Bone said.
Critics of the company's plan, however, contend that not only is the accelerated conversion to fiber unnecessary, but also it is likely to be paid for by consumers.
"What we are fearful of is a one-wire world," said Nancy Becker, executive director of the New Jersey Cable Television Association, a Trenton-based trade association. "If the telephone company is basically unleashed, that will create the most incredible monopoly the United States has ever seen."
The association, along with other organizations including the New Jersey Press Association in Trenton, the American Association of Retired Persons and the Washington-based Consumer Federation of America, is lobbying legislators to block passage of the telecommunications bill.
 
'Rips Away' Regulation
 "The legislation really rips away 80 years of regulation of local telephone rates," Ms. Becker said. "It gives Bell carte blanche to do virtually anything it wants in terms of deregulated services, which are not defined, and it forces the ratepayer to pay for this speculative infrastructure, which could cost New Jersey telephone subscribers $2 billion to $4 billion."
Ms. Becker said the telephone company's proposal to put high-capacity fiber optics into every house and business was "gold plating" the telecommunications system. "Do people really need a six-lane highway going into their driveways?" she said.
Other concerns about the telecommunications legislation revolve around two issues: Should telephone rates in fact be lower than they are now rather than being frozen, and how will the distinction be made between services that are regulated and those that are not?
Robin Portnoi, an assistant deputy public advocate in the State Division of Rate Counsel, said regulatory officials had to first be able to determine whether New Jersey Bell's costs were decreasing -- as many critics charge -- before they could judge whether a rate freeze was appropriate.
"Rate stability in a declining cost industry is not really beneficial to ratepayers," Ms. Portnoi said.
And deregulating competitive services, Ms. Portnoi said, is not easy. The legislation contains no provision defining the level of competition that must be present before rates can be deregulated, she said, nor does it provide for re-regulating services that cease to be competitive.
 
No House Connections Included
 Another issue that irritates some is that the New Jersey Bell plan does not include actually connecting fiber- optic cables to each house. The company intends to leave the fiber "at the curb" for connection to a house only upon the request of the homeowner.
Rob Stuart, program director of the New Jersey Public Interest Research Group in Trenton, said that this proposal only supported the contention that the majority of people would probably not benefit from the new service.
"Our concern is that consumers will not be seeing any increased services for the initial $1 billion investment and then will have to pay an additional charge to take advantage of the service," Mr. Stuart said.
New Jersey Bell officials acknowledged "a lot of misunderstanding about that issue" and said any charge to connect fiber to a house would be a "modest, nonrecurring charge."
At least part of the reason that New Jersey Bell is having difficulty conveying its message to the public, company officials say, is the fact that among its most ardent critics are newspapers and cable television operators.
"I think it's scandalous," Mr. Bone said, referring to some news media reporting on the plan. "Self-interest is in a very real way distorting some of the coverage of this."
 
Annoyed by Cable TV Ads
 Mr. Bone said he was particularly annoyed by advertisements the telephone company has been running on some cable television stations were immediately being followed by cable station-supported advertising criticizing the plan.
Tom Lancaster, a visiting media specialist at Stockton State College in Pomona, agreed that it was perhaps inappropriate for cable television providers and newspapers to use their access to customers to publicize a position on issues in which they have a stake. "Should the telephone industry start using its medium and call all of its customers to express its point of view?" Mr. Lancaster asked.
But John J. O'Brien, executive director of the New Jersey Press Association, a newspaper trade organization critical of the New Jersey Bell proposal, said he believed that the company had been treated fairly by the press. "I don't agree with the fact that because newspapers are editorializing against it, they are not getting a fair shot in the news columns of the papers," he said.
Frank P. DeJoy, vice president and general manager of Suburban Cablevision in East Orange, said his company was running advertisements immediately after New Jersey Bell ads and felt justified in doing so. "We are not in any way censoring or altering the ads that they send us," Mr. DeJoy said. "And I don't think it's inappropriate to run our ad next to theirs. All we're saying is, Don't rush this through until the public has a chance to understand it."
 
Regulated Monopoly FavoredSeen
 But some experts say consumers might be better served by having a regulated monopoly provide cable programming rather than the individual, geographically protected cable companies.
"The competition should not be among the wires that people screw into the back of their TV sets; the competition should be among the programs that are available on those wires," said Lee Goeller, a Haddonfield telecommunications consultant and author. "The best way to do that is to have a public utility that acts as the delivery vehicle."
Mr. Goeller said the telephone company would be singularly suited to provide video programming, particularly "pay per view" services, through which customers order specific programs for a charge.
"There's one thing the telephone company knows how to do well," Mr. Goeller said. "And that's how to bill things a nickel and dime at a time and still make a profit."

HEADLINE: World Markets;
New Questions About Monetary Union

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
The 12 members of the European Community will meet this week in Maastricht, the Netherlands, for their crucial session on monetary, economic and political union. The task of the delegates will not be made easier by the fact that stock markets in Europe have been falling and the European Monetary System has been under stress because of the weakening American dollar, the rallying German mark and Germany's persistently high interest rates.
The pain in the stock markets, many of which have fallen by 4 to 9 percent recently, and the high interest rates throughout the monetary system are samples of the rough side of monetary and economic union. 
 In the 1980's, as Europe's economies grew, the tough anti-inflation discipline of tying a country's currency to the lead of Germany and its strict Bundesbank caused little pain. But now, as most of Europe is slowing economically and political and economic leaders are thirsting for lower interest rates to spur growth, the Bundesbank is saying no. It is focusing on its own domestic problems of rising inflation and the cost of the unification of the two parts of Germany.
The interest rate gridlock that begins in Frankfurt, the home of the Bundesbank, is raising questions anew about the workability of the European Monetary System.
The E.M.S. has brought some stability to European currencies, even the notoriously volatile British pound, which finally joined the monetary system just over a year ago. The system requires members to keep their currencies within fixed bands, and this has come to mean they generally have to follow the Bundesbank on interest rate policy because the mark is the dominant currency.
But today, some argue, a high price is being paid for this stability. This cost is the economic growth being lost as Germany seeks to use high interest rates to deal with its domestic problems.
In light of the stability provided by the European Monetary System, "I think it certainly does look as if it has worked," said Marcus Grubb, European equity strategist at UBS Phillips & Drew in London.
"But," he added, "the question coming to the front of people's minds is, While it is working in terms of stability, is it working in terms of economic growth? If it works, it could work at the cost of a real growth overkill penalty."
David Gilmore, senior foreign exchange economist at MCM Currency Watch in New York, added, "When economies are sinking and Germany has an inflation problem that keeps interest rates high, that is something they did not build into the equation of the E.M.S."
Despite these complaints, the members of the monetary system are adhering to the E.M.S. discipline because the pain is being passed around. France is proof. It raised interest rates last month, despite its sagging economy, to defend the franc and keep it within its range. Even in Britain, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Norman Lamont, has said repeatedly that he stands ready to do what is necessary to keep the pound, which has been weak recently, in line.
It is because the E.M.S. is working that there is a pall over many stock markets right now. And there is no immediate relief in sight. No one expects the Germans to lower interest rates soon, and there is still a chance of another increase.
The Bundesbank did not increase interest rates at its meeting on Thursday, but it was unlikely that the central bank would make such a move just before the Maastricht meeting, which begins tomorrow. That would have thumbed a German nose at European cooperation just as final agreements are needed to push Europe toward a single currency and full economic integration.
Such a move would have been especially ill-timed because it might have put the British pound under even more pressure, which might have forced the Conservative Government of Prime Minister John Major to raise interest rates just months before he has to call an election, for which the Tories are not in great shape.
Raising German interest rates would hardly be helpful for Mr. Major, the most reluctant leader at Maastricht. The Prime Minister is dogged by doubts about economic and political union and is the target of members of his own party, including the former Prime Minister, Margaret Thatcher, who already says he has gone too far.
But while not raising interest rates now, the Bundesbank did send a signal that the option was still open when it set its 1992 money growth targets a notch below what was expected.
All in all, this has made Mr. Grubb of UBS pessimistic for now and the beginning of next year. "It is not looking good," he said of European stock markets. "There are a lot of risks in equities, and in the the short run there is not any light on the horizon." In fact, he does not expect a significant change until the second quarter of next year.
UBS is taking money out of bonds in countries where interest rates have already fallen, like the United States, and leaving it in cash. And they are advising investors to buy put options on stock markets in Europe; these puts will make money for investors if stock markets fall further.

HEADLINE: Abe Peled's Secret Start-Up at I.B.M.

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
HAWTHORNE, N.Y.
On a hillside here in the heart of I.B.M.'s home territory, Abraham Peled, an I.B.M. computer scientist, is trying to recreate Silicon Valley. To the extent that he succeeds -- or fails -- he will be a bellwether for I.B.M. in carrying out ambitious plans to redefine itself, arrest its declining earnings and bolster its falling market share.
Mr. Peled has taken a small group of engineers and programmers and spawned a start-up company inside the International Business Machines Corporation to create a new computer. Tucked away in a rented building within walking distance of I.B.M.'s computer science research laboratory, the group has worked in secrecy and outside the company's normal channels to translate basic research into a commercial product at a breakneck pace. 
 It is the classic approach of entrepreneurs in California's Silicon Valley, where engineers whose imaginations have been seized by an idea rush to get out a high-tech product that can grow into a billion-dollar company.
The result of Mr. Peled's project is the Power Visualization System, a graphics supercomputer, introduced last summer after a mere two years. Such a short product development cycle is an impressive accomplishment for I.B.M., which is famous for its deliberate ways.
"It used to be said that I.B.M. could come in to a market second and clean up," Mr. Peled said. "That's no longer the case."
The graphics supercomputer is intended to let scientists, engineers and product designers "see" the billions of pieces of data their experiments generate. The system can instantly transform the dry tables of numbers generated by research into striking color images on a computer screen. Automobile designers can view lifelike three-dimensional animations of their newest designs. Scientists can follow visual simulations of complex models, like the ozone hole in the atmosphere over the South Pole.
Mr. Peled is gambling that computer visualization will boom in the 1990's and that when it does, I.B.M. will be ready to grab a large part of the business with the machines, which carry price tags of $600,000 to $2 million each.
For I.B.M., Mr. Peled's experiment is taking on vital significance. It is one of a series of projects now underway to explore whether a revitalized I.B.M. can exploit its legendary research prowess -- a prowess that has won two Nobel prizes in the last decade alone -- to quickly identify new businesses and pioneer markets.
Underscoring the project's importance, last week the new supercomputer was on display at a meeting of I.B.M. international managers at which the company's chairman, John F. Akers, explained a far-reaching decentralization plan meant to make the company competitive again.
When I.B.M. announced the new focus last month, it said the company would redefine itself around flexible units that will move products to market more quickly. It took a significant step in that direction last week, saying that a printer company and its large disk drive business would be separated from the mainframe computer division, freeing them to compete on their own.
The company said last month that it will also slash at least another 20,000 employees next year and take a $3 billion charge in the fourth quarter of 1991.
It's all strong medicine for a company that computer and high-tech experts say still has technology that compares favorably with the best in the world. But these experts agree that I.B.M. has frequently fallen behind the pace of the industry. Small, young companies, like Sun Microsystems, a leading work station manufacturer, have proven far nimbler in recognizing new markets, developing products for them and then capturing large segments of market share.
 
The Lag to Market
 Being late in the work station market is a particular embarrassment because I.B.M. made the basic discoveries needed. RISC, or reduced instruction set computing, for example, was a design that I.B.M. invented in 1975 at nearby Yorktown Heights in a legendary research project headed by the computer scientist John Cocke. But the company didn't introduce a commercially successful RISC computer -- the RS/6000 line -- until last year.
"It has been a definite problem for I.B.M. that R.&D. is so distant from the customer," said John Moussouris, a former I.B.M. scientist who helped pioneer RISC technology and now heads Micro unity Inc., a Silicon Valley start-up that is building an advanced RISC chip. "It was classically true in research that you could start any project you wanted to, but getting something finished was almost an impossibility," he said of his I.B.M. years.
The pace may have been slow, but I.B.M. ruled the computer industry for decades. Beginning in the 1980's, that dominance began to erode as thousands of competitors selling desktop computers and other products expanded markets beyond the traditional corporate data processing centers where I.B.M. had held sway with its giant mainframe computers.
"If you look at the growth in the computer industry between 1980 and 1990 and say, 'Which portion comes from existing base and which portion comes from products that didn't exist in 1980?' more than 50 percent didn't exist," Mr. Peled said.
That fact is now seen as the central lesson that I.B.M. learned from the 80's: It must enter new markets as quickly as possible and with the right product. "We must do our research in the marketplace," Mr. Peled said.
But there is a potential dark side to I.B.M.'s new focus. Could it place too much emphasis on getting quick results from research and in the process emasculate what has been one of the world's finest corporate research organizations?
"I worry that the part of research that will be most affected will be the systems thinkers," said Lewis Branscomb, a professor at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government and a former I.B.M. research director who now serves on I.B.M.'s scientific advisory committee.
Last year, I.B.M. spent $6.5 billion on research and development. About 90 percent of this money went to 30 development laboratories to support the increasingly large commitment required to sustain each new generation of computers and their components, such things as software and peripheral products. But at five laboratories -- in San Jose, Yorktown Heights, Zurich, Tokyo and Haifa, Israel -- the remaining 10 percent of the budget, or about $700 million, is spent on more basic research that can win Nobel prizes and make discoveries that lead to dramatic new high-tech products.
Some researchers, both inside and outside I.B.M., are now asking whether decentralization could weaken the labs as groups like Mr. Peled's team are spun off to do their own thing, perhaps in secrecy.
Inevitably, these skeptics contend, some of the the newly independent units will begin to compete for both funds and talent. The fear is that such competition, making it difficult to justify scientific work that might have no direct payoff for many years, could put spending on basic research at risk.
An often-cited example of what might be lost in such a shift is the discovery of high-temperature superconducting materials made at the Zurich laboratory in 1986. The discovery has created a flurry of research at corporate and academic laboratories around the world and won K. Alex Muller and J. Georg Bednorz the Nobel prize in physics in 1987. But despite its great potential, new products that could generate strong revenues for I.B.M. have yet to appear and are probably years away.
I.B.M.'s top executives vow that the new focus will not be permitted to undermine such basic research. "We want I.B.M. research to be famous for its science and vital to I.B.M.," said Jack D. Kuehler, the company's president and its most senior executive with a technical background.
Still, there is little question I.B.M. must capitalize more quickly on its research, and to do this it has set up a number of projects like Mr. Peled's graphics supercomputer group.
 
Future Ambitions
 For example, last year I.B.M. took several of its researchers in high-speed computer networks and made them the nucleus of a new business group called High Performance Computers and Communications. During the 90's, high-speed network computing is expected to match or even exceed the growth of the personal computer, combining a number of existing disciplines: Computers, telecommunications, information providers and entertainment.
The group's mission is to exploit this potential as quickly as possible. It has recently set up joint ventures with a variety of players, including Rogers Cable of Canada, that country's largest cable television provider; BellSouth, and McGraw Hill.
A third example of using basic research to pursue new markets is the color flat-panel display technology, for which I.B.M. researchers pioneered several materials in research during the early 80's. Few basic technologies have the potential that these brilliant displays do as a replacement for the traditional cathode ray tube screen in a host of portable video and desktop computing devices.
I.B.M.'s strategy here is to build an alliance with Japan's Toshiba Corporation to manufacture the displays, first in Japan and possibly later in the United States. So far, the Japanese have dominated the flat-panel market and I.B.M. hopes the Toshiba connection will give it entree to a market that has eluded venture-capital-backed start-up companies.
I.B.M.'s new graphics supercomputer had its roots in an evening in early 1989 when Abe Peled, vice president of systems and director of computer sciences, had dinner with Ralph Gomory, a mathematician who was then I.B.M.'s vice president of research and who now heads the Sloane Foundation in New York City.
Mr. Peled, a Rumanian who grew up in Israel, earned graduate degrees at Princeton and joined I.B.M. in 1974, expressed his frustration about I.B.M.'s inability to quickly enter new computer markets. He was worried that new projects conceived by his researchers would fail because they stepped on toes in the company's deeply entrenched product divisions. The two hatched the idea of creating a small start-up that would function like a private company and Mr. Gomory took it to I.B.M.'s top executives, who were enthusiastic.
Mr. Peled's lab had two groups of researchers -- one interested in building a supercomputer with multiple processor chips and another that wanted to build a high-performance graphics computer. He convinced the two to combine their efforts and then, with the aid of an outside consultant, studied start-ups. Eventually, I.B.M. committed $25 million.
 
Forget the Riches
 Early on, the toughest issue to resolve was whether engineers and programmers would dedicate themselves to a demanding work schedule over several years -- without the stock incentives that are part of Silicon Valley-style start-ups.
"People were skeptical," Mr. Peled recalled. He said he told his team, "Look, you won't get rich, but you'll feel good for having built something that is out there in the market." I.B.M. researchers bought the concept, in part Mr. Peled said, because most of them work principally for the intellectual challenge, having decided that their first priority is not to get rich.
I.B.M. has sold five of the machines so far, and there have been some pleasing surprises characteristic of start-up companies.
One has been learning about who the likely customers are. As expected, a car company (Honda) and scientific research laboratory (Cornell University) were early buyers. But to the researchers' surprise, a large bank bought a system, too. (I.B.M. declined to identify the bank.) Mr. Peled's group has realized that bankers, stockbrokers and economists also want to quickly visualize complex financial and economic models.
That suggests that the I.B.M. team may have hit upon a broader market than it originally thought, a suggestion the group is hurrying to exploit.
A big question still remains: Can start-ups and other approaches like them take root in a corporation that has a reputation for bureaucracy and being slow off the mark?
Yes, answer senior executives. "Over the last 10 years the world has changed drastically," said James McGroddy, I.B.M.'s director of research. "You have to work higher up on the food chain. More importantly, you need to have your eye on the market."
 
 
 
GETTING IT OUT THE DOOR
 If they were going to rush a new computer to market, I.B.M.'s research scientists knew they also would have to find a new approach to marketing it.
So they asked Amanda Morrow, a veteran I.B.M. marketing executive, to put together a special team to circumvent some of the moribund traditional company sales and marketing channels.
She now runs a five-person marketing group that has far more control over the sales process than is customary at I.B.M. It oversees the entire process -- from submitting a bid to a prospective customer to installing the machine at the customer's site once the sale is made.
Moreover, the team has an unusual sales tool: Abe Peled himself. Like a Silicon Valley start-up C.E.O., Mr. Peled has been making sales calls of late.
Ms. Morrow said that she has found running a marketing organization under one roof to be much more efficient than normal I.B.M. corporate procedure. She is able to approach customers and then take their requests directly to the programmers and developers who designed the system.
"I can get off the phone and walk down the hall and get an immediate answer," she said. "That's something that is frequently not possible elsewhere in the company. The reason I took this job is that I wanted the ability to make a direct connection from research to the customer."
 
THE PRACTICAL BLIND SIDE OF BASIC RESEARCH
 When I.B.M. scientists extoll the unexpected benefits of basic research, they often point to a remarkable device called the scanning tunneling microscope, invented at I.B.M.'s Zurich laboratories in 1982. No one could predict back then that the microscope would now have an important role in flat-panel display research at the company.
The microscope has transformed the work of chemists, physicists and materials scientists. Before the microscope, chemists, for example, would use statistical techniques in an attempt to predict how atoms interact in the formation and behavior of materials. But the scanning tunneling microscope permits the scientists to examine the surface of a material atom by atom and actually see what is occurring.
One day recently, the desk of John H. Boland, an I.B.M. chemist, was covered with photos of what looked like rows of eggs. The eggs actually were the atoms of a semiconductor material Mr. Boland is studying. The photos were made by the microscope.
Mr. Boland's research could lead to making flat-panel computer screens that are brighter and more efficient users of battery power.
"Our basic philosophy is to understand the science at the deepest level we can on an atom-by-atom basis and then push toward product applications," he said. The microscope has shown that much of what scientists thought about the flat-panel materials before they could see them at the atomic level was wrong.
