SECTION: Section 3; Page 17; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1067 words

HEADLINE: Argentina Shops Shares in Its Telephone System

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES

 BODY:
The Argentine Government, hoping to sustain its economic turnaround and hasten its privatization program, went on the road this week to persuade international investors to buy shares in the country's telephone system.
Officials want to capitalize on the global popularity of telephone stocks, especially of Latin American companies. But investors are complaining that Argentina is rushing its deal to market with too high a price and inadequate documentation, leaving them too little time to analyze the company and bid aggressively. 
 The Government sold 60 percent of Telefonica de Argentina, representing half of the nation's service, to an investment group last November, but this is the public's first chance to buy shares. Beginning in Madrid and Minneapolis last Monday and continuing throughout Europe and the United States last week, the lead underwriters, Government officials and officers of the company are presenting their roadshow to pension fund managers, mutual fund companies and other institutions.
Thirty percent of the company will be sold, with shares selling for a minimum price of 16.5 cents to raise at least $600 million. Officials hope that an auction similar to the process of selling United States Treasury securities will push the price above 20 cents a share, or more than $800 million.
In the United States, the shares will be directly available only to large institutional investors; smaller buyers will have to buy them through foreign brokers.
Bankers say this departure from the fixed prices of most initial public offerings could discourage some investors. Moreover, they say, only last Monday did the Government release a prospectus and other documentation on the company's balance sheet. "How can I advise my clients if only today I received the documents," said Gordon Davis, a broker on the Buenos Aires Stock Exchange.
Government officials say the offering must take place as soon as possible. "The probability is that they will not maximize value," said one banker close to the negotiations. "But politically it is extremely important that you do this deal before the end of the year. They need the money, and they need to show a credible deal."
The cash is vital for President Carlos Saul Menem's Government to maintain the kind of budget surplus that international lending organizations like the International Monetary Fund are demanding for the country to prove its fiscal stability and responsibility. Argentina is seeking both a three-year, $3.4 billion loan from the I.M.F. and aid under a United States plan to dramatically cut its $60 billion foreign debt.
The country's Economy Minister, Domingo F. Cavallo, has been widely praised for measures that have dramatically reduced inflation, restrained the printing of money, kept the currency stable for more than six months, collected more taxes and deregulated the economy.
But I.M.F. officials have repeatedly voiced concerns that Argentina is not running a large enough budget surplus and thus depends heavily on the cash from privatizations to meet its obligations. They note that such sales are one-time events that may cover deficits now but not in the future.
Mr. Cavallo argues that much of the proceeds from sales are being used for one-time payments of pension fund obligations of the privatized companies.
Few believe that the first sale of telephone stock will be an outright failure, particularly given an underwriting syndicate led by Morgan Stanley, Bear Stearns, Merrill Lynch and J. P. Morgan.
In Argentina, four of the largest banks -- Banco Roberts, Banco Galicia, Banco Rio de La Plata and Banco Tornquist -- are leading domestic sales. Small investors, buying $5,000 or less, will get a 5 percent discount.
Latin American telephone companies have been hot stocks this year. Telefonos Mexicanos, also called Telmex, issued stock to the public in May at the equivalent of $1.36 a share. The shares have risen 85 percent and have recently been trading at around $2.15. On the New York Stock Exchange, Telmex American Depository Shares, each representing 20 shares of the underlying stock, were originally sold for $27.25 and are now trading at around $43.
"The telephone is an essential tool for almost everybody," said Douglas A. Campbell, president of D. A. Campbell Company, a money management firm in Santa Monica, Calif. " Thus, it is a very stable business, almost like food."
Mr. Campbell added that Latin American phone companies tend to be especially productive cash cows, since most have barely begun to saturate their market. California has 85 telephones for every 100 people, he said, while Latin America generally has fewer than 10.
"You have almost unlimited demand, and all you have to do is keep pumping in telephones," he said. "It has got to be one of the most profitable businesses in the world."
For Argentina, the initial public offering of Telefonica comes a year after the nation sold a controlling interest in its telephone system to private investors. In November 1990, Argentina split its telephone company, Entel, in two, giving each company about half of the nation's population. It sold a 60 percent interest in Telefonica to a group of investors led by Citicorp, Spain's national telephone company and an Argentine industrial group called Techint.
A 60 percent interest in the other company, called Telecom, was sold to a group led by J. P. Morgan, Italy's telephone company, France's telephone company and Perez Companc, an Argentine industrial group.
The combined sales earned the Government $214 million in cash and the right to retire almost $5 billion in debt. It plans to sell 30 percent of both entities to the public, and eventually 10 percent to employees. The Telecom shares are expected to be sold in March.
In its first year, Telefonica earned $113 million, after a one-time charge of $60 million. Telecom, which has a much faster depreciation schedule and thus will tend to report lower profits, earned $53 million.
Mr. Campbell noted that Telefonica, at 16.5 cents a share, has a price-to-earnings ratio of almost 12, equivalent to other major international telephone stocks. "That's no bargain," he said. "It is a very full price."
Mr. Davis, the Buenos Aires broker agreed. "For a good deal, you want to price it a little low so that people want to come back for the second offering next year," he said.

HEADLINE: Making a Difference;
A Two-Year Baptism of Fire at El Paso Electric

 BODY:
Since taking over as chief executive of the troubled El Paso Electric Company two years ago, David H. Wiggs Jr. has become steeped in the ways of crisis control. Last week provided another lesson when the utility, buried under $900 million in debt, flirted with bankruptcy by edging close to a default on a key credit agreement.
Mr. Wiggs managed to buy the company more time when he got creditors, including some 30 banks, to extend a Dec. 1 restructuring deadline to Dec. 16. Analysts think there is a better-than-even chance that the restructuring will win approval before then. 
 Previously the company's outside counsel, Mr. Wiggs, 44, had no management experience when he was tapped to head El Paso Electric. His mandate: straighten out a financial mess resulting from a costly investment in an Arizona nuclear power project and a number of real estate ventures that went sour.
"It's been quite a baptism," Mr. Wiggs said last week.
Nonetheless, analysts give Mr. Wiggs high marks for presenting a workable recovery plan to creditors and regulators alike. He has brought in a new board of directors, trimmed expenses and overseen the liquidation of money-losing diversified enterprises.
Although rate increases have been far less than the company has sought, regulators last month committed to a phased-in, four-year recovery for El Paso Electric's investment in Unit 3 of the Palo Verde Nuclear Generating Station 50 miles west of Phoenix. The utility owns a 15.8 percent stake in Palo Verde's three nuclear plants, which were built in anticipation of far more regional growth than actually materialized.
Mr. Wiggs says a Chapter 11 bankruptcy would not help anyone, mostly because of the uncertainty over whether a Federal judge would have the power to order a rate increase to bail the company out.
The bankruptcy route "just doesn't make sense," Mr. Wiggs said. "We think it's better to have a decent, viable recovery plan."
Indeed, analysts say the formidable cost of bankruptcy, which can tie up creditors' money for years, is what has so far spared the Tucson Electric Power Company, another troubled Southwestern utility, from going under.
What's more, even if a judge could order a revenue increase, a jump in rates could backfire in today's uncertain economy, inhibiting growth in demand in the company's service area, said Edward Tirello, a utility analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.
In time, the current increase in demand of 2.5 percent a year combined with more anticipated power sales to Mexico will put El Paso Electric back on track, Mr. Tirello said, adding that he would like to see Mr. Wiggs stay on after that.
As for Mr. Wiggs, he's taking it one day at a time. "I feel like 44 going on 84," he said.

HEADLINE: Business Diary/December 1-6

BYLINE: By Joel Kurtzman

 BODY:

INTERNATIONAL
 
The Unraveling of Robert Maxwell's Posthumous Empire 

A month after his body was found at sea, Robert Maxwell's media empire is in ruins. Last week, Mr. Maxwell's sons, Ian and Kevin, filed for bankruptcy protection in the British courts for the family's private businesses. The New York Daily News, one of the family's companies, filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy law, and Kevin Maxwell vowed to keep the newspaper alive. Britain's Serious Fraud Office began investigating charges last week that Robert Maxwell illegally drained up to $765 million in Mirror Group P.L.C. pension funds to prop up his ailing businesses. It was also discovered that his private companies borrowed $538 million -- perhaps more -- from the public ones. The tattered empire with its hundreds of subsidiaries is now expected to be sold off. But according to John Talbot, an administrator appointed by the British courts, the assets may be significantly less than the liabilities.
 
 
The Intractable Trade Problem
 
Economists often suffer from a disease called hardening of the categories. No matter what reality says, their paradigms stay the same. Trade is one of those categories. Despite seven years of a cut-rate dollar that was supposed to make American products more attractive, America's trade deficit with Japan has barely budged, though there has been remarkable progress elsewhere. And years of trade talks have not put many American goods on Japanese retail shelves. But while economists urge patience, business people are not optimistic. "The Japanese have built a structure that is completely different from ours," said Arnold Brenner, an executive vice president in charge of the Japanese operations of Motorola Inc. "For an American company, it is always going to be especially tough to break in."
 
 
G.E.'s Alliance With South Korea
 
The General Electric Company has been doing its part lately to bring down the trade balance by exporting jet engines, locomotives and power generators. Last week, it made a deal to sell a $400 million communications satellite to South Korea. The Lucky-Goldstar Business Group has agreed to be a partner in the project. G.E. beat British Aerospace P.L.C. for the contract. But it was not just G.E.'s experience that clinched the deal. It also agreed to transfer technology to its South Korean partners -- a promise that some fear might harm G.E. later.


The Biggest L.B.O.
 
 The collapsing Soviet Union got its own version of a leveraged buyout. Boris N. Yeltsin, the President of Russia, said last week he had reached an agreement with the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, for Russia -- the largest and richest republic -- to assume the central Government's debt and payroll. The power of the purse -- not to mention the fact that most of the republics have broken with Moscow -- elevates Mr. Yeltsin and downgrades Mr. Gorbachev. By taking over the budget, Mr. Yeltsin also gets control of the ruble. That gives him a lever to use to stabilize prices. The downside risk, as with all L.B.O.'s, is whether Mr. Yeltsin can afford to take on so much debt.


Even Japan May Suffer
 
They are not exactly jumping out of windows, but Tokyo's investors are not a happy lot. The Nikkei index of 225 stocks fell more than 1 percent on a single day last week and since March has lost 17.3 percent of its value. Companies are also having trouble raising capital -- unusual in Japan. And some investors fear the English-speaking recession (it's hit America, Britain, Canada and Australia) will soon reach Japan. "They are going into a contractionary period," said Carl Weinberg, chief economist at High Frequency Economics. Japan's rate of growth "will decelerate from 3 to 6 percent to 0 to 3 percent and cause fiscal problems for the Government," he said. That's slow, but not a recession. "What's happening in Japan is what happened here, but from a higher base," Mr. Weinberg said.
 

Salomon Wins Back Confidence
 
Last week, after a three-month suspension, Salomon Brothers Inc. said it had won back the World Bank's business. The Bank, as it is called, is the second-largest borrower in the world's financial markets. Its decision was an indication that Warren E. Buffett, the Omaha investor who is Salomon's interim chairman, was succeeding in making the go-go Wall-Street firm more, well, Midwestern. The California Public Employee Retirement System -- the nation's largest -- is considering rescinding its suspension too. If that happens, Solly's rehabilitation may soon be complete.


Sweden's Monetary Medicine
 
Most of the world considers it a bold move when the Federal Reserve raises or lowers the discount rate a quarter of a percentage point. Not in Sweden. Last week, Sweden's central bank increased the rate it charges banks to borrow to 17.5 percent from 11.5 percent -- a six percentage-point jump.
 
 
 
 
COMPANIES

 
Wanna Buy a Route? In Cash?
 
Last week, after its financing deal with Delta Air Lines unraveled, Pan American World Airlines shut down. The airline had been on the verge of extinction for almost a decade, selling off pieces of itself including its New York terminal and signature headquarters building until all that remained was a small domestic operation and some valuable Latin American and Caribbean routes. The routes will go on sale today. But there is one inhibiting factor. Judge Cornelius Blackshear of the United States Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District in Manhattan insists that all bids for Pan Am's routes be in cash. That's the one commodity in today's airline business that remains in short supply.


Digital Quietly Tends to Business
 
While the International Business Machines Corporation anguishes in public about its future, the Digital Equipment Corporation, the nation's No. 2 computer maker, continues to plod along. Last week, it unveiled four aggressively priced workstations built on a new, superfast RISC chip -- for reduced instruction set technology. And while I.B.M. and the Microsoft Corporation continue to feud, Digital and Microsoft are doing just fine, thank you. Digital's new boxes will run Microsoft's Windows NT, its newest operating system.


The Days of 3.25% Interest
 
For those who love 1950's nostalgia, consider this: Citibank, the nation's No. 1, bank, said last week it will lower the interest rate paid on passbook savings accounts to 3.15 percent from 4.34 percent at its Citibank FSB savings and loan in Chicago. That rate has not been around since Cadillacs had fins and blouses had Peter Pan collars.
 
 
 
ECONOMY

 
Making Room for New Ideas
 
Though John Sununu liked to call himself the Administration's "pit bull," many thought of the White House chief of staff, who resigned last week, as more of the monkey on the President's back. A conservative Republican, he helped fashion President Bush's economic strategy. But even conservatives grew to dislike his ideas. "When faced with economic policy failures, he was incapable of admitting mistakes," said Edwin S. Rubenstein, an economist at the conservative National Review magazine. "Holding to the budget agreement the way he did was a mistake -- hubris." Of the new chief of staff, Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner, Mr. Rubenstein said: "He's tough, not so ideological, but a 'yes' man."


A Sickly G.D.P.
 
The economy is still struggling to rouse itself from its slump. The Commerce Department said last week that gross domestic product expanded by a slim 1.7 percent in the third quarter. G.D.P. measures the total output of goods and services within America's borders. For an economy emerging from recession, growth is typically in the 6 percent range. "Will there be a double-dip recession?" asked Samuel D. Kahan, chief economist at Fuji Securities Inc. "No. We'll have slow growth. But a persuasive case can be made for the other side of the argument."

 
Payrolls Drop; So Do Rates
 
The unemployment rate held steady in November at 6.8 percent, as expected. But payrolls tumbled by nearly 241,000, the second-largest drop of the year. Payroll statistics are considered more accurate. The drop in payrolls raised the Federal Reserve's level of concern about a possible "double-dip" recession; last week it dropped the Federal funds rate, the rate banks charge each other, to 4.5 percent from 4.75.


A Few More Construction Dollars
 
No, it wasn't an aberration. Construction spending rose 1.0 percent in October, the fourth straight monthly gain and part of the longest string of advances in five years, the Commerce Department said. Despite the gain, spending on construction is still below last year's level. The industry "needs an economic stimulus package, and we need it now," said Mark Tipton, president of the National Association of Home Builders.

 
Manufacturing Peters Out
 
For months, the manufacturing sector was the lone horse pulling the nation's economic wagon. Domestic and export sales of manufactured goods grew as the rest of the economy languished. But manufacturing lost its snap in November. The National Association of Purchasing Management, which surveys 300 corporate executives on the size of their order books, said its index fell last month to 50.1, from 53.5 in October. A reading of 55 shows expansion, 50 indicates stagnation and below 44 signals recession. "The economy grew perceptively weaker in November," said Robert Bretz, chairman of the association's survey committee.


Detroit Is Quick to Rejoice
 
Ten days of improved sales is not enough to signal an industrywide turnaround. Even so, the numbers sure looked good to Detroit. Sales of domestically built cars and light trucks climbed 20.9 percent in late November, the auto makers said last week. Sales to rental fleets pushed the sales figures higher. Though sales for the entire month were down, Detroit did win back some business from the Japanese. Detroit had 62.3 percent of the market last month, compared with 60.1 percent a year earlier. But before Detroit uncorks the champagne, it should recall that in the 1970's, the General Motors Corporation had 60 percent of the market all to itself.

HEADLINE: All About/Baby Products;
Smaller Families Perhaps, but So Much More to Buy

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER

 BODY:
This is not your parents' baby boom. They bought cribs and strollers from Sears Roebuck; today's new parents might spend up to $3,000 on their newborns for everything from backpacks to electronic monitors. Increasingly, the emphasis is practical -- safety, function and good design.
Fueled by a mini-baby boom, sales of products aimed at newborns to 2-year-olds hit $2.45 billion in 1990, up 8 percent from $2.25 billion the year before, according to the Juvenile Products Manufacturers Association, a trade group in Marlton, N.J. And that is not counting clothing, toys or disposable diapers. 
 The birth rate actually declined slightly in the first six months of this year, after five years of steady increases. But most demographers say the decline is temporary, due to the effects of the recession, and baby-gear makers say they expect sales growth to continue once the recession ends.
"The business has grown dramatically, not just because of the number of births, but because of the amount of new products," said Shirley Pepys, the trade group's president and also president of Noel Joanna Inc., a maker of children's bedding and accessories based in Rancho Santa Margarita, Calif. "New parents are open to anything and if you told them they needed 150 new products, they'd probably buy them."
Style plays a bigger role than ever in baby products, but so does safety, industry leaders say. And while 30-something parents are skeptical of gimmicks, they are looking for innovative products that can make life easier for working parents. Many of these products come from new companies formed by parents turned entrepreneurs.
Fewer children are being born than during the 1950's and 60's, "but people are spending more per child," said Alise Kreditor, a marketing consultant based in Great Neck, L.I., who works with baby products companies. "Parents are more informed and are making better choices," she said, noting that the more outlandish products -- like designer car seats -- are not selling well.

 
 
The 'Perfect' Nursery
Exotic-Wood Cribs And Baby Bedding
 Decorating a baby's room used to be a bit like buying a car from Henry Ford; you could have any color you liked as long as it was pastel pink or blue. No more. Fashion has entered every segment of the market.
"It's very important how you decorate your nursery and a lot of money is spent on decorating that room," said Ms. Pepys of Noel Joanna, which sells wildly colored and patterned sheets, quilts and matching lamps.
Fashion baby bedding "is a huge business in the United States that came out of nowhere," said John Moeller, president of the Simmons Juvenile Products Company in New London, Wisc., which added bedding to its line of cribs recently.
Style is also a deciding factor for parents buying a $500 crib instead of a $99 model, when both meet the same safety standards, Mr. Moeller said. While cribs all used to be finished in the same maple color stain, now they come in white, cherry, natural, washed finishes and even exotic hardwoods. Despite the recession, "some of our best-selling cribs continue to be the most expensive," he said.
 
 
 
New Entrepreneurs
Parents Put Their Insights to Work
 One factor fostering the growth of new products is the entrepreneurial nature of today's new parents. Many new items, like training pants that open up at the sides, are the result of new mothers or fathers creating solutions to their own problems and in the process creating new marketing niches.
"People are innovative -- many products are born of people being new parents," said Ms. Pepys of the Juvenile Products Manufacturers. "The more babies born, the more entrepreneurs," she said.
One new mother who started a profitable business is Ruth Wimmer, president of Wimmer-Ferguson Child Products Inc. in Denver. A former nurse on a neonatal ward, Ms. Wimmer saw a need for an object that would stimulate and hold the interest of newborns. The result was the Stim-mobile, which dangles five disks with simple, high-contrast black-and-white patterns above the infant.
"I had a child and designed the mobile for her," said Ms. Wimmer. "I had been reading the research on early visual development. Health care professionals all knew about the research on contrast."
Initially, those health care professionals and parent educators were the target market. Now the Stim-mobile is sold in baby specialty stores and catalogues.Wimmer-Ferguson has expanded the line to include soft cards and squeezable toys with the same patterns. Research showed that babies like to recognize the familiar in new objects.
"I've been careful to stay close to the research; too many baby products are just cute," said Ms. Wimmer. She and her husband, Allan Ferguson, who handles marketing, have also kept the line relatively narrow. "Babies don't need that many toys; they need a few good ones," she said.

 
 
For Too-Busy Parents
Specialty Catalogues Offer Convenience
 For mothers turned entrepreneurs, like Ms. Wimmer, the baby specialty catalogues are often the fastest route to a broad market. With names like Right Start, Hand in Hand, and One Step Ahead, the catalogues seek out new and innovative products and refresh their offerings often to stay a step ahead of mass merchandisers and chain stores. For baby boomers used to Land's End or J. Crew, the catalogues are a natural source.
"Working moms and dads trying to incorporate a baby into an already hectic life style don't have time to do comparison shopping," said Karen Scott, president of One Step Ahead in Deerfield, Ill. That's where Ms. Scott and her mothers panel come in. They screen hundreds of products each month; less than 10 percent end up in the catalogue.
"We actually see what happens in the household," said Ms. Scott, a former marketing executive with Kraft, turned new mother, turned entrepreneur. "I think parents are getting fussier," she said. "They are not afraid to spend money, but they don't want to spend it foolishly." These parents are looking for products that meet real needs. "The days of just introducing a new bunny pattern are over," he said.
In addition to products aimed specifically at newborns, like the Stim-mobile, Ms. Scott said she has seen the greatest innovation in accessories to make travel with an infant easier, and to make the home and car a safer environment for children. But innovation can go too far. Ms. Scott said an electronic voice-activated crib -- it rocked when the baby cried -- has been dropped from the catalogue.
It put the baby to sleep "in about 75 percent of cases," she said. "But if you were in the 25 percent quadrant you weren't too pleased. It was a bit of overkill."
 
 
 
SELLING SAFETY TO WORRIED PARENTS

Product safety has always been a concern in the nursery. But today, with the media focusing more attention on childhood hazards, safety is a selling point.
"On the anxiety scale, worry about one's children and their safety ranks very high -- that's why safety sells so well," said David Markus, editor of Parenting magazine. "Every article about the accidental death of a child has a ripple effect."
In 1989, more than one million American children age 4 and younger were injured at home seriously enough to require emergency-room care. Many such injuries can be avoided if parents take some simple steps, experts say. An ever-broader array of items is available to help.
Safety items are a big portion of the One Step Ahead catalog, which specializes in innovative products from small companies. "Just in the past six months, safety products have started to provide a really important capacity to improve the odds against children getting hurt," said Karen Scott, One Step Ahead's president.
Ms. Scott praises a vinyl-cushioned bumper guard that fits around the perimeter of coffee tables as "not high tech but ingenious," and a fire-resistant blanket developed by the Monsanto Company, with a special fiber structure, rather than a potentially toxic chemical retardant. And there is an auto safety vest that hooks into the shoulder harness; it promises greater protection against whiplash than a booster seat.
Michael Lerner, who introduced the once-ubiquitous "Baby on Board" sign in 1984 after buying the idea from a friend, has turned child safety into an entire business. Safety 1st Inc., based in Chestnut Hill, Mass., now has 115 products, which are sold in chain stores and baby specialty shops. These range from simple items, like electric outlet covers, to elaborate ones, like a swivel bath chair.
"Parents are more safety conscious than ever before," said Mr. Lerner, Safety 1st's president. He cites working parents as a factor. "Because they don't have as much time to spend with their children, they tend to zero in on health and safety benefits."
Safety is also a big factor in crib sales. More-stringent safety standards -- like narrower spacing of the slats -- introduced in the last 20 years make a new crib a more prudent purchase than a hand-me-down.
"If you buy a crib made before 1990, you're taking an unnecessary risk with your child," said John Moeller, president of Simmons Juvenile Products. A crib "is the one juvenile product designed for the child to be left unattended in," he said. "For the price of a crib, it's almost irresponsible to risk a baby."

HEADLINE: Cloning Casinos With Appeal for the Masses

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS

 BODY:
When William G. Bennett and a partner scraped together $4 million to buy the money-losing Circus Circus hotel and casino here in May 1974, they were convinced that, by applying financial discipline and some marketing flair, they could turn the operation around quickly. It took them all of one month.
"We made a large profit in June and never looked back," said Mr. Bennett, chairman and chief executive. Over the last 17 years, in fact, Mr. Bennett has built Circus Circus Enterprises Inc. into one of the gaming industry's largest and most profitable companies. Its seven Las Vegas casinos netted $84.3 million on sales of $618.5 million in the nine months ended Oct. 31. 
 The company's success, analysts and industry executives say, has also helped change the way casinos approach their business. Mr. Bennett was among the first to branch out beyond high rollers and hard-core gamblers to woo the masses -- what the company refers to as "the middle-income tourist and player" or "middle America" -- with rock-bottom room rates and meal prices.
He was also among the first to recognize the importance of transforming Las Vegas into an entertainment center for all ages. Starting with the flagship property, which, as its name suggests, offers big-top acts along with slot machines, Mr. Bennett has gradually moved toward building properties that owe more to Disneyland than to the shady origins of gaming in Nevada. His largest casino, the Excalibur, is a pseudo-medieval castle, complete with jousting knights in armor, whose 4,000 rooms have been almost constantly booked since the opening last year.
"Circus is clearly the leader in its industry and extremely well run," said Mark Manson, an analyst at Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette Securities in New York. "Their basic concept, that a casino is an entertainment mega-store, is an idea whose time came at about the time they began to exploit it. They've also shown discipline in sticking to their market niche."
Despite a recession that has depressed results for all gaming companies, Circus is now planning to build another casino adjacent to the Excalibur. The property, known at Project X, is to open in less than two years and will center on a 30-story pyramid that any pharaoh would be proud of. It will have a science fiction theme, including "spaceship" elevators and Disney-like rides.
Once a business of entrepreneurs who would throw up a boxy hotel around a dimly lit casino, the industry today increasingly revolves around a handful of large, well-financed corporations with resort-like projects that require huge investments.
"This is part of a long evolution that has Las Vegas becoming the Orlando of the West," said Daniel R. Lee, an analyst at the First Boston Corporation in Boston.
Analysts believe that tourism here will continue to expand steadily -- albeit somewhat more slowly than in the last decade. Still, the casino companies face a certain risk that Las Vegas is becoming as overbuilt as Atlantic City.
At a cost of about $290 million, Project X is the third lavish new project to be announced in Las Vegas in the last several months. Mirage Resorts Inc., formerly Golden Nugget Inc., is planning a $300 million project called Treasure Island and MGM Grand Inc. recently broke ground on a project designed to be equal parts theme park and casino.
Those projects come on top of a huge building boom here in the last several years. Top-ranking casinos like Caesars World Inc.'s Caesars Palace have been undergoing expansions and refurbishments.
And new resorts like Excalibur and the Mirage have largely forced that sort of investment by continuing to establish new standards of flashiness -- the Mirage's smoke-belching volcano, for example. So far, the losers have been older properties, like the privately held Dunes and Aladdin hotels, whose owners have not had the money to remain competitive.
For the 66-year-old Mr. Bennett, building an entertainment powerhouse was not at all in the career plan. He was a Navy pilot in World War II and planned to become an aeronautical engineer -- his passion to this day is flying model airplanes. Instead, he became a furniture salesman. By 1960, he owned a 10-store chain in California and Arizona, but within a decade lost it to a bad recession in the region and went to work for Del Webb Inc., a land developer and casino operator. "In my life, I never saw such waste and mismanagement," Mr. Bennett said. "The retail business is a tough business, and it was easy for me to apply some of that discipline to the gaming business."
Within five years, he headed Webb's operations in Nevada, but he and a friend, William N. Pennington, were looking to go out on their own. After acquiring and turning around the Circus Circus casino in Las Vegas, the company quickly, added rooms and casino space to the existing property and opened similar projects in Reno and Laughlin, Nev.
Mr. Bennett's enduring notion was that there was far more profit in offering a good value to a wide market than in competing for the serious gamblers. To him, there was no shame in running a casino whose parking lot was filled with recreational vehicles carrying two-bit gamblers; Circus Circus welcomed the RVs with open arms, building a special lot with power hookups for them.
Those two-bit players, as it turned out, just kept dropping quarter after quarter into the slot machines -- in volumes that the rest of the industry and Wall Street finally discovered when the company went public in 1983.
"I don't want to brag about what we did, because in some cases we did some really silly things, but we changed this business when we went public," Mr. Bennett said. "People knew we were doing well, but until then nobody knew how well. Once they found out, everyone went after the so-called family business, and that is continuing."
The company's success has richly rewarded its shareholders, notably the founders, who have seen the stock price go from an initial price of $4 a share to a high of $41 earlier this year. The damage of the recession has since pushed the stock to the low-$30 range. According to the company's most recent proxy statements, Mr. Bennett retains nearly 2.6 million shares, or 9.4 percent of the company, worth $83 million at current prices.
Mr. Pennington, Mr. Bennett's original partner, retired as president of the company three years ago at the age of 65. Mr. Bennett had also planned to retire early in 1992, but abruptly changed his mind earlier this year, saying he wanted to stay on to oversee Project X. His decision prompted the immediate resignation, with no new job, of the man who had been slated to replace him, Richard P. Banis, Circus Circus's president, who is widely respected as one of the industry's most skilled executives.
Some analysts wonder whether it was not time for Mr. Bennett to step aside. On the other hand, they say, it is hard to quarrel with Mr. Bennett's leadership. The company has what analysts consider the strongest balance sheet in the industry. Circus Circus has the only investment-grade debt rating of any pure gaming company. (Hilton, which has both gaming and hotel properties, is also investment grade.) Glenn Schaeffer, Circus Circus's new president, said the company is capable of financing all of Project X from its internal cash flow of $150 million a year.
Assuming Project X comes off on schedule and on budget, Circus Circus seems to have strong prospects for growth at least for the next several years, according to analysts. After that, Mr. Bennett said, the company is looking at Atlantic City as a possibility for expansion, despite his dislike of New Jersey's current regulatory and tax policies.
Beyond that, Mr. Bennett said, legalized gaming is expanding rapidly into new areas. There is considerable interest in casinos in the Midwest, he said. It is an opportunity that would clearly appeal to a company built on middle America.
 
 
 
A TWO-BIT ROAD TO PROFIT-BUILDING
 Circus Circus's strategy is built around keeping its costs low and its casinos full. In building the Excalibur, for example, the company spent less than $300 million, not even half what Mirage Resorts Inc. spent to build the ritzier but smaller Mirage, the other big new casino in Las Vegas. Excalibur does not have a volcano or a dolphin pool, as does the Mirage. But its room rates -- currently as low as $28 on week nights, less than half the Mirage's cheapest rate -- keep it consistently more than 90 percent full.
The showplace atmosphere the company tries to create by filling the Excalibur with strolling minstrels, magic shows, arcade games and the like also help attract hordes of people from other hotels. Likewise, a $2.99 buffet is a lure. The company's goal is not to make money on rooms or meals -- and it does not. It simply wants to mobs of people, on the theory that almost all of them will ultimately gamble.
"The casino remains the primary profit engine," said Glenn Schaeffer, the company's president.
The company's core middle-class clientele tends to wager heavily on slot machines, which, not being labor-intensive, generally are more profitable than table games. In 1990, operating profit as a percent of revenue at the Circus Circus casino was 27.5 percent, compared with 16.7 percent at the Strip at Caesars Palace, a favorite of the high rollers.
"When people walk past slot machines," said Robert Maxey, who is heading MGM Grand's new theme park and casino under construction across the street from the Excalibur, "a certain portion of their disposable income gets left behind."

HEADLINE: Managing;
Don't Forget the White Males

SERIES: Third of three articles on retaining employees.

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
NANCY GHEEN, the director of human resources at the Monsanto Company, is sure that white men at the company are never denied promotions in favor of less-qualified women or minorities. But she's having a hard time getting white men to believe that.
"They don't notice when six white guys get promoted," she said. "They notice the one black, or the woman, and they say, 'These are the only folks getting ahead.' Sometimes I have to physically drag them to the bulletin board to prove it's not so." 
 Rightly or wrongly, a great many white men feel that their careers are on hold. They complain that rampant downsizing and the push to eliminate layers of management have reduced the number of high-level jobs available, and that blacks and women are promoted over their heads to fill even those.
Although there has been no mass exodus of white men from the laboratories or managerial corridors in response, many human resources experts are worrying that there will be the minute the economy picks up. In exit interviews and surveys, they have sought clues to what might instill loyalty in white male employees in better economic times.
The conclusion most have drawn is that white men, much like their black and female colleagues, will settle for nothing less than a chance to get ahead on the basis of talent. Thus, companies are seeking color- and gender-blind ways to identify people who should be put on the fast track and to keep them happy if gridlock temporarily takes hold.
"Good working conditions and benefits will hold workers, but only career pathing will keep managers and professionals," said Laurence J. Stybel, head of the Boston consulting firm of Stybel, Peabody & Associates.
Since management jobs rarely open up on cue, some companies are setting up mechanisms to constantly remind people that, while they haven't been promoted, they have not been deliberately sidelined.
Last year, S C Johnson Wax designated about 25 people -- a mix of white and black, men and women -- as officer material. Each got an executive as a personal sponsor and a list of jobs that they should try to have sometime in the next 15 years. "This way, they have a career path to shoot at, and a coach who makes sure they don't get lost in the shuffle," said Gayle P. Kosterman, a divisional vice president of human resources.
The Computer Sciences Corporation's Integrated Systems Division in Moorestown, N.J., cites a similar rationale for beefing up training and management meetings for its designated hitters. It has made several of its technical hotshots deputy project managers, so that they can learn skills that will enable them to manage a project themself, if a suitable one comes in. And it picks about seven mid-level managers every year who have demonstrated promise, tells them they are fast tracked and sets up a series of meetings between them and various vice presidents whom they would otherwise be unlikely to meet in the course of their work.
"We're trying to give our best people the feeling that, even if they're not immediately promoted, high-level people are interested in them and their progress," said Thomas J. Smith, vice president of human resources.
E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company is struggling to convey that feeling to everyone in its far-flung empire of 140,000 employees. This year it started an international "Valuing People" program that aims to combat stereotypes -- including those plaguing white men -- and to help all employees develop satisfying careers. "Yes, we still have affirmative action goals, but we don't want our white men to feel like an endangered species," said Faith A. Wohl, a director of human resources.
Maintaining a sense of evenhandedness is particularly important if a company is abolishing more jobs than it is creating. The American Telephone and Telegraph Corporation recently noticed that too many people, including many white men, were quitting soon after the company had paid for them to get advanced degrees. "They felt we don't give them opportunities to use their new skills," said Ruthann Prang, a human resources strategy manager.
In response, A.T.& T. set up a data system that enables all management employees to call up details about internal job openings via their personal computers. And starting this year, the company's college recruiters will consider A.T.& T.'s own new graduates for jobs that require degrees. "We've got to get them thinking that A.T.& T. really is a place they can build a career," Ms. Prang said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Thomas J. Smith of the Computer Sciences Corporation lets people know they're on the fast track. (Laura Pedrick for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CAMPUS LIFE: Middlebury;
Seminar Strives To Give Students Economic Insights

DATELINE: MIDDLEBURY, Vt.

 BODY:
Far off the beaten flight path linking Washington, New York and Boston, Middlebury College has never been a mecca for economists, captains of industry or Federal policy makers. Now, however, 25 economic experts are trekking to this rural New England college to instruct 30 students in the realities of applied economics.
"We're trying to address the gap between theory and policy," said J. Dewey Daane, a former governor of the Federal Reserve Board, professor emeritus of finance at Vanderbilt University and the inaugural holder of Middlebury's Alan R. Holmes Chair in economics. 
 The site of this bridge-building is a seminar titled "Monetary Policy and Financial Institutions." Taught by Professor Daane and Joanna Wayland Woos, an economics professor, the semester-long course presents juniors and seniors with no-holds-barred accounts of how the Federal Reserve fors its policies and how those policies work in the business world.
 
Fostered by Friendship
 Speakers have an opportunity to meet with Professor Daane, a former colleague of some and authority figure to many, and to honor Alan R. Holmes, who worked for the Federal Reserve Bank of New York from 1948 to 1981, eventually running the bank's domestic and trading operations.
"All of these people came out of their friendship for Dewey Daane or Alan Holmes, and the chance to see Middlebury College," said Sidney L. Jones, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for economic policy.
After Mr. Holmes died in 1982, Robert Jones, former president of MMS International in San Francisco, which provides financial and economic information to businesses, and Middlebury's class of '59, established the $1.85 million chair in Mr. Holmes's name.
"Holmes epitomizes the ideal Fed career person," Professor Woos said. "He was a diplomat, an economist, and savvy on the politics of his era. He was profoundly respected in his field."
The speaker list is impressive, including Sidney Jones, the Treasury official; Dennis Weatherstone, chairman of J. P. Morgan & Company; Paul A. Volcker, former chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, and Margaret Greene, senior vice president of the foreign exchange department of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, as well as a selection of senior business executives from around the nation.
So far, their messages have been eclectic and sometimes surprising. Early in the semester, for example, Mr. Volcker urged students to pursue careers in Civil Service, arguing that a higher standard of professionalism would restore the public's trust in government.
More recently Mr. Jones from the Treasury told the class: "The economy is experiencing moderate growth, but it is different from what most people are used to after a recession. The Administration has repeatedly emphasized that this will be a moderate, cyclical expansion."
Regarding that assessment, Eric Wellmann, a senior majoring in German and economics from Stoneham, Mass., said, "His optimism seemed uniquely high and perhaps out of line with the predictions of the private Fed watchers whom we've heard from, such as David Jones from Aubrey Lanston & Company."
 
'A Better Understanding'
 In a recent interview, Professor Daane said that when he accepted the position at Middlebury last year, he resolved to put students in touch with the men and women who make economic policy or must live with it.
"Students," Professor Woos said, "will come out of this course with a better understanding of the technical complexity of real policy making than some grad students have."
"What we're getting is monetary policy through the eyes of the practitioner," said John Waldron, a senior in English from Bryn Mawr, Pa. "In this class we take a graph relationship from the textbook and put it into real terms."

HEADLINE: In Hard Times, Helping Hands for New York's Neediest Cases;
So a Crying Child May Someday Smile: In a Cold World, Hope Means Helping

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

 BODY:
"Leave me alone," is the refrain of this holiday season. "It's tough all over."
And so it is. People cling to jobs by their fingernails, forego presents and plans, try to scrape by. It is a dim Hannukah, a hard-candy Christmas, an unhappy New Year. "If one more smelly bum sticks his face too close to mine and demands just a dollar . . ." 
 There seems no horror cruel enough to break through the calluses. Underneath the new snow Friday morning, on some park benches one noticed the outline of bodies. People. What is it like to sleep beneath a frozen blanket? It became almost an intellectual question; there was neither time nor inclination to ponder how a life might come to this.
 
Looking Ahead
 Then, something happened that hit home. It happened on a southbound platform in the Times Square subway station. A man stumbled off a car, a little girl beside him. Both wore shabby, soiled clothes.
She had a slight, expectant smile. Suddenly, he slapped her face with the back of his hand. She flinched, looked at him incredulously, seeming to hope against hope that all this was not so. His -- her father's? -- lips curled in a grimace.
An observer felt he knew all he needed to know about the girl's past and future. Some hurts heal and some don't and this instant in the unwritten history of the world was not pretty. It broke your heart. It really did.
It would be a miracle if the little girl were somehow, sometime helped by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, which is conducting its 80th annual appeal. But hundreds of others whom life is trying to crush will surely be helped. There are children without limbs or love or hope, immigrants to this too harsh promised land who live a dozen to a room, Holocaust survivors who dwell alone in the shadows of a dying century, people for whom a bed of their own is an immense dream.
Things are as they were when Adolph S. Ochs, then the publisher of The New York Times, began the fund in 1911 after he was moved by a single beggar to whom he gave a few dollars. The initial campaign began with a depressing description of society, one that has changed little. It spoke of "a world of famine in the midst of plenty; of cruel heart and body hunger with bounty in sight but not in reach."
Truth to tell, things may be worse now. Poverty is deepening in this city even as people become inured to seeing it. The Community Service Society, a private group which keeps track of the needy, reports that New York City's poor population, as defined by Federal guidelines, is now nearly 2 million. Almost one in four New Yorkers is poor.
Not only have the number of poor grown, but the poor have become poorer, the society says. More of the poor are below 75 percent of the poverty threshold, defined in 1990 as $13,360 for a family of four.
All this has greatly strained governments' ability to help. By last count, the city's public assistance caseload reached 937,000, up 77,000 from a year earlier. By next June, city officials project the welfare caseload will climb to an all-time high of 988,000.
The impact of this increase in poverty, the Community Service Society says, is pervasive. Jumps in the incidence of infant mortality, child abuse, homelessness and death rates from liver and other diseases all seem, at least partly, a result of the worsening economic clime. Meanwhile, the city continues to lose jobs in the manufacturing sector, where the unskilled and semi-skilled are most likely to be employed.
These statistics might be persuasive if they were not just statistics. Numbers blur into numbers. And the fact is that the poor cannot speak for themselves. Says the Book of Ecclesiastes, "The poor man's wisdom is despised, and his words are not heard."
For 80 years, the hallmark of the Neediest Cases Fund is that it has given voice to people otherwise too weak, too immersed in their suffering, to be heard. It has expressed the eloquence of their words and lives in case studies like those that will be printed here.
Indeed, it is the needy themselves who have given the more affluent the chance to answer the challenge of Samuel Johnson: "A decent provision for the poor is the true test of civilization," he told Boswell.
 
A Home Is Found
 Certainly, these are sad stories, but just as surely there can be happy endings. Alberto, who has been quadriplegic, blind and profoundly retarded from birth, spent his first years of life in a hospital. The Children's Aid Society brought him to a new program to help these "medical foster boarder babies." The end result is that a foster mother was found, who fell in love with Alberto, who is now 5, and is in the process of adopting him.
Some of the stories grip precisely because they are so human-scale. Mrs. D. is a formerly homeless parent with two children. She needed orthopedic shoes for her 12-year-old daughter who will have to undergo foot surgery when she is older. But their $145 cost was a stretch for Mrs. D., who had just begun a new job. The Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, with the help of the Neediest Cases Fund, paid the bill and made a Christmas.
Sometimes timing is the key thing. Roberta N. found herself divorced at age 56 and living alone in an apartment she could not afford. As if that were not enough, she had become estranged from one of her sons who refused to let her see her grandchildren. Westchester Jewish Community Services -- an agency of the United Jewish Appeal-Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York, Inc. -- stepped in and arranged counseling, and is helping her go back to school and find housing.
"She has a renewed interest in herself, a strong sense of determination and greater self-confidence in her actions and ideas," an agency official said.
 
After Calamity
 There are, of course, real horror stories. The Metropolitan New York Coordinating Council on Jewish Poverty, another U.J.A.-Federation agency, is helping a mother and son who lived through hell shortly after arriving in Brooklyn from their native Georgia in the Soviet Union.
A band of hooligans broke into their apartment in April 1990. They tormented the family with anti-Semitic insults and tortured them with a hot iron and with gas from a stove which they fed into an enclosed room. Then they strangled the father to death, leaving the 51-year-old mother and 19-year-old son alone. The Jewish poverty group is helping with rent and in job-hunting.
Ultimately, the Neediest Cases gives New Yorkers a chance to participate, in however small a way, in helping ameliorate the terrors and sadnesses that seem so omnipresent.
Take the little girl who was slapped by her father in the subway. The Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service stepped in and helped a family that seemed much like that. A mother named Juanita had her three children taken away and placed in foster care because she was discovered to be using excessive corporal punishment.
 
Together, Trying
 She was given intensive individual and group counseling, a 15-week course in parenting skills and gained a high school equivalency diploma. Now, Juanita has her children back and is well on the way to completing a nursing degree. She has learned that hitting her children solves nothing, and the family together attends biweekly therapy sessions.
So can battered and bewildered New Yorkers make a difference in how the city's frailest, most marginal citizens fare? If they do not try, in however limited a fashion, the answer is surely no.
Last year, 15,580 individuals and organizations said yes by contributing $4,439,093.47 to the Neediest Cases Fund.

HEADLINE: In Hard Times, Helping Hands for New York's Neediest Cases;
A Question A Mother Has Feared

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ

 BODY:
A few weeks ago Lillian O. abruptly pulled her daughter off the bus after the 7-year-old pointed to an AIDS poster and asked, loudly, if that was why her mother was sick so often.
It was a few days after Earvin (Magic) Johnson had announced that he was infected with H.I.V. The child's second-grade class had spent hours discussing his future, and their teacher had said that Magic was going to die. 
 On the bus, Lillian's daughter wanted to know whether her mother also was going to die. It was a conversation Lillian had spent a long time preparing for, but she still was not quite ready.
"I panicked," said Lillian. "It felt like everyone on the bus was staring at me. I lied. I told her I didn't have AIDS. And I told her not to shout on the bus."
 
A Year Later
 Later that evening, however, she admitted to the girl that she has the disease, though she cushioned the blow by saying that Magic Johnson still has a long time to live. Her daughter was silent as she heard the news; Lillian is still not sure how she is taking it.
Just under a year ago, in an interview for The New York Times Neediest Cases drive, Lillian, a 31-year-old former heroin addict, had talked about her health, her child and the help they had both been receiving from the Children's Aid Society, one of the seven charities affiliated with the appeal.
The months since then have seen some small victories -- Lillian has learned to take better care of herself, has made progress controlling her temper, has become more open about her condition and has learned, with her daughter, to swim.
But her health has continued to decline. Lillian's high cheekbones have become more prominent, her dark brown eyes more deepset and her round face slightly gaunt. The AZT medication, she said, is "not doing anything any more." Her T-cell count -- an important indicator of one's resistance to the virus -- have dropped dangerously low.
She is no longer able to take advantage of some of the assistance arranged by the Society -- illness forced her to drop out of the college classes in social work she had begun.
Other services, however, have become even more important -- like the counseling she and her daughter receive at Frederick Douglass Mental Health Clinic, a branch of the Children's Aid Society, several times a week.
Last year, Lillian said she often found herself so depressed that it was difficult to move. She had just started talking to her daughter about how "Mommy is going to die some day," but could not bring herself to mention the word AIDS.
Since then, Lillian has received $1,475 from the Neediest Cases through the clinic. The money has paid for her daughter's tuition to a special summer program for gifted children, and gave Lillian much-needed free time to rest. The money also bought the little girl a swimsuit, goggles and summer clothes, and it helped pay for two semesters of social work school for Lillian, where she maintained a "B" average.
 
Help in Being Brave
 Most importantly, the assistance from the Children's Aid Society and the Neediest Cases has allowed Lillian to be brave, to confront her illness and to overcome the prejudices that are linked to the disease.
There was a dentist who practically threw her out of his office when he discovered she has AIDS. And a school administrator asked her to leave the swimming pool area, fearing that she would give the disease to the children. Her mother nervously double-checked that they were not sharing a glass.
But in recent months, Lillian has begun to attend meetings of a support group at the Hispanic AIDS Forum, visit AIDS victims at hospitals and talk to school groups about the disease.
Lillian still insists on walking her daughter to school every morning, but now in the afternoons she tells her daughter to play with her father. (He is unemployed, she said, unable to work because of heart disease.) And she lets him do more of the chores, though she still cooks dinner.
"For a while she was mad with me," Lillian said. "She told me to get a home attendant so that she would have someone who could carry her bicycle downstairs. She would ignore me and say that she was going to play with Daddy. It used to make me feel jealous, but now, I think she understands I need to rest, and it makes me happy to see them playing together.
"I'm glad that I'm taking care of business now," she said. "There are times that I can't see very far ahead, but I feel more secure."

HEADLINE: CAMPUS LIFE: Iowa State;
Despite Protests, Buyers Are Sought For TV Station

DATELINE: AMES, Iowa

 BODY:
Despite a soft market and opposition from some journalism faculty members and students, Iowa State University's commercially run television station has been put up for sale.
The Iowa Board of Regents, which runs the three universities in the state, decided to seek buyers for WOI-TV, an ABC affiliate, after the Iowa State president, Martin Jischke, recommended in September that it be sold. 
 The university last week chose a broker, Ted Hepburn Company of Palm Beach, Fla., to work with potential buyers of the station, which is one of only two university-owned commercial stations in the nation. The Regents said they would consider offers at their meeting in February 1992.
In his report to the Regents, Mr. Jischke said the station's steadily declining profits had decreased cash distributions to the university, which have been used to support Iowa State's biotechnology program.
Mr. Jischke said he based his recommendation to sell the station largely on a 1986 report by the Denver consulting firm of Bortz & Company, which said that investing proceeds from a sale would bring more income to the university than ownership.
The station is reportedly worth $10 million to $15 million, said Ted Hepburn, the broker. He said it would have been double that four years ago. "Right now, we're in the doldrums," he said. "It's gloom and doom."
Still, Mr. Jischke said that now was the time to sell. "No one could assure me with any certainty that values would go up," he said.
Although Mr. Jischke said in an interview that his decision was not related to the university's budget problems of the last year, his report to the Regents cited current finances and a need for alternative sources of money as reasons for selling the station.
Proceeds from the sale would support the biotechnology program, technology transfer, "distant learning" using satellite transmissions to students at off-campus sites around the state and scholarships for students, the report said.
 
Strip-Mining Is Feared
 But Thomas Beell, a professor of broadcast journalism, said Mr. Jischke and the Regents were strip-mining the university. "It will have a devastating effect on our program," Professor Beell said.
Broadcast students are required to work at WOI for one course, and some classes are held in its building on campus. Since the university's telecommunicative arts program is one of 11 programs to be cut because of budget problems, broadcast students may be without production space if the station is sold, Professor Beell said.
Prof. Stephen Coon, who is in charge of the broadcasting program, said many of the 197 students in broadcasting -- and potential students -- were worried. The possible sale is already affecting recruiting efforts, Professor Coon said, noting: "One student decided not to attend I.S.U. He said, 'Call me when the situation is settled.' Multiply that by some unknown factor of those who have not bothered to contact us."
Rodney Fowler, a former broadcast student who is the morning anchor at WOI, says students who are working there are uneasy. "They may get their pink slips," Mr. Fowler said. About 50 students work part- or full-time at the station in news and production.
If the station is sold and moved to Des Moines, as the consultants recommended, the university may be able to retain the building that houses WOI and the station's satellite services for distant learning.
But these concessions may force a discount in the price, said Bishop Cheen of Paul Kagan Associates of Carmel, Calif. The media appraisal company is appraising the station a second time for the Board of Regents.
Although Mr. Cheen could not release details of the valuation, he said it would confirm work by Bortz & Company.
 
'Not as Polished'
 Mr. Cheen said WOI may not command as high a price as other commercial network affiliates because it is university owned and has low cash flow. "It's not as polished because it was a training ground," he said. "There's a lot of room for improved efficiencies."
He also said that moving the station to Des Moines could be beneficial, but with an NBC affiliate and a CBS affiliate already there, the competition could prove fatal to its news department.
"In today's television economics, with local news counting as 40 percent of revenue, is there room for a three-horse race in the news derby?" Mr. Cheen asked. "In other markets, the third horse has given up."
But some buyers, he said, may find a university-owned station a plus. "There's tremendous value in television stations," Mr. Cheen said. "But this is not an era where most owners want to put up their stations."

HEADLINE: In Hard Times, Helping Hands for New York's Neediest Cases;
Love Story: An Invalid, An 'Angel'

BYLINE: By CELIA W. DUGGER

 BODY:
This is a love story about a frail 81-year-old lady and the robust, 26-year-old woman who looks after her.
Dora Goldfarb was living alone in her apartment on the Upper West Side when she fell two years ago and broke her hip. Afterwards, she could no longer walk. Sharon Gibson moved in, with her plants and calypso music, to work for the shrunken woman with the wispy gray hair and wasted legs. 
 "She can't balance anymore," Ms. Gibson explains. "If she goes to stand alone, she's going to fall."
Miss Goldfarb calls Ms. Gibson her angel. "When she gives a bath, boy, does she give a bath! Wash my hair. Cut my hair. Comb my hair. She's an angel!"
But Miss Golbfarb, a social worker in her day, has used up her small savings on medical bills and paying Ms. Gibson's salary for working 7 days a week, 24 hours a day, no holidays or vacations.
 
In Need of Help
 The only thing standing between Miss Golbfarb and a nursing home is a $250-a-month rent subsidy from the Jewish Association for Services to the Aged, which receives money from The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. The agency is also helping Miss Goldfarb apply to Medicaid to cover the expense of home care.
Stephen D. Solender, executive vice president of the United Jewish Appeal-Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York, one of the seven charities associated with the Fund, said a rising number of elderly people are turning to charities for food, clothing and help with rent as medical costs eat away at fixed incomes and the recession puts family members out of work.
Mr. Solender's organization provides rent subsidies to 25,000 people, mostly older people who need help to stay in their homes, through agencies like the one helping Miss Goldfarb. "More people are coming to us for the basics," he said. "We're like an emergency room."
 
Hanging On to Home
 To Miss Goldfarb, nothing is more important than being able to stay in her apartment of 25 years, a one-bedroom on the 17th floor at 96th and Central Park West that smells faintly of moth balls. There, she is surrounded by the familiar -- her parents' glowing brass samovar, her poetry books, the Picassoesque painting from her nephew's blue period."I want my own home and I want her and that's it," Miss Goldfarb says. "Sharon is my life."
Sharon Gibson has been looking after other people since she was a teen-ager. "I took care of my grandmother when she died. I was 15 then. I like nursing," she says. Gesturing to Miss Goldfarb, she says, "She's like a grandmother to me."
Like many immigrant women in New York City, Ms. Gibson is supporting children back home, a 5-year-old son and a 10-year-old daughter in Trinidad. She keeps their photographs at her bedside.
"Get the photographs," Miss Golbfarb tells her. Ms. Gibson comes back with the likenesses of her children. "Isn't he beautiful?" Miss Goldfarb says and kisses the photo.
Miss Golbfarb passes her days on a worn couch in the living room. Sometimes, she lays back in her blue housecoat and listens to Ms. Gibson's calypso and reggae music, her foot tapping on the needlepoint roses of her stool, her hands clapping as Ms. Gibson shimmies across the parquet floors.
Miss Goldfarb's vision is failing, so she looks a lot at the television. "The worst part is not being able to read," she says. She misses poetry especially, but she's vague on what her favorites once were. "I have them here. I don't remember. I can't remember."
But Miss Goldfarb does remember the photographs of Ms. Gibson's children that had been sitting on the coffee table just moments earlier.
"Where are the pictures?" she demands querulously. "The pictures!"
"They're right here," Ms. Gibson reassures her. "I moved them so you could put your feet up."
Ms. Gibson then helps Miss Golbfarb to her rocker and guides her to the bathroom. "This is the one with the biggest heart," Miss Goldfarb says, patting Ms. Gibson's arm. "Sharon, did you eat anything today?"
"I'm not hungry yet," Ms. Gibson replies. "When you're finished let me know."
A little later, Miss Goldfarb says, "Sharon will stay until I die."
"Maybe I'll die before you," Ms. Gibson says, tweaking her boss.
"God forbid!" Miss Goldfarb exclaims. "Shut up!"

HEADLINE: Bridge

BYLINE: By Alan Truscott

 BODY:
The Fall National Championships of the American Contract Bridge League, which ended a week ago in Indianapolis, were the smallest in four years, with fewer than 10,000 tables in play in the 10-day tournament. The poor turnout can be attributed to the recession, a preference for Thanksgiving at home, and the lack of a big local bridge population.
Those who did play enjoyed themselves, and that included nearly all the country's top players. But among those with big reputations on the international bridge scene, only two were able to capture titles. 
 One was Zia Mahmood, who dedicated his victories in the Life Master Open Pairs and the Open Board-a-Match Teams to his 16-year-old niece, Alya Hidyatallah of Manhattan.
The other was Bob Hamman of Dallas, many times a world champion, who won the Blue Ribbon Pairs with Nick Nickell of Raleigh, N.C. Hamman was 1990 Player of the Year, a title Zia has won this year. The award is based on success in major national events.
The most successful players in Indianapolis were David Berkowitz of Old Tappan, N.J., and Larry Cohen of Little Falls, N.J., who won two of the four major events and were second in a third. They would also have won a one-day Swiss Team event, and broken the record for master points won at a single National, but for an odd episode. They were deprived of the chance to play two potentially winning boards at the end of the day because the boards were prematurely removed by an overzealous caddy and could not be recovered. This was one example of a tendency among some members of the directing staff to take prompt, decisive action that later proved ill judged.
Berkowitz and Cohen won both major team championships, including the prestigious Reisinger Board-a-Match event at the end of the tournament. Their Reisinger teammates were Cliff Russell of Miami Beach, Sam Lev of Forest Hills, Queens, Marty Bergen of Farmingdale, L.I., and Bjorn Fallenius of Manhattan. They thus qualified for playoffs that will eventually determine the United States team in the 1993 world championships, but Fallenius is not eligible. He played for Sweden, his native country, in the 1991 Bermuda Bowl in Yokohama, Japan, and must wait until 1994 before he can represent another country.
The winners of major championships almost invariably have large collections of master points, but neither Fallenius nor Lev are life masters. Lev, who used to represent Israel in international competition, won the Reisinger for the second time but lacks points won at the local level, a relatively recent requirement for life master status.
He held the East cards on the diagramed deal from the Reisinger final, and took full advantage of a slight misjudgment by the declarer.
It was normal for North-South to reach a black-suit slam, and it is sure to be defeated with both suits breaking badly. Six clubs is slightly safer, but six spades is more likely to be a winning choice in board-a-match scoring, which is roughly equivalent to match-point duplicate.
In the diagramed auction Russell as West put pressure on his opponents with a pre-emptive jump to five hearts. North's final bid of six spades was pushy, since his heart queen was useless and the energetic bidding by East-West suggested that there would be bad breaks.
Lev was happy to double six spades, and the opening lead of the heart ace was ruffed by South. That player led a spade to the queen, losing to the ace, and was forced to ruff another heart. The play of the spade king brought a heart discard from West, and South knew that the slam was doomed. The question now was the size of the penalty. The position was this:
[DIAGRAM]
South now made an obvious play by leading the club ace. Lev demonstrated that this was a subtle error: Instead of routinely ruffing, he discarded a diamond. This excellent defense guaranteed that South would lose 500 instead of 200. Diamonds were led at this point, but now Lev could ruff the third round. The best South could do was to discard a club, but he was still left with an eventual loser in that suit.
In the post-mortem, South discovered that he should have played diamonds before touching clubs, for he could then have thrown both his club losers. He had given Lev the opportunity to help his team on the road to Reisinger victory, for in the replay the contract was six clubs doubled, failing by one trick.

HEADLINE: Frengiz Surty To Wed in '92

 BODY:
Mr. and Mrs. Rohinton J. Surty of Menlo Park, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter Frengiz Rohinton Surty to Lee Scott Wolosky, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joel Wolosky of Riverdale, the Bronx. A fall 1992 wedding is planned.
Ms. Surty, 24 years old, graduated cum laude from the University of California at Los Angeles. She is a consulting associate at Cambridge Associates, an investment advisory concern in Boston. Her father is a senior engineer and project manager for I.B.M. in San Jose, Calif. Her mother, Villoo R. Surty, is a graphic designer in Menlo Park and San Francisco. 
 Mr. Wolosky, 23, graduated magna cum laude from Harvard University, where he is a research assistant in Soviet political and economic reform at the John F. Kennedy School of Government. His mother, Beverly Wolosky, is a specialist in speech and language disorders in Riverdale. His father is a partner in the New York law firm of Parker, Chapin, Flattau & Klimpl.

HEADLINE: Brain Surgery For Protest Movement

 BODY:
My compliments on the tragic lobotomy feature "Lingering Effects of Lobotomies of 40's and 50's" [Nov. 3]. It's a story that for too long a time has been relegated to the dustbin of history. Especially deplorable was the use of lobotomies to tranquilize thousands of battle-fatigued emotionally broken veterans of World War II who crowded the psychiatric wards of Army hospitals. This so-called behavior-modifying procedure finally came to an end in the early 1950's, leaving a lobotomy wasteland littered with some 50,000 human "retreads," many of whom slid into a permanent vegetable state.
But there is a sequel to the lobotomy story. In the mid-70's it became known as psychosurgery. It was performed through the implantation of very thin electrodes into certain sections of the brain, the amygdala region, where "bad" brain cells, targeted by electrocephalogram readings and presumed associated with violent behavior, were burned out with an electrical charge. 
 Though claims for its scientific validity were denounced by some of the leading neuropsychiatrists, it caught on with municipal and government law-enforcement authorities, who viewed it as a quick fix to the rise of social disquiet across the country soon after the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King. Hundreds of thousands of his followers were in the streets demanding that their civil rights be recognized and that Dr. King's assassins be brought to justice.
For the police, the psychosurgery possibilities proved attractive in dealing with the leaders of the protests. Two of the principal medical sponsors of this approach, Dr. Vernon H. Mark, a neurosurgeon, and Dr. Frank E. Ervin, a neuropsychiatrist, both of Harvard, wrote to The Journal of the American Medical Association stating that though indeed there were socioeconomic reasons for the demonstrations, the individuals who were involved in violent behavior were suffering from brain dysfunction and could be remedied by pschosurgery.
Especially impressed with this theory was Ronald Reagan, then Governor of California, who promised to allocate $1 million to a violence-rreduction center to be set up in California. In the South there were reports of 50 psychosurgeries at the Atmoree State Prison in Birmingham, Ala. The Veterans Administration declared openly that it had used psychosurgery in V.A. hospitals in Durham, N.C.; Long Beach, Calif.; Minneapolis, and Syracuse.
Civil libertarians and prominent psychiatrists, together with various citizens' groups, saw this trend as an emergence of a racist threat, since most of the prison population was made up of Afro-Americans and other minorities. Eventually, because of the concern expressed by the Congressional Black Caucus, Health Education and Welfare Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger appointed a commission of physicians, lawyers and experts on medical ethics to study the situation.
For nearly a year in weekend meetings in Washington they pondered the matter, in the course of which it was disclosed that some psychosurgery enthusiasts would extend the procedure to such "deviant" individuals as hyperactive children, homosexuals, drug addicts and political nonconformists. The commission, officially known as the National Commission for the Protection of Human Subjects of Biomedical and Behavioral Research, wound up its deliberations with a fuzzy resolution that didn't endorse the use of psychosurgery, but advocated further examination of its dubious claims.
Because of the growing economic disarray in the United States and the rise of the incidence of violence due to absence of gun controls, I believe it timely to remind the citizenry that socioeconomic problems require appropriate political solutions and not some bizarre behavioral approaches that have little to do with the social roots of violence.
 
SAMUEL CHAVKIN
 New York
The writer, a member of the National Association of Science Writers, wrote "The Mind Stealers," published by Houghton Mifflin in 1978.
