HEADLINE: May U.S.-Japanese Friendship Grow Stronger

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The 50th anniversary of Japan's attack on Pearl Harbor is upon us. 
 The people of Japan embrace deep feelings of regret over their country's wartime history, and they have taken the lessons from this experience to heart in treading the path toward peace and democracy over the last 50 years. The United States-Japan relationship has grown closer and healthier into the most important bilateral relationship in the world. When problems have developed between our countries, they have been resolved through dialogue in a spirit of good will, without confrontation.
The visit of President Bush to Japan early next year will be a good opportunity to highlight the accomplishments of that relationship over half a century and to prepare to serve the entire world as we move toward the 21st century.
However, there are areas in this relationship where the level of understanding remains insufficient. Also, it is most regrettable that some quarters of both countries, including the news media, sneeringly focus on our differences and fuel the fires of misperception. An example is Karel van Wolferen's "An Economic Pearl Harbor?" (Op-Ed, Dec. 2). He pays no consideration at all to the development of democracy in Japan, to the fact that the Constitution is supported by the vast majority of the Japanese people, to the importance of the Japan-United States alliance for the Asia-Pacific region, to the international contributions Japan has made or to the serious domestic debate on what further contributions Japan should make in the future.
In any country, and especially in a parliamentary democracy, it unavoidably takes some time to determine the course of the nation. When Japan needs time to reach difficult decisions, it is altogether inappropriate to say that the decision-making process does not function or that there is a lack of domestic leadership. It is also wrong, in my view, to criticize the political systems or practices of other countries because they are different from the American or European model.
The Japanese want and yearn for world peace and the development of mutually beneficial relations among the countries of the world. It is not true that Japan distrusts the rest of the world. In building a new world order in the wake of the cold war, Japan will continue to cooperate with the United States and other countries under its policy of making an international contribution commensurate with its national capability.
The article also inaccurately states that I repeatedly used the term "Japan-bashing" at the Congressional Economic Leadership Institute to make "Americans hold back what they want to say about Japan for fear of being considered racist." As one who welcomes constructive mutual criticism, I would like to make it clear that any references to "Japan-bashing" (one in the body of my remarks and two in answer to questions about "Japan-bashing") were intended to express my concern that the biggest enemy to both countries and our relationship is emotional reaction created by an insufficiency of knowledge of the facts and a lack of objectivity on both sides. Any concerns between the United States and Japan should be resolved through dialogue between our countries, where problems can be pointed out on a friend-to-friend basis.
Indeed, isn't this already an important characteristic of our nowmature relationship? It is a relationship in which each party exercises self-control and strives to create an environment where we both can grow. Japan is prepared to say what needs to be said, but it is also ready to lend serious ear to any appropriate comment the United States has to make as well.
 
RYOHEI MURATA
Ambassador of Japan to the U.S.
Washington, Dec. 3, 1991

HEADLINE: How Much Is He Treading Water?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Trapped in the Impoverished Middle Class," (Nov. 17) quoted Donald V. Fites, chairman of Caterpillar Inc., as seeing the shrinking of American incomes as a good thing. As the wife of a Federal employee, who has seen our family's income lag behind that of the rest of the middle class thanks to the anti-government-worker attitudes of the Carter and Reagan Administrations, I'm curious: What is Mr. Fites's annual compensation? How much of a pay cut has he taken in recent years? How many perks and bonuses has he declined to accept or given back? In short, has he had to "tread water" along with the rest of us?
 
REGINA F. McCORMICK
Arlington, Va., Nov. 17

HEADLINE: ...And About Bringing Down Wages

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It was gratifying to learn that Donald Fites of Caterpillar believes that increases in living standards of people in poor countries require some constraints on resource use by people in rich countries. Inevitably, however, that approach has limitations. For example, the real wages of Caterpillar workers have declined. Have Caterpillar executives sacrificed along with their workers? And what insures that workers in the developing world benefit as the United States standard of living declines? Mexican workers, mentioned by Mr. Fites, suffered a 3.5 percent average yearly decline from 1980 to 1987.
Having American incomes "tread water" while developing-country workers catch up, as Mr. Fites proposes, is not necessary if we pursue rising living standards in environmentally sustainable and community-enhancing ways. This could be done by building a less violent society, both at home and abroad -- one with greater social concern for families, and with secure, interesting and less-stressful work for all who want it.

JUNE ZACCONE
Hempstead, L.I., Nov. 20
 
The author is an associate professor of economics at Hofstra University.

HEADLINE: Frank S. Kristof, 74, Ex-Official Who Criticized Rent Regulations

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
Frank S. Kristof, a retired housing official for New York City and an outspoken opponent of rent control, died on Friday at his home in Highland Lakes, N.J.
Mr. Kristof, who also had a home in Manhattan, was 74 years old. He died of Alzheimer's disease, his family said. 
 He served as president of the New York City Rent Stabilization Association from 1978 to 1981. Earlier, he served as the city's housing economist under Mayors Robert F. Wagner and John V. Lindsay.
A critic of rent regulation, Mr. Kristof once said, "It is essentially a middle-class rip-off of the most unpopular victim of our society -- the landlord." He blamed rent control for reduced construction, and the deterioration and abandonment of buildings.
 
Wide Housing Experience
 He was born in Manhattan and graduated from City College in 1942. From 1943 to 1946, he served in the Air Force as a first lieutenant. He then worked as a substitute high school teacher while studying at Columbia University, earning his master's degree and a doctorate in economics.
In 1952, he started work as a market analyst for the Federal Housing Administration and in 1955, he became a consultant for the State Rent Commission. The next year he was appointed assistant chief of housing for the United States Census Bureau. In 1960 he was named deputy director of planning and program research for the City Housing and Redevelopment Board and in 1963 was promoted to director. In 1967 he became assistant administrator of the City Housing and Development Administration.
Moving to the State Urban Development Corporation, Mr. Kristof became its director of economics and housing finance in 1968 and its vice president of planning and program development in 1977. He was also appointed twice as a member of the City Rent Guidelines Board, which sets rent rates for stabilized apartments.
As an international consultant, he worked in Africa and Barbados for the United Nations, in Thailand for the World Bank, in India and Bahrain for the Ford Foundation and in Brazil for Columbia University. He taught at Hunter College, Pratt Institute and Columbia and wrote many professional articles.
He is survived by his wife, the former Roseanne Miller, whom he married after the death of his first wife, the former Helen Reilly, and by a step-sister, Mary Maier of Rhinelander, Wis.

HEADLINE: End of Story?;
Hostages Go Free at Last, But Iran Bears Watching

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
NOTHING marked the senselessness of hostage-taking so well as the release last week of Terry A. Anderson for no easily understandable reason or discernible gain for his Lebanese captors.
While there were scenes of joyous reunion as the last American captive of Beirut's dungeons blinked his way into the daylight and there were some sickening tales of abuse at the hands of the kidnappers, who remain at large, there was also a sense that the whole thing had been a grotesque exercise in futility. 
 The end of the hostage drama brought with it no measurable victory for any side that has played in Lebanon's violent hinterland, no political credit for the sitting American President whose predecessors toiled incessantly for the freedom of hostages, and no breakthrough in relations between the United States and Iran, whose 1979 revolution reinvented hostage taking as a modern terror weapon against "Western arrogance."
Perhaps the American obsession with Iran was over, and for understandable reasons: with the collapse of the Soviet empire, all the rules of East-West competition -- and Iran's role in it -- are changing. Moreover, after the American demonstration of force in the Persian Gulf war, the tectonic plates of power in the Middle East are realigning.
The Iran that drove the Reagan White House to distraction, and to indictments in the Iran-contra affair, was the Iran of an earlier era, even if it was hijacked by a populist religious revolt led by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini. The Shah of Iran was America's cold war bulwark against Soviet expansionism to the warm water ports of the Persian Gulf, to the bountiful oilfields along the gulf littoral and to the controlling shoreline of the Strait of Hormuz.
But the East-West struggle for the Iranian trophy, a vestige of four decades of containment policy aimed at Moscow, is all but dead with the end of the cold war. With it died the temptations that so obsessed Mr. Reagan's operatives on the National Security Council that they traded arms for hostages in an effort to ingratiate themselves with the scheming mullahs who had thrown out the Shah.
While many bystanders to the liberation of Mr. Anderson, who led the final march that included Alann Steen and Joseph J. Cicippio, were left wondering whether some new American-Iranian deal had paved the way for his release, many analysts of the Middle East were pointing to the more obvious reality that the end of the hostage crisis marks a surrender of Iranian radicalism to a changing power equation in the region.
The man holding the white flag is Hojatolislam Hashemi Rafsanjani, the Khomeini acolyte and President of Iran, who is still trying to pull his country out of the devastation left behind by the Iran-Iraq war.
More than two years after Ayatollah Khomeini's death, President Rafsanjani is struggling against a radical majority in his Parliament to increase the pace of economic reform in Iran, to restart industries, to improve the country's human rights record, to attract Western investment and to coax back the many Iranians who fled, with their money, to London, Geneva and California.
Whether he succeeds next spring in the first parliamentary elections since 1988, when radicalism was at its zenith, may determine whether Iran's revolution ultimately succeeds or spins once again out of control, taking with it Iran's chances to re-emerge as a major regional power.
In January 1989, six months before he died, Ayatollah Khomeini sent a delegation to Moscow in what turned out to be his last attempt to play off East against West. At the time, Mohamed Javad Larijani, the architect of that Soviet gambit, warned visiting Americans that unless they moved quickly to reconcile with Teheran, the train carrying Soviet-Iranian relations might leave the station, and America, behind.
Today, such a ploy would only draw ridicule. But that does not mean Iran will be unimportant for American security interests, many analysts say. Though there is no longer any risk that Iran might fall under Moscow's sway, the economic strain from exploding population growth, moribund industries and agricultural production all make Iran a potential threat to its neighbors, principally Saudi Arabia, its chief rival for material and spiritual leadership of the world's one billion Muslims.
Will a resurgent Iran with a population of 100 million at the turn of the century be tempted to look across the narrow waterway that separates it from the Arabian Peninsula and covet the rich oil resources of the lightly populated Arab sheikdoms? Will Teheran's post-revolutionary leaders seek to acquire nuclear weapons in light of the nuclear competition that has broken out on Iran's flanks in Southwest Asia? Will Iran continue to employ assassination and terror as instruments of foreign policy? These are the questions that officials in Washington must come to grips with in evaluating future policy toward Iran. The Bush Administration has yet to produce its long-awaited new security arrangement for the Persian Gulf; whatever is in that arrangement, the role of Iran remains crucial to regional stability and, therefore, to American interests, most experts agree.
Mr. Bush is likely to move cautiously. If Iran's proxies in Lebanon clear the final hostage accounts by producing the two remaining German captives as well as the bodies of the two American hostages who didn't make it through their ordeal alive -- William Buckley of the Central Intelligence Agency and Lieut. Col. William R. Higgins of the Marines -- some analysts expect to see the longstanding trade embargo against Iran lifted. An upgrading of the diplomatic contacts with Teheran, now conducted through the Swiss, would likely follow, but these are small steps.
In the meantime, the landscape of terror that the hostages will leave behind in Lebanon now falls to the Syrians, the Israelis and the Lebanese to heal, and the task is anything but easy.
In a little-noted postscript to the final communique Mr. Anderson read on behalf of his kidnappers, he said: "The causes of this troubled episode are complex and difficult. It is these causes which must be addressed and eliminated."
If anything, he was referring to the outcry from Lebanon's dispossessed Shiite Muslims, whose radicalization helped create the synergy of political revolt, terror and kidnapping to which Mr. Anderson fell victim. Radicalized by years of disenfranchisement, invasion, warlord anarchy and impoverishment, this Shiite population -- which had become the largest of Lebanon's many competing religious groups -- was therefore susceptible to Ayatollah Khomeini's call to revolution and struggle against the Great Satan, America, and the Little Satan, Israel. Significant miscalculations by the Reagan Administration in trying to pacify Lebanon following Israel's 1982 invasion, as well as the ill-fated Iran-contra scheme, only prolonged Lebanon's agony and the long hostage internment, in the view of many analysts.
For better or worse, Lebanon's fate has been settled on Syria's terms and the tension in Lebanon today surrounds the incomplete task of disarming the remaining militia forces, including the Party of God warriors who protected Mr. Anderson's jailers. This would pave the way for the Lebanese Army to establish real security in the country for the first time since the civil war erupted in 1975.
If Syria and Lebanon are ever to persuade Israel to withdraw from the buffer zone it holds in southern Lebanon, they will have to bring to an end the era of sanctuary in Lebanon for Palestinian and Iranian-backed guerrillas who attack through Israel's northern border. Southern Lebanon is steeped in the blood of Arab "martyrs," Israeli soldiers and their surrogates. The Lebanese held by Israel in its prison at Khiam, including Sheik Abdul Karim Obeid, the Lebanese Shiite mullah kidnapped by Israeli commandos, are still hostages to this unresolved conflict, and their fate remains tied to Israel's demand to bring home the remains of its lost servicemen in Lebanon and to free an Israeli Air Force navigator, Ron Arad, who is believed to be still alive.
Thus a number of pieces must fall into place for the "complex and difficult" episode Mr. Anderson described to end, but his long-awaited emancipation was certainly among the most hopeful events to have occurred in Lebanon in many years.

PUB-DATE: December 8, 1991

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1; Column 4; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1243 words

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Bush Picks A New Crew And Prays For Updraft

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IN 1984, President Reagan and Vice President Bush won re-election by asking Americans if they were better off than four years earlier. In 1992, unless there is a quick economic recovery, the Democrats may well use that question to torment President Bush.
But as he moved last week to put himself and the White House in a campaign mode, the President showed signs that he plans an approach aimed at minimizing his vulnerability in the event the recession doesn't just go away. 
 "I really run on a wide array of questions," Mr. Bush said on Friday. "I hope that by the time this election is held, and I'm quite confident that by the time this election is held, the economy will be much, much better. And in many ways I could answer that affirmatively right now, because of world peace and because of a lot of other things."
While members of his new campaign team listened, Mr. Bush added, "I'm prepared to take my whole record to the American people."
The political strategists have begun plotting ways to make it safe for Mr. Bush to do what he said: run for re-election not on personal popularity and foreign policy credentials alone but also by answering the challenge to his domestic leadership.
Even at this early stage, the outlines of Mr. Bush's election strategy, as well as the problems he must solve, can be discerned in the politically bruising weeks since Labor Day, during which he has suffered about as much political damage, some of it self-inflicted, as any other President in so short a time.
One of Mr. Bush's primary arguments will be that the Democrats are not offering anyone as experienced as he is, nor offering any economic plan of their own.
"The real question is, 'Are you better off than you were 12 years ago?' " said Charles Black, the campaign's senior adviser. "Even if somebody answers, 'No, I'm not better off than four years ago,' they still have to answer this: 'Is there anybody else who can do better?' "
 
Suddenly, Contestable
 Mr. Bush is the heavy favorite for re-election. But between Labor Day and Thanksgiving, his position slid from unassailability to contestability. As members of his own party began to smell blood, Mr. Bush remained reactive.
He kept up small-bore events and foreign travel and resisted pressure to correct the disarray within his staff and the confusion in his domestic policies. All this suggested that he suffered from the politician's malady: an inability to recognize when virtues become vices.
Loyalty and a penchant for letting a moment ripen before taking action can be great assets. But Mr. Bush may have taken them to a damaging extreme by putting off a solution to the political liability created by John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, and in delaying the formation of his 1992 campaign staff.
Friday's news conference, at which he named Samuel K. Skinner as his new chief of staff and introduced his campaign team, was supposed to address that problem.
But Democrats and conservative Republicans rushed to point out that a game of musical chairs was not going to fix Mr. Bush's troubles, and Bush aides reluctantly agreed.
Republican strategists, alarmed at how long Mr. Bush took to realize that the recession was causing serious problems, are trying to make the President seem more caring. During another Administration, the Doonesbury comic strip lampooned Jimmy Carter as having a "Secretary of Symbolism." Perhaps that is just what Mr. Bush needs.
Because he feels so comfortable with his position in the world, Mr. Bush does not seem to understand why people think him insensitive when he talks about things like unemployment from what he considers innocent, natural settings -- the golf course, the tennis court or his speedboat.
But getting Mr. Bush off the golf course has proved difficult for his image-makers and it is not clear whether the Bush campaign staff will have much more success in letting new voices penetrate the White House walls.
Mr. Bush has been listening to the voices to which he is accustomed -- the oil patch, happy with the price increase and secure market they got from the Persian Gulf war, and Wall Street, content to weather slumps if there is low inflation and stable interest rates.
But there are other voices shouting at Mr. Bush now, as they did last week on one of his not-yet-a-candidate swings, as he lunched on macaroni and hamburger casserole with workers at a Tropicana orange juice plant in Florida.
He had just given a speech about a capital gains tax cut, I.R.A. savings accounts and "successful positioning in foreign markets." The workers, most of whom make less than $10 an hour, wanted to talk about their jobs.
They wanted to know why he opposed a bill that would ban the hiring of replacement workers during a strike and why he was so bent on a free-trade agreement with Mexico, which they feared would cost American jobs. "We talked about the homeless and he said they were trying to do something about it," said Shirley Yeck, who culls oranges from a conveyor belt. "I don't know . . ."
But even if he is able to persuade voters that he shares such concerns, simply caring may not be enough. Incumbents run on achievements, not promises.
So while the White House works on specific economic proposals for the President's State of the Union Address in late January, Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher, who was appointed general chairman of Mr. Bush's campaign last week, said the campaign will refine an argument that Mr. Bush has tried out on the stump recently: that foreign and domestic policy are linked.
"It's an argument I think we can pretty damn near prove, not just make," Mr. Mosbacher said, "by the increase we've seen in exports, by the degree of international competitiveness that we're building, by the sales of high-tech goods, on and on, that we've built through George Bush's efforts around the world."
For better or worse, Mr. Bush has established himself as a believer in the trickle-down theory that ordinary workers will benefit, eventually, by giving tax breaks to those people with enough money to invest. And he has been arguing that if Americans will just keep their chins up, the economy will get better.
That may be reasonable enough in a macro-economic sense, but it is not the stuff of a great campaign message, especially when Mr. Bush adds the curious line he often uses to reassure voters: "We're not going to do anything dumb."
These arguments could signal workers that Mr. Bush is willing for them to suffer for the greater good and, to the discomfort of many Republicans, they smack of Herbert Hoover's politically disastrous attempts to persuade Americans that if they were simply more confident the nation's economic problems would correct themselves.
 
No More Mr. Guerrilla?
 Mr. Bush is facing decisions about tactics. He waged guerrilla warfare against Michael S. Dukakis in 1988 with racial, patriotic and law-and-order images. But slash-and-burn campaigning might not go over well from an incumbent who has spent four years painting himself as the nice guy next door, flipping hamburgers in his backyard, dandling his grandchildren on his knee.
Mr. Bush could always try changing the subject. But that can sound plaintive, as he did on Friday when he said the 6.8 percent unemployment rate for November was lower than predicted.
"Please don't go into these little details," he told reporters. "Let's look at the big picture."

HEADLINE: HEADLINERS;
A Symbol of a Different Era Collapses

BYLINE: By CARLYLE C. DOUGLAS

 BODY:
THE story of Pan American World Airways can be read in its changes of address.
A little more than a decade ago, its logo was a beacon above the heart of mid-Manhattan, topping a tower that bestrode Park Avenue. Last week, as some of its 7,500 New York employees were moving to the company's new lodgings at Miami International Airport -- the equivalent of a flat above the store -- Pan Am died broke. 
 The company, which has been laboring for nearly a year to reorganize under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Act, ceased operating abruptly, stranding hundreds of passengers waiting to board planes at Kennedy Airport in New York, and leaving in uproar the travel plans of thousands of people who had purchased tickets for flights in the near future. With the reorganization gone by the boards, the company's assets are to be auctioned off tomorrow in bankruptcy court.
There were a couple of obvious factors in the demise of the 64-year-old airline, which once dominated international air travel. There was the current bad economic weather, which has been particularly bumpy for the travel industry. Then there was the horror of the worst of terrorist bombings, the destruction of Pan Am Flight 103 over Scotland in 1986. Travel agents say that people asking not to fly Pan Am often cite the bombing.
But last week, some questioned whether Pan Am was given a final shove down the chute by Delta Airlines, which under an agreement reached last summer had paid $460 million for Pan Am's Northeast shuttle and some of its European routes. As part of the agreement, Delta was to provide cash to keep Pan Am flying until it was reorganized as a smaller, Caribbean-oriented airline.
The collapse was precipitated when Delta announced that the extra $115 million it had put into Pan Am so far was the limit. A lawyer for some of Pan Am's unsecured creditors suggested that Delta had planned all along to let the company die after snapping up its best assets. Delta denied it.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
The Refugees Match Wits With Uncle Sam

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH

DATELINE: MIAMI

 BODY:
THE lawyers who represent Haitian refugees being held by the thousands aboard Coast Guard ships and at the United States Naval Base at Guantanamo Bay had in hand a major legal victory. Yet they had a strangely solemn look about them as they emerged from a Federal District Court in Miami last Tuesday.
The court had upheld an injunction temporarily preventing the repatriation of the mounting population of Haitians, and it had granted the refugee advocates other concessions. But the advocates knew that the Government was far from having exhausted all its weapons, and that the most important one may prove to be time -- time in which to erode the Haitians' desire to reach America and thus persuade them to return to Haiti without being forced. 
 The case began in late October, one month after a violent military coup overthrew Haiti's first democratically elected president, the Rev. Jean-Bertrant Aristide. Since then, a combination of military reprisals against Father Aristide's supporters and starkly increased economic hardships growing out of aneconomic embargo have caused nearly 6,000 Haitians to flee in overcrowded boats for the United States.
The dispute between the Government, which has been intercepting the boat people at sea, and the advocates has been over which of the refugees are fleeing poverty, an insufficient cause for asylum under American law, and which truly face persecution.
 
New Tactics
 Now, while each side prepares to go all the way to the Supreme Court to determine whether the United States is making adequate efforts to assure that no bona fide political refugees are returned to a strife-torn Haiti, Washington has quietly begun to shift its tactics on another front.
The new strategy includes increasing the capacity of the camp at Guantanamo to more than 10,000 with a view to holding the line indefinitely against significant numbers of Haitians coming into the United States.
Meanwhile, other changes like a switch from kitchen-prepared chicken, rice and beans to the bland packaged Army rations known as M.R.E.'s suggest that the Government is also trying to assure that the courts will not be the only place where it is decided who is a political refugee and who has fled for purely economic reasons.
One official, in fact, expressed confidence that the Haitians at Guantanamo will eventually become discouraged and decide to return home, thus undercutting arguments that most of the refugees face danger from political persecution at home.
The official cited the case of the Haitian boat people who had been taken to Venezuela and Honduras as part of a burden-sharing plan conceived by Washington in the early days of the five-week-old exodus. Last week, many of them asked to return to their country rather than endure the uncertainty and isolation of the camps.
Now, reporters returning from Pentagon-authorized day trips to Guantanamo say small numbers of the nearly 5,000 Haitians there are beginning to make similar requests. "I can't imagine you won't begin to see more of the kinds of decisions that were made in Venezuela," said the official. "That is why it is important for the Administration not to cave in. If there is any caving in, this will just become a massive springboard to the United States."
 
Politicians Visit
 But immigration advocates have been expecting the Government to try to demoralize the would-be refugees, and they have already begun trying to counter such a strategy by encouraging visits by concerned American political and entertainment figures. This weekend, Jesse Jackson, Representative Charles B. Rangel and the filmmaker Jonathan Demme are visiting Guantanamo.
"One of our concerns right now is that these people are cut off from everything," said Cheryl Little, a lawyer for the Haitian Refugee Center of Miami, which brought the suit against the Government. "It is important not to let them feel neglected."
Ms. Little also expressed concern that as Christmas approaches, relations between the troops at Guantanamo and the refugees they are guarding could deteriorate "when the members of the Army realize they are not home with their families because of the Haitians."
Despite a strongly worded decision in the refugee advocates' favor by C. Clyde Atkins, a Federal district judge in Miami, both sides say the legal odds in the case will increasingly tilt in the Government's favor as it works its way through appeals.
Judge Atkins's decison, which barred the forced return of refugees until a more thorough screening procedure could be devised, was based largely on a United Nations protocol on refugees, rather than on American statutes. Officials involved in the case expressed confidence that eventually an appellate court will rule that such protocols are not binding.
But just as the Justice Department and Pentagon have shifted their tactics in the battle over the fate of the Haitian refugees, the advocates for the boat people have also laid contingency plans. These focus on taking the debate from the courts into the perhaps more sympathetic arenas of world opinion and domestic politics.
"U.S. courts are unduly nervous in founding decisions on international law relating to the human rights of refugees," Arthur C. Helton, an immigration expert with the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights, said in a telephone conversation from Geneva, where he was campaigning for foreign support for the refugees.
Already, he said, the United States has come under international criticism for its handling of the Haitians. Citing the visits of Mr. Rangel and others and growing interest from other Washington politicians, Mr. Helton said, "We are winning the battle of moral outrage."

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Fujimori Aims for a Head-on Collision With 'Shining Path'

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru

 BODY:
PERU'S President and Peru's Maoist rebels appear to be on course for a major confrontation in 1992.
Marshaling the forces on one side is Alberto K. Fujimori, the mild-mannered university president who after becoming Peru's president 16 months ago suddenly worked Latin America's most rapid and most radical free market revolution. Last month, the determined leader turned from economics to counterinsurgency and issued a blizzard of decrees intended to give Peru's army a free hand in fighting terrorism. On a recent visit to California, Mr. Fujimori predicted that Peru would be pacified by the end of his term, in 1995. His advisers say by the end of 1993. 
 On the other side is the Sendero Luminoso, or Shining Path, the Maoist guerrilla group that took advantage of vacillating Peruvian presidents in the 1980's to spread terror into every region of this country. Convinced that a worker-peasant state dominated by an Indian and mixed-race power base will be achieved by the end of the decade, Luis Arce Borja, the movement's European spokesman, predicted recently to Lima's Expreso newspaper, "Nothing will stop the triumphal march of the Shining Path."
Gustavo Gorriti, a Peruvian journalist writing a history of the rebels, believes that "1992 is going to be much more violent, because we now have two locomotives running toward each other on the same track."
"Fujimori believes he is going to pacify the nation in two years," Mr. Gorriti said. "Sendero believes they are going to win in this decade. The meeting of these two radical convictions are going to produce greater violence."
In the clash, two issues of concern to Americans may be lost in the dust: human rights and cocaine interdiction.
On human rights, Mr. Fujimori often speaks with two voices. To win American aid before a September visit to the White House, he ordered police and military commanders to open bases to Red Cross visits and told the military to stop making terrorist suspects "disappear."
But addressing military audiences at home, he later attacked human-rights groups as "legal arms of subversion" and "useful fools" manipulated by terrorists. After Amnesty International charged that 250 people had "disappeared" since Mr. Fujimori took office, the President blasted back in a late November speech before air force officers: "The terrorists present themselves as victims before the world, using for their ends the efforts of institutions like Amnesty International and Americas Watch."
This fall, stung by earlier charges that their reporting had been one-sided, both human rights groups condemned many atrocities committed by the Shining Path who, to drive any other authority out of areas they control, have killed clergy, foreign aid workers and even housewives running slum soup kitchens.
But, noting that three human rights activists have been killed since 1989, the groups say the president's verbal attacks endanger them too.
The fight against the export of semi-refined cocaine also seems to be a low priority. The underpaid police are seizing coca base and paste at rates half those of last year. The United States Drug Enforcement Administration has had little success persuading the government to shut down air taxi companies that fly cocaine.
Many Peruvians believe that the Shining Path is a far greater threat than cocaine and that the focus of American aid should be the defense of Peru's democracy. Low salaries and poor equipment add up to low morale: Peru's army loses one officer a day to civilian jobs. This week, Hector Jhon Caro was dismissed as head of Peru's anti-terrorism police because 16 subordinates allegedly stole a $23,000 agency payroll.
The cost of Peru's "Fuji-shock" -- Mr. Fujimori's abrupt adoption of free market policies and reintegration into the world financial community -- has been greater poverty, and better Shining Path recruiting conditions.
"Schoolteachers' children are not eating three meals any more, tuberculosis is up, real malnutrition is up," said an American priest driving through a Lima shantytown daubed with Senderista graffiti: "Fujimori = Genocide."
A rise to power by the brutal Shining Path could destabilize the region the same way the ascendance of radical Shiites did in Iran in the 1970's. Believing their movement "a beacon for world revolution," Shining Path leaders hope to export Marxist revolt to Bolivia and Ecuador.
"Peruvian democracy is a conquest of the people, and the Shining Path seeks to destroy this democracy," said Carlos Tapia, a sociologist affiliated with the Socialist Left party. "But the political parties tell the military 'kill them quick, so we won't have to get our hands dirty.' "
So far, Peru's feuding politicians show little interest in forming a common front.
"Alan inocente, Alan presidente," supporters of Alan Garcia Perez chanted this week on learning that a supreme court judge had decided not to open a trial on embezzlement charges against the former president . The judge, an appointee of the former president, taught Mr. Garcia geography in high school. During Mr. Garcia's five years in office, Peru had 2 million percent inflation, but the 42-year-old politician is seen as a leading contender in the 1995 presidential race.
However, popular support for Mr. Fujimori is strong. A mid-November poll gave him a 58 percent approval rating; one among business executives gave him an even higher approval rate -- 95 percent. "Fujimori is our first president to get into the saddle on the terrorism issue," said an industrialist here, unconsciously using an image long associated with Latin American authoritarianism -- the man on horseback.

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Pearl Harbor's Smoke, Hiroshima's Fallout

BYLINE: By SUSAN CHIRA

 BODY:
THE torrent of retrospectives on Pearl Harbor in the last few weeks shows how history continues to cloud the way the world's two most important economic powers see and treat each other.
For all the ways the United States and Japan have drawn closer together -- in political cooperation, economic interdependence, the exchange of rock 'n' roll and sushi -- there remains a troubling symmetry between the emotions surrounding Pearl Harbor and today. 
 In the United States, the images of Japan as sneaky, threatening and unfair that were flash-frozen by Pearl Harbor resurface now in talk of Japanese as samurai in business suits, out to do economically what they could not militarily. In Japan, where any sense of responsibility for the aggression of Pearl Harbor is dwarfed by the horror of Hiroshima and Nagasaki, America now seems more like the decadent superpower once portrayed in Japanese wartime propaganda.
To some extent, both countries remain trapped by history and their selective memories. In the United States, for example, the sense of treachery at Pearl Harbor and the racist wartime depictions of Japanesecontinue to resonate today.
While wartime denunciations of Germany tended to focus on Hitler and always left open the idea of the "good German," anti-Japanese propaganda tarred all Japanese as subhuman or fanatical, according to John W. Dower, professor of history at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, who studied such images for his book, "War Without Mercy." One cartoon comparing Nazi atrocities in Czechoslovakia with Japanese massacres in the Philippines showed Hitler standing over Czechoslovakia and a gorilla with Japanese features in the Philippines. Professor Dower finds traces of those attitudes in present-day portrayals of Japan's economic triumphs -- as in the headlines shouting, "Japan Invades Hollywood."
"We don't do slavering monsters, we do the sumo wrestler," he said. "Although these images are much more benign on the surface than the old ones, it is again the idea of the superman and of someone who doesn't play by the same rules."
Many Japanese still believe racism motivates much American behavior toward Japan, from the internment of Japanese-Americans during the war to the decision to drop the bomb. And many see the United States as particularly threatened by Japan's ascent because Japan is the first nonwhite economic superpower.
Cries of racism, however, can also be disingenuous in light of legitimate concerns about Japanese business practices. "That these images persist may have less to do with American racism, which, like Japanese racism, is abundant, than with the way Japan has prosecuted its postwar economy," said Richard J. Samuels, a professor of political science at M.I.T.
But Japan is no freer from historical distortions. The overriding lesson Japanese learned is that war brought them suffering, not that war made them do reprehensible things. In six years of living in Japan, this reporter frequently heard a proverb in response to questions about the war: "Let the past flow away like the river." In pursuit of forgetfulness, Japan's Government has allowed textbooks to be increasingly sanitized -- in just one infamous example, the invasion of China was called an "advance." An outspoken group of revisionist historians and politicians are even justifying Japan's conduct during the war, arguing that Japanese rule freed Asian nations from Western colonial domination, and maintaining that accounts of Japanese atrocities were exaggerated.
In the 1930's, as now, there were intense economic frictions. Japan saw itself a victim of protectionist policies triggered by a worldwide depression. Militarist leaders decided Japan would win by force raw materials it was denied through trade. Japan annexed Manchuria, invaded China, and drove into French Indochina. The United States issued an ever-tougher series of sanctions, which culminated in the summer of 1941 with measures that essentially cut off 80 percent of Japan's oil supplies. What Americans saw as principled protests against Japanese aggression in Asia, Japanese saw as a tightening economic vise. Pearl Harbor, to many, was an act of war, not of treachery, by a nation pushed to the brink.
Some Japanese intellectuals have long labored to raise public consciousness about the war, and 114 of them recently called for the uncensored teaching of history and an apology for Japan's brutality in Asia. Although such a resolution is before Japan's Parliament, President Bush's refusal last week to apologize for dropping the atomic bomb on Hiroshima and Nagasaki made action on any such apology remote. Mr. Bush's comments stirred considerable anger in Japan, where the atomic bomb is seen as a war atrocity that effectively wipes the slate clean.
Indeed, most Japanese have failed to grapple with the question of individual responsibility for wartime acts and policies.
"Japanese history is dominated by the sense that the state dominated," said Carol Gluck, a professor of history at Columbia University who is writing a book about Japanese public memory of the war. "Japanese haven't faced up to the responsibility, complicity, incrimination of all of us in total war."
World War II not only shrouds Japan's past, but hovers over its present. Japanese aversion to war has become so deep that it nettles the very Americans who wrote the idea of renouncing war into Japan's postwar Constitution. Strong Japanese opposition to the Persian Gulf war and reluctance to dispatch military forces abroad even to play non-military support roles in United Nations peacekeeping efforts have angered Japan's Western allies.
These lingering sensitivities for Japanese, and the continuing wariness of Japan's Asian neighbors and former colonies, have hampered efforts to define a new world role for Japan commensurate with its economic might. Other than economic prosperity, Japanese shy away from preaching any political philosophy.
By contrast, memories of World War II continue to imbue Americans with a sense of strength and rectitude. Compared with those in most other countries, "Americans came out thinking this was a good war," Professor Dower said. "We were supremely confident in our future and our righteousness."
This legacy of the war is one thing that makes it difficult for the United States to confront weaknesses that some Americans and most Japanese believe are eroding America's relative world power. While the United States remains mired in a recession, there is little public discussion of the link between the economic malaise and the country's low savings rate, accumulation of debt, or failure to invest nearly as much as Japan in research and development.
"There is a huge denial in the U.S.," said Clyde Prestowitz, president of the Economic Strategy Institute and a former trade negotiator with Japan. "People want to believe that everything is O.K."
The war also encouraged a persistent American ethnocentrism. Even as images persisted of Japanese as sneaky, Americans needed to see their new postwar allies against Communism in a different light -- as a people who wanted to become more like Americans. A growing number of scholars, journalists and economists assert that this belief has blinded Americans to the fact that Japan's economy, in particular, is guided by fundamentally different rules and assumptions.
That argument remains hotly contested, but the debate makes clear that many people assume that a close alliance is possible only if nations are similar. "Different" means treacherous, alien or hostile.
"If you openly say the Japanese system is different, people say you will wreck the relationship," Mr. Prestowitz said. "It's precisely this insistence on similarity when no similarity exists which is making it impossible to deal effectively with the sources of friction between us."

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
If Israel and the Arabs Can Pencil Each Other In

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
WHILE Israelis and Arabs were demonstrating last week that old habits die hard, there were two intriguing notes in their posturing over negotiations in Washington: nobody packed his bags and Americans seemed not to care.
The United States had invited Israel, Syria, Lebanon, Jordan and the Palestinians to Washington to resume the peace talks begun last month in Madrid. The meeting was originally called for Wednesday, but Israel, which for decades had said it would meet Arabs for peace talks any time, anywhere, decided to reject that date to protest Washington's unilateral invitation to the parties to meet in America rather than in the Middle East. 
 The Palestinians and other Arabs then returned the truculence; they said they were reluctant to meet on the day Israel suggested -- tomorrow -- because that is the fourth anniversary of the Palestinian uprising and it may be more important to commemorate it than to talk peace with the Israelis. Nevertheless, by last Friday, it appeared that the parties were likely to find a mutually agreeable date some time in the coming week.
This wrangling, though, is a reminder that the closer you follow these peace talks, the more confused you become. The best way to follow them may be to tune in once every few months (or years), because only in a long time frame can any real progress be measured.
After all, what really happened in Madrid? Stripped of the hoopla, what occurred was that 13 years after the Camp David peace process was launched, four parties that opposed it -- Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel, along with Syria, Jordan and the Palestinians -- finally accepted it. That was not insignificant, since Camp David remains the only agreed framework for Arab-Israeli talks. But it may take another 13 years to reach firm agreements. Still, the important things to keep an eye on are not the procedural wrangles that will develop along the way. Better to watch the larger forces that brought these parties to accept something they would never have accepted before, and whatever else will be required to translate that acceptance into peace accords.
Neither Israel nor the Arabs turned up in Madrid by accident. All went because pressures growing out of the end of the cold war and the outcome of the gulf war made it impossible to say no to the American invitation: The Syrians have lost their Soviet patrons and need a relationship with Washington; the Israelis are besieged with Soviet immigrants and more in need of American aid than ever; the Palestinians and Jordanians, isolated and impoverished because they supported Iraq, are grasping for a lifeboat.
 
History's Lessons
 The central question is whether the external pressures and inducements are enough only to bring the parties to the table, or whether they will also prove sufficient to get them to sign agreements. If history is any guide, external pressure alone is necessary to produce Arab-Israeli agreements, but not sufficient.
One lesson of the Egyptian-Israeli treaty signed in 1979 is that only by triggering internal changes within the respective parties, motivating them to act on their own for peace, will concrete agreements be possible. Madrid has not triggered much change within the parties, except among the Palestinians, whose new messengers and more moderate message are now acceptable to a significant portion of the Israeli public. The state-run Syrian media, by contrast, still has not told its people that their own troops fought alongside America in the gulf war, let alone why their leaders have reversed four decades of policy and entered direct peace talks with Israel.
At the same time, Mr. Shamir has refused to acknowledge that the principle on which he initially rejected the Camp David formula is no longer viable: that Israel can indefinitely keep control of the West Bank without ceding anything at all to the Palestinians there.
These oversights are not accidental. Syria's President, Hafez al-Assad, knows that once he acknowledges that change is afoot in relations with Israel, the Syrian people will ask for a lot of other changes in their lives too. And Mr. Shamir is afraid that if he offers the Palestinians a softer version of occupation he will inadvertently create a domestic constituency for the territorial compromise he still opposes.
The other sign that the parties are getting serious will come when they don't just talk to one another across a table in order to please the Americans, but when they talk to one another's publics in order to persuade them that they are sincere. There is something absurd about Palestinians, who talk to Israelis every day in Israel, refusing to speak with Israeli officials in Washington except in formal negotiating sessions. Do the Syrians really expect to get the Golan Heights back by doing less than what Anwar el-Sadat did in 1977 to get the Sinai back -- appeal directly to the Israeli people with a grand gesture?
But there was some good news last week; nothing might better get Arabs and Israelis to really start talking to one another, rather than to the Americans, than noticing where major American newspapers put the news of the absent peace talks last week: See page A39.
Arabs and Israelis alike might well find a message in the silence with which their bickering was received in America, which is preoccupied with its own domestic troubles, fascinated by the Palm Beach rape trial and, in the post-cold war world, rather bored with the Arab-Israeli feud. Recognizing this new reality could be the beginning of wisdom for all the parties, for it might strip the Arabs of any illusion that Washington will make peace on their behalf, and the Israelis of any illusion that after the cold war they remain a strategic asset so valuable to Washington that it will always extend massive economic aid irrespective of how Israel deals with the Arabs, or of competing interests that may arise.

HEADLINE: Rochester Schools Ban Military Recruiters

DATELINE: ROCHESTER, Dec. 7

 BODY:
Students in city schools will no longer get a pitch to join the Army on their way to the cafeteria.
The city school district board last week voted to ban military recruiters from its schools because of the Department of Defense's policy against enlisting gay and lesbian recruits. 
 The city schools are believed to be the first district in the country to prohibit military recruiters, according to the Department of Defense and the National School Boards Association.
"We realize this is just a little policy by a little school district and it isn't going to change the stance of the Defense Department," said a board member, Karen Grella. "But I think it sends a message that we don't support discrimination of any kind."
But military recruiters say the result may be fewer opportunities for the district's low income students.
 
'A Lot to Offer'
 "We offer students another avenue of opportunity," said Army Capt. Richard Threatt, who oversees Army recruiting in western New York. "We have a lot to offer and now I'm concerned some students may not have full access to it."
The board on Thursday voted 5-to-2 for the change, which prohibits recruiters from any organization that has "a stated policy which discriminates."
The board had been thinking about the change for more than a year.
Mrs. Grella said the presence of military recruiters undermined the school system's own policy against discrimination.
"How would it look to our students if we said discrimination is wrong, but in the military's case it's O.K.," she said.
Two school board members, Michael Fernandez and Frank Willis, who voted against the measure said they feared it would take economic opportunities away from some students.
But supporters, including the board's president, Catherine Spoto, poInt to a provision that will continue to allow school counselors to disseminate information about the armed forces, including how to contact recruiters off campus.
Captain Threatt, however, said that eligibility guidelines frequently change as do some benefits, and counselors may be hard pressed to keep up on top of their other duties.
 
No Plans to Change Policy
 "It won't hurt us," he said. "We will still get quality personnel from the Rochester area."
James Turner, a spokesman for the Department of Defense, said the department has no plans to change its policy on lesbians and gay men.

HEADLINE: Germans Follow Own Line on Yugoslav Republics

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BONN, Dec. 7

 BODY:
Chancellor Helmut Kohl's promise to recognize the independence of Slovenia and Croatia before Christmas has provoked a split among Western allies and has led Bonn into an unusual conflict with Washington.
The Presidents of the two breakaway Yugoslav republics visited Germany this week, and Mr. Kohl told both of them of his decision to recognize their republics as sovereign nations. Several other countries, including Sweden, Italy, Austria and Hungary, are likely to follow Germany's lead. 
 Mr. Kohl had previously maintained that his Government would recognize Slovenia and Croatia only if the entire European Community did so. He changed his position when it became clear that some members of the community opposed quick recognition.
French officials have criticized Germany for its willingness to recognize the two republics without further discussions about borders, human rights and other matters.
 
'Prejudicial for Europe'
 "We are striving to make our partners understand, starting with Germany, that it would be prejudicial for Europe as a whole," the French Foreign Minister, Roland Dumas, said on Friday. "The attitude of unilateral recognition could be damaging for the community."
The French position, which is largely shared by Britain and the United States, is that recognition of Croatia and Slovenia should come only as part of an overall peace agreement.
American officials have said they oppose quick recognition because they fear that it would encourage other Yugoslav republics to press for independence, and perhaps also set an example for secession-minded provinces in other parts of Europe.
The United States has imposed economic sanctions against all six Yugoslav republics, hoping to force all of them to make concessions, while German sanctions apply only to Serbia and its ally Montenegro.
 
'Aggression Against Croatia'
 President Franjo Tudjman of Croatia, who was in Bonn on Friday, said he was amazed by the American position. "Taken objectively, that equals support for the aggression against Croatia, support for this barbaric war that is unparalleled in the world today," Mr. Tudjman said.
For a time, debate over Yugoslavia threatened to overshadow other topics to be discussed at the European Community summit meeting next week in the Netherlands. The issue is still likely to be discussed there, but government leaders have agreed to leave final decisions to a meeting of foreign ministers on Dec. 16.
At the heart of the dispute are two opposing perceptions of the Yugoslav conflict. American, French and British officials view it as a civil war between rival ethnic factions, while Germans and those who support their view see it as an attack by Serbian Communists on peaceful people whose only crime has been to vote democratically in favor of independence.
 
Historical Ties
 Germany has long historical ties, both glorious and shameful, to Slovenia and Croatia. Slovenia was part of the Austro-Hungarian empire, and many people there still identify with the German-speaking world. There has also been German influence in Croatia, and during World War II, Croatia was ruled by a pro-Nazi regime.
This aspect of Croatian history, and the fact that the Tudjman Government has refused to disassociate itself from the Croatian fascists who ruled the republic in the 1940's, has made European leaders unwilling to move quickly toward recognition.
German public opinion is strongly pro-Croatian and anti-Serbian. Newspaper cartoons portray Serbia as a giant brute attacking helpless victims, and campaigns to raise funds for Croatia have been quite successful.
But the enthusiasm in Germany has convinced some Europeans that its ultimate goal is to rebuild a sphere of influence that could stretch across the continent from Tallinn in Estonia to Zagreb in Croatia.
 
Plans for Embassies
 When European foreign ministers meet in Brussels on Dec. 16, it appears unlikely that they will reach a consensus, which would most likely lead Germany and its supporters to act by themselves.
Officials in Bonn are already making plans to open embassies in the Slovenian and Croatian capitals and to fashion aid packages for both republics. Germany is not considered likely to supply them with weapons, but the fact that they will have a measure of international legitimacy would make it easier for others to do so.
 
 
 
SPORADIC FIGHTING IN CROATIA
 BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 7 (Reuters) -- The Yugoslav Army and Croatian forces fought sporadic battles in the breakaway republic of Croatia today.
Both sides said fighting was heavy around the central Croatian towns of Lipik and Pakrac but gave no details. The Croatian radio said three people were killed in an army attack overnight on the central town of Sisak.
On Friday, the Croatian radio said, 19 people were killed and 60 wounded in an attack on Dubrovnik that shattered a two-week-old cease-fire there.
A spokesman for European Community observers in Croatia said that the mission had lodged a protest with the army over the attack and that military would investigate the attack. The Yugoslav Army "promised a full investigation later," the spokesman, Ed Koestal, said. "A statement of regret and apparent intent to discipline certain people was received."
The Croatian radio said Dubrovnik was briefly shelled again today but reported no new damage.
The special United Nations envoy to Yugoslavia, Cyrus R. Vance, is seeking to arrange for the dispatch of United Nations peacekeeping troops to Croatia, but has warned that the force will not be sent unless a truce holds..
The fighting on Friday was the worst in weeks in a conflict that has killed thousands of people since Croatia declared independence from Yugoslavia in June 25.

HEADLINE: Only Free Commonwealth Will Survive, Yeltsin Says

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Dec. 7

 BODY:
Hours before the beginning of crucial talks among Russia, Byelorussia and Ukraine, the Russian republic's President, Boris N. Yeltsin, said today that only a commonwealth of fully independent countries -- not the confederation envisioned by the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev -- could emerge from the old union.
The idea of a union of sovereign states delegating some responsibilities to a central authority is dead, Mr. Yeltsin told members of the Byelorussian Parliament in the republic's capital, Minsk. 
 He said that even a looser commonwealth would probably be doomed without Ukraine, the second-largest republic, which last weekend voted to become independent.
"Ukraine is a powerful state," Mr. Yeltsin said, "and without its participation, not only will the configuration of any commonwealth change, but above all, the balance of interests, the economic potential and the political prospects of its members."
 
Yeltsin to Offer Alternatiives
 He added that Russia would propose several alternatives for a new community of states during the weekend's talks, which began in the Byelorussian city of Brest tonight.
In remarks made at the Minsk airport as he arrived for the talks,Leonid M. Kravchuk, the Ukrainian President, echoed Mr. Yeltsin's remarks on the fate of the union. "You can persuade Kravchuk, but you cannot persuade the Ukrainian people,' he said. "The old Soviet Union is doomed."
Last weekend, Ukrainians voted overwhelmingly to break loose from Moscow. Still, despite this enormous setback, Mr. Gorbachev continues to be a tireless advocate of union, using every meeting and television appearance as a platform to warn of the disaster that will occur if the union dies.
The continuing disintegration has raised alarms here of a hard-line backlash, a fear heightened today by reports that Mr. Gorbachev had accepted the resignation of Gen. Vladimir Lobov, chief of staff of the armed forces.
According to the independent news agency Interfax, General Lobov, replaced by Gen. Viktor Samsonov, former commander of the Leningrad military district, resigned after Ukraine's vote to withdraw from the union called into question "the continued existence of a united military in the Soviet Union."
 
New Coup Fears
 Mr. Gorbachev and others have recently talked about the possibility of another coup attempt, perhaps involving the military and the old Communist Party apparatus, and most likely set off by popular protests against high prices and food shortages.
Today, in a meeting with American businessmen, the Soviet President reaffirmed his commitment to preserving the union. "I will take active efforts and reach out to the masses if necessary," Mr. Gorbachev said.
But his authority is slipping fast, as the leaders of Russia, Ukraine and Byelorussia meet without him this weekend at a Government villa outside Brest to sort out the future shape of the Slavic heartland.
Mr. Gorbachev said today that he pinned high hopes on the "Slavic summit," but as Mr. Yeltsin's remarks suggest, no outcome is likely to advance the cause of a larger political union.
"The participants in these talks are becoming fewer and fewer," Mr. Yeltsin said. "If it continues like this, there will be nobody around the table at all. Today, we see the failure of the idea of a half-federation, half-confederation, that would implicitly bind each state under a system of dual power."
 
Slavs and Muslims
 Without Ukraine, Russia would be left in a union made up mostly of Central Asian states, which have a different culture, religion and economic base than the Slavs. But if Ukraine chose to be a member of a reformed commonwealth, then a balance would be maintained between Slavs and Muslims, with the republic of Kazakhstan, which has a large Russian population, playing a key role.
On Monday, the Presidents of the three Slavic republics will meet in Moscow with Mr. Gorbachev and Nursultan A. Nazarbayev, the Kazakh President.
The Slavic republics, though they share deep historic and cultural roots, are divided over important questions involving the transition to a market economy.
Russia's plans to liberalize prices this month worry its neighbors, who fear that scarce goods will pour across the border as sellers seek higher prices. And Russia is concerned about the dumping of rubles on its territory, as neighboring republics -- Ukraine in particular -- move toward creating their own currencies.
 
Accord Must Be Practical
 Mr. Yeltsin said that he expected the three would be able to iron out their differences, "as long as we do not ask the impossible of each other." Otherwise, he said, "any treaty, however correct, may just turn into another piece of paper.
"In the critical sphere of finances and currency," Mr. Yeltsin pledged that Russia would refrain from unilateral actions, "as long as it is not provoked by other republics," the Soviet press agency Tass quoted him as saying.
"An exceptionally complex situation has formed on the territory of the ex-Soviet Union," he said. "Therefore, it is important now to look for points of interaction with the sovereign republics rather than to panic."
Most republics have signed two-party treaties over recent months to guarantee continued trade links. Seven republics, including Ukraine and Byelorussia, signed an agreement fixing ceilings on certain food items that will continue to be subsidized under any new price plan.

HEADLINE: SENATORS ASK BAR TO AID TO AMMAN

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7

 BODY:
The Senate Foreign Relations Committee is seeking to block $45 million in American military assistance to Jordan for suspected violations of the international trade embargo against Iraq.
Most of the more than 3,000 tons of goods flowing into Iraq daily by truck from Jordan are food, medical supplies and other humanitarian aid permitted under the United Nations guidelines, Bush Administration officials say. These totals are just a fraction of daily consumption before the Persian Gulf war. 
 But Baghdad is also importing from Jordan communications equipment and spare parts for oil refineries, water treatment plants and electrical power generators, Administration officials said. Reporters traveling into the country along the only open highway saw goods prohibited under the embargo being trucked into Iraq, including newsprint, tractors, tires and crates of machinery that could not be identified.
Iraq is using cash reserves, some secret foreign loans and newly unfrozen assets in foreign banks to pay for the goods, which so far include very little, if any, military equipment, Administration officials said.
 
'Insignificant Leakage'
 The illicit imports represent "relatively insignificant leakage" that does not seriously weaken the embargo's bite, Administration officials said. Without oil revenue, Iraq is unable to support large-scale smuggling and the Administration believes that preventing Baghdad from selling oil for more than a year has had a devastating effect on the country's economy.
Senior American officials concede that they are reluctant to press King Hussein of Jordan, who is struggling to manage his country's feeble economy, particularly as the United States tries to broker a Middle East peace agreement.
"It's a hard balancing act to see how much pressure we can bring to bear without hurting him politically," said a senior Defense Department official.
To punish Amman for its tilt toward Iraq in the gulf war, Congress earlier this year blocked an Administration request for aid to Jordan. The legislation had a provision that allowed President Bush to restore the aid if he determined that Amman was helping the Middle East peace process. Mr. Bush invoked the clause in July for economic aid and last month for military aid, prompting the latest Congressional protest.
 
Barrier Is Built
 A spokesman for the Jordanian Embassy in Washington, Timoor Daghistani, said that Amman was "abiding by the letter of the sanctions." He said that Jordan had built a six-foot-high dirt barrier along the length of its eastern border with Iraq to discourage smuggling, and had increased army desert patrols.
Administration and Congressional officials said that some smuggling was also taking place along Iraq's borders with Iran, Turkey and Syria, but that these were very small operations.
Several members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, which oversees American assistance, have raised concerns that military aid to Jordan should be suspended until Washington is satisfied that Amman is not breaking the embargo.
"There are substantial grounds to question whether Jordan is and will comply fully with the U.N. sanctions," said Senator Claiborne Pell, Democrat of Rhode Island and chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, in a letter sent last month to Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d.
"I believe Jordan should be in full compliance with all international sanctions against Iraq before we resume military assistance," Mr. Pell wrote.
A State Department official said the agency was preparing a response to Mr. Pell's letter, but declined to give any details. The official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, defended resuming military aid to Jordan as a way to insure political stability in the current Government.
 
Bush's Stance
 President Bush released about $35 million in economic assistance in July, and in October sent a letter to Congress saying he was pleased with Jordan's cooperation in the peace process, and would move to release $20 million in military aid and $2 million for training. In addition, the Administration has proposed sending $57 million in aid for the fiscal year that began Oct. 1, including $25 million for military assistance.
In his letter, Mr. Pell raised questions that Jordan may be serving as a conduit for exporting Iraqi sulfur, refined oil products, trucks and earth-moving equipment. Iraq may also be importing steel and communications equipment from Jordan, the letter said.
Iraq cannot sell its main export, oil, on the world market except for about 55,000 barrels a day to Jordan, which the United Nations tacitly approves to offset Iraq's prewar debt to Amman, Administration officials say.
A State Department official said that Jordan stopped exporting Iraqi sulfur and other goods, after Washington protested. Five American, British and Australian ships continue to inspect foreign vessels sailing into the Red Sea port of Aqaba. But there are no inspectors checking the 200 to 300 trucks that cross into Iraq on the main highway from Jordan every day.
Members of Iraq's Republican Guard have reportedly been given three pay raises since the invasion of Kuwait in August 1990, insulating them to some extent from the pinch. There are no clear signs that the sanctions will topple President Saddam Hussein anytime soon.

HEADLINE: PEARL HARBOR REMEMBERED;
Bush, in Breaking Voice, Recalls Day of 'Infamy'

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HONOLULU, Dec. 7

 BODY:
Sniffling a bit and trying to hold back his emotion behind a lopsided smile, George Bush grasped the hand of Lewis Robinson.
"Nice to see you," the President said to the architect from Solana Beach, Calif. "What were you doing that day?" 
 Mr. Robinson, who was wearing a cap and name tag identifying him as a survivor of the Japanese bombing of Pearl Harbor on Dec. 7, 1941, was a seaman first class on the battleship Arizona. The ship became a watery morgue for 1,177 sailors when she was sunk in the Japanese attack that sleepy Sunday morning 50 years ago.
"I was on liberty, trying to get back to the ship," Mr. Robinson told Mr. Bush, who was shot down by the Japanese as he was flying a torpedo bomber named Barbara in the South Pacific in 1944.
The two World War II Navy veterans were standing on the white crescent-shaped Navy memorial that arches above the sunken Arizona, with her rusting gun turret still sticking above the water in the harbor.
 
Emotional Time for Bush
 Only moments earlier, after observing a moment of silence at 7:55 A.M., the moment the attack began, the President had become teary as he finished a speech honoring the dead sailors of the Arizona. He had stopped for a moment, trying to regain his composure by fiddling with his note cards. But his voice broke as he finished the last line of the speech: "God bless America -- the most wondrous land on earth."
President Bush, who shies from personal and emotional content in his public remarks, had told his writers not to fill his three speeches today with personal memories about the day in 1944 when, as a 20-year-old pilot, his plane was shot down over the Chichishima Islands with the loss of his two crewmen. Mr. Bush bailed out, then had to paddle a raft for two hours with his hands, avoiding Japanese patrol boats, before his rescue by an American submarine.
He did recall a bit about the Pearl Harbor attack that persuaded him, when he was a student at Andover, to join the Navy.
"I remember exactly when I first heard the news about Pearl Harbor -- as I'm sure all of you do, too," he told a group of veterans and their families in a speech on the pier in Honolulu.
"I was 17 years old, walking across the green at school," he said. "My thoughts in those days didn't turn to world events, but mainly to simpler things: making the basketball team, entering college. That walk across campus marked an end of innocence for me.
"Like all American kids back then, I was swept up in it. I decided that very day to go into the Navy to become a Navy pilot. And so, on my 18th birthday -- June 12th, 1942 -- I was sworn into the Navy as a seaman second class."
 
Time to Forget Rancor
 Mr. Bush had set a difficult task for himself today. He wanted to give proper due to "the day of infamy," as he called it, paraphrasing President Franklin D. Roosevelt's memorable phrase. But he also wanted to strike a note that it was time to leave the "rancor" about the Japanese behind and move ahead with the Japanese as allies.
For many of the survivors of Pearl Harbor, it was a hard message to swallow.
"The shooting war is over, but the economic war has begun," said Mr. Robinson, after meeting the President.
Asked if he was happy that Mr. Bush had not apologized to Japan about dropping the atom bombs on Hiroshima and Nagasaki, Mr. Robinson said: "Darn right. I would have been disappointed if he had."
But Mr. Bush was determined to use the day to talk about healing and to preach that the lesson of Pearl Harbor is that the United States should never succumb to isolationist tendencies.
 
Thanks to Japanese Leader
 In his final speech on the pier today, the President thanked the Japanese Prime Minister, Kiichi Miyazawa, for his statement about Japan's "responsibility" in starting the war.
"Much appreciated by the people of the United States of America," Mr. Bush said, describing it as "a thoughtful gesture."
Mr. Bush said that his reaction to returning to Pearl Harbor was a generous one, and he urged the other veterans to feel the same.
"I have no rancor in my heart towards Germany or Japan -- none at all," he said. "I hope you have none in yours. There is no time for recrimination.
"No, just speaking for one guy, I have no rancor in my heart. "I can still see the faces of the fallen comrades, and I'll bet you can see the faces of your fallen comrades, too, or family members.
"But don't you think they're saying, 'Fifty years have passed; our country is the undisputed leader of the free world, and we are at peace?'
"Don't you think each one is saying, 'I did not die in vain?' "

HEADLINE: PEARL HARBOR REMEMBERED;
Excerpts of Bush Speech at Ceremony

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: HONOLULU, Dec. 7

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from President Bush's address today to World War II veterans and military families on the 50th anniversary of the attack on Pearl Harbor, as provided by News Transcripts Inc., a private transcription company. 
 Over 2,000 men died in a matter of minutes on this site a half a century ago. Many more died that same day as Japanese forces assaulted the Philippines and Guam and Wake Island, Midway, Malaya, Thailand, Singapore, Hong Kong. On that day of infamy, Pearl Harbor propelled each of us into a titanic contest for mankind's future. It galvanized the American spirit as never, ever before into a single-minded resolve that could produce only one thing, victory.
Churchill knew it as soon as he heard the news. He'd faced the Nazi conquest of Europe, the blitz of London, the terror of the U-boats. But when America was attacked, he declared there was no more doubt about the end. He knew then that the American spirit would not fail the cause of freedom.
The enemy mistook our diversity, our nation's diversity, for weakness. But Pearl Harbor became a rallying cry for men and women from all walks of life, all colors and creeds. And in the end, this unity of purpose made us invincible in war and now makes us secure in peace.
 
. . .
 Ironically, isolationists gathered together at what was known in those days as an American First rally in Pittsburgh at precisely the moment the first Americans met early violent deaths right here at Pearl Harbor.
The isolationists failed to see that the seeds of Pearl Harbor were sown back in 1919 when a victorious America decided that in the absence of a threatening enemy abroad we should turn all of our energies inward. That notion of isolationism flew escort for the very bombers that attacked our men 50 years ago.
 
. . .
 And now we stand triumphant for the third time this century, this time in the wake of the cold war. As in 1919 and in 1945, we face no enemy menacing our security. And yet we stand here today on the site of a tragedy spawned by isolationism. And it is here, and we must learn and this time avoid the dangers of today's isolationism and its economic accomplice, protectionism. To do otherwise, to believe that turning our backs on the world would improve our lot here at home is to ignore the tragic lessons of the 20th century. The fact is, this country has enjoyed its most lasting growth and security when we rejected isolationism, both political and economic, in favor of engagement and leadership.
 
. . .
 Fifty years ago we paid a heavy price for complacency and over-confidence. That, too, is a lesson we shall never forget. To those who have defended our country, from the shores of Guadalcanal to the hills of Korea, and the jungles of Vietnam to the sands of Kuwait, I say this: We will always remember. We will always be prepared -- prepared to take on aggression, prepared to step forward in reconciliation and prepared to secure the peace.
In remembering, it is important to come to grips with the past. No nation can fully understand itself or find its place in the world, if it does not look with clear eyes at all the glories -- and disgraces, too -- of the past.
We in the United States acknowledge such an injustice in our own history. The internment of Americans of Japanese ancestry was a great injustice, and it will never be repeated.
