HEADLINE: Washington at Work;
A Bush Campaign Chief Who Knows Questions

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 7

 BODY:
Robert M. Teeter, the poll taker chosen Thursday to run President Bush's re-election campaign, knows what proportion of Americans favor the death penalty and how many voters think the country is in recession.
But do not expect him to lead the 1992 Bush campaign to focus on any abstract discussion of issues, with the candidate artfully trying to take the same positions that polls indicate are held by the American public. 
 Mr. Teeter himself works comfortably with candidates who hold many sorts of views. Describing an inclination that guides his own campaign advice, he says he has always made decisions about politicians on the basis of character and dedication rather than issues.
 
'Wiser Than the Pundits'
 "I don't think that's unique with me," he said in a telephone interview. "I think that's true of the voters. They are much wiser than the pundits who always bemoan the lack of issue voting. The voters really often have little idea of what the toughest problems will be, and they don't want to pay attention to every little nuance.
"They don't line up eight issues and decide which one they line up with more. They want someone they trust to make value judgments for them."
Issues, he continued, matter most "in the sense that the issues a candidate chooses to talk about, the priorities, give people insight into just what kind of a person that candidate is."
When Mr. Teeter was beginning in Michigan politics in the 1960's, poll takers were hired by campaign managers to provide a product. It was often more mysterious than bumper stickers or even television spots, but it was still a product.
Today, this 52-year-old poll taker is in charge, but not in the sense of studying printouts to figure out what Mr. Bush should be for or against. His approach is more, as Charles Black Jr., a senior adviser to the Bush campaign, puts it, "What is the candidate for that's going to work?"
Eddie Mahe Jr., one of the party's most respected consultants, says Mr. Teeter follows that with the question, "Who can be persuaded?" Mr. Mahe calls him a superior strategist and not merely a tactician, if perhaps "a little professorial." In the campaign, he said, Mr. Teeter will be backed by Mr. Black and Richard N. Bond in providing the "street smarts."
 
'The First Job'
 Polling will contribute to the shape of this campaign, but not immediately, Mr. Teeter said. "The first job is to put together a good campaign team, get good people in all the right jobs and organize them in a way they can work together."
"The next order of business to get the state political organizations set up," a task that has become more urgent with Republican primary challenges coming from State Representative David Duke of Louisiana and probably Patrick J. Buchanan, the conservative columnist.
"Then the third thing is to sit down and think through what the fundamental message of the campaign should be," Mr. Teeter said. Of course that will involve polling, but in his view polling will hardly be dominant. With an incumbent running for re-election, he said, "the biggest single thing you have running for you is your record."
If the economy remains bad, it may be the most important issue in the campaign, Mr. Teeter said, but "you play the cards you get dealt."
The admiration expressed by Mr. Mahe and Mr. Black, who calls Mr. Teeter the "wisest strategist in the party today," is widely shared among Republicans. But some conservatives, who refused to be quoted by name, argued that he was not conservative enough nor as quick to recognize values that appeal to conservatives as he was to those that appeal to, say, suburban moderates.
And he has something of a reputation as an ineffective manager, which Fred Steeper, who has worked with him for 20 years, attributes to a sense that some problems should not be solved in a hurry.
He built Market Opinion Research, a long-established Detroit company that produced marketing and political polls in Michigan, into the dominant Republican polling concern in the nation. He sold his shares in 1987.
And Mr. Steeper is an example of a Teeter management talent that aided the company's rise. He was one of Market Opinion Research's early recruits from the University of Michigan's Institute for Social Research, which provided trained poll takers who then insured high methodological standards at the company.
Not an academically trained survey researcher himself, Mr. Teeter brought two major strengths to Market Opinion Research polling. One was a curiosity about the wording of questions, about how they would sound and what people would hear. "He forces me to make the question more relevant and more interesting to the respondent," Mr. Steeper said. At Market Strategies Inc., a company he helped form after he left Market Opinion Research.
Mr. Teeter's other primary strength was an ability to identify and disregard data that did not seem to make sense, not to regard polls as political Scripture. Robert D. Ray, a Teeter client who was Governor of Iowa from 1969 to 1982, said, "He can read a poll and tell you what's wrong with it, and what's wrong with the answers and what to watch out for."
Mr. Teeter's father, Howard, was active in Republican politics in Coldwater, a small town in southern Michigan for which Mr. Teeter's consulting company, Coldwater Corporation, is named, and the son became involved at 25. That was in 1964, when his father was a delegate to the convention in San Francisco that nominated Barry Goldwater for President.
Howard Teeter recalled that just before the convention his son was at loose ends on vacation from a coaching job at Adrian College in Michigan. "I arranged for him to go" to the convention and "he ends up an assistant sergeant at arms," he said.
He went on to do advance work for Gov. George Romney's re-election bid that summer, and from there he went to the Republican State Committee. By 1967 Mr. Teeter had joined Market Opinion Research.
 
Gerald Ford's Assessment
 He polled for Richard M. Nixon, but the first Presidential candidate he was close to was Gerald R. Ford, in 1976. "His polling gave us, I think, the right issues to use, not only in the pre-convention against Reagan, but in the general election against Carter," Mr. Ford said Friday.
In 1980 he worked for Mr. Bush's ill-fated campaign against Mr. Reagan.
Mr. Reagan was no favorite of Mr. Teeter, and he said in March 1980 that he would not vote for the Californian in November. But he said he did. By 1984, he was the coordinator of Mr. Reagan's television advertising.
In Mr. Bush's 1988 campaign he provided much broader advice than he would as a poll taker alone, and he suffered in silence when others said he pushed Dan Quayle for vice president. It is a subject -- because it was a decision by Mr. Bush -- that he will not discuss.
When Mr. Teeter did not join the Administration, Washington found inconceivable the explanation that he did not like the city much and that he preferred to let his teen-agers, Katy and John, finish school in Ann Arbor. The conventional explanation here was that he could not get along with John H. Sununu, Mr. Bush's chief of staff, whose influence was soaring. Mr. Teeter said that they often disagreed, but that they got along fine.
Katy is now a freshman at Princeton University, but John's hockey at Ann Arbor Pioneer High School will still draw Mr. Teeter back to Michigan. So will his cottage at Coldwater Lake, where, his wife, Betsy, says, he loves to fish for crappies. "He doesn't catch much," she said. "Well, the fishing isn't as good as it used to be."
Those trips home will become less frequent as the campaign heats up. After all, Mr. Steeper's latest numbers on a survey question that he and Mr. Teeter popularized show that only 24 percent of the public says the country is going in the right direction and 68 percent say it is pretty seriously off on the wrong track.
Mr. Teeter offers no such doubts. He calls Mr. Bush "dedicated to public service in the best sense of the word."
 
 
 
ROBERT M. TEETER

 
Born: Feb. 5, 1939.
 
Hometown: Ann Arbor.
 
Education: B.A., Albion College; M.A., Michigan State University.
 
Career Highlights: 1961-64, instructor at Albion College and Adrian College; 1964-66, positions with the Michigan Republican State Committee and George Romney's gubernatorial campaign; 1966-87, management positions with Market Opinion Research of Detroit; 1988, senior adviser and chief poll-taker for the Bush presidential campaign; 1989-present, President, Coldwater Corporation, a political consulting company.
 
Hobbies: Reading, fishing, hunting and sailing.

HEADLINE: A.N.C. Figure to Lead Communists

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, Dec. 7

 BODY:
Despite initial reluctance from the African National Congress, its popular military leader, Chris Hani, was named today to lead the South African Communist Party as the party mobilizes support for what it hopes will be a Marxist future for South Africa.
Chris Hani, who is chief of staff of the congress's guerrilla wing, Spear of the Nation, was elected at the Communists' four-day congress to succeed Joe Slovo as General Secretary. Mr. Slovo, who is ailing, assumed the largely honorary role of national chairman. The congress was the party's first inside South Africa in 41 years. 
 Both Mr. Hani, who is 49 years old, and Mr. Slovo, 65, are expected to remain on the African National Congress's executive committee and its inner working group. The two organizations have been allies for more than three decades and, as Mr. Hani observed today, Communists are active in the congress leadership.
Mr. Hani's election seemed likely to reinforce the Communist Party's longstanding alliance with the African National Congress while bolstering its own identity. The popular Mr. Hani, who peppers his speeches with Marxist language, is especially popular with militant black youths eager for radical solutions to the economic inequities caused by apartheid.
At the same time, the Marxist-Leninist line taken by the party -- at a time when that ideology has been discredited elsewhere in the world -- seemed likely to raise fresh questions about how the congress would justify such close ties with the Communists in soliciting foreign investment and other Western support. The party's new constitution demands an end to "capitalist exploitation" and its replacement with undiluted socialism.
 
Mandela Advised
 In July, the congress refused to let Mr. Hani work full time for the Communist Party, contending that he could not be spared. Nonethless, Mr. Hani was nominated without opposition on Friday and confirmed today as the party's General Secretary.
At a news briefing today, Mr. Slovo said the congress's leader, Nelson Mandela, who is in the United States, had been informed of Mr. Hani's new post and did not object.
Mr. Hani told reporters that he hoped to have some ties with Spear of the Nation but doubted that he could remain as its chief of staff, the top military position.
"The position of General Secretary of the S.A.C.P. is a full-time job," he said. "Obviously, I've got to spend more of my time doing party work."
Mr. Slovo said Mr. Hani would probably lead the Communist delegation to the convention of political parties on Dec. 20 that is expected to launch negotiations on ending white-minority rule.
The South African Communist Party, which says it has a membership of 25,000, sees a glowing future for the future of Marxism there.
The congress delegates, by a 3-to-1 margin, voted to eliminate the word "democratic" from a principle committing the party to establish a "democratic socialist society" in South Africa. Some delegates argued that socialism was inherently democratic. Mr. Slovo, who wanted to keep the adjective, contends that Communism failed in the Soviet Union because it was not democratic.
 
De Klerk to See Gorbachev
 The ideological gap between the South African Communists and their former patrons in the Kremlin is expected to grow even wider when President F. W. de Klerk arrives in the Soviet Union on Friday and meets President Mikhail S. Gorbachev during a four-day visit.
Mr. Hani was the party's most prestigious candidate to replace Mr. Slovo, who is battling cancer of the bone marrow and wants to concentrate on his duties with the African National Congress. There was also pressure to choose a black to replace the Lithuanian-born Mr. Slovo, since most party members are black.
Mr. Hani, who was born in the Transkei in 1942, considered becoming a Roman Catholic priest before be was drawn into anti-apartheid politics. He joined the congress's guerrilla wing in exile in 1962, becoming chief of staff in 1987. Since the African National Congress suspended its armed struggle against white rule 16 months ago, Mr. Hani has become more active in political matters.
Mr. Hani was elected to the congress's National Executive Committee in 1974 and represents the congress's more militant wing.
Though his full name is Martin Thembisile Hani, he is known to friends and enemies alike as Chris.

HEADLINE: PEARL HARBOR REMEMBERED;
Veterans Talk of Horror of War and Forgiveness

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Dec. 7

 BODY:
"We watched them dig their graves and we watched their firing squads -- everybody had to fall out for that," said Arnold Bocksel, a 78-year-old survivor of the Bataan Death March, recalling the shootings and beheadings of hundreds of fellow prisoners along the 65-mile journey through the Philippine jungle.
Mr. Bocksel spent three and a half years as one of the about 27,000 Americans who, military records show, were taken prisoner by the Japanese during World War II. He was one of about 16,000 who survived captivity. 
 His vivid and painful recollections were part of the debate of the issues involving the United States and Japan during World War II discussed here at a conference sponsored by by the Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt Institute and Hofstra University.
The three-day conference, which ended today with a memorial ceremony, was one of the many observances in the New York metropolitan area and across the country to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor.
 
Mayor Addresses Veterans
 In New York, at the Intrepid Sea, Air, Space Museum at Pier 86 on the Hudson River, Mayor David N. Dinkins addressed a group of veterans, including 21 survivors of Pearl Harbor.
The Mayor said he was speaking to honor all the victims of the attack, including 56 civilians. "They died not on battleship row, or Wheeler Field, but on the streets and in the houses in the city of Honolulu," he said. "That day they joined 2,400 other Americans from all branches of the armed services in a procession of martyrdom that this nation cannot, must not and will not forget."
 
Academics Debated Issues
 At the conference in Hempstead, historians and economists-- such speakers as Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr.; Eliot Janeway; C. Douglas Dillon, the former Secretary of the Treasury; and Paul H. Nitze, the former Secretary of the Navy -- debated the causes of the war, Japanese-American internment camps, strategic policy, naval strategy and the events leading to Pearl Harbor.
Akira Iriye, a history professor at Harvard, reminded the several hundred students at the conference that Japan not only made war against the United States, but against all the peoples of Asia.
"Those people still remember the war strongly and emotionally," he said. "It was a war against humanity and Japan does owe them an apology."
Professor Iriye said that German historians had been more self-searching and critical of Germany's role in World War II, but the Japanese have "chosen to forget."
Stephen E. Ambrose, a historian who was a keynote speaker at the conference, said the 50th anniversary of American entry into World War II invited new study by " the fresh eyes of a new generation born since the war."
But as a member of the generation that fought the war, Mr. Bocksel, of Wantagh, L.I., said he attributed his survival to "faith and lots of luck."
"It was an emotional roller coaster," he said. "To be a prisoner of war is to enter a dimension that is entirely alien to anything you have ever experienced before."
"I forgive the Japanese for what they did to me," he said. " My personal religious ethic teaches me that. To me it's like a serious wound I've had that's left an ugly scar."

 
VETERAN BURNS JAPANESE FLAG
 CONYERS, Ga., Dec. 7 -- A World War II veteran placed a Japanese battle flag in a barbecue grill in the back of his pickup truck this morning and set it afire to mark the 50th anniversary of the attack on Pearl Harbor.
The veteran, Bob Mensinger, burned the battle flag before a crowd of about 50 people at 7:55 A.M. The bombing of Pearl Harbor began at 7:55 A.M. on Dec. 7, 1941.
Mr. Mensinger said he wasn't trying to offend present Japanese citizens, but was remembering the 2,000 who died at Pearl Harbor.
City officials had asked Mr. Mensinger not to burn the flag and urged four Japanese-owned companies with plants here to ignore the event.
An official at one company, Seiji Ohmasu, general manager of Takahashi Works Company, said, "We are too busy to be angry."

Mayor David N. Dinkins, second from right, joined in the ceremonies. (Keith Meyers/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Violent Crime in Dublin Shakes the City's Serenity

BYLINE: By JAMES F. CLARITY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DUBLIN, Dec. 7

 BODY:
A recent spate of iolent crime in the Dublin area has shaken the city's sense of security and its reputation as one of Europe's more peaceful capitals.
The crime rate here is hardly comparable with the rates of larger European or American cities. There is not a proportionately large drug problem here, and there is no widespread mayhem in the streets, even in the tougher parts of the capital area, where about a third of the country's 3.5 million people live. 
 But to the Irish, the problem is alarming, and the perception is growing that violent crime is markedly on the rise. On Friday a gang of masked men with shotguns ran through rush-hour shoppers in the center of the capital as they took about $18,000 from a security guard at a restaurant in fashionable St. Stephen's Green and about $5,700 at an antiques auction being held in Mansion House, which includes the residence of the Lord Mayor and is a short walk from Trinity College and the Parliament.
Two weeks ago, police officers and firefighters in suburban public housing areas have been stoned by mobs of young toughs. Youths also steal cars, joyride them up and down the streets to the cheers of bystanders, then set them afire to finish the show. Until recently, this was the kind of thing that people here thought happened only in Britain and America.
Two months ago a gang of youths leaving a pub around midnight beat a man senseless on the city's main avenue, O'Connell Street. A German camper was mugged and killed last summer in Phoenix Park, a few steps from the residences of President Mary Robinson and the American Ambassador, Richard A. Moore.
 
From Homicide to Hepplewhite
 The police, who have 3,900 officers in the capital area, are often accused of playing down crime. The state police weekly television program usually starts with reports of a homicide or rape, but quickly moves into descriptions of stolen lawn mowers, family jewels and Hepplewhite chairs, asking the public to phone in clues.
The most recent police statistics, for 1990, show that the overall crime rate per 1000 people was 24.8 nationally and 47.6 in the Dublin area. There were 35,453 "offenses against property with violence" in the nation, an increase of 2 percent. A sharper increase is expected when statistics are compiled for 1991, since the effects of the recession began to accelerate this year.
The Lord Mayor of Dublin, Sean Kenny, attributes the increase to the weakened economy. He said in a recent interview that he feared that tourism, one of Ireland's major money earners, would be hurt by a perception that Dublin is becoming more dangerous.
Officials are hoping for an increase in tourists from the United States next year. Last year, tourism from the United States dropped sharply. Americans were afraid of flying becuse of terrorist threats during the Persian Gulf war.
The crime increase is largely in suburban areas, but there also is a rise reported by residents in working class parts of north Dublin -- near the district where the film "The Commitments" was made, the commuter train station was recently set on fire by vandals -- and in wealthy areas of the inner city. In recent months, the houses of four American diplomats have been broken into; in one case, a senior diplomat was tied up by the robbers, who broke into his house at night.
 
The Price of Recession
 "Oh it's definitely on the rise," said a middle-aged Irishwoman. "It's the unemployment. They should put them to work, cleaning up the streets, things like that. At least when they come home at night, they'll be tired."
"The consequences of unemployment and isolation are well known," said The Irish Times in an editorial calling on the Government to "embark on the program of financial and political investment which is so clearly and so urgently needed."
There is little disagreement that the recession in the rest of Europe and the United States is the cause of the increase in unemployment, now 20 percent nationally and as high as 70 percent in some working class Dublin area neighborhoods.
The Government, after acknowledging in a parliamentary debate this week that crime generally had risen 8 percent in the first half of the year, announced that it was setting up a task force of Government department heads to deal with the problem. Other Irish have various ideas of their own.
As public outrage rose with the attacks on the firefighters and the police, Mayor Kenny urged people not to form vigilante groups. Instead, about 2,000 people marched peacefully Thursday night in the western suburbs of Ronanstown and Neilstown. Some youths in the area have said that the police harass them. But for now, virtually all the public sympathy is for the police and the fault is laid to thugs and the economy.

HEADLINE: Feinstein Says Use of Control Board Deserves Study

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
As the Dinkins administration struggled yesterday to squeeze a new round of budget cuts from New York City agencies, a major municipal labor leader said it was time to consider the merits of having the State Financial Control Board step in to oversee the city's fiscal affairs so the painful cuts might be stretched over more time.
In raising that prospect, the union leader, Barry Feinstein, president of Local 237 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, appeared to be stepping up public pressure on Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and Mayor David N. Dinkins to agree swiftly on a plan to address huge budget shortfalls in the coming years. 
 Governor Cuomo heads the control board and has said he would be reluctant to invoke its powers. Mayor Dinkins sits on the board and has vowed to resist its intervention at all costs.
Mr. Feinstein also seemed to be signaling to the chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, Felix G. Rohatyn, that he was so eager for the city to win the $1 billion in aid that Mr. Rohatyn has said could be provided by refinancing M.A.C. bonds that Mr. Feinstein would consider a stepped-up role for the control board. Mr. Rohatyn has said the control board would have to approve any aid plan.
It was far less clear whether Mr. Feinstein would actually welcome intervention by the control board, which could assume sweeping powers and essentially suspend normal collective bargaining. But the board could also give Mr. Feinstein a villain to blame if his union is required to accept more cuts.
 
Willing to Lose Face
 Frustrated at months of fitful talks with the city, Mr. Feinstein has repeatedly said he does not trust the administration to craft a plan of its own and has sought to involve the Governor and other state officials more closely. But he has not challenged Mr. Dinkins's insistence that the control board not take a greater role.
Speaking at a conference on city finances sponsored by the Citizens Budget Commission, a private watchdog group financed by businesses, Mr. Feinstein stressed that he was not calling for the control board to take over.
But he said that he now believed that the city's economic problems were so severe, consensus on how to solve them so lacking and the probable impact of further cuts in the city workforce so disruptive that every option should be explored, even if it meant some loss of face for the city or the Mayor.
"It seems to me that one of the things we'd better look at again is why a control board process is just an anathema," he said. Instead of dismissing the idea as something that scares everybody, he said, "we ought to re-understand and redefine and check again."
The control board was established during the fiscal crisis of the mid-1970's to supervise the city's finances. It has broad powers to approve labor contracts and make harsh cuts to bring the budget into balance. Since the early 1980's it has had only oversight authority, but the board could resume binding powers if the city failed to balance its budget or appeared likely to fail.
If the control board resumed powers, the city could be freed from the necessity of balancing the budget each June, suspending the tight controls under which it has had to operate for the last decade. That might give the city more time to bring revenues and spending into line instead of having to make deep cuts all at once.
But Mayor Dinkins has repeatedly said that any such possible advantages were illusory and would be far outweighed by the stigma of ceding control of the city's spending decisions to others. The Mayor has said that deep cuts would have to be made in any case.
"Since the Financial Control Board has no greater power to manage or improve the city's fiscal condition than the powers the Mayor already has, Mr. Feinstein's suggestion shows a singular lack of imagination in identifying innovative solutions to the problems we face," the Mayor's press secretary, Leland T. Jones, said yesterday.
Mr. Jones said that Mr. Feinstein was "trying to divert people from the real problems" and should concentrate instead on working with the city to bring down the cost of employee health benefits and make the workforce more productive.
Mr. Cuomo, wrestling to keep the state's own huge budget problems under control and settle the question of his presidential candidacy, has repeatedly said he would not favor a takeover by the control board as long as the mayor opposed it.
Several times yesterday, Mr. Feinstein expressed frustration at the stalemate over the budget, and at Mr. Rohatyn's and other fiscal monitors' reluctance to provide the M.A.C. aid, despite the administration's latest plan for cutting the budget further.
"The non-government government has decided that the four-year plan that the government government gave did not meet the non-government government's needs," he said.

HEADLINE: More Cuts Sought of New York Agency Heads

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
The heads of all New York City agencies were summoned to special budget meetings yesterday because the plans they submitted last week for long-term cuts fell short of their targets, the city's budget director said.
The director, Philip R. Michael, said several of the agencies had submitted plans that relied too heavily on work-rule changes and labor concessions that they have no control over. He said the purpose of the meetings yesterday was to begin finding cuts that could be made without the help of municipal labor unions. 
 Mr. Michael declined to specify the targets, which have been requested both as part of the city's efforts to revise its long-term fiscal plan and as a contingency in case the state cuts its aid sharply in closing its own budget gap.
But some agency heads said they had been asked to cut at least 3 percent a year from their budgets for supplies, rent and other costs outside of salaries and to reduce their work forces by 8 percent a year over the duration of the plan, through attrition if possible. Some agencies are looking at cuts of up to 20 percent.
 
Beyond Worst Case
 "It's a horror-show scenario," one commissioner said during a break in the meetings yesterday. "It's beyond a worst-case scenario."
Mr. Michael said yesterday that layoffs were being considered in the last two years of the plan, but he would not give details. He said the revamped plan "emphasizes that attrition is the way to go, but it recognizes that due to managerial perogatives there could be layoffs that are necessary."
Mr. Michael called the plans being drawn up "speculative." Asked what chance they have of coming to pass, he said, "It's likely a lot of these cuts are going to have to be made."
The meetings, which were closed to the public, occurred against a backdrop of growing apprehension among state fiscal monitors and bond-rating agencies about the city's ability to come up with a workable plan to bring its spending in line with falling tax revenues over the next several years. The recession has decimated tax revenues, and the city is facing at least $7 billion in budget gaps over that period.
 
Scrambling for Magic
 Last month, Mayor Dinkins agreed to overhaul the five-year budget plan he unveiled on Nov. 6 after state fiscal monitors complained that it lacked specifics, failed to cut the work force enough and hinged on highly uncertain labor concessions and special fees.
A crucial piece of the Mayor's plan was $1 billion in aid that could be provided through the refinancing of bonds sold by the state Municipal Assistance Corporation. The chairman of the corporation, Felix G. Rohatyn, has repeatedly said he will not provide the aid unless the city gets a stamp of approval for its plan from the state Financial Control Board, which was set up in the 70's to oversee the city's finances and has had only advisory powers since the early 1980's.
Responding to criticism from the assistance corporation, city budget officials have been scrambling to find a magic formula that would put flesh on the Mayor's skeletal goals, avoiding politically unpopular layoffs or tax increases while satisfying Mr. Rohatay and state control board officials.
Adding to the complexity of the problem, the city's fiscal picture has changed since the November plan was unveiled because the estimates of the state government's budget gap for the next fiscal year have nearly doubled, to $3.6 billion, casting doubt on nearly $2 billion in extra state aid the Mayor was counting on. How the state will handle its deficit is still in question, but the city agency heads were laying out plans yesterday for the worst case, city officials said.

HEADLINE: Take Psychics, Add Malls, Watch Business Grow

BYLINE: By CHARLES STRUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARSIPPANY, N.J.

 BODY:
For expatriate urban dwellers who have long believed the future was in the suburbs, now comes evidence that this is true, perhaps beyond their wildest dreams.
And like most things in the suburbs, the future is available at the mall. Nothing flashy, no thunderbolts, no Steven Spielberg. Just a few tables, perhaps booths for privacy and 8 or 10 astrologers or psychics to help the earth-bound see beyond the horizon. 
 But like most good malls and anything as vast as the future, organization is needed. And organization ultimately means office space, which must be leased. Which is how Adcom Inc., an advertising and marketing agency run by Vincent and Shirley Tabatneck, became Adcom Inc.-Psychic Fairs. That was 15 years ago, when they organized their first psychic fair at the Willowbrook Mall in Wayne, and, it goes without saying, they never looked back.
"Willowbrook was one of our accounts, and at lunch one day we were talking astrology and metaphysics," Mrs. Tabatneck said. Willowbrook's response was, "Oh, what a great idea! A tearoom for mother."
So Mrs. Tabatneck, a one-time astronomy student at Fairleigh Dickinson University who turned from telescopes to charts, parlayed a lifelong study of astrology into a labor of love.
 
No Beaded Curtains or Incense

The future, then, truly begins not at a mall, but in a pleasant if nondescript office park just east of the 24-hour Par-Troy diner on Route 46. There, in a small suite of several undecorated offices, just beyond a tiny waiting room where, curiously enough, most of the magazines are at least a year old, the Tabatnecks keep tabs on a loosely knit nationwide registry of psychic consultants, each of whom must fill out an application and provide evidence of experience as a reader of minds.
Mrs. Tabatneck also does private consulting there, but note the absence of beaded curtains, burning incense, crystal balls or the soundstage gypsy trappings.
Mrs. Tabatneck is no Madame Arcati seeking communion with blithe spirits. She is as comfortable speaking the lingo of stockbrokers (many are clients) as she is speaking of the cosmic effects of a retrograde Mercury transit. (No it's not a car, it's a troubling planetary sign that means stay away from business deals for the present.)
"I'm not a fortuneteller," she said. "Fortunetellers can be psychics." But too often, she said, "they are the type of people who would tell you anything you want to hear, and cast out the evil spirits and have you bring water from your faucet."
This is not read-and-run, Mr. Tabatneck said. "Sometimes a person doesn't hit it off with a reader. After a few minutes, that person can decide it's not working and try another one." No charge for the one that didn't work.
Mr. Tabatneck said psychic fairs have fallen off a bit during the recession, and now Adcom has established a 900 number for readings by phone.
Because there is no national association of clairvoyants, the Tabatnecks weed out the fortunetellers through a word-of-mouth network.
But the questions persist: Is this entertainment or something more complicated? And who's to judge?
"The malls don't want to take a stand on this one way or the other," Mr. Tabatneck said. "Some states have laws that say it has to be advertised for entertainment purposes."
If it entertains, so be it. The Tabatnecks are true believers in the power of the cosmos, and they take their parapsychology seriously. After Willowbrook came Livingston and Menlo Park and Paramus Park and Nanuet and Cross County, as well as Florida, California, Indiana, Ohio and Pennsylvania. At grand openings, grand reopenings or white sales, Adcom has been there with tables of perhaps 10 psychics, prepared to consult the stars, read palms or decipher tarot cards, for $15 a quarter-hour.
But if the future, in fact, is in the suburbs, does it stand to reason that the future also comes with a suburban tinge?
No, says Mrs. Tabatneck. People, wherever they are, still care about the same things: love and money. But she has noticed some changes recently.
 
Love, Money and Cuomo's Run
 "People are talking about going back with their ex-husband or ex-boyfriend. Everyone is into resuming relationships right now and it's the strangest thing.
"It's the AIDS situation, No. 1, and No. 2, it's the economic situation in the country," she said. "They also realized that the reasons they broke up in the first place were not real."
Taking chances, though, is something most people are poised to do when they visit a psychic. The question is: should they take it? Of late, some visitors have been politicians.
"They ask if they're going to make it," she said. "So far the only ones I've advised have been the ones I told were not going to make it. Although they are going to make it in the future."
And then there is the case of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.
"I feel he's going to run. I feel he's really, really worried and really nervous about it. I still feel Bush is going to get in."
Gov. Jim Florio in '93? "I don't think so."
Phil Simms or Jeff Hostetler as the Giants' first-string quarterback?
Shifting in her chair, with a sensation of discomfort in her back, where Hostetler suffered some broken bones against Tampa Bay, she said: "I think it will be Simms."

HEADLINE: New York State to Install 3,000 More Prison Beds

BYLINE: By SELWYN RAAB

 BODY:
Saying they are out of space to handle an overflow of prisoners, New York State authorities began installing 3,000 bunks last week under an emergency $40 million-expansion program.
With no new prisons on the drawing board and with the inmate population still rising, officials said as many as 6,000 bunks might have to be added to the 57,000 beds now in the state prison system. The new bunks will be placed atop existing beds in medium-security dormitories. There will be no double-bunking in maximum-security cells. 
 The state is resuming double-bunking in prison dormitories although many prison experts maintain the policy often creates security problems. Many experts frown on double-bunking, claiming it heightens tension between inmates and guards, overcrowds sanitary and recreational centers and can even generate prisoner disputes over watching television.
 
Tighter Security
 Thomas A. Coughlin 3d, the state's top prison official, said that about 760 correction officers would be hired to tighten security and reinforce the 18,000 guards now on duty.
New Jersey and Connecticut have also instituted double-bunking to house larger prison populations created by surging crime rates in the 1980's and harsher sentences.
New York State authorities said their emergency double-bunking plan was prompted mainly to trim a growing backlog of almost 3,000 convicted and sentenced prisoners in New York City jails -- known as state-ready inmates -- who are awaiting transfers to state custody. The city's jail population had decreased sharply in the summer but a recent transfer slowdown because of the lack space at state prisons has brought the city's jails to the brink of overcrowding.
"We were getting a lot of flak from them," said Mr. Coughlin, the Commissioner of the state's Division of Correctional Services, referring to complaints from city officials about the transfer slowdown. About 60 percent of the state's inmates are city residents.
 
'A Grim Move'
 The state had virtually abandoned double-bunking earlier this year. Mr. Coughlin said the decision to resume the practice was a "grim move," and one he made reluctantly. But he said he did it because there was little chance of eliminating the overcrowding through quick legislative approval for new prisons or expanding alternatives to incarceration like probation and work-release programs.
"There was no light at the end of the tunnel," he said.
The city's 17 jails held 22,055 inmates on Friday, putting them at 98 percent of their capacity of 22,300. As recently as September, only 1,100 prisoners in New York City were awaiting transfer to state prisons. Last week the number swelled to almost 3,000.
The state prison population rose to 57,000 last week, about 9,000 inmates above the intended capacity.
Mr. Coughlin said that the first 3,000 beds would be in place by February.
State Health Department officials, he emphasized, had reviewed the plan and found that the tighter living conditions would not create any added risk of tuberculosis. A new strain of drug-resistant tuberculosis has killed 13 inmates and a guard this year in the state prison system.
 
Longer Mandatory Sentences
 In addition to the transfer backlog, officials attributed the recent overcrowding at state prisons to two other factors: slower turnover of prisoners because of longer mandatory sentences that judges must impose on recidivist criminals and the high unemployment in New York City, which has sharply cut the number of inmates who can be released into a work-supervision program.
Since June 1990, New Jersey has converted 680 cells into double bunks. The state's 15 prisons were designed for about 18,000 inmates and currently hold about 24,000, said Patricia Mulcahy, a spokeswoman for the state Department of Corrections.
Ms. Mulcahy said about 3,300 prisoners are being kept in county jails and 3,000 are housed in trailers and in prison classrooms, gymnasiums and chapels that have been renovated into dormitories.
New Jersey has no immediate plan to expand double-bunking and would probably rely on more trailers outside prison buildings as an emergency measure, she said.
In Connecticut, about 7,500 of the state's 10,000 inmates are held in cells and dormitories with double bunks. William E. Flower, a spokesman for the state's Correction Department, said that Connecticut's 21 prisons were roughly at 100 percent of capacity and that three new prisons are expected to open in the next two years to ease overcrowding.
 
Inmate Disturbance in 1990
 Except for an inmate disturbance in 1990 at the Carl Robinson Correctional Institution in Enfield, Mr. Flower said that double-bunking had been extensively used without serious security problems in Connecticut.
New York State's prison population has climbed from 28,499 in 1982, when the state had 39 prisons, to a current 57,000 inmates housed in 68 centers. The system is intended to hold about 48,500 inmates. In recent years, overcrowding has been handled by squeezing more single beds into dormitories and temporarily converting closed psychiatric hospitals into prisons.
The state's budget shortfalls have shelved plans for large-scale prison construction. A medium-security prison for 750 inmates costs $80 million to build and $18 million to operate each year.
Richard H. Girgenti, the state's Criminal Justice director, said that about $40 million would be allocated in the current budget to cover the cost of the double-bunking program and the payments to New York City and counties for temporarily housing state inmates.
The state pays counties and New York City about $40 a day once a prisoner is certified as ready for transfer. However, the city has pressed the state for quicker transfers, claiming that it spends $158 a day to maintain each inmate.
New York City and counties are responsible for the custody of defendants who are awaiting trial or who have been convicted of misdemeanors with sentences of less than one year. The state incarcerates people convicted of felonies with sentences of more than a year.
State officials said the prison congestion stemmed partly from a law requiring repeat felony offenders to serve at least half of their maximum terms before becoming eligible for parole. The law, in effect since 1980 as a means of getting tough with criminals, has increased the average prison term for 50 percent of the state's prisoners.
Most first-time offenders can be paroled after serving one-third of their maximum sentence, thereby allowing a faster exodus from prisons.
State prison officials said they had expected to open up more space this fall by discharging 2,500 inmates to live and work in the city through a program called "Day Release." To qualify an inmate must be within six months of parole and have a job and a residence in the city.
Mr. Coughlin said that the program was cut back to 800 because most prisoners were unable to find work in the city.
Mr. Girgenti, who is Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's top aide on criminal-justice matters, said that as part of a plan to reduce overcrowding, the Cuomo administration would propose that the Legislature give judges more discretion to hand out shorter sentences for nonviolent and noncoercive felony crimes -- primarily drug possession convictions.
He said that the administration would also urge the Legislature to grant judges more authority to send drug offenders to rehabilitation programs instead of prisons.
Nine upstate prisons for men will get double bunks along with the Bedford Hills Correctional Facility in Westchester County, a women's prison. The double-bunking began this week at prisons in Ogdensburg and Watertown, both in the northern part of the state. The bunks are being built and installed by prisoners employed by the Correctional Division.
The return of double-bunking has raised concerns about health and security. "There are a lot of unnecessary perils associated with double-bunking," said Robert Gangi, the executive director of the Correctional Association of New York, a private body empowered by the Legislature to inspect and report on conditions in state prisons.
Mr. Gangi said he was "skeptical about claims that this kind of widespread overcrowding won't increase tuberculosis risks."
Bob Lawson, a spokesman for the the union that represents correction officers, Council 82 of the Security and Law Enforcement Employees, said the council was pleased that 614 officers who had been laid off this year would be rehired. "The bitter part of this is that double-bunking is extremely dangerous for officers," Mr. Lawson said, warning that the additional beds and crowded conditions made it more difficult to observe and control unruly inmates.

HEADLINE: New Jersey Moves to Standardize the Cleanup of Toxic Waste

BYLINE: By CHARLES STRUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWARK, Dec. 6

 BODY:
New Jersey is about to chart the future of its industrial economy, its land and its water in a way no state ever has.
The vehicle is a set of guidelines being drafted by the state's environmental regulators to cover the cleanup of almost 200 toxic compounds. The guidelines represent a benchmark in environmental management and control, but just as important is their potential as a catalyst or an obstacle to development. 
 The Federal Government and the states have customarily applied cleanup standards case by case, which industrialists and regulators acknowledge can be slow and expensive. With the state overseeing thousands of sites and technology evolving, businesses say they are ill served by standards that seem to change in the middle of the game, sometimes forcing manufacturers to clean their properties more than once.
That is how New Jersey has approached toxic cleanup since 1983, when the Environmental Cleanup Responsibility Act took effect. The act requires contaminated industrial sites be cleaned before they can be transferred or abandoned. But it lacks specific standards.
 
Time for Standards
 "The science just wasn't there" at the time, said Lance R. Miller, an assistant commissioner in the State Department of Environmental Protection and Energy, who is at the center of the drafting of the guidelines.
But with scientific advancements, prodding by the courts and agreement among business people and environmentalists that setting standards makes sense, the department is preparing to submit draft regulations to its Commissioner, Scott A. Weiner, before the end of the year. Meanwhile, the President-elect of the State Senate, Donald T. DiFrancesco, said recently that the Legislature should consider revising the cleanup act so businesses would have more incentives to clean properties rather than abandon them.
Mr. Weiner said he recognizes the challenge before his department. Now, he added, it is time for clearly articulated standards, "generic guidance, but with the flexibility to apply that to a specific case."
Whether the new rules will help revive the state's faltering economy or stunt its growth has been debated since last spring, when something the department called its pre-proposals became public.
 
Ideally, a Spur to Growth
 Optimally, the guidelines could help encourage the kind of development that Newark, Camden, Trenton, Paterson and other cities desperately need to regain their status as centers of commerce. The rules could encourage new interest in waterfront reclamation and the widespread cleanup and preservation of aquifers. They could also set a pattern for other states and the Federal Government, which modeled its Superfund cleanup law on legislation adopted in New Jersey in the 1970's.
Industry spokesmen and some public officials, notably Mayor Sharpe James of Newark, applaud the goal, but warn that if the regulations are too stringent, cities will have little hope of keeping or attracting industry.
Environmentalists counter that if standards are too lenient, the state will have mortgaged the health of its citizens, the quality of its water and its open space for immediate economic gratification. Eventually, they say, the state and its citizens will pay a far higher price.
"Everyone wants to have a standard, but what standard do they really want?" said Rob Stuart, program director for the New Jersey Public Interest Research Group. The research group said the environmental agency's pre-proposals were seriously flawed.
 
Industrial vs. Residential
 The battle centers on basic issues. For example, should there be different standards of cleanliness for industrial and residential sites? Environmentalists say no. Business groups and some public officials say yes.
Hal Bozarth, a spokesman for the Chemical Industry Association, contends that there should be separate standards because a longtime industrial site is unlikely to be used for anything else. Mayor James of Newark concurs, saying that if an industrial site near housing can be made safe for its neighbors, it need not be cleaned beyond that standard.
"The City of Newark is not advocating a trade-off of public health protection for economic development," he said. But he added, "when industry leaves the city, there are fewer jobs and fewer ratables, which in turn potentially results in additional cases of homelessness, child abuse and drug abuse, and less money to address these problems."
Environmentalists argue that cleaning a site to meet only human health standards ignores that a safe standard for humans may be unsuitable for more susceptible organisms. Besides, they say, what about ground water runoff, blowing soil and other so-called pathways of contamination?
 
How Much Say for Towns?
 Other debates have centered on the right of towns to set their own rules within departmental guidelines and the use of deed restrictions. Industrialists favor deed restrictions that confer permanent industrial status on a site so that it need not be cleaned to a higher standard. They also argue that municipalities retain the right to determine which, if any, sites should be set aside for industrial use.
Edward Lloyd, director of the Rutgers Environmental Law Center in Newark, rejected that view. "We shouldn't take the responsibility for future generations," he said. "New Jersey isn't big enough to leave a particular area contaminated. Do we want to have signs up all around that say Personal Risk -- Do Not Enter?"
Mr. Lloyd said the draft proposals also raise questions about the future of aquifers. By allowing some contaminated aquifers to remain uncleaned, he said, the proposals "write off" a valuable potential source of drinking water.
James W. Hughes, a professor of urban planning at Rutgers University in New Brunswick, called the debate "a classic environmental and economic quandary."
Asked if he believed economic interests would carry extra weight in the debate over cleanup standards, Dr. Hughes suggested that economic interests were hardy perennials, and he pointed to the swings in business cycles and their effect on policy.
Comparing the 1980's and 90's, he said: "Every time we go through an explosive growth period we become complacent and standards start rising -- the quality of development, the size of development. We're so overwhelmed about managing new growth that the older cities' problems are put on the back burner.
"When we hit the down cycle," he said, "we hit a threshold change in attitude: 'Hey, we're desperate for economic change and planning!' "
"We do a lousy job of managing growth," he said. "We do a worse job of managing decline."
 
Where There Is Agreement
 "No one will object to goals of a perfectly clean environment," Dr. Hughes said. "But we're not the affluent society we once thought we were."
Which is not to say that the outcome in Trenton will necessarily favor one side over the other. "For the most part, all sides are talking about the same thing," Mr. Weiner said. "The environmental community is concerned about different degrees of risk tolerance in different settings. The industrial community said, 'Set the standards realistically, then let us figure out how to do that on the site.' "
The balance between environmental and economic soundness has never been easy to strike, and there are plenty of New Jersey business owners with complaints to prove it.
One is Avon Products Inc., which tried to sell a subsidiary in Belleville, near Newark, and ran afoul of the Environmental Cleanup Responsibility Act. When Avon and the state disagreed over cleanup measures, Avon balked. When the state sought to seize about $1 million Avon had posted for the cleanup, Avon sued, and the Appellate Division of Superior Court in Essex County stopped the seizure. The court also directed the state to come up with the guidelines it is preparing now.
After months of public hearings and private discussion, New Jersey's cleanup standards will soon be on Commissioner Weiner's desk in Trenton. The commissioner will be able to adopt some or all of the proposals, change them or reject them.
"This is not the end of the process," he said. "The standards have to be living, adaptive documents."

HEADLINE: A Corner of Camden Revives, Block by Block

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: CAMDEN, N.J., Dec. 7

 BODY:
In some parts of this city, abandoned, crumbling homes dominate neighborhood blocks, the detritus of Camden's industrial decline and the exodus of thousands of residents that followed.
The vacant properties -- more than 3,500 scattered around the city -- are an eyesore for residents, targets for arsonists and a haven for drug dealers. 
 As this city of 87,500 residents tries to revitalize its economy, local groups are trying to rebuild their neighborhoods block by block. The task is enormous in a city where more than 10 percent of the housing units are vacant.
"It's a challenge," admits Sister Peg Hynes, president of the Heart of Camden, a nonprofit housing group in South Camden. "But we realize we can make a difference."
An outgrowth of the Sacred Heart Church, the volunteer group has rehabilitated more than 50 homes since 1984. It is among a half-dozen groups that have begun rehabilitation projects in neighborhoods around the city.
"It's a very monumental task to revitalize the neighborhoods of Camden," said Thomas A. Roberts, executive director of the city's Redevelopment Agency. "They're very tough, but they can be brought back."
The city's neighborhoods began declining in the 1950's with the departure of thousands of residents to the suburbs, some drawn by the promise of single-family homes and green lawns and others joining the so-called "white flight" as blacks moved in. Between 1950 and 1980, the city lost almost a third of its population.
"We had a lot of vacant buildings left," Mr. Roberts said. "They were eventually abandoned and the city came to own them."
Using volunteers from churches, schools and civic groups, the Heart of Camden volunteer group is refurbishing five blocks in South Camden, a racially mixed area near the Delaware River. At one time there were almost 200 vacant homes in the area, Sister Hynes said. Most being renovated have been vacant for a long time.
"We really have to gut them and start all over again," Sister Hynes said in an interview. "It takes a lot more muscle and a lot more time."
It can take months for work crews to refurbish the homes, replacing walls, installing sprinkler systems and upgrading the properties to meet building codes, Sister Hynes said.
 
Fresh Paint and a Garden
 Residents say the effort is making a difference. Freshly painted row houses now line Holcain Street, a narrow alley that was once filled with trash. Nearby is a fenced-in garden park.
"Nobody would have thought these houses could be brought back," said Herb Clayton, who has lived nearby on Jackson Street for 14 years. "They were almost ready to fall down."
The Heart of Camden acquires the abandoned properties from the city and sells the rehabilitated homes to low-income families at low cost.
"We're not in this to make money," Sister Hynes said, noting that the annual income for most families is under $10,000. "We're in this to help families find homes."
Eligible families receive interest-free mortgages with no down payment required. The average monthly mortgage payment is about $200, including taxes, Sister Hynes said.
Mayor Aaron A. Thompson said the city cannot afford to demolish all the abandoned properties. The city is giving priority to razing buildings left in ruins after an arson spree on a "mischief night" around Halloween.
While the city has concentrated on a $500 million waterfront revitalization project that includes a state aquarium, Mr. Thompson says neighborhoods will not be overlooked. "For us to grow on our waterfront and not in our neighborhoods would be a tragedy," he said.
Despite the scattered success of grass-roots organizations, critics say the city should play a larger role in rebuilding neighborhoods and demolishing vacant, dilapidated homes.
"They say we are building Camden block by block, but I think we are losing this city block by block," said Maribel Roman, a member of the Camden Churches Organized for People, which has asked the city to demolish or rehabilitate 58 abandoned properties by the end of the year. "We need help and we need it fast."

HEADLINE: NOTEBOOK;
Owners Discover Spring Free-Agent Bargains Are Worth the Wait

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 7

 BODY:
The glare of the Bobby Bonilla signing, the Mets' aggressive pursuit of Bonilla and Eddie Murray, and the Los Angeles Dodgers' lightninglike deals with Orel Hershiser and Tom Candiotti might have temporarily blinded viewers to the plodding nature of this year's free-agent market. But the fact is the pace of signings has been the slowest since the days of collusion.
No cries of Collusion IV have been heard -- how could there be when the lushest contract ever has been bestowed on Bonilla? -- but there could be another game afoot. Call it the K Mart Caper. 
 The seeds of the game were planted, perhaps unwittingly, last winter when a series of veteran but capable players were left to scrounge for jobs just before or during spring training. Willie Randolph, Candy Maldonado, John Candelaria, Gary Carter and Brian Downing were all forced to accept less money than they might have gained had they been signed in November or December and not been subjected to the Great Free-Agent Freeze-out.
 
Making Players Sweat
 A theory gaining support among players' representatives suggests that the results of those signings so impressed the owners that they have decided to expand the corps of free agents to be ignored, at least for now. They will wait until February, the theory goes, when they figure they will be able to get bargains, like people who shop at K Mart instead of Saks.
"The idea is to cut straight to the date they feel the bottom drops out from under these players," one agent said. "They'll get fewer years, less money, less guarantees, less bidding."
The first-flight free agents, of course, are not included in the K Mart group. That, however, doesn't exclude many players. As long as the Bonillas, the Candiottis and the Morgans are pursued vigorously and signed lavishly, the players would not have grounds to question the legality of the owners' tactics, as they did with collusion.
No one complained last winter about the delayed signings of the veteran players, who initially weren't even signed. They were invited to spring training with agreement on what their contracts would be if they won jobs.
Randolph, for example, signed for $500,000 with Milwaukee and earned an additional $400,000 in bonuses for number of games played, earning only $25,000 more than the year before. He hit a career-high .327, third best in the American League. Downing wasn't even invited to camp until March 28, then signed with Texas for $425,000. He picked up an extra $175,000 in bonuses for his number of plate appearances but still earned less than half of his 1990 salary of $1.25 million. He hit 17 home runs and batted .278. Gary Carter was invited to the Dodgers' camp in February, signed for half of his $1 million salary in 1990 and wound up playing in 101 games, many more than the Dodgers had anticipated.
In other words, the clubs saved money while getting significant production out of the players. The owners saw the light and liked what they saw.
"It's not an idea I would dismiss," Donald Fehr, head of the Players Association, said when asked about the possibility of the K Mart Caper. "But I'm not ready to conclude that that's what's happening. With those few exceptions, the market has been slow. We have to see if it's caution or if everything is going to be confined to a small group of free agents."
As the agent for Wally Joyner and Rick Sutcliffe, Barry Axelrod has had some action, but he also sees a difference in the clubs' approach this year compared with last year.
"I'm not going to say collusion, but there are economic concerns," Axelrod said. "Every team you talk to talks about severe economic constraints. It's like a de facto salary cap. I'm not saying baseball has said, 'Here's your salary cap,' but everybody seems to be saying they're working on a budget. They say we have $32 million to spend on our payroll."
 
More Waiting and Talking

General managers lament that players' agents have taken over the winter meetings. Last year, for example, 19 free agents signed during the meetings in Chicago; included were Terry Pendleton, Vince Coleman, Dave Righetti, Willie McGee and George Bell. Twenty-five signed the year before in Nashville, including Dave Parker, Jeff Reardon and Kent Hrbek. This year's meetings, which begin officially tomorrow, are also expected to feature free-agent signings, but the number depends on the owners' strategy.
General managers would prefer controlling the week; that is, be free to make trades and not be encumbered by waiting for this or that free agent to sign so that this team or that knows what its needs are. They nevertheless manage to make trades, sometimes exciting ones, like last year's swap of Joe Carter and Roberto Alomar for Fred McGriff and Tony Fernandez.
Barry Bonds could be the biggest name traded this week, if Larry Doughty, the Pittsburgh general manager, can find a team willing to offer enough worthwhile players in return while knowing the enormous sum it would take to keep Bonds beyond next season.
Most teams will scour the lobby of the Fountainebleau Hilton Hotel for pitchers. Prime targets include Chuck Finley of California, Erik Hanson of Seattle and Kevin Appier of Kansas City. The Cincinnati Reds, having already shored up their pitching staff, are prepared to trade Randy Myers for a hitter, preferably a leadoff batter.
Some teams would be willing to trade front-line outfielders for pitchers, meaning McGee would be available from San Francisco, and Mike Greenwell or Ellis Burks from Boston. The Giants had been prepared to trade Kevin Mitchell, but his arrest on rape investigation charges has interfered with that plan.
With the signing of Bobby Bonilla and Eddie Murray, the Mets have the most front-line players to trade -- Kevin McReynolds, Dave Magadan, Gregg Jefferies, Hubie Brooks. Philadelphia would like to trade Dale Murphy and/or Von Hayes.
As always, many more players will be talked about or rumored to be going elsewhere than will be traded. More, too, will be traded than signed as free agents.
 
A Major Minor Draft
 The major league draft of unprotected minor league players, which takes place tomorrow, isn't the most exciting event of the meetings, but it should probably receive greater attention. Look at the attention two of its graduates received last week.
In the space of 24 hours, Bobby Bonilla, draft of '85, and Mike Morgan, draft of '84, received contracts totaling $41.5 million. Mitch Williams, draft of '84, is also a free agent, and he, too, will sign a lucrative contract.
A year ago, George Bell, draft of '81, was a free agent and signed a $9.8 million contract. Early this year, Kelly Gruber, draft of '83, signed for $11 million. If that sort of thing continues, teams may start ignoring the draft; it's becoming too expensive, going well beyond the $50,000 a drafted player costs.
The success of those players, on the other hand, shows that teams can benefit from careful scouting and judicious drafting. Those players have received those millions because they have become stars -- well, at least in most cases.
Shane Mack hasn't gained millions yet, but he is the most recent worthwhile selection. Minnesota drafted him from the San Diego organization two years ago, and he has responded to the Twins' $50,000 interest by hitting .326 and .310.
The same day the Chicago White Sox drafted Bonilla from Pittsburgh, the Padres plucked Bip Roberts from the Pirates. The Pirates reacquired Bonilla in a trade seven months later. Roberts has been targeted for the Cincinnati Reds in a trade for Randy Myers, but if the Padres can get Barry Bonds from the Pirates, Roberts could return home, too.
 
Another Yankee Problem
 Oh what a tangled web the Yankees' spiderman has weaved.
For all of those clamoring for the return of George Steinbrenner as the Yankees' managing partner, two points of information:
*He created the fouled-up circumstances in which the club is immersed, first by causing his own exile, then by putting in place the people who have further befuddled matters.
*He, and not Robert Nederlander or Leonard Kleinman or Gene Michael, oversaw the 10-year deterioration of the Yankees. It was his team, not theirs, that finished last in 1990 with a dreadful 67-95 record.
Those points made, the relationship between Steinbrenner and Kleinman, the Yankees' chief operating officer, has created a deliciously ironical dilemma.
If Steinbrenner has any thought of being allowed to return from his personal Elba, he knows he first would have to induce Kleinman to drop his lawsuit against Commissioner Fay Vincent. Kleinman has indicated he would be willing to do that, but he would do it because he wants to be managing partner.
The lawsuit is Kleinman's bargaining lever to achieve his goal. I'll drop the suit, he could tell Steinbrenner, if you nominate me to be managing partner. But Steinbrenner has no intention of nominating Kleinman. He would want the suit to disappear so he could return as managing partner. Kleinman, though, would derive nothing from that combination of actions so why should he foresake the suit?
Kleinman would seem to have Steinbrenner right where he wants him.
Kleinman has become a thorn in Steinbrenner's side in another way. The owner brought Kleinman in as a financial officer, never intending for him to take on significantly greater responsibilities. But with Nederlander unwilling and unprepared to get into baseball personnel matters, Kleinman began insinuating himself into that area, even though he has no experience or knowledge about players. Recently, he, more than Michael, has served as the club's spokesman on personnel matters.
The development has not pleased Steinbrenner.

HEADLINE: BACKTALK;
Winning the Heisman for God, for Country and for Iowa

 BODY:
The Heisman Trophy, the most prestigious award in college football, will be awarded on Saturday at the Downtown Athletic Club in Manhattan. One of the previous recipients was Nile Kinnick, a running back at the University of Iowa who became a national celebrity after winning the award in 1939. Kinnick's moving Heisman Trophy speech is included among selected letters to his family and entries from his diary in a recently published book, "A Hero Perished" (University of Iowa Press, $27.95).  
 After graduation in 1939, Kinnick began legal study to prepare for a political career, then entered the Navy Air Corps as a fighter pilot. He was assigned to the U.S.S. Lexington on its shakedown cruise. On a training mission on June 2, 1943, his plane -- later found to be defective -- went down in the Gulf of Paria, between Venezuela and Trinidad, and Kinnick was never found. He was 24 years old. The following are excerpts from his speeches, letters and diaries:
 
 
To the Family
PUB-DATE: January 16, 1939
 It is my belief that the essential thing to be gained from a college education is to learn to think, to think for yourself; to develop an active, alert inquiring mind.
It would seem quite natural that we should turn to the writings of the great minds of the centuries gone by to discipline and guide our own mode of thinking. However, the little experience I have had with Plato, Socrates etc., leads me to believe that the subject matter is of little consequence and interest.
The most important thing -- and I am sure I am right -- is to maintain an active, alert interest in everything going on about you. Analyze and think for yourself. Read and listen only insofar as it stimulates and aids your own thinking. Don't read and parrot back in the language of another; don't think and explain thru [sic] the already formed concepts of someone else all the time. Don't be afraid to grasp, develop and expound your own ideas. "An expert is often just a glib fellow away from home." Be alert, inquire, question, read, discuss, understand.
 
 
Heisman Award Address
PUB-DATE: December 6, 1939
 I consider my winning this award as indirectly a great tribute to the new coaching staff at the University of Iowa headed by Dr. Eddie Anderson, and to my teammates sitting back in Iowa City. A finer man and a better coach never hit these United States, and a more courageous bunch of boys never graced the gridirons of the Midwest than that Iowa team of 1939.
Finally, if you'll permit me, I'd like to make a comment which in my mind is indicative perhaps of the greater significance of football and sports emphasis in general in this country, and that is, I thank God I was warring on the gridirons of the Midwest and not on the battlefields of Europe. I can speak confidently and positively that the players of this country would much rather struggle and fight to win the Heisman Trophy than the Croix de Guerre. Thank you.
 
 
Commencement Supper Address
PUB-DATE: May 29, 1940
 We all seem to have the courage to face the physical forces of life -- sickness, poverty, unemployment, even war itself -- but how about courage of conviction, of morality, of idealism, courage of faith in a principle, tangible proof of which is slow in appearing. Herein lies that phase of these problems which we must meet by ourselves, unaided by any university-given tools. Here is that angle of the greater difficulty which most often has proven the weak point in graduates of the past.
 
 
To Arletta G. Clarke [Kinnick's grandmother]
PUB-DATE: April 29, 1941
 It is very sobering to realize just what the future holds for a boy of my age. On the other hand, it is a practical challenge to a man's courage and personal integrity. A man who talks but is afraid to act, who sacrifices principle to expediency whenever real danger threatens is not worthy to keep and enjoy what he has. He is not worthy of his background and heritage who kowtows to tyranny in order to cling to his temporary safety and comfort. This is no expression of oratory or emotionalism but cold, hard truth. I trust I will have the courage to act as I speak, come what may. It will not be easy -- but should, therefore can, be done.
 
 
To Nile Kinnick Sr.
PUB-DATE: June 29, 1942
 All the while that I was driving down here, my mind was thinking what I might do when this war is over. Almost entirely, my thoughts were of a farm and how much the soil and sun and crops appeal to me. My imagination ran rampant. Oh, for the farm where a man is truly independent, and where he deals with fundamentals, where the changing seasons bring changed work, and a man is out of doors all the time. It is on the farm that a man can devote his life to his investment and see the improvement and growth from year to year.
 
 
To the Family
PUB-DATE: April 14, 1943
 Happiness unshared is like a picture without those colors which give it warmth and meaning. Give a man one close friend, tried and true, and he is fortified against the world; make that friend a woman and there are no heights he cannot scale.
 
 
Diary Entries
PUB-DATE: January 18, 1942
 I must admit there is nothing I enjoy more than the companionship of a beautiful woman who also possesses breeding, grace, charm and wit. There have been a few such women in my life but not enough. There may have been a time when I was in love with love -- but no more. However, I shall not consider my mortal existence complete until I have loved and won a woman who commands my admiration and respect in every way.
 
 
PUB-DATE: May 23, 1943
 If you really want to win, never give a sucker a break. Press every advantage to the limit.
Safety in aviation demands a healthy respect for your aircraft, unceasing alertness.
 
 
PUB-DATE: May 24, 1943
 Realize that every close call with danger is proof of God's care and that the demands of a tough assignment are a challenge to your worth and courage. This kind of thinking knows no fear.
Learn to sleep soundly and efficiently regardless of circumstance if you would be a man of stamina.
 
 
PUB-DATE: June 1, 1943
 How I wish that I could sing and play the piano!
It is a sad mistake to try to be head man in everything you attempt.
The axiom "if it's worth doing at all, it's worth doing well" has its limitations. Stay on the ball most of the time, but learn to coast between moments of all-out effort.
People must come before profits!!

SECTION: Section 4; Page 16; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 525 words

HEADLINE: The United Fates of Europe

 BODY:
The leaders of the 12 nations of the European Community assemble in the Dutch city of Maastricht tomorrow to propel Europe toward a united future. The road to Maastricht has been tortuous. Disputes rage because no nation finds it easy to sacrifice prerogatives. What's required is a common commitment to compromise -- no matter how painful.
On the agenda are economic and political treaties that would reshape Europe along lines only visionaries like Jean Monnet could have imagined after the bloodletting of World War II. The questions to be resolved are momentous, like whether to adopt a single currency, or impose a single standard for working conditions and workplace management. 
 The U.S., a bystander, has a strong rooting interest in Maastricht's success. European unity is the best guarantee that no member will ever again turn against its neighbor. It is also the best guarantee that Europe will prosper, providing a market for U.S. exports. What matters is not specific timetables but whether Maastricht keeps unification marching forward.
Underlying a host of economic and political disputes is a single, wrenching tradeoff: Members of the Community can reap benefits of closer cooperation only by sacrificing the privileges of independence.
Take the issue of a single currency. The purpose of replacing the pound, mark and 10 other currencies with one standard unit is to make trade between Paris and Athens as hassle-free as trade between New York and Houston. But, as Britain complains, monetary unity comes at a stiff price. Without its own currency, Britain couldn't have a monetary policy. In a recession, that would mean it couldn't lower interest rates to spur investment or devalue to spur exports.
Americans might wonder what the fuss is all about. After all, Texas doesn't have a monetary policy either. True, but Texas has something else: a security blanket called Washington. When the economy sours, Texans get Federal aid and pay less Federal tax. But if Britain hit the skids, the Community would provide minuscule help.
On the other hand, Britain exaggerates its current independence. The value of the pound is tied to the value of the German mark. In effect, that means London can't create pounds much faster than Germany creates marks.
Britain is on more solid ground when it opposes proposed Community regulations that are unjustifiably intrusive. Under the guise of protecting workplace health and safety, for example, it's been proposed that Germany's prohibition on Sunday retailing be extended to everyone else.
Other proposals would impose strict caps on deficits that countries could generate. Yet states within the U.S. operate budgets without Federal limits; instead, capital markets rein in excessive state borrowing.
The Maastricht summit meeting won't settle these issues once and for all. Nor need it try. The important point is that leaders define their needs narrowly, compromise at important junctures and push unification forward. As for the U.S., it cares less about who wins and loses individual battles than a broader outcome: treaties that commit members to a united fate.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Making Taxation Fairer

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The continued truncation of our progressive income tax rates at 30 percent is preposterous. Nor is Representative Dan Rostenkowski's timid proposal of an increase to 35 percent for a limited few the answer. 
 One category of taxpayers makes the inappropriateness of a 30 percent rate particularly striking. We have 60 United States billionaires and some 500,000 people with $5 million or more of accumulated wealth. The 30 percent rate only snowballs the accumulations. A traditional progressive income tax such as those in effect from 1950 to 1980 could bring in from this group alone additional revenues in the range of $15 billion a year. But the reach of an equitable income tax should go beyond those with vast accumulations and include those with high salaries and high earnings.
The Congressional Budget Office calculates that after-tax income, adjusting for inflation, of the richest 5 percent of the population has grown 60 percent over the last 15 years. It has not trickled down.
At the other end of the scale, 20 percent of all children and 50 percent of all black children live in poverty.
The 30 percent truncation was introduced with the Reagan "voodoo" economic package. If we are to restore the essential democratic precept of taxing according to ability to pay, we must return to the fairness of a traditionally progressive income tax.
 
ETHAN A. HITCHCOCK
New York, Nov. 25, 1991
