HEADLINE: PEARL HARBOR REMEMBERED;
Recalling Pearl Harbor, Bush Urges an End to Rancor; 50 Years After Attack, Survivors Are Told to Forget Animosity

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HONOLULU, Dec. 7

 BODY:
Amid solemn ceremonies honoring the Americans who died in the Japanese surprise attack on Pearl Harbor 50 years ago today, President Bush told an assemblage of more than 2,000 survivors that the time had come to put aside their animosity toward Japan.
"I have no rancor in my heart toward Germany or Japan -- none at all," said the President, a former Navy pilot who was himself shot down by the Japanese in the Pacific in 1944. "I hope you have none in yours. This is no time for recrimination." 
 Mr. Bush added: "World War II is over. It is history. We won. We crushed totalitarianism, and when that was done we helped our enemies give birth to democracies." [Excerpts, page 24.]
The President's words were the climax of nearly a week of emotional events marking the 50th anniversary of the attack, which drew the United States out of its isolationism and into the war.
He spoke from a podium in a huge shed on Pier 8 at Pearl Harbor. Behind him, across the calm, sunlit waters, stood the gleaming white monument that straddles the sunken remains of the battleship Arizona, on which 1,177 Americans died during the attack.
Docked to his left, in a gesture that could only irritate modern Japanese sensibilities, was the battleship Missouri, aboard which the Japanese formally surrendered on Sept. 2, 1945.
 
Words of Reconciliation
 But Mr. Bush's words were clearly meant to foster reconciliation. He praised the veterans for their valor and restated American regrets over the internment of thousands of Americans of Japanese ancestry in the hysteria that swept the nation after the attack on Pearl Harbor.
And he warned against any relapse into political or economic isolationism.
"We stand here today on the site of a tragedy spawned by isolationism," the President said. "And it is here we must learn -- and this time avoid -- the dangers of today's isolationism and its economic accomplice, protectionism."
To the leaders of Japan "in particular" he said, "this solumn occasion should reinforce our determination to join together in a future energized by free markets and free people."
He spoke on a day much like the Sunday morning in 1941 when the attack began.
The sky was bright, a 10-mile-an-hour breeze wafted in from the east, and soft nimbus clouds hovered over the volcanic mountains of central Oahu, over which the Japanese naval bombers and torpedo planes swept out of the sky and wreaked death and havoc on the American forces and fleet.
The attack, which came in two waves and lasted nearly two hours, killed 2,335 soldiers, sailors and marines, and 68 civilians. Twenty-one ships, including eight battleships, were sunk or damaged, and 188 Navy and Army Air Forces aircraft were destroyed.
The ceremonies today spoke volumes about the complex relationship that has since developed with Japan. The aged veterans who returned to the scene of their youthful terror and herrorism carried Japanese cameras, and the television monitors they watched were made in Japan.
 
The Veterans' Last Hurrah
 For the veterans, now mostly in their 70's, it was a last hurrah, certainly the last time they would ever gather in such numbers.
The reactions of the assembled veterans varied.
Vern Ray Arnet, a retired Air Force colonel from Baltimore, who lost an older brother, Ray, on the Arizona, called the events "a wonderful thing -- I'm glad to see the American public rallying to the support of the military."
Bill Keyes, a 72-year-old veteran from Wethersfield, Conn., near Hartford, who was an infantryman at Schofield Barracks, said of the events, "It takes you right back."
A Navy veteran who would not give his name became upset when questioned and said, "I'd rather not talk -- it's too depressing."
The events began with a daybreak ceremony at the National Cemetery of the Pacific in Honolulu, where 776 victims of the attack on Pearl Harbor are buried.
Mr. Bush, accompanied by his wife, Barbara, was introduced by Gerald Glaubitz, the national president of the Pearl Harbor Survivors Association.
At that ceremony, too, the President spoke against the racial animosities that the anniversary has aroused in some people. "Americans did not wage war against nations or races," he said. "We fought for freedom and human dignity against the nightmare of totalitarianism."
And, as he did at every place he spoke, the President lauded the Japanese-Americans who fought in the American armed forces during the war and expressed regrets to those interned "innocent victims who committed no offense."
But he also called for eternal vigilence, lest there be another Pearl Harbor. "The cause of harmony among nations is not a call for pacificism," he told the veterans at the cemetery.
From there, the President went to Pearl Harbor, about five miles east of downtown Honolulu, and went by barge to the Arizona Memorial, where the names of the 1,177 men who died in the sunken battleship are engraved in marble. Together, he and Mrs. Bush solemnly dropped flowers into the water above the sunken hull.
At 7:55 A.M., the exact time at which the Japanese bombers first appeared 50 years ago, there was one minute of silence as a new cruiser, the Chosen, glided past the memorial. Then, in a thunderous roar, three fighter jets of the Hawaii National Guard flew over.
Today's ceremonies capped nearly a week of commemorative events in Honolulu. It was a week for old soldiers, sailors and marines to reunite and to retell old war stories and stories of horror and heroism on the morning 50 years ago when the Japanese planes descended on the Hawaiian island of Oahu and permanently changed the history of the 20th century.
But the events, which included a jovial parade down Kalakaua Avenue in the Waikiki hotel area on Friday morning by more than 2,000 survivors, were tinged with complexity and ambiguity. This was particularly true for Hawaii, whose economy today is more tightly tied to Japan than any other state and whose politics are dominated by Americans of Japanese ancestry, or A.J.A.'s, as they are called. They make up 23 percent of Hawaii's population of 1.1 million, but they wield political power far out of proportion to that by virtue of the tightly knit Democratic political machine here.
The Japanese are crucial to the state's $11 billion tourism industry. One of every five visitors to Hawaii comes from Japan, and they typically spend more than four times as much money than American tourists.
For months before the anniversary, local business and political leaders worried that the commemorative events would rekindle anti-Japanese feelings, already running high in the United States because of resentment over Japan's economic prowess, and drive away the tourists.
There also was much discussion in Honolulu this week over whether Japan had properly atoned for Pearl Harbor. Earlier in the week Foreign Minister Michio Watanabe was quoted in The Washington Post as saying that Japan felt "deep remorse about the unbearable suffering and sorrow" it inflicted during the war. Today The Post quoted Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa as expressing "deep remorse," and Mr. Bush said he appreciated that statement.
But doubts have arisen about how strong the Japanese statements were. News reports from Tokyo published here Friday said that Mr. Watanabe used the word "hansei," which translates into "self-reflection" rather than "remorse." Mr. Miyazawa used the term "sekimin," meaning "deep responsibility."

 
 
JAPAN PRAISES BUSH SPEECH
 TOKYO, Sunday, Dec. 8 (Special to The New York Times) -- The Foreign Minister of Japan, Michio Watanabe, said this morning that he was "deeply moved" by President Bush's renewed call for reconciliation between Japan and the United States, and he restated Japan's "deep self-reflection" over its World War II aggression.
The Foreign Ministry, in its English translation of Mr. Watanabe's statement, quoted him as saying he was "deeply remorseful" over Japan's past actions, but the more usual translation of the words employed -- fukaku hansei -- is deep self-reflection or thinking twice about something.
Mr. Watanabe's statement has been the only formal statement issued by a government official for the 50th anniversary of the attack on Pearl Harbor, but it was identical to one given earlier in the week to The Washington Post. Both the newspaper and Mr. Bush in a speech Saturday in Hawaii referred to that statement as speaking of Japan's deep remorse about the attack.

CORRECTION-DATE: December 10, 1991, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Sunday about the memorial ceremonies at Pearl Harbor referred incorrectly to the new United States cruiser that sailed past the Arizona Memorial at 7:55 A.M. on Saturday, precisely 50 years after the Japanese attack. She is the Chosin.

SECTION: Section 10; Page 3; Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1204 words

HEADLINE: Focus: Escondido, Calif.;
D-Day for Mobile-Home Property Rights

BYLINE: By MORRIS NEWMAN

DATELINE: ESCONDIDO, CALIF.

 BODY:
CHARLES DuPONT owns a mobile-home park with about 100 spaces on an enviable site bordered one one side by an orchard and on the other by new one-family houses. Yet because of a rent-control law he has been unable to raise most of his rents beyond what tenants paid in 1986.
Mr. DuPont is one of eight owners of mobile-home parks in this city 25 miles north of San Diego who have challenged its rent-control law in court. Their cases, grouped together, have won a review before the United States Supreme Court, which has become increasingly willing to hear property-rights cases as its membership has taken on a more conservative cast. It is likely to hear the cases next month. 
 Property-rights advocates are hopeful that the court will decide one of the most controversial issues in rent control: whether government can restrict landlords from raising rents on rent-controlled property even after old tenants leave.
One of the eight cases, brought by Dr. John Yee, an Orange County physician who owns 159 mobile home spaces in the city, is of particular interest to property-rights theorists because many affected tenants own mobile homes that sit on rented land. For that reason, rental rates are reflected in the market value of the homes.
A locked-in low rent may be attractive to buyers and let a seller charge more for a mobile home, while a high rent may erode its value.
Under a law approved by local voters in 1988, rental rates on mobile-home spaces were rolled back to their levels of January 1986. Park owners cannot raise the rent without first making formal application to a rent-review board.
Mr. DuPont says that most of his tenants pay outdated, under-market rents of $210 a month and that their rents would exceed $400 "in a free market."
Yee v. Escondido started at San Diego County Superior Court, which ruled that the city's rent-control law was not a taking. An appeals court upheld that decision and the California Supreme Court declined to review the case.
The case has aroused wide interest among such leading property-rights watchdogs as the Pacific Legal Foundation in Sacramento, which plans to file one of at least 12 "friend of the court" briefs expected in the case.
Richard Epstein, a professor at the University of Chicago School of Law who has written extensively on rent control and the issue of "taking," said the court's decision has the potential to "alter the line between private and public, between the marketplace and politics." Mr. Epstein said the case could help to clarify the sometimes murky legal doctrine of unconstitutional "taking" of property.
Jerry Harmon, this city's Mayor, championed the rent-control measure three years ago as a City Councilman.
Because many mobile-home park residents own their homes and lease the land underneath, he said, they are vulnerable to the whims of landlords.
"Basically, they are people of retirement age who live on fixed incomes," he said.
The Mayor says that some park owners, in light of the recent housing boom in the area, want to raise rents, rid themselves of low-rent tenants and attract affluent new renters now streaming into the area.
BUT Robert Jagiello, the attorney for the mobile-home-park owners, says the solution chosen by Escondido voters three years ago represents an unconstitutional taking of property by the government.
Tenants whose spaces are rent controlled, he said, get a premium price when they sell their homes "and that premium represents a monetarization of the right to occupy the space."
By getting high prices for homes on rent-controlled land, Mr. Jagiello said, tenants take profits out of the hands of the land owners and keep the economic benefit for themselves.
Mr. Jagiello cited a recent case in Los Angeles, Azul Pacifico v. City of Los Angeles, in which a mobile-home owner testified she paid about $77,000 for a mobile home that she later traded in, getting only $5,000 for it. She had paid $77,000, he contends, not for the home itself, but for right to occupy the rented space on which it stood.
Mr. DuPont says his situation is analagous to that of a homeowner who invites a guest into his home and then cannot get rid of him.
"It is as if the Mayor came over and said, 'That guest can stay there for the rest of his life,' and can sell the right to stay in your house to anyone else," he said.
Defenders of the law say that tenants stand to lose the ability to sell their mobile homes profitably if landlords charge prohibitively high rents.
"The park owners can unconscionably raise the rents of their space, and the owner of the mobile home becomes unable to sell it," said Joan Gallo, the city attorney of San Jose.
She is one of several lawyers preparing a "friend of the court" brief for Yee v. Escondido in support of the law. In her view, a high rent on land that erodes the value of the property is a kind of taking in itself.
In recent years, California has been a cauldron of property-rights cases. In 1987, the High Court ruled, in First English Evangelical Church of Glendale v. County of Los Angeles, that property owners have a right to compensation if government deprives them all economic benefit from their property, even if only temporarily.
And in Nollan v. California Coastal Commission of the same year, the court ruled that government may charge fees and make other demands of property owners only when there is a direct relationship between those "exactions" and the actual impacts of the private development on public areas.
Beyond issues of taking, however, the larger issue, according to Gideon Kanner, a retired professor at Loyola Law School in Los Angeles, is whether rent control laws like the one in Escondido accomplish their aim: to protect the affordability of housing.
If lower rents lead to higher-priced mobile homes, Mr. Kanner argued, the law is a failure, since people who buy mobile homes in rent controlled-areas are likely to pay higher, rather than lower, prices. New tenants are not protected by the ordinance, since housing prices continue to rise, resulting in the same effect as that of landlords raising rent.
The only difference is that the beneficiary is the mobile-home seller, rather than the park owner.
"THE whole ordinance is irrational, because the intent was to lower the cost of mobile homes," said Mr. Kanner.
"But it does not preserve affordable housing," he continued. "It simply allows tenants to rip off landlords."
Mr. Epstein of the University of Chicago suggested that if government wants to ensure affordable rents to low-income tenants, the public should bear the burden collectively.
"Why does the landlord have to subsidize these welfare tenants?" he said. "That is an issue for society as a whole."
For the time being, Mr. DuPont tends his mobile-home park quietly as he waits for his day in the Supreme Court. Despite the high profile of the case, the mobile-home park owner says his relationship with tenants is usually friendly, although he avoids discussing the case with some people.
"I don't bring up the topic if I know there will be argument," he said. "Both of us understand this is a question that will be decided by a higher authority."

SECTION: Section 8; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk

HEADLINE: FOCUS;
D-Day Nearing for a Mobile-Home Case

BYLINE: By MORRIS NEWMAN

DATELINE: ESCONDIDO, CALIF.

 BODY:
Charles DuPont owns a mobile-home park with about 100 spaces on an enviable site bordered one one side by an orchard and on the other by new one-family houses. Yet because of a rent-control law he has been unable to raise most of his rents beyond what tenants paid in 1986.

"It is as if the Mayor came over and said, 'That guest can stay there for the rest of his life,' and can sell the right to stay in your house to anyone else," he said.
Defenders of the law say that tenants stand to lose the ability to sell their mobile homes profitably if landlords charge prohibitively high rents.
"The park owners can unconscionably raise the rents of their space, and the owner of the mobile home becomes unable to sell it," said Joan Gallo, the city attorney of San Jose. She is one of several lawyers preparing a "friend of the court" brief for Yee v. Escondido in support of the law. In her view, a high rent on land that erodes the value of the property is a kind of taking in itself.
In recent years, California has been a cauldron of property-rights cases. In 1987, the High Court ruled, in First English Evangelical Church of Glendale v. County of Los Angeles, that property owners have a right to compensation if government deprives them all economic benefit from their property, even if only temporarily.
And in Nollan v. California Coastal Commission of the same year, the court ruled that government may charge fees and make other demands of property owners only when there is a direct relationship between those "exactions" and the actual impacts of the private development on public areas.
Beyond issues of taking, however, the larger issue, according to Gideon Kanner, a retired professor at Loyola Law School in Los Angeles, is whether rent control laws like the one in Escondido accomplish their aim: to protect the affordability of housing.
If lower rents lead to higher-priced mobile homes, Mr. Kanner argued, the law is a failure, since people who buy mobile homes in rent controlled-areas are likely to pay higher, rather than lower, prices. New tenants are not protected by the ordinance, since housing prices continue to rise, resulting in the same effect as that of landlords raising rent.
The only difference is that the beneficiary is the mobile-home seller, rather than the park owner.
"The whole ordinance is irrational, because the intent was to lower the cost of mobile homes," said Mr. Kanner. "But it does not preserve affordable housing; it simply allows tenants to rip off landlords."
Mr. Epstein of the University of Chicago suggested that if government wants to ensure affordable rents to low-income tenants, the public should bear the burden collectively.
"Why does the landlord have to subsidize these welfare tenants?" he said. "That is an issue for society as a whole."
For the time being, Mr. DuPont tends his mobile-home park quietly as he waits for his day in the Supreme Court. Despite the high profile of the case, the mobile-home park owner says his relationship with tenants is usually friendly, although he avoids discussing the case with some people.
"I don't bring up the topic if I know there will be argument," he said. "Both of us understand this is a question that will be decided by a higher authority."

HEADLINE: America Is Only as Great as Its Shoppers

BYLINE: By Joseph Nocera; Joseph Nocera, a columnist for GQ, is working on a history of personal finance.

DATELINE: NORTHAMPTON, Mass.

 BODY:
So there he was, the President of the United States, preparing to lead by example, offering to show us the way out of our economic morass. It was the day after Thanksgiving. The President had come to Frederick, Md., to go to the mall. It was a typical middle-income, middle-class mall, filled with Foot Lockers and Radio Shacks, Thom McAns and Fashion Bugs. The President headed straight for J. C. Penney. He bought four pairs of tube socks and a toddler's sweatsuit. He paid $28. None of the accounts I read mention whether he paid in cash or with a credit card. I'm guessing cash.
You see a thing like this and you don't know whether to laugh or cry. Tube socks? Twenty-eight dollars? This is how we're going to spend our way out of the recession? 
 I don't mean to suggest that we won't eventually spend our way into a healthier economy; we always have before. It's just that President Bush's performance lacked a certain, shall we say, conviction. He made no impulse purchases; he didn't browse through the mall all afternoon; and he didn't buy anything he couldn't really afford, but figured, ah, I'll use my credit card. He may have bought, in other words, but he didn't shop. The economists all agree that we're not going to pull out of this recession until we really start shopping again.
It's a funny way to think about it, I suppose. The economists usually prefer nice-sounding phrases like "an upswing in consumer spending," which lends a patina of respectability to the crass business of buying things. Consumer spending is shopping. An upswing in consumer spending is more shopping. Shopping is the Great American Pastime. Myself, I think we ought not be so sheepish about admitting it out loud.
Do you doubt me? Never mind Rodeo Drive or Fifth Avenue. What about Aspen, where, on a glorious midsummer's afternoon, sun shining against breathtaking mountains, the streets are lined with tourists, wandering from one pricy shop to the next? Santa Fe? Freeport, Me. (America's outlet capital)? Haymarket Square in Boston? Ghirardelli Square in San Francisco? The Galleria in Houston? They're all lined with tourists, wandering from store to store.
It can seem insane sometimes, this urge to shop, when there are so many other possibilities. It can also be impossible to resist. I had a free day in Chicago this summer, so I decided to drive out to Oak Park and take the Frank Lloyd Wright walking tour. There were maybe a dozen other people on the tour. Then I went down to Michigan Avenue, the heart of the shopping district. Thousands of people were strolling up and down the street, in and out of stores. They had this great, wonderful city at their feet and they were shopping. Then again, so was I.
As it happens, I live in a shopping town, though a small one. Our cute, revitalized downtown is lined with the kind of shops, as a writer once memorably put it, "where you can get what you want, but not what you need."
On Saturdays, our little streets are every bit as crowded as Michigan Avenue, as people come from miles around just to shop. The old-timers hate it, of course -- hate the way the hardware store has been pre-empted by a Benetton's. The newcomers sniff, the way locals always sniff at the tourist trade. But I think we're lucky. Our town has survived the Massachusetts downturn much better than most neighboring towns. We've been saved by shopping. The country has always been saved by shopping.
For better or worse, shopping is embedded in our culture. It is what we do. It has also been an engine of prosperity. Surely, the most important financial innovation in this century was the installment loan, which made it possible for Americans to buy things with money they didn't yet have. When the credit card arrived in the late 50's to further propel the economy, it was simply a more convenient form of installment loan.
Thirty-five years ago, in "The Affluent Society," John Kenneth Galbraith lamented the rise of the installment loan, the consumer society it was fueling, and the advertising that "creates the wants it seeks to satisfy." There was much truth in what he said, so much so that tens of thousands of Americans went out and bought his scathing indictment of their behavior, pushing "The Affluent Society" onto the best-seller list. And then they went right on shopping. And the economy kept right on growing.
It's when we stop shopping that we get into trouble -- when we lose our zest for the sport, fearful that we won't have the money tomorrow to pay for the things we can't afford today. So here we are, on a Sunday in December, 17 shopping days till Christmas. (And isn't that a phrase that speaks volumes about who we are?) I suppose we could plunk down $28 for tube socks as the President did. Or we could do something else. We could buy something big, something we probably don't need, something we'll have to pay off over time. We could shop till we drop. What the heck. That's what made this country great.

LENGTH: 1575 words

HEADLINE: POP MUSIC;
A Newcomer Meets the Hit-Making Machine

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WALKER; Michael Walker writes about pop music for The Los Angeles Times.

 BODY:
There are household names. Then there is Russ Irwin, a 23-year-old singer-songwriter from Dix Hills, L.I., whose ballad "My Heart Belongs to You" recently slogged its way up and down the charts. To promote the song and his debut album, "Russ Irwin," he has thus far played on the "Tonight" show, appeared briefly on ABC's "In Concert," taped two videos, endured a round of interviews with teen-age fan magazines and made personal appearances at a numbing litany of radio stations.
"Wichita Falls? In Texas? I was there," Mr. Irwin says over lunch in a midtown Manhattan resturaunt, a dusting of makeup from a magazine photo shoot clinging to his face. He is recounting a recent two-week promotional odyssey to radio stations. "I've been to Seattle, L.A., Chicago, Atlanta, Nashville, Chattanooga, Dallas, Abilene, Waco, Rockford." 
 All of this has been at the behest of Mr. Irwin's label, SBK Records, which has a reputation for spending lavishly on new artists. Mr. Irwin is one of the dozens of young, first-time musicians launched by record companies each year, and his experience offers a window into the calculated world of modern hit-making. While approaches vary, breaking a baby act like Mr. Irwin involves as much marketing as music.
Getting the public to recognize a new act is never easy, especially now. The record business is in a slump, and the charts are clogged with new releases by superstars like Michael Jackson, Hammer and Guns 'n' Roses, making it that much harder for an unknown like Mr. Irwin to get heard on radio, still the crucial factor in a record's success. Because of the recession, record buyers aren't making as many impulse purchases. Nevertheless, the successful debut albums of SBK's Wilson Phillips and Vanilla Ice have proved that, if marketed skillfully, first-time acts can score big.
The company's strategy has so far yielded hits. Although critically savaged, Wilson Phillips's debut album sold more than 5 million copies in the United States; Vanilla Ice's "To the Extreme" spent 16 weeks at No. 1 and sold more than 7 million copies.
SBK, which is considered a rare success among new record labels, hopes that Mr. Irwin's album will be its next hit. Aside from Jesus Jones's "Doubt," which recently sold a million copies after months of heavy promotion, SBK is between best-selling albums. Sales of the first Wilson Phillips recording have peaked, and the trio is only now in the studio making its second; Smokey Robinson's first album for SBK got off to a shaky start, and Vanilla Ice seems to have exhausted his tenuous appeal. The rapper's bid for screen stardom, "Cool as Ice," bombed spectacularly at the box office after its release in October. The latest Vanilla Ice single, "Cool as Ice (Everybody Get Loose)," crested at No. 81. SBK also announced last month that it was merging with Chrysalis and EMI Records, bringing layoffs to all three companies, although according to Don Rubin, SBK's vice president of artists and repertory, there are currently no plans to furlough any SBK musicians. Charles Koppelman, SBK's chairman, will head the combined companies.
The fact that "My Heart Belongs to You" squeaked into the Top 30 is no small accomplishment. But even with a minor hit, an album, a star producer (Phil Ramone, who handled some of Billy Joel's biggest albums) and a doting record company, Mr. Irwin's commercial success hinges on intangibles. Mr. Ramone points out that no matter what the album's artistic merits, or how skillfully it is promoted, it is the public that will decide "whether or not we've got the goods."
Mr. Koppelman signed Mr. Irwin after the singer played a handful of compositions on a piano in the label president's New York office in 1989, SBK's first year of operations. "His melodies, though not lyrically developed the way they should have been, had this thing that was very fresh to my ears," Mr. Koppelman says.
(SBK would not reveal the specifics of Mr. Irwin's contract. A typical deal for a first-time mainstream pop musician, however, could include an advance against royalties of around $30,000.)
Mr. Irwin studied both classical music and the music business at New York University. He is therefore far from an innocent. "My lawyer was surprised that I understood most of the jargon -- cross-collateralization, how publishing splits work," he says of his contract negotiations with SBK.
Mr. Irwin and the label hired a band to play on the record and to tour. Mr. Rubin says the label "wanted to create the self-contained feeling of a band." The ensemble rehearsed for six months while Mr. Rubin and Mr. Ramone monitored Mr. Irwin's songwriting progress.
The label arranged for Mr. Irwin to compose with a group of polished freelance songwriters, which he did, grudgingly. "I'm not a big fan of collaboration, as far as writing goes," he says. "I like to write my songs myself." In the end, Mr. Irwin wrote all but two songs on the album.
According to Mr. Rubin, about $50,000 had been spent by the time Mr. Irwin and his band entered the Power Station, a Manhattan recording studio, early last spring. They were there for three months. Hiring Mr. Ramone, with his connection to Billy Joel, another Long Islander, gave Mr. Irwin the benefit of a seasoned hand and also fit into the label's plans. SBK invokes Billy Joel's name freely in talking about Mr. Irwin. "The singer-songwriter mold was what we were looking for," says Mr. Rubin. "We used Billy Joel as a boilerplate example of what we were trying to go for with Russ."
Once the album was finished, SBK's promotional arm swung into action. "We had a major meeting where we picked the first single," says Mr. Koppelman. One option was to exploit Mr. Irwin's coltish good looks with the teen-age press.
"I said, fine, let's try it," says Mr. Irwin. But after being asked who he would most want to be stuck in an elevator with, Mr. Irwin balked, he says, and told SBK to try something else. ("I answered Clarence Thomas," Mr. Irwin says. "I don't think the interviewer knew who I was talking about.")
Because Mr. Irwin's songs range from plaintive ballads to snarling rockers, they can be played on several radio formats, from album rock to easy listening. SBK released "I Need You Now," a long number showing off Mr. Irwin's skill as a pianist, expressly to album-oriented rock stations at the same time "My Heart Belongs to You" was shipped to Top 40.
Mr. Koppelman and Daniel Glass, SBK's general manager, pleaded Mr. Irwin's case to more than 50 radio stations on a three-week promotional swing. "I wanted to explain that this is, in my view, a franchise artist for SBK, a young man with a lot of music yet to be made," Mr. Koppelman says. He made a similar junket for Wilson Phillips, though such appearances by company presidents are rare.
As a publicity stunt, the label handed out free copies of Mr. Irwin's single at the Hamptons exit of the Long Island Expressway over the Labor Day weekend. ("Those guys," says Mr. Irwin.) SBK also sent a promotional mailing to Long Island residents who had bought tickets to Genesis concerts. "We think the people who like Billy Joel, Phil Collins, are going to like Russ Irwin," explains Mr. Glass.
The label spent about $250,000 to record and promote the album, a portion of which will come out of Mr. Irwin's royalties when it starts to sell. According to an executive at SBK, who spoke on condition of anonymity, Mr. Irwin's launch was about half as costly as the splash that accompanied Wilson Phillips's debut.
The week of Sept. 14, "My Heart Belongs to You" entered Billboard's Top-100 singles chart at No. 91 after it was added to the play lists of 43 radio stations. Billboard recommended the song to radio programmers in a review that praised Mr. Irwin's "edgy vocals" and Mr. Ramone's production, and closed with the benediction: "Sounds like a smash." Five weeks later the song had climbed to No. 47 and garnered a special "Power Pick" award for its strong sales in some markets, particularly in the Northwest. "We sold 56 singles in Lewiston, Idaho," says Mr. Glass.
The song's progress slowed when it entered the competitive Top-40 section of the chart, and finally peaked at No. 28 in its ninth week. Then came the fall: No. 30, No. 55, No. 86. Last week, the single was lingering at No. 98 and the album had not appeared on the Top 200 chart at all.
What went wrong? Ballads, says Mr. Rubin, traditionally take longer to find a radio audience. By the time "My Heart Belong to You" was fading at the first stations that played it, there were not enough new stations, particularly in markets like New York and Los Angeles, adding the song to sustain its rise. Steve Wyrostok, the program director of Houston's KRBE, which was the first station to add the song to its play list, notes, "We really did believe in the record and it did fairly well -- it made it onto our Top 10. But ballads that turn out to be great performers tend to stay in the top three for five or six weeks. It never really reached that level. It wasn't in people's faces enough."
SBK is already moving on. In January, the label will release "Don't Like the Way You Look at My Love" (one of the songs Mr. Irwin did not write) and the scrabbling promotional process will begin again.
The single could do nothing at all. Then again, the record business has always taken heart in one of its truer aphorisms, that all it takes is one song.

HEADLINE: With Lottery Prizes, the Bigger the Better

 BODY:
To the Editor:
M. R. Katurbus (letter, Nov. 22) argues that awarding 350 prizes of $100,000, instead of a single prize of $35 million, would make the New York State Lottery more attractive to would-be players, but does not take into consideration that New York State pays out its large prizes over a period of 20 years. 
 A prize of $100,000, spread over 20 years, means extra annual income of $5,000, or about $3,500 after taxes (with a 30 percent tax rate). The value of such a series of payments, assuming 5 percent inflation over the next 20 years, is $43,617. That's not the type of life-altering award that lottery players dream of; for most people, that might be enough to keep up with the rising cost of living.
With a jackpot of $35 million, on the other hand, a single winner is guaranteed more than $1 million net take-home pay every year for the next 20 years. With that kind of money, one can spend on luxuries previously only dreamed of and also dabble in investments with the goal of making even more money. I would rather get a shot at that kind of prize -- even if it means battling odds 350 times greater.
 
ZACHARY M. BERMAN
Brooklyn, Nov. 24, 1991

HEADLINE: THE EUROPEAN SUMMIT;
West Europeans Gather to Seek A Tighter Union

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MAASTRICHT, the Netherlands, Dec. 8

 BODY:
In an atmosphere of great expectation tinged with no small apprehension, European Community leaders gathered here tonight for a crucial two-day summit meeting that should determine the region's place in the world well into the 21st century.
Their aim is to prepare the 12-nation community to compete with regional economic groups led by the United States and Japan and to exercise greater political influence in international affairs. To achieve this, they hope to speed up Europe's 34-year-old march toward political and economic integration.
They will therefore be taking up proposals to establish a single currency and a regional central bank, to move toward common foreign and security policies, to give more power to the European Parliament and to harmonize their approaches to social and environmental questions.
 
Nowhere Near Full Union
 The measures fall far short of creating anything resembling a United States of Europe. While some politicians like to evoke the centuries-old dream of full union, it is at least decades away.
Yet if approved, the changes will significantly bolster the community's existing plan to form a single regional market of 340 million consumers on Jan. 1, 1993, eventually turning what is already the world's largest trading bloc into the world's dominant financial power.
Adoption of the Maastricht agenda is far from assured. Britain, long the community's most resistant member, fears an excessive loss of sovereignty. Changes to the 1957 Treaty of Rome, which created the community, require the unanimous assent of its members, and a plan acceptable to Britain has still to be thrashed out.
Specifically, Britain remains at loggerheads with the others over how the community should manage its common foreign and security policy, over whether the 12 should move toward building an independent military capability and over when the community can dictate domestic policies.
Everything hangs on four negotiating sessions over the next two days, with the fate of the summit meeting probably unknown until late Tuesday or, as one European official put it, "the last five minutes." The meeting may even be extended to Wednesday if an accord seems within reach.
 
'Train Is About to Leave'
 "The train to European union is standing at the platform," Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher of Germany wrote this weekend, seemingly addressing Britain. "It is about to leave. Anyone who does not climb on board will not stop it from going. They will be left standing alone."
Yet, despite the real risk of an 11-to-1 deadlock, the mood was fairly upbeat as community leaders arrived in this ancient Dutch city tonight, with optimism bolstered by progress made in several disputed areas during a flurry of ministerial talks last week.
For instance, the 12 informally agreed to accommodate Britain's refusal to commit itself to a single currency by 1999. An annex to the planned treaty on monetary union should allow Britain to "opt out" if the British Parliament later blocks disappearance of the pound sterling.
Britain has also strongly objected to a passage in the draft treaty to be voted on this week that the community has a "federal" vocation, but that should no longer be an obstacle to agreement. Other governments now seem willing to change the wording to an endorsement of "ever closer union" -- if Britain makes concessions in other areas.
 
Britain to 'Give and Take'
 While wrestling with an anti-Europe group in his Conservative Party, Britain's Prime Minister, John Major, insists that he is ready to "give and take" to reach an "acceptable" agreement.
President Francois Mitterrand of France and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany, who have been the driving force behind this new stage of integration, have signaled that they too will show flexibility. "Britain is complicating the game," a senior French official said, "but we have never wanted Britain's exclusion."
Certainly, the two sides were much further apart when separate inter-governmental conferences on economic and monetary union and on political union began last December. Then, many governments were focusing more on the goal of union than how to achieve it. Now, under British pressure, a step-by-step approach has been adopted.
For instance, on monetary union, rather than rushing toward a single currency, community countries now accept the need for gradual "convergence" of their economies through a leveling of inflation rates and budget deficits. Similarly, before a regional central bank comes into existence, a less formal body to be known as the European Monetary Institute will be charged with coordinating the region's monetary policies.
Events outside Western Europe have underlined the community's limited ability to speak with a single, forceful voice. During the Persian Gulf war, while Britain and France sent troops to the front, the community as such lacked authority to act. More recently, the 12 have been embarrassed by their failure to settle the Yugoslav conflict.
 
Britain Wants a Veto
 Nonetheless, on the eve of the Maastricht meeting, major obstacles still stand in the way of broad agreement on foreign policy and security matters, most of them reflecting British reluctance. While agreeing that the community must act as a bloc if it is to have real power on foreign-policy questions, Britain is insisting that community positions be adopted unanimously, thus enabling it to retain a veto and avoid the risk of being outvoted.
On the sensitive question of regional defense, Britain favors strengthening a nine-nation military pact known as the Western European Union, but argues that French and German demands that it be integrated into the community could undermine the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
Britain is most prickly about not allowing the community to "interfere" in its domestic affairs -- specifically on police, immigration and judicial matters as well as on a broad array of social and environmental questions. Here again, it objects to community rulings through majority vote.
While Mr. Mitterrand and Mr. Kohl have much to gain politically from an agreement, both have warned that they will only go so far to appease Mr. Major. The French leader likes to remind London that he too has a veto right.
Mr. Kohl in turn believes that a stronger Europe must be a more democratic Europe, and to this end, he is demanding that new powers of "co-decision" be given to the 518-member European Parliament, which at present can discuss -- but cannot propose or block -- community laws.
 
Mitterrand Backs Kohl
 Mr. Mitterrand, who used to say the community's political authority should be exercised by governments rather than legislators or bureaucrats, has now agreed to back Mr. Kohl. Mr. Major may also accept the principle of "co-decision" with Parliament, but only in limited areas.
If the British, French and German leaders can work out their differences, most other problems will fade into insignificance. Jacques Delors, who as President of the European Commission will be the 13th person at the summit table, has complained loudly that his executive body will acquire little additional power, but he has neither vote nor veto.
Working in favor of an accord is fear of the consequences of failure. Any country considered responsible for a breakdown will inevitably face isolation and recrimination. Confidence in European currencies may slump. And the community as a whole could suffer a crisis of identity with long-term negative effects.
Born as a six-nation common market in 1957, the community has known many ups and downs over the years, including squabbles over British entry in the 1960's and economic stagnation in the 1970's. But since 1985, when it agreed to build a single market by the end of 1992, new momentum toward economic integration has also given it a stronger political voice.
The collapse of Communism and, above all, the unification of Germany abruptly changed the European scene in 1989 and 1990, but France was able to persuade its partners -- including Germany -- that the moment required the community to establish even more ambitious goals of unity.
 
Economic Union More Likely
 Many experts believe that the community will continue to advance more quickly toward economic union than political integration. Goods, services, capital and people should move freely in the region after 1992, while the prospect of a single currency and regional central bank before the end of the century will accelerate harmonization of economic policies.
With the United States, Canada and Mexico talking about a North American free trade area and Japan working hard to strengthen its trade ties in the Far East, European businessmen are strong advocates of economic union, convinced that otherwise they will be unable to compete. Already, many European companies are engaged in their own "union" through mergers.
Politically, though, community governments seem to have less of a mandate. Polls show that outside Britain, most Europeans have no clear understanding of what is at stake in Maastricht. They also suggest that ordinary citizens are far less enthusiastic than their leaders about ceding sovereignty to "foreigners."
Nonetheless, governments and businessmen agree that Europe's immediate future will be charted at Maastricht. It may be that no one emerges fully satisfied with the result -- going too far for some, not far enough for others. But, as one French official put it, "this is a process, and what isn't done now can be done later." In any event, the 12 plan to review any Maastricht treaty in 1996.

HEADLINE: DECLARING DEATH OF SOVIET UNION, RUSSIA AND 2 REPUBLICS FORM NEW COMMONWEALTH

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Dec. 8

 BODY:
The leaders of Russia, Ukraine and Byelorussia declared today that the Soviet Union had ceased to exist and proclaimed a new "Commonwealth of Independent States" open to all members of the former union.
In a series of statements issued after a two-day meeting at a Byelorussian government retreat, the leaders of the three Slavic republics declared void all efforts to create a new union on the ruins of the old one. But they called for the creation of new "coordinating bodies" for defense, foreign affairs and the economy that would have their seat in Minsk, the capital of Byelorussia, and decided to maintain the ruble as the common currency. 
 They declared that the "norms" and activities of the former union ceased as of the moment of signing, and that the new commonwealth assumed all international obligations of the Soviet Union, as well as control over its nuclear arsenal.
 
Gorbachev's Move
 "The U.S.S.R., as a subject of international law and geopolitical reality, is ceasing its existence," the leaders declared. [Text, page A8.]
The action essentially stripped President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of his office and authority, and the immediate question was whether the tough and tenacious Soviet leader would resist -- and if he did, whether the military or other levers of power would support him.
The three cofounders of the new commonwealth -- President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia, President Leonid M. Kravchuk of Ukraine and Stanislav Shushkevich, Chairman of the Byelorussian Parliament -- were scheduled to meet on Monday with Mr. Gorbachev and with Nursultan A. Nazarbayev, the President of Kazakhstan and the unofficial spokesman for the Muslim republics of Central Asia.
 
Portents of Disaster
 Mr. Gorbachev had no immediate reaction. But in a taped interview with French television broadcast today, he argued fervently that the consequences of dismantling the union would make the war in Yugoslavia "a simple joke by comparison."
The Central Asian republics had all indicated an interest in retaining some form of union, and it was not immediately clear why Mr. Nazarbayev was excluded from the Byelorussian declaration, or how he would respond. Arriving in Moscow today, he declared that he was still in favor of preserving an association, and at least in maintaining joint control over the nuclear arsenal.
The predominantly Slavic republics declared that they drew their authority to dissolve the union from the fact that they were its original cofounders. They and the Trans-Caucasus republic, later divided into Georgia, Armenia and Azerbaijan, were cosigners of the original 1922 treaty that created the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics.
The "sphere of joint activity" assigned to the new commonwealth, however, resembled the functions that Mr. Gorbachev had sought for his new "union of sovereign states": responsibility for foreign policy, development of a "common economic space," "customs policies," transportation and communication systems, the environment and the battle against organized crime.
One major difference was that the three core Slavic republics, which together account for 73 percent of the population and 80 percent of the territory of the Soviet Union, were now inviting other republics to join, not to negotiate, a new association.
It was a stance certain to irritate the Muslim and Caucasian republics, but also one that stood to curtail the endless bickering that characterized inter-republican negotiations since the coup.
 
Clean But Dangerous Slate
 Another major difference was that the move to Minsk and the formal disbanding of the old union cleared the slate of old structures and bureaucracies, freeing the participating republics of the need to haggle with Mr. Gorbachev and the old ministries over the new order they meant to shape.
But the approach had its own dangers. If Mr. Gorbachev was one potential source of resistance, others included the potent military-industrial complex and the trade unions, which could feel threatened by new masters dedicated to reducing the budget.
Resistance could also come from national parliaments and nationalist movements, especially in Ukraine, which could see in the agreement a trick to revive the old union under a new sauce.
Yet the commonwealth appeared to be the most practical compromise. It disassociated itself from Moscow, it created a core of the most important republics, and it blocked the disintegration that threatened to destroy critical intra-republican economic ties.
 
Ruble Coin of Realm
 The agreements called for coordinated economic reforms, echoing fears in Ukraine and Byelorussia that the impending reforms in Russia would create havoc with their prices. They declared the ruble to be the currency of common commerce, and they called for mutual agreement before any new currency was introduced, responding to Russia's fear that a separate currency in Ukraine would flood Russia with excess rubles.
And they declared the Chernobyl disaster site a common responsibility, touching on the fears of all three republics that the damaged nuclear power plant would be left untended.
The leaders pledged that existing borders would remain open and unchanged, and they vowed to respect each other's sovereignty and "observe international norms of human and national rights."
On an issue that has raised considerable anxiety abroad, the leaders said they had decided "to preserve the joint command over the common military-strategic space and the single nuclear arms controlling body." There was no immediate indication, however, how the control would be shared.
Outlining the responsibilities of the central authority they proposed to form in Minsk, the agreement said: "The parties regard the following as the sphere of joint activity: the coordination of external political activity, the formation and the development of the common economic space, the European and Eurasian markets, the customs and migratory policy, the development of the transportation and communication systems, protection of the environment and ecological security, and the struggle against organized crime."
In a statement announcing the creation of the commonwealth, the leaders said that talks on forming a new union treaty had reached an impasse, while the withdrawal of republics from the Soviet Union had become a "fact of reality." The statement placed the full blame for the economic and political crisis at Mr. Gorbachev's feet, pointing out "the center's short-sighted policy."
The three leaders said the new commonwealth would be open to all members of the Soviet Union, "as well as other states sharing the aims and principles of this agreement."
A separate statement on joint economic policy declared that "preservation and development of close economic ties that have taken shape between our states is vitally important in order to stabilize the situation in the national economy and create preconditions for economic revival."
The key provision called on the three republics to coordinate their economic reforms, indicating that Ukraine and Byelorussia would follow Russia's lead in releasing prices and the ruble rate. The agreement, however, raised doubts that Mr. Yeltsin could follow his announced timetable, which called for prices to be freed on Dec. 16.
The proclamation appeared to culminate a process that began last spring, when Mr. Gorbachev finally abandoned efforts to control the union by force and opened negotiations with the republics on a new union treaty.
 
The Receding Center
 Kremlin hardliners threatened by the new arrangement staged the ill-fated coup in August. Instead of blocking the treaty, as they had intended, they undermined central authority and sent republics scurrying to declare independence.
Efforts by Mr. Gorbachev to renegotiate a new union treaty were repeatedly stymied, usually by fears among republics enjoying the first tentative taste of real self-government that any new political or economic agreement would somehow encourage the restoration of the "center."
In the end, it was the strong vote for independence in Ukraine that finally drew the curtain on Mr. Gorbachev's quest. Without Ukraine, both Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Yeltsin agreed, there could be no meaningful union.
All through the week, Mr. Gorbachev railed against the Ukrainian decision. And in a rambling taped interview with Ukrainian television, broadcast today, he warned that "we are close to the limit behind which anarchy and chaos begin." Today's agreement confirmed anew the growing stature of Mr. Yeltsin as the prime arbiter of the fate of the former Soviet empire. If the Ukrainian vote was the catalyst for his decision, it was his decision to choke off spending by the center and to proceed with radical reform, with or without other republics, that first signaled the end of the central government.
The pain to Mr. Gorbachev, who launched perestroika almost seven years ago and fought a long and bitter political battle with Mr. Yeltsin, was obvious. Associates said his appeals for union were not a struggle for personal power, but an expression of the faith in a renewed union that had guided him throughout his courageous odyssey.
Yet even if Mr. Gorbachev was not immediately capable of appreciating it, the commonwealth that was being formed was not so different from the one he envisioned.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
White House Waits
 WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (Special to The New York Times) -- President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia called President Bush at the White House today to tell him about the commonwealth agreement, but the White House declined to release details of that conversation or comment on the agreement.
"Yeltsin promised the President that he would send him additional information about the agreement and we're awaiting that information," said Bill Harlow, a spokesman for the White House.

HEADLINE: BACKING FOR CUBA IN SOUTH AFRICA

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, Dec. 8

 BODY:
The South African Communist Party concluded its first legal congress in four decades today with a spirited pledge of support for Cuba to offset the Soviet Union's desertion.
The party promised to mount a protest campaign "to expose the intrigues of U.S. imperialism against Cuba" and to raise funds for the Cuban people. 
 The solidarity expressed with Cuba was part of a package of resolutions approved at the party's four-day congress, at which hard-liners restored the party's lapsed adherence to Marxism-Leninism, an ideological orthodoxy that some other Communist parties have jettisoned, and dropped the word "democratic" from its endorsement of socialism.
The party's identification with Cuba, which some party officials say offers the closest model to what they want for South Africa, could discomfit its longstanding ally, the African National Congress, whose president, Nelson Mandela, has spent the last week in the United States seeking political and financial support.
But Chris Hani, the Communist Party's newly appointed general secretary, who also sits on the African National Congress's executive committee and is chief of staff of its military wing, said he doubted that it would object because, he said, "the A.N.C. does not hide its close bond with Cuba."
 
Role in Angola Cited
 Cuba has been popular with many militant blacks because its troops fought South African forces in Angola and because its policies are seen as improving the lives of poor Cubans.
Speaking at a news conference, Mr. Hani said Cuba had assisted the African National Congress and now needed help itself after being cut loose by the Soviet Union.
"The A.N.C. agrees with us that Cuba is an important part of the struggle of mankind for freedom, national liberation and social justice," Mr. Hani said. "The A.N.C. has got very strong links with Cuba."
The South African Communist Party said it would forge "close fraternal links" with surviving Marxist parties and would re-establish the "proletarian internationalism" of mutual support that was shattered when Communism collapsed in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union.
"We want the Communist movement to regroup and reassert themselves," Mr. Hani said. "We don't want a situation where we have to fight in isolation."
The manifesto approved by the 413 delegates at the congress hailed the party as "the political vanguard of the working class, basing itself on the guiding principles of Marxism-Leninism" and said it had more members and support than ever before in its 70-year history.
After some debate, the delegates decided to describe their party as a vanguard party, a Leninist concept for a revolutionary elite, rather than as a mass party with broad appeal. Charles Nqakula, the party's new deputy general secretary, said a vanguard party did not mean a limited membership.
"Our definition of a vanguard party is a party of activists, not a party of sleeping members," Mr. Nqakula said.
Joe Slovo, the retiring general secretary, said Thursday that the party had signed up 25,000 members. According to Ronnie Kasrils, a central committee member, 75 percent of party members come from the working class, of whom 40 percent are unemployed. Most members are black.

HEADLINE: Texts of Declarations by 3 Republic Leaders

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Dec. 8

 BODY:
Following are excerpts of a preamble and two declarations issued today by the leaders of Russia, Ukraine and Byelorussia, as transmitted by the Soviet press agency Tass. The preamble was translated from the Russian by Reuters and the declarations were translated by The Associated Press: 
 PREAMBLE
 We, the republic of Byelorussia, the Russian Federation and the Ukraine, . . . state that the U.S.S.R., as a subject of international law and a geopolitical reality, is ceasing its existence.

 	 	 		. . .	 	With the aim of developing equal and mutually beneficial cooperation of the peoples and states, it has been decided to conclude special agreements in the spheres of politics, the economy, culture, education, public health, science, trade, the environment and other fields.

 	 	 		. . .	 	The members of the community . . . will strive for elimination of nuclear weapons and for total disarmament under international control. At the same time, the sides will respect each other's desire to achieve the status of nuclear-free zone and neutral state. It has been decided to preserve unified command of a common military-strategic space and united control over nuclear weapons.

 	 	 		. . .	 	From the moment of the conclusion of the agreement, the application of the norms of third countries, including the former U.S.S.R., on the territory of the states which have signed it, is not permitted, and the activity of bodies of the former union ceases.
 
STANISLAV SHUSHKEVICH and VYACHESLAV KEBICH,
Republic of Byelorussia
 
BORIS YELTSIN and GENNADI BURBULIS,
Russian Federated Republic
 
LEONID KRAVCHUK and VITOLD FOKIN,
Ukraine
 
POLITICAL PACT
We, the heads of state of Byelorussia, Russia and Ukraine:
NOTING that talks on the preparation of a new union treaty have reached a dead end and the process of the secession of republics from the U.S.S.R. and forming the independent states has come to reality;
STATING that the shortsighted policy of the center has led to a deep political and economic crisis, to disintegration of the economy and catastrophic decline of the living conditions of practically all the sectors of the population;
TAKING into account growing social tension in many regions of the former U.S.S.R., which have led to ethnic conflicts and resulted in numerous victims;
ACKNOWLEDGING the responsibility before our people and the world community and the growing necessity of practical implementation of political and economic reforms;
HEREBY declare the formation of a Commonwealth of Independent States, about which the parties signed an agreement on Dec. 8, 1991.
 
STANISLAV SHUSHKEVICH,
Chairman of Parliament, Byelorussia
 
BORIS YELTSIN,
President, Russian Federation
 
LEONID KRAVCHUK,
President, Ukraine
 
ECONOMIC PACT
Preservation and development of the existing close economic ties between our states is vitally necessary for stabilizing the situation in the national economy and creating the foundations for economic revival.
The parties have agreed to the following:
* To carry out coordinated radical economic reforms aimed at creating feasible market mechanisms, transformation of property and ensuring the freedom of entrepreneurship;
* To abstain from any actions economically harmful to each other;
* To develop economic relations and mutual accounts on the basis of the existing currency unit -- the ruble. To introduce national currencies on the basis of special agreements which will guarrantee the preservation of the economic interests of the parties;
* To sign an interbank agreement aimed at curbing monetary emission, providing for the effective control over money supply and forming a system of mutual accounts;
* To conduct coordinated policy of reducing the republics' budget deficits;
* To conduct coordinated policy of price liberalization and social protection;
* To undertake joint efforts aimed at providing for a single economic space.
 
VYACHESLAV KEBICH,
Prime Minister, Byelorussia
 
GENNADI BURBULIS,
Secretary of State, Russia
 
VITOLD FOKIN,
Prime Minister, Ukraine

HEADLINE: Washington Memo;
In New Social Era, Moynihan Sees 'New' Social Ills

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8

 BODY:
Professor Daniel Patrick Moynihan, a United States Senator with a history of flashy ideas, has a new one.
Or sort of a new one. 
 Or a new name for an old one, anyway.
For months, Senator Moynihan has been telling reporters, assistant cabinet secretaries, other senators and who knows who else that he thinks America is undergoing the kind of shift that has not happened for 100 years or so, into what he is calling the era of "post-industrial social policy."
 
A New Social Phenomenon?
 For the last 100 years, he argues, the central concern of social policy has been to blunt the destructive effects of industrialization, particularly unemployment.
While those problems clearly persist -- and have grown in the current recession -- Senator Moynihan contends that they are being overshadowed by a rise in welfare dependency so severe that it constitutes a new social phenomenon. He likens the current efforts to understand it to an earlier generation's first, fumbling attempts to measure and ameliorate unemployment.
"We think we have a new social condition," he said in a get-together that was not so much an interview as a tutorial, filled with digressions about 19th century economists, statistical sampling techniques and the like.
"Just as unemployment was the defining issue of industrialism, dependency is becoming the defining issue of post-industrial society," he said.
In talking about welfare dependency, Mr. Moynihan is also referring to related problems like family disintegration, failure in the schools and criminal behavior. Arguing that America knows precious little about the causes of these problems or about solutions for them, he has introduced legislation that would require the Government to produce an annual dependency report, full of new statistical gauges that he hopes will bring insights and increased attention.
Senator Moynihan said he could no more specify the kind of statistics that would be produced than Benjamin Franklin could diagram the internal combustion engine, but he said he hoped they could answer questions like: Why do people go on welfare? How do their children do in school? How do the problems in Oklahoma differ from Ohio's?
 
Focus on Dependency Is Goal
 "I don't know what I don't know, but I want to know a lot, lot more than we do now," he said, conjuring up a future in which the periodic issuance of dependency figures generated headlines and convened Cabinet meetings the way unemployment numbers do now.
Senator Moynihan's reputation as a trend-spotter is such that few people dismiss out of hand his proclamations, however grandiose. But some critics are quick to distinguish between the majority of welfare recipients, who spend little time on the rolls, and the smaller though substantial group for whom welfare becomes a way of life.
Others argue that Senator Moynihan's use of phrases like "post-industrial" deflects attention from large and troubling trends in the economy, including the erosion of wages for unskilled workers about which he has himself expressed concern. Those trends, they say, are responsible for some of the dependency problem.
Still others have grown weary with what they see as the Senator's record of posturing as a visionary while failing to offer solutions.
"I think Moynihan takes the figures we provide and, perhaps to emphasize his point, sometimes simplifies them for effect," said Professor Greg Duncan, a University of Michigan economist whose research is frequently drawn on by Senator Moynihan. Nonetheless, Professor Duncan said, "by and large he's concerned about the right thing."
Of course, Senator Moynihan has been worrying out loud about the rise in dependency and the collapse of the family since at least 1965, when, as a Labor Department aide he issued an explosive paper subsequently dubbed "The Moynihan Report." In it he highlighted government figures showing that a quarter of black children were being born to single mothers -- a condition he called new and alarming.
 
'We Were Right'
 The report was condemned by many blacks and liberals, who said it "blamed the victim," and for decades the condition of the black family was seldom discussed in political and academic circles.
In the meantime, the situation grew much worse: 26 percent of all American children were born to single mothers in 1988, and among blacks the figure was 64 percent.
It is not hard to detect in Senator Moynihan's current statements a note of pride in vindication. "We were right," Mr. Moynihan wrote in a September issue of the magazine America.
Now he argues that welfare dependency is so entrenched and extensive that it represents not just the worsening of an old problem but the emergence of a new, qualitatively different one. While in the past welfare dependency has fluctuated with economic conditions, he argues, it now may have reached such proportions that it has taken on a momentum of its own.
To push his case, Senator Moynihan has become a press agent of sorts, for a statistic that was drawn from a research project called the Panel Study of Income Dynamics at the University of Michigan. It concludes that 22 percent of all American children born in the late 1960's spent at least a year on welfare before the age 18. Among blacks, the figure was 72 percent.
Senator Moynihan argues that European countries are experiencing a similar onslaught of dependency, noting that about 29 percent of births in England are to unwed mothers.
In calling for the generation of new statistics, Senator Moynihan contends that it is easy to forget how little the nation once knew about cycles of wide unemployment -- a concept that baffled the world when it first arose with industrialization in the 19th century.
 
The Cart Before the Horse?
 Significantly, he says, policy makers addressed unemployment before they even knew how to measure it. Federal unemployment insurance was passed in 1935, but the first annual unemployment statistics were not published until 1946. Similarly, he says, America has been providing for dependency, through welfare, while knowing little about it.
Among those who would add caveats to Senator Moynihan's current pronouncements is Robert Greenstein, director of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a Washington research group.
"The key development in poverty trends in the 1980's was not increases in dependency, but the erosion of wages," he said.
This draws no argument from Senator Moynihan. "That's why we need more data."
Professor Lawrence Mead, a political scientist at New York University, shares Mr. Moynihan's view that a new social condition has emerged. But he calls it more mysterious than the rise of unemployment, and he doubts that new statistics will do much to correct it.
 
Search for Answers
 While few people question Senator Moynihan's talents for publicizing the problems of dependency, his critics say his record in offering solutions is less impressive. A 1985 article in Washington Monthly magazine showed that Senator Moynihan had a long record of reversing his positions on plans to combat dependency. "He's struck out on finding the answers," it concluded.
In 1988, Mr. Moynihan was the principal author of the Family Support Act, which requires some welfare mothers to attend work or training programs. Since then, he has alternated between celebrating the law as a revolutionary move and playing it down as a humble first step.
"He's unusual among Washington policy makers in that he focuses on the problem and not the solution," said Mr. Mead, who finds the trait a strength and a weakness. "He's not able to say he advocates anything."
Senator Moynihan shrugs off such criticism.
"I plead guilty," he said. "There are worse things to do than trying to identify a problem."

HEADLINE: Skinner Faces Task of Injecting Oil Into Rusty Domestic Policy Machine

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 8

 BODY:
As Samuel K. Skinner takes charge of the White House staff, he inherits a domestic policy apparatus that has atrophied from disuse.
An Administration's proposals to solve domestic problems, like the recession, unemployment, homelessness and the soaring cost of health care, do not come out of thin air. An organizational structure is needed to encourage the development, refinement and discussion of proposals before they can be translated into action, current and former officials say. 
 And while Democrats continually criticize Mr. Bush's domestic policy, some of the sternest critics of the policy making process are Republicans in the White House itself and elsewhere in the Administration.
They complain that John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff for the last three years, and Richard G. Darman, the director of the Office of Management and Budget, have trampled on other people in the Administration who are nominally responsible for formulating domestic policy: the White House Office of Policy Development, the White House Office of Policy Planning and the Domestic Policy Council, an advisory body of eight Cabinet officers.
 
Darman as 'Choke Point'
 A top aide to President Bush said Mr. Darman has been "the choke point on domestic policy," blocking fresh ideas that come through the pipeline in his zeal to preserve the 1990 budget agreement. Another Administration official said the domestic policy process was suffering from "oxygen depletion." A third official said that O.M.B. now stands for "One Man Band."
And a fourth said that Mr. Sununu and Mr. Darman allowed few of the "family squabbles, the healthy dust-ups over policy" that used to occur in the Reagan Administration.
The officials all insisted on anonymity, recalling occasions when Mr. Sununu or Mr. Darman had scolded them for speaking to journalists. Indeed, the fear of leaks to the press is a major reason that Mr. Sununu and Mr. Darman have contracted the circle of those involved in making policy.
 
Skinner's Challenge
 Mr. Sununu's resignation as chief of staff takes effect Dec. 15, but he will stay on as a counselor to the President with Cabinet rank through March 1, 1992. His departure might enhance the budget director's influence. But some officials say they think Mr. Skinner will try to open up the policy making process, as he did at the Transportation Department, so that Mr. Bush will be exposed to a wider range of opinions and recommendations.
Mr. Skinner, viewed as far more receptive than Mr. Sununu to new ideas, has vowed to change the staff he will inherit and its method of operation, if he discovers problems. But whether he can invigorate domestic policy is an open question, given the financial constraints and Mr. Bush's lack of strong ideology.
In his book "Presidential Decision Making," published in 1980 by Cambridge University Press, Roger B. Porter, who is now assistant to President Bush for economic and domestic policy, said: "A good decision-making process cannot guarantee good or wise decisions. It can, however, provide the means for the President to make his decisions intelligently and not ignorantly."
The Domestic Policy Council is theoretically the chief engine for formulating and coordinating domestic policy in the executive branch, on everything from health and education to crime, drugs and the environment. William P. Barr, the new Attorney General, is expected to become the council's chairman on Nov. 26, White House officials said. The council was headed by his predecessor, Dick Thornburgh, from August 1988 to August of this year.
 
Plea by Thornburgh
 In an interview, Mr. Thornburgh said the council "was underutilized by the White House, the President and the people who served him," and Mr. Thornburgh left no doubt that those people included Mr. Darman and Mr. Sununu. But he also emphasized that it was "the President's call" to define the council's role.
In a memorandum more than a year ago, Mr. Thornburgh pleaded with Mr. Sununu to give the council a more active role as a catalyst for the formulation of domestic policy initiatives -- "a specific agenda based on the values and principles" Mr. Bush espoused in the 1988 Presidential campaign.
"At a time when the domestic agenda is obviously going to be at center stage, for the next two years at least, I am inclined to think a more active role for the D.P.C. should be an option given careful consideration by White House staff and the President himself," Mr. Thornburgh said in the memorandum, dated Nov. 15, 1990.
Mr. Sununu did not answer the memo except to tell Mr. Thornburgh, "You're doing a great job; keep up the good work," said an Administration official. The council has generated proposals for clean air legislation, tenant management of public housing and limits on medical malpractice lawsuits.
 
A Rusting Machine
 Administration officials said there was nothing inherently wrong with the structure of the domestic policy machinery -- the same basic structure President Ronald Reagan created in April 1985 to foster participation by a wide array of Government agencies. But "unused muscles atrophy," a Bush Administration official explained.
President Bush is ultimately responsible for his own domestic policy. Several officials suggested that the policy making process would be more dynamic if Mr. Bush paid more attention to it and articulated his priorities more clearly.
Mr. Bush's domestic policy is enshrined in, and constrained by, the 1990 budget agreement, which raised taxes, set limits on Federal spending and prevents shifting money from the Pentagon to domestic programs.
"The budget agreement is the hieroglyphic that orders our universe, and Darman is the only cryptographer who can crack the code," said one official, noting the law's rigid, arcane rules and Mr. Darman's formidable staff of more than 500 at the budget office.
Thomas Bruce, a spokesman for the budget office, said there would be no formal response to the unfavorable comments about Mr. Darman.
 
Nebulous Health Policy
 The Bush Administration's difficulty in formulating health policy illustrates its neglect of the established policy making machinery. In his State of the Union Message in January 1990, Mr. Bush announced a Domestic Policy Council review of soaring health costs and the problems of 34 million people with no health insurance.
Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, Secretary of Health and Human Services, studied the issue exhaustively and prepared a package of recommendations, but they have not been formally discussed or analyzed by the Domestic Policy Council. Meanwhile, Mr. Darman has set up a little shop in the Office of Management and Budget to sift through all proposals for overhauling the nation's health-care system. Hounded by Democrats, Mr. Bush now says he hopes to have "a comprehensive health care plan that I can vigorously take to the American people" in the 1992 campaign.
In his 1980 book, Mr. Porter, the White House aide, said there should be more than one channel for transmitting policy advice and recommendations to the President. He strongly endorsed a system of "multiple advocacy," to expose the President to competing arguments and to avoid the suppression of conflicting views.
Members of the White House staff and Presidential appointees in several Cabinet departments said the ideal described by Mr. Porter has been impossible to achieve because Mr. Darman and Mr. Sununu have so dominated the formulation of domestic policy.
The White House Bulletin, a newsletter published daily by Paul Roellig, a former White House aide under Presidents Reagan and Bush, reported this week a widespread feeling in the Administration that creative ideas were unwelcome if they came from officials outside "the Sununu-Darman axis."

Media Business

That raises more doubts about the future of the newspaper, which Mr. Maxwell acquired in March 1991. [Page A1.]
