HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
NHK of Japan Ends Plan for Global News Service

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Nov. 8

 BODY:
Japan's semiofficial broadcasting giant, NHK, is abandoning its plans to start a worldwide 24-hour news service to compete with the Cable News Network and the British Broadcasting Corporation.
NHK's proposal for a Global News Network had promised to become Japan's first journalistic voice around the world, an Asian counterpoint to Western-dominated broadcasts. While industry analysts were skeptical whether the broadcaster could assemble the journalistic talent for such an undertaking, few of them had doubted that NHK, formally known as Nippon Hoso Kyokai, could find the money to take on its American and European rivals. 
 But on Friday, at a luncheon for foreign correspondents, Mikio Kawaguchi, NHK's new chairman, said that while the project "seemed feasible until the summer," further investigation showed that "setting up GNN is totally out of the question."
 
A Question of Costs
 With Japan's economy slowing, Mr. Kawaguchi said, NHK now feared that it could not afford to spend up to $800 million a year on the Global News Network.
Although the time frame had never been specified, if the new satellite network had been started it would have propelled NHK into the broadcasting big leagues, especially against the BBC, with which it is most often compared. The Global News Network was the idea of NHK's former chairman, Keiji Shima, a newsman-turned-executive who ruled NHK with an iron hand and had long complained that CNN was "trying to force U.S. news on the rest of the world."
Because Mr. Shima was so committed to the project, which he proposed last year, NHK was expected to proceed with the Global News Network. NHK was to provide eight hours of programming a day, specializing in coverage of Asia. Eight more hours would have been provided by a partner in Europe and another eight hours would have come from a partner in the United States. The BBC and ABC were often mentioned as possible partners, but no definite agreements had been reached.
All of the broadcasts would have been in English and the headquarters of the project would have been in New York -- presumably to be in a more central time zone and to further distinguish the network from NHK's news operation in Japan.
The project ran into trouble, however, as soon as Mr. Shima was forced out of office earlier this year in a bizarre scandal involving accusations that he lied to the Japanese Parliament over his whereabouts during the failed launching of an NHK satellite. Mr. Shima had testified that he attended the launching in the United States; it later turned out that at the time he was involved in a sexual liaison with an NHK employee.
 
Journalistic Limitations Seen
 Though the reasons offered for canceling the plans were largely financial, many of those familiar with the project say the real problems were journalistic. In times of world crisis -- most recently during the Persian Gulf war -- NHK's own news reports seemed well behind other news organizations. In fact, the network had to rely heavily on CNN, which it rebroadcasts on one of its channels, and on ABC, with which it has had a long relationship.
In Asia, NHK is still regarded with some suspicion because of Japan's years of colonial rule over Korea and Taiwan, then known as Formosa. Several countries sharply limit satellite broadcasts from Japan, saying that they fear cultural domination from their former colonial ruler. Mr. Kawaguchi noted the other day that because of restrictions in Asia, "it is quite questionable whether we can get enough news to cover eight hours."
The conservative network has also run into news-gathering problems in Japan. Although it raises its money largely from subcriptions paid by Japanese viewers, NHK is closely tied to the ruling Liberal Democratic Party and it has gained a reputation for moving very slowly on reports that seem potentially embarrassing to the country's leadership. Its news programming in Japan has steadily lost market share to privately run networks.
Nonetheless, NHK now runs an increasing number of English-language broadcasts in Japan, including one nightly general news program and one focusing on business and finance. Mr. Kawaguchi said that "we will keep the concept or spirit of the Global News Network," but added that he had concluded that "as a business, it is not feasible."

HEADLINE: U.S. Communists' Meeting Has Its Own Fractionalism

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER

 BODY:
The Communist Party of the United States of America, its meeting hall decked with mementoes of its glory days in the 1930's, its leadership surrounded by guards and its membership bitterly divided, ended its quadrennial convention in Cleveland Dec. 8 after repudiating the policies of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, Boris N. Yeltsin and other former comrades.
There was no indication, however, that the former General Secretary of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union or the current President of the Russian Republic noticed or cared. 
 At the end of the convention, the party leadership, under criticism as "fossilized," told 600 fractious delegates that the party would "struggle to defnyend the living standards of Americans and change the political direction of the country," a convention spokesman said. During the gathering, the leadership also showed it had the muscle to silence or shut out many of those who wanted to change thw party's own political direction.
 
Hotel Command Center
 Unlike the hard-line leaders of the failed Soviet coup, who tried and failed to secure the nerve centers of an entire nation last August, the leadership of the party here had to secure only the sixth floor of the Sheraton City Center. They succeeded, with the help of armed Cleveland police officers, hired at the request of party leaders.
This accomplished, Gus Hall, party chairman since 1959, took to the floor on Friday for a three-hour speech, vowing to continue the struggle for socialism and excoriating the dissidents in his own ranks -- a group that includes some of the country's best-known Communists, Angela Davis among them.
"Factionalism is usually the work of the enemy from within," Mr. Hall told the convention, which represented 3,000 dues-paying party members. "The fight against factionalism is a fight against alien concepts and alien practices with the party."
The dissidents smiled sardonically about the irony: the leader of a party whose members were once persecuted by police, and whose ideas were once denounced as an "alien ideology" issuing the same denunciations and calling on police to protect him.
 
Dissidents Stay Private
 But few dissidents, who are largely from Northern California, New York, Minnesota and Massachusetts, would talk to a reporter. "We don't want to air our dirty Lenin in public," said one.
Even Michael Bayer, the head of the convention's press committee, said that the dissidents had a significant following, though he added, "I doubt it numbers 10 percent" of the dues-paying membership. One dissident, speaking on condition that he not be identified, said that their actual numbers were as high as 900 nationwide.
There were enough of them in Cleveland to fill a 250-seat hall at the Convention Center, across the street from the hotel. Dissidents spent the weekend shuttling between the hotel and the convention center carrying news bulletins to comrades who were excluded.
But there were not enough of them to dislodge Mr. Hall from the leadership.
The two groups were divided by a variety of issues. One was their response to the Soviet coup. Both opposed it, but the dissidents think Mr. Hall's condemnation was late and ambivalent. A second was their analysis of the collapse of Soviet Communism.
"It's like driving somewhere in a car," said one dissident who also spoke only on condition of anonymity. "What matters is where you're going. A few little clinks and rattles don't bother you, as long as you know where you're going. But when the transmission and the gearbox fall out, you have to worry about the car and how it's made."
But Mr. Bayer rejected the notion that the vehicle of Communist social organization had broken down.
"This is human error," he said, explaining the events in the Soviet Union. "They dismantled the social and economic mechanism and they didn't replace it with anything."
The weekend's internecine warfare seemed an anachronism, more suited to the 1930's, when there were bitter doctrinal disputes and American party members flocked to the Soviet Union to build Communism, than to the end of 1991, when Soviet citizens are flocking to the West or begging capitalist to invest in their country.
 
Odd Convention Scene
 It was doubly surreal in the happy-talk setting of the hotel. In the lobby tearoom, a tuxedo-clad pianist played "As Time Goes By," a foreign businessman discussed sites for a new Honda plant, the people wearing the badges of "disenfranchised delegates" talked about dumping the leadership and the hard-liners' yellow-ribboned "security" officials walked around, whispering into walkie-talkies.
Despite the bitterness, memories of the past were poignant for several generations at the assembly.
Ms. Davis, who joined in 1966, did not attend the convention but sent her fellow party members a wistful letter.
"Like many comrades, I still feel very much connected to the popular progressive struggles of our time," she wrote. "But I do not feel that as a party we have maintained a vital link to those realities."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Effort Seen To Lower Prime Rate

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Many analysts expect the Federal Reserve Board to follow its move last Friday easing monetary policy with additional moves in a few weeks to bring down the prime rate, now at 7.5 percent. That would put more downward pressure on long-term interest rates, including home mortgages.
But after 30 months of watching the Fed push down short-term rates, investors and economists are becoming more convinced that lower rates alone cannot quickly put the economy on track. 
 True, the Fed's rate reductions are probably preventing a more severe economic downturn. But its control over long-term rates -- and the influence of interest rates in general on economic activity -- is limited, so monetary policy alone cannot quickly restore consumer spending and confidence.
 
Not a 'Jump-Start'
 "Every drop in rates helps a little, but I don't think that lower interest rates -- even lower rates for long-term bonds, which have been slow to fall -- are going to jump-start the economy," said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Securities Inc., an affiliate of Chase Manhattan Bank.
While businesses are using less than 80 percent of existing capacity and consumer spending is sluggish, Mr. Fine said, there is not much incentive for companies to borrow and expand, though lower rates do help corporate profits and make some expansion projects slightly more attractive.
In the housing market, another part of the economy that is sensitive to rate changes, mortgage rates are already well below the levels of 10 percent or more that prevailed in 1988, a year in which the economy grew by more than 3 percent and about 1.5 million housing units were started.
 
Weakness in Housing
 Despite the steady drop in mortgage rates to as low as 8.5 percent for fixed-rate loans and below 6 percent for adjustable-rate mortgages, construction of new homes remains weak, at an average annual rate of just under 1.05 million units in the three months that ended Oct. 31. Home-building activity is up only slightly from the first three months of the year, when new units were started at an annual rate of 915,000.
While new construction is not booming, mortgage lenders say borrowing activity is increasing, particularly among homeowners who can lower their monthly payments by refinancing old high-rate mortgages. On a $100,000 fixed-rate mortgage, for example, each 1/8-point reduction in the mortgage rate reduces the monthly payment by nearly $10.
"I'm encouraged by the increased activity, but the housing market is still being held back by questions about the economy," said Jerry Butler, a managing director at the Countrywide Funding Corporation, a mortgage banking company in Pasadena, Calif. "Too many people are wondering whether they will still have a job next month."
One problem for the housing market is that long-term interest rates have not declined nearly so much as short-term rates. The yield on 30-year Treasury bonds -- the benchmark for fixed-rate home mortgages and long-term corporate borrowing -- is about 7.84 percent, down only about 1.3 percentage points from 9.17 percent in April 1989, when the decline in short-term rates began.
In that same period, the Fed-controlled rate for overnight bank loans in the Federal funds market -- a closely watched benchmark for rates like certificates of deposit and the prime -- has fallen to about 4.5 percent, down from 9.84 percent in April 1989.
The relatively small drop in bond yields has puzzled many analysts, particularly since it comes at a time when inflation is expected to remain low, which would normally increase the demand for long-term bonds, driving up their prices and lowering their yields.
One reason may be a widely circulating fear that Congress and the President will not make tax cuts and stimulative spending until after the Fed has eased monetary policy further. Such tardy fiscal stimulus, combined with the Fed's previous easing of monetary policy, could make for more inflation late next year or in 1993.
 
Strength in Notes
 Among other explantions for high bond yields, Robert Andres, a partner at Martindale Andres & Godshalk, an investment advisory firm, noted that investors have generally done better with intermediate-term Treasury notes than 30-year Treausry bonds. Consequently, he said, the bond market lacks enough traders and speculators to buy bonds and push long rates back down to the 7.5 percent level that prevailed for much of 1986 and 1987.
Stephen Smith, an executive vice president at Brandywine Asset Management, noted that the high level of Treasury bond yields reflects in part the availability of higher bond yields in Germany, France, Britain, Italy and Canada, combined with the weakening of the dollar.
Mr. Smith and other analysts also blame high Treasury bond yields on selling by Japanese investors, who were major buyers in the middle and late 1980's.
Thomas G. Gribbon, a senior Treasury bond trader at Nomura Securities in New York, said there had been substantial selling of Treasury bonds, including zero-coupon issues, this year. But he noted that in recent weeks, the selling has become more sporadic, and its impact has probably been exaggerated by Wall Street rumors.
Whatever the amount of Japanese selling, it has been enough to reduce the price of long-term zero-coupon Treasury bonds to such a level that their yield is now higher than that of the same bonds with interest coupons intact. Late last week, the 30-year zero-coupon issues were offered at about 9.25, or $92.50 per $1,000 bond, to yield about 8.18 percent.
 
Many Corporate Issues
 While the decline in bond yields may be a disappointment to economic policy makers, it has been well received by corporate treasurers. Last week, more than $6.1 billion of new corporate bonds were offered, led by the first long-term public offering by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company since 1985. The weekly total was more than half the average monthly volume for the year.
Investment bankers expect another active week as corporations try to take advantage of lower rates and complete their offerings before investors and securities dealers begin retrenching for the holiday season.
Several companies are poised to issue securities when the 30-year Treasury bond yield drops to 7.75 percent, a level reached briefly Friday.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Last Day For Dallas Times Herald

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES

 BODY:
The Dallas Times Herald, the city's oldest daily newspaper, ceases publication today after slowly losing ground in advertising and circulation for more than a decade against its archrival, The Dallas Morning News.
The A. H. Belo Corporation, the Dallas-based company that owns The Morning News, announced yesterday that it had bought most of The Times Herald's assets, including presses and circulation lists, for $55 million. 
 Antitrust law would normally prohibit such an acquisition by a direct competitor, but John Buzzetta, principal owner and publisher of The Times Herald, said yesterday that in the last year he had unsuccessfully approached more than 100 prospective buyers. Late last week, the Justice Department approved the sale of The Times Herald, which was established in 1879, to The Morning News.
 
An Intense Rivalry
 On Sunday morning, Mr. Buzzetta told Roy E. Bode, editor of The Times Herald, that the paper was closing, and Mr. Bode began summoning his staff to prepare for the final issue.
"While it wasn't unexpected, I didn't know it was going to hurt this much," said Molly Ivins, a Times Herald columnist. Comparing the two papers, she added, "The Herald had the guts and the writers; The News had the money and the circulation."
In fact, both papers had moments of excellence, and their intense rivalry -- one of the few remaining battles between independently owned newspapers in the same city -- had enriched Dallas since The Times Herald began to challenge the pre-eminence of The Morning News in the early 1970's.
The Times Herald won Pulitzer Prizes in 1964, 1980 and 1983, The Morning News in 1986, 1989 and 1991.
In the late-1970's, The Times Herald's Sunday circulation briefly overtook that of The Morning News, the city's Republican and more conservative newspaper. The Herald's traditional readership was Democratic and blue-collar.
But The Herald eventually succumbed because of a local economy that has been depressed for five years and the inherent disadvantages of being the smaller, traditionally afternoon paper in an era when few cities can support two dailies.
Last month, The Arkansas Gazette in Little Rock was sold to its rival, The Arkansas Democrat, and closed. But in that case, The Democrat had successfully shifted from afternoon to morning publication and overwhelmed the city's long-dominant paper, The Gazette.
The Herald had tried the same approach, but it failed.
 
Investment by Times Mirror
 In 1970, when The Herald was acquired by the Times Mirror Company, owner of The Los Angeles Times and Newsday, it trailed The Morning News in overall circulation but had the lead in Dallas County. The two papers essentially divided the city's newspaper advertising.
Times Mirror invested heavily in The Times Herald in the mid-1970's and turned it into an all-day paper, which put it head-to-head with The News in the morning.
But in 1980, Times Mirror acquired The Denver Post, which was locked in a battle with The Rocky Mountain News, and it named the publisher of The Times Herald to manage The Denver paper as well. At about that time, The Morning News was roused by The Times Herald's aggressiveness and proved to be a sleeping giant.
The momentum began to turn against The Times Herald, and the paper never recovered.
 
Sold Twice in the 80's
 Times Mirror sold both The Times Herald and The Denver Post to William Dean Singleton, chief executive of Media News Group Inc., in the mid-1980's, and Mr. Singleton sold The Herald to Mr. Buzetta and a group of investors in 1988.
In recent years, The News's advantage in circulation had become a rout.
The Times Herald's daily circulation was 201,000, compared with 407,000 for The News, according to the Audit Bureau of Circulations. Sunday circulation of The Times Herald was 289,000, compared with 618,000 for The Morning News.
Similarly, in 1990 The Morning News had 62 percent of total newspaper advertising, and the gap was widening because in hard economic times, when advertising is scarce, the dominant paper tends to get more. For instance, The Morning News had nearly 68 percent of the classified advertising for the first 10 months of the year, compared with 63.5 percent in the period a year earlier.
Mr. Buzzetta said The Times Herald would not declare bankruptcy and would use the $55 million purchase price to pay suppliers and provide 60 days' severance pay to its 900 employees.
He said his equity partner, Equitable Capital Management, and its bank, the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, had cooperated in the negotiations. He said the price he had paid for the paper -- reported to have been $140 million -- was excessive, but declined to say what he had paid.
"We're obviously selling for less than we paid," he said.
In 1989, Belo formed a partnership with Universal Press Syndicate, which removed all of its syndicated columns and comic strips from The Herald. The move stripped The Herald of some of its most popular features, including "Dear Abby" and "Doonesbury," and the paper sued on the grounds that Universal did not have the right to cancel its contracts.
Though The Herald lost the court battle, it appealed. Belo announced yesterday that the matter had been settled through payment of $1.5 million to The Herald.
 
Belo Declined Joint Effort
 A year ago, Mr. Buzzetta tried to persuade The Morning News to agree to merge the production and business aspects of the papers in a joint operating arrangement that would have allowed The Times Herald to survive as a news organization. But Belo declined, on the grounds that such a deal was not in the financial interests of its shareholders.
Burl Osborne, publisher and editor of The Morning News, said that paper estimated that about 135,000 of The Herald's daily circulation and 165,000 of the Sunday circulation did not subscribe to The News.
Mr. Osborne said The News would offer jobs to some Herald employees and add some of the paper's syndicated features.

HEADLINE: Environmentalists Assess Corporate Pollution Records

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
The Mobil Corporation may be responsible for cleaning up wastes at 47 sites under the Federal Superfund program, a fact not disclosed in the company's annual report.
A subsidiary of the Amoco Corporation tried to install hazardous-waste incinerators on Indian lands, ostensibly to avoid state and Federal emissions regulations. 
 The American Cyanamid Company releases four times as much toxic waste into the environment per $1,000 of sales as the average chemical company.
These nuggets of information -- not denied by the companies involved -- are in a series of environmental profiles being published by the Council on Economic Priorities, a nonprofit group in New York that monitors social policies of large corporations. The reports are intended to appeal to socially conscious investors and to encourage companies to minimize pollution.
The council's reports are part of a growing effort by public interest and environmental groups to examine and publish analyses of the vast amounts of environmental data that the Government has required companies to file in recent years. Early next year, the Investor Responsibility Research Center, a Washington-based organization that conducts investment research for university endowments and pension funds, will publish statistical summaries of the environmental performance of all 500 companies in the Standard & Poor's index.
Both organizations sell their research, but are operated on a nonprofit basis.
While not refuting many of the specific statements in the council reports, the companies contend that the documents distort their environmental performance by dwelling largely on past problems.
Other groups are digging into environmental data as well. Friends of the Earth, for instance, issued a critical 112-page study of E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company's environmental performance in August in response to television advertisements the company has run that depict animals applauding Du Pont's decision to use double-hull oil tankers. The group said the Du Pont study was the first of a series of reports on what it calls "corporate environmentalism."
The new reports come in addition to the annual compilations of toxic emissions issued by Citizens Fund, another public advocacy group.
Industrial companies are required by the Government to report their emission levels for several hundred chemicals believed to be toxic, even if the emissions are within permitted limits. Citizen Fund aggregates the plant-by-plant data submitted by the companies and characterizes the chemical as acutely toxic, cancer causing or linked to birth defects. Since the data were first published three years ago, many major corporations, including Du Pont, Mobil and the Monsanto Company, have announced programs to cut their emissions sharply.
Some officials of environmental groups have said that publication of the toxic emission data has had a more powerful effect on reducing pollution than 20 years of regulation by the Environmental Protection Agency. William Reilly, the administrator of E.P.A., described the data as "one of the most important tools we have to reduce toxic emissions."
 
Range of Environmental Criteria
 The new reports go beyond toxic emissions to look into data concerning E.P.A. enforcement actions and fines paid, Superfund liabilities reported in documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, and published accounts of environmentally related incidents. Alice Tepper Marlin, the director of the Council on Economic Priorities, said the reports came in response to requests by users of the group's other research services.
"The environment has emerged as the No. 1 concern with much of our audience," she said. The group also publishes "Shopping for a Better World" and "The Better World Investment Guide," both of which rank companies on a variety of social criteria, including advancement of women and minorities, animal testing and charitable giving.
Margaret Carroll, executive director of the Investor Responsibility Research Center, said investors were beginning to realize that sloppy environmental policies could hamper the financial performance of companies. "This is not so much a moral or ethical issue as one that potentially affects the bottom line," she said. "There may be indications in the data of future liabilities."
One example, said Scott Fenn, another official of Investor Responsibility, is Superfund liabilities. Legally, each company involved in a site is liable for the complete cost of cleanup, although in practice the cost is usually spread among several companies.
Knowing that one company has dozens of Superfund liabilities and has paid large fines for environmental violations could help an investment manager evaluate it against another that has little liability and few fines.
Ms. Tepper Marlin said the 35 companies covered in the first set of reports were given an opportunity to review the findings and supply additional material.
 
Mobil's Protest
 A sampling of the companies involved indicates they are uncomfortable with the council's analysis, even when some of their responses are included in final drafts. In a letter to Jonathan Schorsch, the council's project director, Mobil described its profile as "incomplete and unwarranted."
In particular, the company objected to the council's use of published accounts of environmental incidents without any effort to check the underlying facts. "Conclusions reached in the profile appear to be based, at least in part, upon a combination of limited factual information and unproven newspaper allegations, media perceptions and incomplete reports," the company said in a six-page letter to the council.
At Amoco, Walter R. Quanstrom, the vice president for environmental affairs and safety, "commended" the group for including many of the company's comments, but questioned what he called a misplaced emphasis on a small subsidiary.
Mr. Quanstrom said it was true that the company's Waste-Tech Services unit opened negotiations with some Indian groups about building incinerators on their land, but said the company backed away from the proposal and none was actually built.
"Waste Tech represents less than one one-hundredth of Amoco's revenues, but they have a whole page on it," Mr. Quanstrom said. "I think that is a wee bit overplayed."
Mr. Quanstrom of Amoco said he had observed a trend toward measuring the environmental performance of companies much the way financial performance has long been analyzed. "I think what we're going to do is develop some rules," he said, "so that apples are measured against apples."
Charlotte Cuff, public affairs director for American Cynamid, said that the council had not used most of the material her company provided in support of its position and that the council added allegations after the company reviewed an early draft. The report, she said, "should have little credibility as a source of information."
The Council on Economic Priorities plans to profile an aditional 100 companies next year and plans to be monitoring 500 by 1996. The individual reports are available on a sliding- fee scale ranging from $20 for individuals and small nonprofit institutions to $100 for corporations.
The Investor Responsibility Research Center, in contrast to the 20- to 50-page reports issued by the council, confines its statistical summaries to two pages.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Some Holiday Traditions Fall Victim to the Recession

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
AS the advertising industry's recession continues, its traditional holiday-time largesse toward employees has noticeably diminished.
A growing number of shops across the country, particularly in the Northeast, are reducing or even eliminating holiday bonuses, parties and other special seasonal rewards for employees. Some, though, are trying to make up for that, by offering alternative compensation. And some, hoping to turn thoughts to those less fortunate, are encouraging agency-wide charitable activities. 
 That is to not to say that the Grinch will be visiting every address on Madison Avenue; many agencies are adhering to their annual holiday plans. But the pervasiveness of the cutbacks is yet another reminder of the industry's economic plight.
For instance, most of Young & Rubicam Inc.'s agencies are canceling general staff bonuses, a spokesman said. Last year, there were cash bonuses, typically about 5 percent, based on salaries.
Although the general bonuses have been eliminated, the spokesman added, Y.& R. intends to continue "a fairly aggressive program of incentive bonuses," the spokesman said.
While bonuses will still be awarded at the Leo Burnett Company, a spokesman said, the agency's annual contribution to its employees' profit-sharing fund will be cut slightly. It is only the second time that has occurred since the fund was established in 1943.
At DDB Needham Worldwide's New York office, managers will not get the bonuses -- 1 percent of salary -- they received last year, a spokesman said, adding that all other employees will receive them. At the agency's Chicago office, he continued, the 1 percent bonus that everyone received last year has been modified; it will be given only to employees who earn less than $50,000 a year.
In lieu of a cash bonus at McCann-Erickson Inc., a spokeswoman said, employees will receive extra vacation days; offices will close at noon on Dec. 24 and reopen on Dec. 30.
Several agencies giving employees time off are asking them to devote that time to altruistic pursuits.
Dec. 20 will be "J. Walter Volunteer Day" at the six nationwide offices of J. Walter Thompson U.S.A., a spokeswoman said. Under the program, which began last year at Thompson New York, employees will have the day off to perform volunteer work for local charitable organizations.
The New York office of Thompson's sibling agency, Ogilvy & Mather, is adopting the program this year, a spokeswoman said, sponsoring a "corporate service day" on Dec. 17. Several agencies in Philadelphia plan a similar program, called "the heart of advertising."
Other agencies are making donations of cash rather than time. For the second consecutive year, BBDO and Backer Spielvogel Bates Inc. will each donate to charities money that was earmarked for office parties, spokeswomen for those agencies said.
One agency maintaining its holiday traditions says that continuity is particularly welcome in a year like this.
"People are working really hard, and they look forward to it all," said Joseph P. Mack, chairman and chief executive of Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising in New York, where employees will receive their regular bonus, a week's salary and a party.
"If we can afford it," he added, "it's the first thing to do."

SECTION: Section C; Page 11; Column 1; Cultural Desk

HEADLINE: Critic's Notebook;
A New Movie House Revives Memories Of the Good Old Days

BYLINE: By VINCENT CANBY

 BODY:
Before the multi-plexes of the 1970's and 1980's, before the advent of art theaters in the 1950's, moviegoing in Manhattan was something else.
Walking into the lobby of the old Roxy Theater, which stood at the corner of Seventh Avenue and 50th Street, was like entering the reverie of the manicurist played on the Roxy screen by Alice Faye. Here was Sleeping Beauty's castle, the pilasters of its towering keep molded in plaster, its trysting alcoves equipped with drinking fountains, staffed by ushers who looked as if they had been shanghaied from the chorus of "The Student Prince." 
 Like so many great movie theaters built in the 1920's and 1930's, the Roxy represented a particularly American kind of decadence, exotic but clean-cut and family oriented.
Only one other theater could lord it over the Roxy: Radio City Music Hall, when movies accompanied by stage shows were its principal source of income. Radio City was Manhattan's class act. It was vast and vaguely totalitarian in its efficiency. It was also a monument to the forgetfulness it could offer at modest prices to more people (6,000) at a single sitting than any other theater in the country.
It wasn't a place to encourage the rowdies. Its thick carpets absorbed all thought of horseplay. Also anxiety. The sheer size washed the brain, making the patron feel small, comfortably infantile.
Theaters then were named the Paradise, the Riviera, the Albee, the Fox and (on Chicago's North Shore) El Teatro del Lago. They were names to suggest escape, or to celebrate the buccaneers who built them.
In this era of multi-plexes, with common lobbies sometimes serving as many as 9, 10 or 12 theaters, going to the movies is no longer an esthetic experience in itself. Indeed, it's often as infuriating as a visit to the Department of Motor Vehicles, when you don't know which queue you're in until you get to the head of the line.
There will be no doubt about that at the Lincoln Center Film Society's spanking new Walter Reade Theater, which opens today and which may well be the most inviting new movie house to open in New York in years.
The theater doesn't turn back the clock all the way to the 1920's, but it accommodates our romanticized moviegoing past without denying the practicalities of the present.
The Walter Reade has the style of an art house, updated for our time. It acknowledges that the movies we watch today are a mix of the contemporary and the classical, those films that make up the heritage that didn't exist, or wasn't yet recognized, when the old movie theaters were new, or even middle-aged.
It's a handsome, comparatively small (268 seats) but spacious house of nervy character, seemingly unencumbered by the sobriety and uplift of its high-art context. It has its own entrance (off the plaza of the center's new Samuel B. and David Rose Building), unattached to any Walter Reade 2 or 3, or even to the Film Society whose headquarters it shares.
When you buy your ticket, $7 for each of its four different daily shows ($5 for Film Society members), you know that you are going to the movies, not to a museum. That's not to put down museums, but to emphasize the successful way in which the Walter Reade bridges the gap between art and commerce.
There is even a lobby concession stand: popcorn, soda and brownies, though no hot dogs and sauerkraut as yet. The theater's seats, which would seem to be as big and comfortable as those in M-G-M Air's first-class, are equipped with holders for drinks. No need to plop the paper cup down on the floor, first to be forgotten, then to be absently kicked over to drench the running shoes of the person in front.
These are only the amenities, though. It's the auditorium that counts, and the Walter Reade's is no shoe box with a smallish screen at the far end. Its screen is big and dominant, the ceiling high and the room's length in agreeable proportion to its width. The floor is sloped in front, then sharply raked to provide good sightlines from virtually every seat. It will take someone seven feet tall with a pumpkin-shaped head to obscure the subtitles here.
The decor is as eclectic as the theater's programming policy, and discreetly suggests the more florid look of the Ziegfeld Theater, the 1,151-seat house built by Walter Reade Jr., the exhibitor for whom the Lincoln Center house is named.
Reade died in 1973 in a skiing accident in Switzerland. He was a tall, flamboyant man, who wore a white carnation in his buttonhole and liked to be recognized. He would appreciate the fact that he is now identified with Manhattan's most attractive, most elegant small house, as well as with the Ziegfeld, which has evolved into the best big theater in the city.
The Ziegfeld and the 1,525-seat Astor Plaza are the last two theaters in New York where it's possible to see a film such as "Lawrence of Arabia" in the only way that it can be seen, on a large screen that reveals its original glory. Though they are relatively new, the Ziegfeld and the Astor Plaza evoke the memory of the great movie palaces that were designed to compete with each other, not with television and home video.
To assert itself, especially during the Great Depression, each theater developed its own magical personality. Movies came and went, but the theater was a continuing presence in the community. It might lure you in, even if the current attraction didn't.
Movie palaces were convenient. You entered and left at your own whim. Films were shown around the clock; there was no nonsense about intermissions. Tickets were cheap and, in summer, there was air-conditioning.
To be honest about them, though, they were not always the best places to see movies. They were drafty. Dust accumulated on the plaster cupids. The light on the screen was often dim. As time passed them by, they turned into barns. Conceived to have more character than the films they presented, they eventually became grotesque. When audiences dwindled and expenses rose, they had to go.
There are sound economic reasons for multi-plexes, but not for the manner in which most of them have been designed and run. We've leaped from a time when movie theaters had too much character to a time when most have none at all. Up to a point, a movie theater should be anonymous. The film is the thing, but too much anonymity also palls.
To understand the possibilities, compare two large West Side operations, the Worldwide Cinemas, which has six theaters that are efficient and comfortable, though the space is huge, with the Chelsea Cinemas, an eight-theater complex that has all the charm of the Port Authority Bus Terminal.
There are balances to be struck, sometimes beautifully, as at the Angelika Film Center, six theaters and a big airy lobby in a magnificent old Stanford White building. Also, the Film Forum, three spotless theaters that show, week in and week out, a greater variety of consistently interesting films than any other complex in Manhattan (though I know one man who goes there mostly for the great espresso).
The upscale standbys remain: the Cinema 1, the Cinema 2, the Baronet, the Coronet, the Lincoln Plaza, the Beekman and the fine old Paris Theater, now called the Fine Arts.
It is this group to which the Walter Reade belongs. New York's newest even has a screen curtain, something that I thought had gone out of style. The Walter Reade's deep green draperies mask the large white eye that, before the show starts at other theaters, stares out to accuse you of possibly wasting your time. There is nothing emptier than a movie screen without shadows.
The Walter Reade's bill today: Sergio Rubini's "Station," a new film from Italy; Euzhan Palcy's "Sugar Cane Alley" (1983), and the splendiferous "On the Town," directed by Gene Kelly and Stanley Donen, which will be shown twice. "On the Town" originally opened here as the 1949 Christmas attraction at -- where else? -- Radio City Music Hall.

HEADLINE: SOCCER;
World Cup '94: Genie Is Out of the Bottle

BYLINE: By FILIP BONDY

 BODY:
In less than one hour yesterday at the Paramount Theater in Madison Square Garden, 141 national soccer teams were efficiently matched with their alibis, with their worst nightmares, and with their impossible paths to glory.
When the 1994 World Cup qualifying draw was done and the hostess, Barbara Eden, the actress, had mispronounced the name of her last soccer celebrity, delegates from six regions of the world wondered aloud if they would ever reach the shores of the United States in 31 months' time for the greatest sports spectacle of them all. 
 "England, Holland, Poland and Norway gave problems to Italy," said Sepp Piontek, an official with the Turkish Soccer Federation. "Our group could not be much worse."
 
22 Will Qualify
 After nearly two years of home-and-home qualifying matches, 22 of these nations will qualify for the first World Cup ever in the United States. Germany, as the defending champion, and the United States, as the host country, hold automatic berths, avoiding the pratfalls but also the toughening that comes with an arduous qualification process.
Yesterday, some preplanned emergency maneuvering by FIFA, soccer's international governing body, avoided potential disaster on a global scale. When the little ball that contained the name of Iraq was plucked at the worst conceivable moment, that country was immediately removed from Saudi Arabia's group and safely placed with China. Soccer tantrums can be as violent as those over oil, or territory.
"Over all, the groups are well-balanced," decided Franz Beckenbauer, who was coach of the West German team that won in Italy in 1990. "It would be difficult to choose between one and another."
Still, there were interesting matchups, from a purely soccer standpoint: Argentina was matched with Colombia, Paraguay and Peru in Group A of South America, competing for only one guaranteed spot and another berth that would require two more qualifying games; evenly matched Belgium, Czechoslovakia, Romania and Wales (plus Cyprus) would have to travel to the remote Faroe Islands, to play on that tiny nation's brand-new, first grass field, and the fractured Soviet Union was matched with chaotic Yugoslavia, Hungary, Greece, Iceland and Luxembourg, in a wide-open grouping that could produce a surprising survivor among its two qualifiers.
 
Europeans Not Pleased
 As usual, the loudest post-draw whining came from the powerful European sides, who found many things wrong or worrisome with their draws.
The delegations from England and the Netherlands agreed to a summit on Jan. 26 in Amsterdam to discuss security arrangements for the naughtiest fans on the continent.
"It's not as much of a headache as it was three or four years ago, I hope," Graham Kelly, general secretary of the English Soccer Federation, referring to the prospect of fan violence. "At least we're not in with Ireland this time."
The travel agent for the Northern Ireland Soccer Federation could not believe his misfortune at drawing the only seven-nation grouping in Europe, including not one, but two, of the new Baltic nations. Lichtenstein was an 11th-hour dropout from the draw because of this very same threat.
"This is a nightmare in logistics," said David Segel, who must arrange round trips for the Northern Ireland team to both Latvia and Lithuania. "Who in Latvia is going to do a deal with us?"
The Italian delegation, completely remade after a loss to Norway in qualification matches for the 1992 European championships to be played next summer in Sweden, liked its group, but began lobbying immediately to be headquartered in New York City for the 1994 World Cup. It did not seem to matter to the Italian Soccer Federation president, Antonio Mattarese, that the sites for the World Cup have not been selected yet, and that Giants Stadium has not yet been recognized as a viable venue.
"Coming to America and not playing in New York would be a big affront to the Italian community, " Mattarese said.
Mattarese took another look at Italy's grouping, with Scotland, Portugal, Switzerland, Malta and reborn Estonia. He was not concerned.
"This group won't cost us any sleep at night," he said. If it did, Mattarese would be as unemployed as his predecessors.

HEADLINE: BOXING;
Foreman Fires Away As Ellis Sees Fireworks

BYLINE: By PHIL BERGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RENO, Dec. 8

 BODY:
There's no recession in the George Foreman market. Foreman, who will be 43 years old next month, made $5 million on Saturday night for taking batting practice against a jut-jawed target disguised as Jimmy Ellis.
That was how easy it was for the 257-pound Foreman at the Reno-Sparks Convention Center, where he stopped Ellis at 1:36 of the third round of a scheduled 10-round bout. 
 Ellis, a linebacker for the Los Angeles Raiders for part of the 1987 National Football League season, during the strike, was a willing accomplice in the assault and battery Foreman committed on him.
Ellis kept moving forward, absorbing the thudding punches Foreman threw at him, while trying unsuccessfully to damage big George with punches of his own.
 
Deflecting Throws
 Foreman largely deflected the blows with his gloves or caught them on his forearms. Then back to the attack he would go.
With an almost insouciant air, Foreman would throw a volley of punches and then step away so as to cue Referee Richard Steele to take mercy on Ellis and stop the fight. Steele declined to be that gracious.
So Foreman kept bludgeoning the 27-year-old Ellis. Foreman threw big looping shots that seemed to be on delayed tape. But those punches camouflaged his better weapons: the short snapping uppercuts, the left hook and clubbing right hands that move at far greater velocity and from close quarters.
By the first round, Ellis was bleeding from the bridge of his nose. A round later, he was bruised under his left eye and was wobbling like a tipsy sailor from the impact of Foreman's combinations. Ba-boom, ba-boom: Foreman kept hitting Ellis and Ellis tried to act like the toughest man in Reno.
But he fooled no one, least of all Foreman. It was a mismatch. Ellis did not have the tools or experience to deal with Foreman. All he possessed was a big-league quotient of courage, insufficient for keeping big George at bay.
Late in the second round, Steele made a move as if to stop the fight, but appeared to change his mind at the last instant. That Ellis was in need of the kindness of strangers like Steele was clear from how he navigated at the bell ending the second round.
 
Going the Wrong Way
 With a dazed expression, Ellis started toward Foreman's corner, which was already occupied. That was when Ellis's trainer, Lonnie Bennett, retrieved his fighter and walked him back to the proper corner.
By the third round, Foreman was driving Ellis backward with his pistonlike jabs to the head. Ellis's face was reddening from the battering.
A computer punch count indicated that Foreman landed 40 of the 49 punches he threw in the third round. When he assayed the 48th (a left hook) and 49th (a jab) punches in the round, Steele decided that Ellis had finally had enough and called an end to the bout.
"I hit him with a lot of hard shots," Foreman said in the ring afterward. "He must have been a helluva football player. He hit me hard a few times. He had no respect for his elders."
 
Experience Counts
 What he did have was the face of a loser: a purplish welt beneath his left eye, a crusted fleck of blood on the bridge of his nose and red discolorations on his forehead.
"A good experience," Ellis said afterward. "I'm still learning. I have a lot of room to improve. And I'll be back."
Back to football would seem the better part of valor for Ellis, who earned $325,000.
Foreman (70-3, with 66 knockouts) said that he wanted to meet the winner of the Feb. 7 match between Ray Mercer and Larry Holmes. Meanwhile, Ellis (16-1-1, 15 knockouts) can research headache remedies.

HEADLINE: THE EUROPEAN SUMMIT;
Leaders Hearken to History, Ambition and Voters Back Home

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING

 BODY:

Francois Mitterrand
President of France
 Francois Mitterrand, who at the age of 75 is now in his 11th year in office, has long been a strong advocate of greater European integration. He argues that it will be good for Europe but also, perhaps more importantly, for France. He believes that by belonging to a strong economic bloc, France can withstand competition from the United States and Japan and keep the power of a united Germany in check.
As a Socialist, he was an ardent anti-Gaullist, and when he became President in 1981 he immediately set about applying Socialist policies, including the nationalization of banks and other strategic industries. But when his program proved disastrous, he began applying orthodox monetarist policies that revived economic growth. 
 Since his re-election to a second seven-year term in 1988, he has dedicated his energies to accelerating European union.

HEADLINE: Recession Surprise: New York Hotels Are Packed

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
Never mind the recession: in New York City this holiday season the bright lights at hotels are likely to read 'No Vacancy.'
For Robin Breakiron and Vicki Malik, friends from Uniontown, Pa., who arrived on Saturday, finding a room was something like a relay race. The adrenalin flowed. Their credit cards were at the ready. 
 "We've spent the last two hours flagging cabs and going from hotel to hotel to hotel," said Ms. Breakiron, looking haggard but steely eyed as she struggled through a throng of tourists at the Marriott Marquis hotel just north of Times Square.
"For the price you pay in New York, we never expected this," complained Ms. Malik. Having found no rooms at the Marriott or the Hilton, the two women hailed another cab, this time for yet another hotel and sped off into the neon glow of a Times Square night.
Their ordeal was shared by thousands of unlucky, last-minute or unprepared visitors to Manhattan. At a time of terrible fiscal problems, devastating job cuts and early indications that Christmas shoppers are in advanced recessionary trauma, something happened over the weekend that seemed a reminder of the New York of old.
 
Glimmer of Reassurance
 Almost every Manhattan hotel reservation was used, and every room full. While that came as a shock to Ms. Breakiron, Ms. Malik and many others, it may offer a small glimmer of reassurance to a a troubled city.
"Considering that the only thing that has been used up in New York over the last year are unemployment insurance benefits, this has be considered a nice surprise," said Rosemary Scanlon, chief economist of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.
Of course, those who arrived on Friday and Saturday came during one of the busiest weekends of the year. From after Thanksgiving to Christmas, when the tree at at Rockefeller Center twinkles, department store displays dazzle and Broadway boasts of its hits, Manhattan has always filled with tourists and shoppers, even during the worst of times.
Early December also brings conventioneers, who combine days of shop talk with nights of holiday cheer. Among those competing for hotel space last weekend were 5,000 anesthesiologists and 3,500 shoe executives.
"This period is known around the world as a particularly delightful time to be in New York," said Greg Gibadlo, director of marketing for the New York Hilton Towers, at 53d Street and Avenue of the Americas. The hotel has 2,042 rooms. Every one was filled on Friday and Saturday.
Still, the crowds at reception desks on Friday and Saturday represented something more than business as usual for New York.
One reason is that the hotel industry, following the overbuilding that created gluts of new office space and condominiums, is completing its biggest surge of construction since before World War II.
That means there are more rooms to fill. According to Pannell, Kerr & Foster, a Manhattan accounting firm, eight large new hotels have opened in Manhattan since the beginning of 1989, with 3,541 rooms. The New York City total now is 64,621 rooms, and two more hotels, with another 700 rooms, are scheduled to open in 1992.
 
Room Rates Have Fallen
 For the first time in memory, room rates have declined, falling to an average of $134.50 a night during the first nine months of 1991 from $140.33 during the same period a year earlier, according the accounting firm.
"The city has been doing a lot better since the late fall," said Stephen Brenner, a Manhattan broker of hotels who also analyzes demand for rooms. He said that Manhattan hotels, which averaged 75 percent occupancy in 1989 and 1990, would fare slightly worse for all 1991, but that the last six weeks of the year were showing a "nice surge."

HEADLINE: Repeal Vote On New Tax Coming Soon In Hartford

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Dec. 8

 BODY:
A vote to repeal Connecticut's three-month-old income tax could come Monday, but legislators who gathered at the Capitol today to put the final touches on the plan said its details were still not finished and might not be until hours before the vote.
Some of the details are small -- like whether the sales tax rate should rise to 8 percent or 8.25 percent from 6 percent. Others are big -- like whether to allow cities to raise money through video slot-machine gambling, the final shape of $200 million to $300 million in state spending cuts and, finally, how to close a gap in the plan that has been estimated at $300 million to $500 million. 
 Those decisions could be politically pivotal as leaders of the repeal movement try to raise their anti-income-tax majority to the two-thirds they would need to override Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s certain veto.
And enough lawmakers have given themselves wiggle room on the question to make it interesting, saying they hate the income tax but will only vote for an alternative that makes sense for the state.
 
Each Piece Carries Votes
 To each of the unresolved questions are attached some potential votes. For example, video gambling could raise revenues for troubled cities like Bridgeport and Hartford -- and gain some crucial urban Democratic votes. But other legislators, including many of those who are lukewarm on repeal, say that including the gambling part could harm the package's chances by introducing something that some lawmakers oppose almost as much as the income tax.
Given the wave of public anger about the 4.5 percent flat-rate tax on adjusted gross income, which began coming out of residents' paychecks in October, legislators on both sides of the issue say the pressure to act quickly on the tax issue is enormous.
The plan sketched by repeal leaders is for a vote to repeal by the House on Monday, followed by the Senate late Monday night or Tuesday. They assume that Mr. Weicker would be prompt with his veto, setting up the showdown on overriding it for Thursday or Friday.
With the state's economy generally perceived to be worse off, or at least no better, than it was during last summer's budget impasse, and with the holiday retail season near its peak, any sign of uncertainty or deadlock now about the fiscal future could dampen buyers' spirits even further.
 
Eyes on Shopping Days
 "The last thing we need is to be here debating this on the second-to-last weekend before Christmas," said Representative Jonathan Pelto, the political director for the state Democratic Party, which has majorities in both the House and Senate.
A major focus of the weeklong debate is expected to be just how bad Connecticut's economy is, and what effect turning the tax code upside down in the middle of the fiscal year might have on businesses or customers. And reports last week on the ravages of the recession could bolster the arguments on both sides.
The Connecticut Department of Labor said that although the seasonally adjusted unemployment rate fell in October to 6.3 percent from 6.7 in the previous month, jobs continued to evaporate. Since February 1989, when total employment peaked in the state, 106,000 jobs have disappeared, a 6.2 percent drop, in a non-agricultural work force that now totals about 1.6 million.
Another report issued by an economists' group called the New England Economic Project said the new wage tax had taken what was already the worst recession since the 1930's and made it worse.
"What you have is substantial amount of discretionary purchasing power that is being pulled out the economy," said the report's author, Edward J. Deak, a professor of economics at Fairfield University. "That's helping to depress consumer spending."
Another economist, Ronald F. Van Winkle of West Hartford, said he believed that whatever lawmakers do this week could end up a wash for the economy as a whole. He said that while reducing taxes by $300 million or more, as the repeal plan calls for, would stimulate the economy, the tax cuts are being matched by state spending cuts that would hurt the economy by reducing the total demand for goods and services.
"It's more of a political issue than an economic issue," he said.

HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook;
Buy Down the Red Army

BYLINE: By LEON V. SIGAL

 BODY:
Are the U.S. and its allies willing to spend $1 billion to get rid of the Soviet threat?
That's not a pitch for some exotic new weapon. It's for severance pay to induce Soviet officers to retire. 
 It's not a crazy notion when one considers that the U.S. is still spending $300 billion a year on defense, roughly half of it to deter a Soviet attack on Western Europe. Cutting that budget in half would free up substantial resources to meet domestic needs -- but only if the Soviet threat evaporated. Taking a billion from defense for a bonus for Red Army retirees could buy a lot more security than $150 billion worth of arms.
For decades, the Soviet armed forces stirred neighbors' worst fears. Their sheer size, some 3.4 million strong, prompted Americans to allocate trillions of dollars to keep them at bay. Now, with Soviet disunion, those forces are falling apart. Funding for new arms is sure to be cut sharply and salaries won't keep up with soaring inflation. The troops already complain about short rations.
Next year, funding for the Red Army will depend on the largesse of the republics. But they have to bring their budgets into balance and get inflation under control; they can't afford to maintain a huge army. The republics with the largest troop contingents on their soil, Russia and Ukraine, are looking for ways to reduce them drastically.
Most short-term draftees would be only too happy to go home early. But career officers have no place to go. Many of those returning from Eastern Europe lack jobs and housing. Russia's Vice President, Aleksandr Rutskoi, himself a former army colonel, broke with President Yeltsin over military budget cuts last week, warning, "You cannot endlessly play with people who bear arms" because it "may end in disaster," implying another coup.
Restiveness in the upper ranks is a major reason that Ukraine, which has joined Russia and Byelorussia in a commonwealth, is talking about building its own 400,000-man army. Ukraine now has 1.2 million men at arms on its territory, about a third of them natives of Ukraine and all of them now on Ukraine's payroll.
Apart from the ultra-nationalists, Ukrainians know they can't afford even a 400,000-man army and that such an army, larger than united Germany's, alarms their neighbors. While they'd like to make sharp cuts in the armed forces, they worry about large numbers of retired officers, underpaid and ill housed, with nothing to do but growl in their beer and plot revenge.
That's where America and its allies can help. Retraining for civilian jobs might work. But it's expensive, slow and inefficient. Civilians in a Moscow think tank have a better idea -- severance pay of $1,000 in hard currency for every officer and non-com who leaves the army.
The officers would be free to do what they wanted with the money -- build or buy housing, spend it on Western goods, start a business, even drink it away. A thousand dollars would go a long way in today's depressed Soviet economy, and could provide a stimulus to growth.
About a million men and women in the Soviet armed forces would qualify. At $1,000 a head, it's possible to buy down the Red Army for about $1 billion. To assure that the money is not misappropriated, a foundation with a board of Soviets and Americans would oversee disbursements.
Congress has already had the sense to allocate $400 million from next year's defense budget to help the Soviets store and dismantle their nuclear warheads. An additional $1 billion in severance pay would go far toward eliminating the Soviet threat altogether.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Middleman's Mistake

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
If President Bush can get the Arab states to negotiate directly with Israel, the talks will make progress. If he lets Secretary Baker become the middleman carrying messages and finally recommending the settlement -- the "peace process," a phrase coined by Henry Kissinger nearly two decades ago, will fail.
So far, despite the great debt of survival owed to America by the Arab states, Secretary Baker has not been able to arrange talks other than "through" the U.S. That's because Arab leaders believe the Americans can pressure the Israelis to give up the West Bank, the Golan Heights, and in the end part of Jerusalem. 
 Only when the light dawns on Arabs that the only way any territorial compromise can be achieved is to stop using U.S. intervention as a crutch -- and to deal directly, face to face, with the nation they cannot defeat or forever ignore -- will business begin. Israelis are ready to deal with people who are ready to deal with them.
Apparently the Arabs -- especially Syria's dictator, Assad -- are not ready. That explains the fussing about venue: the Israelis want home-and-home meetings, as befits equals, while Arab leaders insist on some far-off setting using America as permanent middleman.
President Bush is acceding to the Arabs' wishes. His invitation to Washington, presented to Israel as an insulting summons, contained language showing that the U.S. would tilt toward Syria on stripping the high ground of the Golan from Israel's defense.
And on the West Bank, our meddling middlemen have an opening deal in mind as a first step toward imposing a grand bargain that American soldiers would be forced to police. In return for Israel giving up the right to live on land that both Arabs and Israelis claim -- "freezing settlements" is the phrase -- Mr. Baker will arrange an end to the Arab boycott and throw in the sweetener of repealing the U.N.'s Zionism-is-racism resolution.
There is no deal there. It's a dead end. The economic sabotage is unlawful, an act of war to be condemned and not treated as a bargaining chip; and the U.N.'s resolution is an abomination, a moral burden to the Arabs and the old Soviet bloc. Israel would be crazy to hand over the key to its territorial security for the cessation of a couple of evil deeds. Yet Mr. Baker persists in pretending this guaranteed non-starter is the basis for a serious negotiation.
Thus, we have been drawn in as a middleman and blocking conduit, thereby undermining our goal of encouraging direct talks; and our opening intercession is a loser. Is there a way to get this back on the track?
Fortunately, three pressures are pushing in the right direction.
In Israel, the infusion of educated brainpower from the old Soviet empire and the strength of racial diversity brought by the Ethiopian Jews offer new confidence and renewed sense of mission to the Jewish state.
Long term, the wave of immigrants is a great economic and diplomatic asset; nearly a half-million people have been absorbed, live under roofs, and two-thirds have jobs. Short term, with 200,000 more expected this year, immigration is also a headache; in November's elections, most unemployed arrivals will vote against the party in power, putting Likud under internal pressure to seek peace progress.
In the U.S. too, politics can be a force for good sense. Candidate Bush wants a deal to run on, which he cannot get by bullying an isolated Israel; moreover, in a close race, the difference between minuscule support of Jewish-Americans for Goldwater and the much bigger vote for Nixon and Reagan could affect the outcome in key states. Mr. Bush will want to claim that he has accomplished the start of long-sought direct negotiations.
In the Arab world, if Syria remains bellicose, a joint venture on the Golan can await Assad's successor. But Palestinian Arabs are at last eager to attain the autonomy the P.L.O. disdained at Camp David long ago. Tired of being pawns, Palestinians will reach for more self-determination in association with Jordan and cooperation with Israel than can be found in any Arab dictatorship.
A quartet of self-ruling Palestinian cantons in a barrier-free West Bank is the way to Arab dignity and Israeli security. The world can help by embargoing arms to the area, but interference with direct dealing will only botch the prospects for peace.

WHO IS CARING FOR THE CHILDREN?
The darker side of the nanny business was starkly illuminated with the arrest in Thornwood, N.Y. of a 20-year-old au pair from Switzerland, who was charged in the death of a 3-month-old girl in her care. Thousands of parents entrust the care of young lives to nannies. And yet there is precious little families know about the people they hire. Page B1.

The broadening civil war for control of the Colombo organized crime family claimed the life of an innocent victim, an 18-year old boy working in a Brooklyn bagel shop who was shot to death when he was mistaken for someone else, the police said. THE MOVE HOME TO LOVE CANAL
One by one, about 25 families have moved back into the neat but abandoned houses of Love Canal, the Niagra Falls neighborhood sitting atop 21,800 tons of buried toxic chemicals. Amid heaps of burned tires and rusting car wrecks on a hiking trail in Theills, N.Y. is a strange, peaceful and desolate sight: a two-acre graveyard overgrown with hundreds of T-shaped iron markers. Few people ever visit these graves. Those buried there were forgotten before they died: residents of New York State's vast institution for the mentally retarded at Letchworth Village. HEADLINE: It Isn't Cold War II

BYLINE: By Suzanne Berger and Kenneth A. Oye; Suzanne Berger and Kenneth A. Oye are, respectively, professor and associate professor of political science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
The cold war is dead, but the cold war mentality is not. As America observed the 50th anniversary of Pearl Harbor, we heard familiar arguments in debates about U.S.-Japan relations.
These cold war arguments, which demonize Japan, have arisen as economic tensions between both countries have also regenerated a World War II mindset: once again, Americans say the Japanese have motivations and aspirations that differ fundamentally from ours. 
 Do we really need to conjure up foreign enemies to explain away our own economic deficiencies?
Analysts who counted nuclear arsenals in the East and West and evaluated the appeal of Communism to European countries and less-developed societies are switching their attention to Japan's economic threat. They are comparing it, wrongly, to cold war strategic competition.
For example, a C.I.A.-sponsored study that involved the Rochester Institute of Technology's president says: "Japan is an economic superpower whose world dominance appears inescapable and incontrovertible, absent some dramatic unified reassertion of Western intent, coupled with an equally dramatic economic resurgence. Mainstream Japanese . . . are creatures of an ageless, amoral, manipulative and controlling culture -- not to be emulated -- suited only to this race, in this place."
Polls seem to echo this thinking. While by 1990, only 33 percent of the American public and 20 percent of its opinion leaders characterized the Soviet Union's military power as a critical threat to the U.S., 60 percent of the public and 63 percent of opinion leaders called Japan's economic power such a threat.
A PBS "Frontline" program opened and closed with an American auto parts manufacturer calling for a "Desert Storm for the economy." The narrator declared that victory in the gulf disguised the fact that the U.S. is fighting, and losing, a war with Japan.
A noted political scientist, Samuel Huntington of Harvard, says America "is obsessed with Japan for the same reasons that it was once obsessed with the Soviet Union. It sees that country as a major threat to its primacy in a crucial arena of power." He argues that we have as much reason to struggle to remain the world's No. 1 power as we did throughout the cold war.
But are the stakes really the same? Should we be willing to be less well off in order to preserve our position? America didn't sacrifice blood and treasure in the struggle against Communism because of an abstract commitment to No. 1 status. Of course, we took pride in our role as world leader, but our sacrifices were borne, not to preserve our pre-eminent rank, but to contain the military expansion of a nuclear power that had occupied Eastern Europe and possessed global ambitions that threatened freedom.
During the cold war, national security analysts contended that either side could gain only at the other side's expense. That approach is now being used to define U.S.-Japan relations. But even at the height of the cold war, the U.S. and Soviet Union did not wholly see things as your-gains-are-my-losses; on the contrary, they successfully acted on mutual interests. Both sides minimized risks of nuclear war, sought to reduce nuclear proliferation and avoided direct conventional military conflict.
Thus, it is entirely misleading to invoke the metaphor of war to characterize today's U.S.-Japan relations.
Japan poses no ideological challenge the way Communism did. Whatever may be said about the successes of Japanese lobbyists, the Japanese way of life in no way compares to the appeal of postwar Communism to parts of Europe and the developing world.
Japan poses no military danger. There are no indications that it wishes to abandon the pacifist foreign policy that has contributed so much to its economic success.
But of course there are major economic issues that both sides must face squarely. Trade negotiations have significantly improved access to Japanese markets for such American exports as beef, citrus, cellular telephones and financial services. Nonethless, formal impediments on imports of rice and informal bars to other products and services remain firm.
Japan is leaping ahead in semiconductors and in the development of advanced materials, superconductivity and optoelectronics, according to a 1990 Commerce Department report. This lead gives Japanese companies the power to control prices and to deny U.S. companies access to technologies.
While Japanese companies are investing heavily in the U.S., there are real concerns about whether they will locate enough headquarters and research-and-development facilities in America, thus creating high-wage jobs and new skills, or mainly assembly plants. Will these be companies in which Americans will be permitted to rise to the top?
There are also concerns about whether U.S. investors are getting a fair shake in Japan, and whether intellectual-property rights and patents are being respected there.
During the Persian Gulf war, questions arose about whether Japan was doing enough; today, we ask whether it is doing its part to reconstruct Eastern Europe. Questions are also arising about whether Japan is doing enough basic research and paying its fair share for U.S. basic research that results in Japanese products.
We need to press Japan to address these issues before they dominate Presidential politics, because that may well heat up counterproductive cold war rhetoric.
In negotiations with Japan, however, our goal should not be to diminish Japan's economic status but to improve our own. We seem to be losing sight of this need.
Robert B. Reich, who teaches political economy at Harvard, asked opinion leaders to choose between a 10-year scenario in which our economy grew at 2.5 percent a year while Japan's grew at 6.5 percent, and another scenario in which our economy grew at 1 percent and Japan's at 1.1 percent. A majority preferred slower growth -- if only Japan could be held down, too! This thinking is no prescription for economic growth.
And it suggests that if we do have an enemy, it is not Japan but ourselves. The resources that might remedy our economic decline lie in our own hands, but we have been unwilling to devote them to productive purposes.
We should raise our investment level from 14 percent of the gross national product, not because Japan invests 27 percent but because higher investment will ultimately improve the American standard of living.
We should fully commit the resources necessary for educational excellence, not because Japanese primary and secondary schools are good but because investment in human capital is crucial to improve the nation's economic performance.
We should create fiscal incentives for American corporations to look beyond the next quarter's profits, not because Japanese companies look decades ahead but because long-term thinking is the key to reducing the costs and improving the quality of American products.
America does not need to scapegoat Japan, but to rebuild itself. The use of World War II and cold war imagery deflects attention from this basic point.
