HEADLINE: ALBANY NOTEBOOK;
And Cuomo Chooses: (Budget? Duty? Ego? Gore?)

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Dec. 9

 BODY:
"It's as simple as that," Gov. Mario M. Cuomo was saying today, explaining how the state budget mess continues to control his decision on whether to run for President.
But to many who watched Mr. Cuomo in the last two months, little has seemed simple about his decision making. Those who have dared to read the Cuomo tea leaves have found a muddy brew of contradictory signals in their cups. 
 Last week, for instance, Mr. Cuomo convinced many political analysts that he had decided to run because three of his top advisers had begun setting up a shadow campaign organization.
But today, Mr. Cuomo suggested strongly that he could not announce his candidacy without a legislative agreement to close this year's budget gap, a message that seemed to provide a disincentive for Republican legislators to reach a compromise.
 
Knocking Opportunity
 "If the negotiations aborted or we don't have a current year plan, under those circumstances I couldn't in good conscience declare a candidacy," he said in an interview on WAMC-FM radio in Albany. "It seems to me to be inappropriate to ask the nation for a grander opportunity of public service when I have not yet adequately dealt with the one to which I'm already committed."
Thus just as Mr. Cuomo seemed to be edging toward a formal declaration, he continued to reinforce a rationale for why he could not run.
For Mr. Cuomo, there is a certain logic to all of this. The Governor says he wants to run but is prevented from doing so by his sense of duty to the state. Realizing that time is growing short, he has decided to make all possible preparations to run an effective campaign if he decides to enter the race.
But the country is cynical these days about politicians who claim to place duty ahead of ambition. And many political analysts have long viewed Mr. Cuomo's protracted deliberations as a calculated strategy to dominate the political news as a non-candidate while shortening his campaign for the Democratic nomination.
On the other side, some longtime Cuomo advisers in Albany believe that Mr. Cuomo has never had a deep desire to run for President, and does not now. But unable to resist the ego gratification of a Presidential draft, they say, he revived speculation about his ambitions and then took a self-indulgent political joyride.
Now, these advisers speculate, Mr. Cuomo needs an excuse not to run and has found it in the state budget. Even some of his aides have theorized that Mr. Cuomo wants to make a convincing case that the budget is the only reason he cannot run and that he does not suffer from self-doubt, skeletons in the closet or lack of support.
Those aides guessed that Mr. Cuomo may be trying to advance the perception that he truly wants to run, and thus approved the highly public effort by the State Democratic Party Chairman, John A. Marino, to lay groundwork for a campaign.
 
Rumors, Rumors, Rumors
 The only thing more prevalent here and in Washington than theories about Mr. Cuomo's intentions are the rumors about when he will say something and what it might be.
Last Friday, Mr. Marino's switchboard lit up with calls from reporters who had heard that Mr. Cuomo and his son, Andrew, were making courtesy calls to the announced Democratic candidates telling them of the Governor's plans to run.
On the same day, Harold Holzer, a press secretary to Vincent Tese, the state's Economic Development Commissioner and a Cuomo confidant, got calls from reporters who had heard that Mr. Tese had canceled a weekend golf outing in Augusta, Ga., because he wanted to be around for Mr. Cuomo's announcement. Mr. Tese had canceled his golf trip to be with his family, Mr. Holzer said.
For several weeks, the rumormongers were saying that Mr. Cuomo wanted to announce a running mate at the same time he announced his candidacy, and that Senators Albert Gore Jr. of Tennessee and Lloyd Bentsen of Texas were the leading contenders. Another tidbit, which was just as inaccurate as the others, had Senator Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, an announced Democratic candidate, visiting the Executive Mansion for a job interview several weeks ago.
Other rumors crop up almost hourly predicting that Mr. Cuomo will make an announcement on a particular day this week or next week. One of them is likely to be right.
"It's so out of control that I'm not spreading any more rumors," Mr. Holzer said. "That's a saturation point I've never reached before."
 
Fears for Credit Rating
 Mr. Cuomo, who discussed the budget with legislative leaders and their aides in an hourlong meeting tonight, said today that the absence of a state budget would create not only a logistical obstacle to his candidacy but a political obstacle as well. He predicted that further delay would damage the state's credit rating, which is already the third lowest in the country after those of Louisiana and Massachusetts, and give his potential opponents more ammunition about his New York record.
"How can you run for President if you're leaving behind a state whose credit is failing?" he asked. "I cannot use Washington as an excuse for not having a budget here."
Another factor weighing on Mr. Cuomo and his advisers is the jury in the Federal fraud trial of Assembly Speaker Mel Miller. If Mr. Miller is convicted, Mr. Cuomo's budget negotiations with the Legislature could be thrown into chaos as a leadership fight develops in the Assembly.
"That would be everything," said one Cuomo adviser. "Talk about a kicker."

HEADLINE: In Switch, Business Groups Favor Keeping New Taxes

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Dec. 9

 BODY:
Business groups that adamantly opposed Gov. Jim Florio's $2.8-billion tax increase 18 months ago warned today that New Jersey would collapse if the taxes were eliminated.
In testimony before the Senate Appropriations Committee, the state's most powerful business associations, the New Jersey Chamber of Commerce and the New Jersey Association of Business and Industry, predicted "chaos" if the taxes are withdrawn and accused the Democrats of undertaking a "scorched-earth policy" for moving to repeal the taxes. 
 The dramatic reversal by the business groups paralleled that of New Jersey Republicans, who opposed the taxes when they were enacted and campaigned against them to win overwhelming control of the Legislature last month, but who now accuse the Democrats of being irresponsible for trying to repeal them.
 
The Wave of Voter Anger
 Republican members of the Appropriations Committee boycotted the hearing today at which the tax-repeal measures were debated.
The Republicans also refused to attend a general session of the State Assembly at which the same repeal package was to have been introduced.
The Senate committee hearing was held to consider five related bills that would repeal the $2.8-billion increase in state sales and income taxes at the end of the current budget year next June 30. Ending the tax increases would mean that the next Legislature, in which the Republicans will hold two-thirds majorities in both houses, would have to restore all or part of the taxes or face the prospect of sending the state into bankruptcy.
The alternative, cutting billions of dollars out of the next budget, is widely viewed as impossible. By one measure, overcoming a $2.8-billion cutback in revenue through job cuts would mean eliminating every one of the 65,000 jobs in state government.
The turnaround in attitudes toward taxes came only a month after the Republicans' runaway election victory, which resulted almost solely from voters' anger over the tax increase voted by the Democrats in the Legislature at the urging of the Governor.
Although Republicans campaigned relentlessly against the entire tax increase, once the election was over they said they would cut only a part of it, a one-cent increase in the sales tax that accounted for about $590 million.
Then the Democrats announced that they would seek a rollback themselves, in the lame-duck session they will control until the Republicans take over next month.
 
Labor and Business Agree
 When the repeal package came before the Senate committee today, representatives of the American Federal of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations testified against it, as did the Communications Workers of America, which represents 38,000 state employees, and the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, which represents an additional 10,000.
They were joined by James Morford, vice president of the New Jersey Chamber of Commerce, who said that removing the revenues the taxes produce would have severe effect on government services, create uncertainty and unpredictability and adversely affect the business climate in the state.
Bruce Coe, president of the New Jersey Business and Industry Association, said that repealing the taxes or adding a "sunset" provision to them would throw the state into "chaos."
Asked if he trusted the incoming Republican majority to act responsibly in reinstating taxes to keep the government going and the economic climate sound, Mr. Coe smiled and replied, "Who was it who said that no man is safe and his property secure when the Legislature or the Congress is in session?"
The committee chairman, Laurence S. Weiss, a Democrat of Woodbridge, said the hearings would resume on Wednesday and the repeal bills would come to a vote on Thursday.
 
The Republicans Are Missing
 The repeal of all or a substantial part of the tax package in the Senate is considered likely.
Predictions are harder to come by in the Assembly, where the Speaker, Joseph V. Doria Jr. of Bayonne, accused the Republicans of willfully impeding the legislative process and threatened to have them dragged back by the sergeant at arms or state police, if necessary, to get a quorum.
Garabed (Chuck) Haytaian, the minority leader and the lone Republican to appear for the Assembly session today -- he reported himself officially absent -- said Republicans would not attend any session unless the Democrats mustered a quorum on their own.
"If the Democrats wish to ignore the will of the people and continue the error of their ways, they will do so without our help," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Bruce Coe, president of the New Jersey Business and Industry Association, said that repealing the taxes or adding a "sunset" provision to them would throw the state into "chaos." (Laura Pedrick for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Market Place;
A Bleak Season For Natural Gas

BYLINE: By Thomas C. Hayes

DATELINE: DALLAS

 BODY:
THE futures market for natural gas and the market for shares of natural gas companies have both just about written off the winter of 1991-92 as another disappointment for the long-depressed industry.
The contract for January gas in the spot market fell again yesterday, by 4 cents, to $1.94 for one million British thermal units, from a peak of $2.33 on Oct. 15. The plunge has coincided with several weeks of unusually warm weather in the East. 
 And after a selloff in the last month, shares of a group of large independent natural gas producers, including Enron Oil and Gas, Anadarko Petroleum, Burlington Resources and Cabot Oil and Gas, are up 8 percent for the year, compared with an increase of 14 percent in the Standard & Poor's index of 400 industrial company stocks.
Two years ago, many analysts and producers figured that the end was near for a period of gas oversupply dating from the early 1980's. The dominant view is that gas prices are likely to remain depressed, with the yearly average spot price not rising much above $2 for one million B.T.U.'s before 1995, from about $1.40 this year.
Timothy J. Curro, energy analyst at UBS Securities in New York, said, "I don't think a very strong case can be made for the price of natural gas for the next three or four years."
Ronald J. Barone, a managing director and analyst at Kidder, Peabody in New York, said, "This is the worst year for gas prices in a long, long time."
Rising output from areas like the Gulf of Mexico, the Mobile Bay region of Alabama and the Anadarko Basin in Arkansas and Oklahoma helps explain the ample supply. So do the recession and warm winters, which have curbed demand.
Advances in drilling technology, including seismic studies that give geologists a clearer gauge of likely reserve sites and improvements in completing wells, are another factor. Production is up, even though the number of rigs drilling for gas plunged to 299 in the week ended Dec. 6, from 495 a year earlier, according to Baker Hughes Inc.
Also, big inventories remained in pipelines and storage tanks this fall after one of the warmest winters of the century last year.
Supplies also increased as a result of tax credits that Congress approved last year for gas drillers. Drillers are now receiving credits of 87 cents for one million B.T.U.'s of gas produced from coal layers, called coal-seam gas. Another tax credit, equal to 52 cents for one million B.T.U.'s, has sharply expanded drilling in tight-sands areas, where gas is locked in dense rock formations.
William A. Johnson, president of the Jofree Corporation, an energy consulting firm in Houston, forecast last month that tax-subsidized gas produced in the United States would rise to 5 percent of total gas output in the next few years, from 2.4 percent this year. Subsidized gas "is a major culprit currently driving down prices" and could send spot prices below $1 next summer, he said.
The prevailing gloom among gas producers is a striking reversal from the optimism of 1989, when the shares of many independent producers soared by more than 50 percent. The popular view then was that production would gradually fall, especially in the abundant Gulf of Mexico fields, and that demand would be raised by the Clean Air Act and new gas-fired electricity plants being built.
"We were very bullish on prices a few years ago," said Robert W. Harvey, head of domestic natural gas consulting at McKinsey & Company in Houston. His view is a centrist one in the debate over gas supplies and future prices. He sees prices rising barely above $2 in 1993.
"A couple of years ago, people acted on the belief that the gas bubble's demise was imminent, and they drilled more," he said. "We've seen a complete reversal on the score. The bearish view that has swept the industry today may be the first sign that a correction is possible in gas prices over the next two to four years."
Some analysts are more bullish. Paul R. Leibman, a principal at Petrie, Parkman & Company in Denver, said that falling drilling rates should cut into supplies within the next three years. "We actually see a tight gas market in the '93-'95 period," he said, with prices rising to $2.50 per million B.T.U.'s.
Indeed, some independent producers like Tom Brown Inc. in Midland, Tex., have acquired gas reserves at bargain prices in the last few years in the hope that prices will rebound.
"I want to be there with a big pile of reserves when the market turns," said Donald L. Evans, chairman and chief executive. "But with a recession and what looks like a mild winter, there is not a lot of reason to feel like gas prices will move to higher levels soon. We're hoping for '92, but it might not be before '94."

HEADLINE: OUR TOWNS;
Learning to Survive After Mate Loses Job

BYLINE: By Andrew H. Malcolm

DATELINE: NORWALK, Conn.

 BODY:
A FRIEND of Judith Guthman recently confided that her husband had been downsized. This is corporate-speak for fired. Mrs. Guthman knew that joblessness was happening to thousands across the country, 241,000 last month alone. Everyone knows someone who's been downsized. That's how dread of the future spreads.
Mrs. Guthman knew the standard rationale for job-chopping, the need to cut costs by cutting people, especially middle management. But until recently Mrs. Guthman had no idea of the familywide impact of this modern Darwinism on the husband, on the wife, on their emotional and physical relations, on the children and on everyone's values and expectations for the future. (Not to mention the wrath directed at political incumbents.) 
 Which is how about 20 women happened to gather at Norwalk Community College the other morning for an unusual new one-day course: How to Survive the Holidays and Beyond When Your Husband Is Looking for Work. "Everybody feels this mounting vulnerability," said Mrs. Guthman, who works in the college's continuing education department. "You see friends picked up right and left by these immense impersonal forces. It's really a fundamental restructuring of society."
Randy Nelson, a psychotherapist and one of the teachers, saw it similarly. "The Northeast," she said, "is an area brimming with anxiety. If I have a job, will I lose it? If I lose my job, will I get another? If I get another, will I lose it too?"
The teachers were women who were psychologists, counselors and writers, most of whom had experienced the pain of living with an unemployed spouse. The students were nearly two dozen wives, youthful to middle-aged, whose husbands have brought involuntary unemployment into their well-maintained, well-mortgaged homes in affluent communities named Greenwich, Darien, Westport and Fairfield. It's a new phenomenon among white-collar workers raised in an economic culture promising to reward hard work and company loyalty with lifetime employment on the success ladder. Now they don suits and ties only for rare job interviews.
The wives were attentive, taking notes, nodding and expressing intense reluctance to be identified. They described suddenly sullen husbands isolating themselves, which worried the wives, frightened the children, and corroded the family.
The scene was eerily similar -- down to the uneaten doughnuts -- to sessions in community colleges and church basements across the Midwest eight years ago when farm wives would secretly gather with church counselors to whisper about their troubled husbands. In those days local banks cut costs by tightening the screws on many farm families, who were only doing what their parents had always assured them would insure success: work hard and everything will take care of itself.
In the Norwalk class, Bernadette Kenny, a onetime victim of downsizing who now helps train dismissed workers to find new work, described the familiar scene. One day the workers are called in and turned out for reasons having little if anything to do with their work. She recalled one manager who had devoted his entire life to one company before being fired, surveying the ruins of his career and repeating, "It isn't fair."
The women were warned their unemployed spouses will experience grief, anger, a sense of betrayal and denial, and possibly be consumed by silent, useless wonderings over what they could have done differently. "Don't try to figure it out," advised Gilda Dangot, whose salesman husband has been twice unemployed. "Chances are your husband did nothing wrong. It's someone else's fault and he's probably still working."
The women were advised to be supportive, not blaming; to share their fears even if he doesn't reciprocate; to steer husbands into all-male support groups to counter destructive isolation and to temper the temptation toward Pollyanna-ism with an understanding of his embarrassment and the unaccustomed and demeaning powerlessness of job-seeking in a buyer's market.
Teachers also suggested organizing politically and re-inventing year-end holidays, making them less a time of excessive spending and more a time of investing attention in each other through inexpensive games, renting movies, making clothes, even exchanging massages.
"Yes, unemployment is unpleasant," said Ms. Dangot. " But I'm not alone. We may emerge stronger. And joblessness is not terminal."

HEADLINE: I.B.M. Argues Its Case, But Wall St. Is Bearish

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
Calling 1991 a "disappointment" and an "aberration," John F. Akers, I.B.M.'s chairman, argued the company's case before Wall Street analysts yesterday at an unusual briefing in which the company's top five executives detailed plans for decentralizing the world's largest computer maker.
But in Wall Street's eyes, yesterday's presentation fell short. 
After hearing the company's cautious 1992 earnings forecast, skeptical Wall Street investors hammered I.B.M.'s stock, sending it down $3.875 to a nine-year low of $85.125 yesterday in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
"After the presentation, a lot of analysts returned to their offices and began cutting their earnings estimates," said Steven Milunovich, an analyst at Salomon Brothers. He said many analysts decided that their projections were too high after the International Business Machines Corporation said its revenues were expected to grow at a single-digit rate next year.
 
Disappointed Analysts
 Other analysts said they had a negative view of I.B.M. because they still did not see the company making fundamental changes to control costs, despite its plans for decentralizing its operations and cutting its payroll by 20,000 next year. As such, a number of portfolio managers decided to sell the stock because any significant earnings growth seemed to await improvements in the economy.
"The key for me is the overwhelming view that I.B.M. is trying to grow its way out of its problems, and really nothing's changed," said Stephen K. Smith, an analyst at Paine Webber. "That's not what people want to hear. I.B.M. still continues to see the mainframe through rose-colored glasses."
The briefing followed the company's recent disclosure that it would break itself up into a federation of competing businesses. Yesterday, Mr. Akers reiterated that the company was considering a variety of options, including eventually selling portions or perhaps all or several of its businesses, seeking new investments and joint ventures and taking its top executives out of the day-to-day operations of its newly independent companies.
When I.B.M. disclosed two weeks ago that it planned to cut its work force by at least another 20,000 employees next year through a program of incentives and early retirements , it said it was setting aside $3 billion to cover the costs of the changes.
Mr. Akers said yesterday that the plan for radically changing I.B.M.'s structure and freeing its individual businesses to act with more autonomy, detailed last week, would re-energize the Armonk, N.Y., company.
"We are about to close the books on the most difficult year in the history of the information-technology industry," Mr. Akers said. "We're embarking on a very different I.B.M. than you and I have known all of our professional lives."
Saying that I.B.M. planned to increase its return on equity, which is now about 14 percent, to 18 percent over the next three years, I.B.M.'s chairman challenged the company's Japanese competitors. He argued that they would soon find I.B.M. was a tough competitor in many equipment and component markets.
"The strategy of the Japanese has been to attack the suppliers of their competition," said James Magid, a financial analyst at Needham & Company. "I.B.M. recognizes that system is open at every level and that they have to be a major participant at all levels of the business."
Despite the bearish Wall Street analysts, some appeared favorably impressed by Mr. Akers's aggressive performance.
A number said that they saw meaningful long-term changes at the company and gave Mr. Akers credit for making hard decisions and implementing the corporate restructuring.
"It was a good meeting," said Jay P. Stevens, an analyst at Dean Witter Reynolds. "This is the first time we've ever seen the C.F.O. stand up there and present real business models."
Frank Metz, the company's chief financial officer, said that I.B.M. expected the computer industry's revenues to grow 7 percent to 10 percent next year and that he believed I.B.M. would increase its revenues by 7 percent to 8 percent. He said, however, he had based the company's business model for next year on a growth rate of 6 percent.
 
Roster of Executives
 Yesterday, in rapid-fire order, analysts heard from Mr. Akers; C. Michael Armstrong, senior vice president in charge of world trade; Terry R. Lautenbach, who is responsible for the company's American business; Jack D. Kuehler, the company's president, who is in charge of I.B.M.'s personal systems and technology businesses, and Mr. Metz. They all outlined the problems the company faced and its new plan to gain ground in an increasingly competitive computer industry.
Then the company's top officers spent an hour answering questions from analysts, trying to show that I.B.M.'s management was grappling effectively with the striking changes that have forced it to rethink its fundamental approach.
Mr. Akers said that if earnings growth did not return by the middle of next year, the company would take a hard look at a new round of cost-cutting.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
A Forecast for '91 Spending Is Revised to Show a Decline

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
Advertising spending in the United States will decline this year for the first time in 30 years, a leading industry forecaster said yesterday, calling it the largest drop in that closely watched barometer of economic activity since World War II.
For the year, spending will total $126.7 billion, Robert Coen, senior vice president and director of forecasting for McCann-Erickson U.S.A., said at the opening session of the 19th annual Paine Webber Conference on the Outlook for the Media. That would be a 1.5 percent decline from the $128.6 billion spent last year, and it marks the second time that Mr. Coen has slashed his 1991 estimate. Last December, his forecast stood at $136 billion, up 4.6 percent; in June, he trimmed it to $132.6 billion, up 3.1 percent. 
 "It was a disastrous year," Mr. Coen said, speaking of 1991 in the past tense, as if that would hasten its departure. He attributed the decline to "the fact that the Persion Gulf war hit early in 1991, when companies had realized they really were in a recession."
Following Mr. Coen's semiannual forecast at the conference, which continues this week at the McGraw-Hill Building in midtown Manhattan, came more deeply pessimistic predictions from John Perriss, chairman and chief executive of the Zenith Media Worldwide subsidiary of Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C. He estimated that domestic ad spending would fall 2.9 percent this year, then rise by only modest amounts through 1994.
Not since 1961, when ad spending fell eight-tenths of 1 percent, have American advertisers spent less to pitch their products than they did the previous year. Larger declines occurred in the early 1940's, when wartime shortages of consumer goods, coupled with a scarcity of paper for newspapers and magazines, resulted in sustained spending reductions in both local and national advertising. For instance, in 1942, ad spending plunged 4 percent from 1941.
Mr. Coen's forecast, coupled with a cut in his estimate for 1992 spending, comes amid mounting evidence, from layoffs to losses, that the advertising business is nowhere near emerging from the slump that began two years ago.
Local advertising has continued to be the laggard in spending this year, Mr. Coen said, adding that among media carrying such advertising, newspapers have fared most poorly, because of shortfalls in classified and retail advertising. These categories will be down 6 percent this year, he continued, to $26.7 billion, compared with declines of 1 percent for local television and 3.5 percent for local radio.
Mr. Coen's forecast for '92 now calls for total ad spending of $134.6 billion, up 6.2 percent from '91. That assumes a 3.5 percent rise in inflation and real economic growth of 2.4 percent. In June, he had estimated a more robust gain of 8.5 percent, to $144 billion.
A sharp rebound is likely, Mr. Coen said, because of an expected economic recovery as well as the quadrennial spending gains brought by the Winter and Summer Olympic Games and a Presidential election.
Mr. Coen, perhaps the country's most widely followed forecaster of ad spending, has been tracking those trends since 1948. Other forecasters, however, are less optimistic for '92, primarily because they expect advertisers participating in Olympics marketing programs to use already-budgeted money, rather than to raise total ad outlays.
One is Mr. Perriss of Zenith, who forecast growth in '92 of eight-tenths of 1 percent, including inflation.
"My message is really a pretty bearish message," he said. "While 'doom and gloom' is too strong, I do not see '92 as anything like a bounce-back year."
A second gloomier forecast comes in a survey to be released today by Myers Marketing and Research, a consulting firm in Parsippany, N.J. It calls for an ad-spending gain next year of 4 percent to 6 percent before inflation, or an increase of zero to 2 percent, accounting for inflation.
For spending outside the United States, Mr. Coen continued to paint a rosier picture. This year, he said, total ad spending overseas should total $152.6 billion, up 5.5 percent from 1990, though that figure, too, was reduced from an earlier estimate of a 6.1 percent gain.
For '92, his overseas estimate was $161.5 billion, or up 5.8 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Dollar Is Mostly Higher; Gold Prices Narrowly Mixed

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar settled mostly higher in extremely quiet trading on world currency markets yesterday.
Gold prices were narrowly mixed. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $369.30 an ounce, off 10 cents from Friday. The Republic National Bank said gold slid 5 cents an ounce, to a late bid price of $368.70. 
 Analysts said the dollar failed to get much help from unsettling developments in the Soviet Union, where three Slavic republics have proclaimed the creation of a new commonwealth of independent states.
The dollar is typically considered a haven in times of world turmoil. But in this case "there seems to be eternal optimism that the situation in the Soviet Union is going to work itself out," said Mike Malpede, an analyst with Refco Group Ltd. in Chicago.
 
Effect of European Meeting
 John McCarthy, chief dealer at ABN-AMRO Bank International in New York, said the landmark summit meeting of the European Community in Maastricht, the Netherlands, was keeping the dollar in check. Western Europe's leaders are seeking to resolve remaining disputes over monetary union, among other political issues, ahead of the creation of a single market in 1992, and traders are waiting for any comments that could influence currency trading.
Many market participants said a chronically stagnant United States economy would force the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates again before the end of the year. That prospect is also dampening enthusiasm for the dollar. Lower interest rates make dollar-denominated securities less valuable to investors.
Activity was particularly quiet. "Holiday trading has set in," Mr. McCarthy said.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell 0.52 yen, to 128.18 yen. Later, in London it was quoted higher, at 128.40 yen. In New York the dollar settled at 128.27 yen, up from 127.95 yen on Friday.
In London the British pound fell to $1.8067, from $1.8095 late Friday. In New York it cost $1.8128 to buy 1, less expensive than Friday's $1.8167.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's rates, included: 1.5705 German marks, up from 1.5675; 1.3875 Swiss francs, up from 1.3845; 5.3680 French francs, up from 5.3590; 1,188.00 Italian lire, up from 1,187.00, and 1.1358 Canadian dollars, down from 1,1364.
Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $370.75 an ounce, from $367.90 bid late Friday. In Zurich, it rose to $370.60, from $367.75. Earlier, in Hong Kong gold was unchanged, closing at $368.18.
Silver prices slid. On the Comex, silver bullion settled at $4.011 an ounce, down from $4.020 on Friday. In London it slipped to $4.06 an ounce, from $4.07.

HEADLINE: Business and Health;
A Plan to Cover Early Retirees

BYLINE: By Milt Freudenheim

 BODY:
LARGE companies that promise extensive medical benefits to future retirees could save enormous amounts if the Medicare eligibility age dropped to 60 from 65. But the change, which was proposed by Representative Dan Rostenkowski, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, is strongly opposed by small businesses, which typically do not provide extensive retiree health benefits.
Mr. Rostenkowski, Democrat of Illinois, whose bill would be paid for by raising the Medicare payroll tax paid by employers and employees, has said that Congress is unlikely to enact sweeping changes in health policy until after next year's elections. But debate on the measure could become part of the broader issue of a national health insurance system. 
 Representative Pete Stark, the California Democrat who heads the Ways and Means subcommittee on health, said comprehensive national health insurance would cost about $70 billion a year, about 10 percent of national spending on health care. The Rostenkowski proposal would cost about $25 billion. Mr. Stark said the Medicare eligibility plan was not intended to be a back-door approach to national health insurance but was aimed at the many uninsured retirees under age 65.
"This is not a proposal to creep up on folks and expand Medicare," Representative Stark said. "This is to cover those early retirees."
The General Accounting Office estimates that the total liaibility of all private employers for retiree health care was $335 billion this year. The G.A.O. testifed last month that the amount would have dropped to $99 billion if the age-60 rule had been in effect.
Concern about the issue is growing because all private companies are required to evaluate and report their promises for retiree medical benefits under a new accounting rule that takes effect in 1993. Companies with older workers and generous health plans, like American Telephone and Telegraph, General Motors and I.B.M., have already announced liabilities in the billions of dollars.
Not surprisingly, executives at several large companies said they supported the age-60 concept.
"The Rostenkowski bill would reduce our post-retirement medical liability by about 25 percent, to $450 million from $650 million," said Dr. Jacques Sokolov, vice president and medical director at the Southern California Edison Company.
Walter B. Maher, the Chrysler Corporation's health-care spokesman in Washington, said that the proposal "is certainly a step in the right direction."
Labor unions also support the bill, which would increase the financial security of nine million people who rely on retiree health insurance. Meredith Miller, assistant director for employee benefits with the A.F.L.-C.I.O., said that because of medical cost inflation, many employers were asking retirees to pay for a larger portion of their coverage. And some unions have accepted limits on retiree health benefits as a trade-off for other improvements, like wage increases. "Our immediate concern is to try to bring some relief to this area as soon as possible," Ms. Miller said.
Most industrial workers retire in their early 60's, some when employers cut payrolls or close factories. But Mr. Maher and others noted that lowering the Medicaid age would probably encourage workers to retire early voluntarily. This is one reason the National Association of Manufacturers opposes lowering Medicare eligibility, said Sharon Canner, an assistant vice president at the association. She added, "Since there are fewer new entrants in the work force, we want to encourage people to work longer."
G. Lawrence Atkins, director of employer benefits policy at Winthrop, Stimson, Putnam & Roberts, a Washington law firm, said the Rostenkowski bill would reduce the obligations of one of his clients by 30 percent. But he said that transferring costs from companies with large retiree health-care obligations to those with lesser obligations was a form of Government "industrial policy" that could be unpopular.
Just how unpopular was made clear by John J. Motley, chief lobbyist in Washington for the National Federation of Independent Business. He said that small businesses paid three-quarters of their taxes in payroll taxes, which have "no relation to the profitability of the firm." Raising the payroll tax is "a prescription for disaster in terms of jobs," he said.
"This bill creates winners and losers," said Neela Ranade, vice president for welfare benefits counseling at Actuarial Sciences Associates, a unit of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. She suggested that the Rostenkowski proposal might attract wider support if employers had to pay "a flat dollar amount based on the numbers of active and retired employees, plus a percentage of payroll" so the burden would be heavier at large companies with many retirees.

HEADLINE: Broadway Prices Going Up And Down

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS

 BODY:
The price of orchestra seats at "Miss Saigon" and "The Phantom of the Opera" will rise to $65 from $60 starting March 9, the producer Cameron Mackintosh announced yesterday. On that date the $100 top-price ticket for "Miss Saigon" will be dropped and a new $15 ticket-price scale will be initiated for "Miss Saigon" and his other musicals, "Phantom," "Les Miserables" and "Five Guys Named Moe," which is to open on Broadway in April.
The top orchestra price at "Miss Saigon" and "Phantom" will be raised "to make available the new low-price seats," said Alan Wasser, Mr. Mackintosh's general manager in the United States. Mr. Mackintosh was on vacation and could not be reached for comment. 
 The new price for the $100 front-mezzanine seats at "Miss Saigon" will also be $65, "to be more in keeping with the mood of the country," Mr. Wasser said. He added, "We also have a sense that people were thinking that all orchestra seats to 'Miss Saigon' were $100."
Referring to the $15 tickets, Mr. Wasser said: "The economy is absolutely a factor in this. People are hurting because of it, and we see some indication that it's affecting our advance sales. We wanted to do something to get people in who haven't been able to afford the shows."
If advance sales in lower price ranges are weakening, there is no sign of it now. According to weekly Variety, attendance is 100 percent at "Miss Saigon," 101.7 percent at "Phantom" (including standing room), and 94.4 percent at "Les Miserables," now in its fifth year. "Miss Saigon," which opened last spring, will recoup its $10 million investment in January.
"Middle-price tickets are the hardest to sell," Mr. Wasser said, "and in watching our advance sales, we've noticed a falling-off of attendance in our lower-price tickets." Mr. Mackintosh introduced at $15-ticket policy at the Los Angeles production of "Phantom" five months ago, "and our advance increased $800,000," Mr. Wasser said.
 
Rear-Mezzanine Bargains
 The lowest regular-price seats at "Miss Saigon" have been $30. In March, 197 of the 1,761 seats at the Broadway Theater, where the show is playing, will be available at $15 for the rear mezzanine. The lowest prices at "Phantom" have been $35; in March, 82 seats will be available for $15. The price of about 200 obstructed-view seats in the orchestra at "Phantom" will not be affected; they cost $50 and $37.50.
The top price for "Les Miserables" will remain at $60; the lowest price has been $30, and in March, 88 seats will be available for $15. Tickets for "Five Guys Named Moe" will be $15 to $55.
Mr. Wasser said that the Mackintosh musicals had never been sold at the half-price TKTS booths run by the Theater Development Fund, but that there had been half-price student discounts for some seats and reduced-rate coupons offering discounts of one-third.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
State of Game? Not the Same Everywhere

BYLINE: By CLAIRE SMITH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Dec. 9

 BODY:
As the rhetoric between small markets and large markets in major league baseball continues to heat up, Commissioner Fay Vincent added his own chilling message today by echoing the fears of teams outside of New York, Chicago and California and citing the potential for a drastic falloff in national television revenues after contracts with CBS and ESPN expire following the 1993 season.
"The present salary situation is out of hand and small-market franchises cannot compete in this environment," Vincent said here today during his state-of-the-game address at the annual winter meetings. 
 He noted that local cable television and radio deals allow the most prosperous club to generate revenues in excess of $100 million per year, while the club with the smallest annual revenue brings in less than $40 million a year.
"And yet small-market franchises must compete on the field and in the player-compensation arena with the larger market teams," he said. "Small-market clubs simply have no choice but to arrange their payrolls on an entirely different scale."
 
An Unhappy Prospect
 Vincent, concerned not only about the size of player contracts, but also their lengths, talked as well of the potential danger of committing to pacts that run beyond the 1993 expiration of the national television contracts.
"If the deal were to be made today, during the worst media advertising recession in recent history," he said, "we would be looking at the unhappy prospect of accepting at least $4 to $5 million less per club per year than in the present contract."
Executives from small-market teams concurred with Vincent.
"I never in my wildest dreams expected this last escalation," said the Minnesota Twins' general manager, Andy MacPhail. "I didn't think the envelope would be pushed any further. When we negotiated Kirby Puckett's contract in 1988, the highest contract was $3 million. Now we've almost doubled that and we're only in December 1991. It's making it unmanageable for us, no matter how good our farm system is or how much bottom fishing we do in the Rule 5 draft."
He was referring to the draft by big league clubs of players from the minors.
 
'Don't Have Resources'
 MacPhail said that this was not necessarily a criticism of large-market clubs, because recent signings like the $29 million, five-year deal signed with the Mets by Bobby Bonilla do not test the bottom lines in bigger cities. "But we just don't have the resources," MacPhail said. "That's just a fact of life."
As if to prove his point, MacPhail said the Twins, once very hopeful of re-signing free-agent pitcher Jack Morris, have all but shut down negotiations with him because of the current market.
"We were close and tried to get it done before the market established itself," MacPhail said. "Then Bonilla, Morgan, Candiotti and Hershiser signed and the market moved. But our bottom line didn't change."
Fred Claire, general manager of the Dodgers, on the defensive after signing Candiotti, a free agent, for four years at $15.5 million, argued that, despite the angst, small-market clubs cannot deny their successes. "The Twins are the world champions," he said. "The Pirates won their division two years in a row. Money has never equaled winning. You can't buy a pennant. I think the basis of the game still comes back to the basics: scouting, growing your own."
Those are principles that the Dodgers are dedicated to, Claire insisted, but he also pointed out that sometimes things happen. As an example, he said, the Dodgers could not re-sign pitcher Mike Morgan because they did not want to commit to more than three years and Morgan insisted on a four-year deal after Milwaukee lured back the free-agent pitcher Bill Wegman with a four-year, $9.5 million deal.
"It's not a case of finger-pointing, but Mike Morgan goes off because Bill Wegman signs a four-year contract, in a small market," Claire said. "I don't fault Milwaukee for that. But does it have an impact? Yes. Those are just the truths. So if the small markets look at the big markets and say, 'You are the villains,' well, I guess, everyone's entitled to their view, but I don't think it's fair."
Vincent, while citing the potential for much smaller national television contracts after 1993, did say he believed the current baseball networks were not doing as poorly on their deals as indicated by network officials. (CBS has estimated it will lose $282 million before taxes by the time its four-year, $1.08 billion contract expires. ESPN is also claiming substantial losses on the four-year, $400 million deal, which also started in 1990.)
"The CBS affiliates were in disarray and I believe the CBS executives made a sound, innovative and strategic judgment to hold the network together and to keep the affiliates in place by cornering the sports market," Vincent said. "CBS bought time and patience from its affiliates by making the baseball deal."
As for the cable affiliate, Vincent said: "Where would ESPN be without baseball? There are only so many tractor pulls and billiard matches you can televise."
 
INSIDE PITCH
 The Yankees lost left-handed pitcher RAFAEL QUIRICO from their Columbus roster in the draft of minor leaguers. He was taken by the Giants. Quirico, 22 years old, was 12-8 with a 2.26 earned run average for New York's Class A Greensboro club.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Bowl Game To Top All Bowls

BYLINE: By IRA BERKOW

 BODY:
JOE PATERNO was saying that, sure, as a coach and a competitor he would like to see a national championship game between the two top college football teams in the nation. Such an event has been in the news recently since the Home Shopping Network has offered the National Collegiate Athletic Association the not inconsiderable holiday package of $33 million for a proposed Jan. 18 game in Tampa Stadium, with the money being distributed among the 106 Division 1-A schools.
Paterno grew up in Flatbush in the 1930's, and remembers the games between 26th Street and Avenue R, when it was first down and two sewers to go, and you wanted to see who was best in the neighborhood then, too. In those days the two biggest obstacles, he recalled, "were cars driving down the street and the people calling the cops because we were too noisy." 
 He moved on to Marine Park, where he and his friends didn't have much equipment. "We put towels in our knickers and sweaters and woolen hats for padding," he said. "Sometimes we'd use leaves for padding, too. But leaves can be itchy."
The rest is history: Paterno played quarterback at Brown University and then became head coach at Penn State. He is in town for the National Football Foundation and College Hall of Fame dinner tonight at the Waldorf-Astoria, and will be honored with that organization's Distinguished American award.
"I remember three years when we were undefeated and won bowl games, and didn't get ranked No. 1 in the polls," he said. "That was in 1968, 1969 and 1973. We were beaten out by Ohio State, Texas and Notre Dame. And it was hard for my kids. I wish they'd had a chance to prove they were the best."
It may be a similar case this year, with Washington and Miami, the two top-ranked and lone major-college undefeated teams in the nation. Washington will play Michigan in the Rose Bowl and Miami meets Nebraska in the Orange Bowl.
While there are national championship games, and a playoff structure, in most college sports, including the most wildly popular, the wildly propagandized March Madness wackiness, and there is also a playoff in Division I-AA football, there is and never has been anything like it in Division 1-A, the top level of competition.
The reason is, the bowl games. Many schools believe that they would lose money if they left the bowl bounty. Right now, for example, the Big 10 and the Pac-10 split $10 million from their traditional Rose Bowl game.
There are a number of people in academia and out who deplore the commercialism of college football and believe that it has gone too far. One of them is Ed Marinaro, the actor, who is being inducted into the Hall of Fame tonight, having been a star running back at Cornell, coming in second in the Heisman Trophy award in 1971. "It's enough," said Marinaro about the college football scene. "I mean, how far away from the classroom are they going to get? What's next? All-year-round football?"
Paterno and Marinaro agree that what might be even more destructive for classroom participation than the long college season is the freshman eligible rule. "I was on the freshman team at Cornell and it was great for me to get adjusted to a new way of life," said Marinaro. Paterno said: "I heard the Ivy League is planning to make freshman eligible, too. If that happens, it's all over. They're the last bastion."
Such bastions in college sports have been toppling like mad. Once there were four bowl games at the end of the season, for example; now there are dozens. And it isn't just television that is to blame. It is the colleges, because the money is just too good to resist.
It is true that many schools, like many households, are in an economic crunch, and it is true that many schools believe that sports are the geese that can lay golden eggs for them. But in many instances much of the sports earnings go back into the sports programs, and little filters into the libraries and chemistry labs.
But there is no stopping college sports now. And it is not just for the sake of competition, which is Paterno's stated concern, but for the lovely lucre that is envisioned at the end of this gridiron rainbow.
Yet somehow one clings to a bizarre dream that one day a brace of college presidents will rise up and shout: "No more! We are the models for the youth we teach, and we will demonstrate to them that money isn't everything. Priorities are all!"
Then we wake. Rest assured that that championship game will be played, if not this year, then next year. Or the year after. And with all the bowl games intact, too.
Let the geese begin.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Coach Joe Paterno (R & R Sports Group)

SECTION: Section A; Page 30; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 516 words

HEADLINE: Out of the Soviet Wreckage

 BODY:
Recognizing that further disintegration can lead to common suffering, the leaders of Russia, Ukraine and Byelorussia have wisely banded together to form a new commonwealth. Americans can only hope that by doing so, the three Slavic republics of the former Soviet Union can stave off ethnic and border strife, prevent beggar-thy-neighbor economic nationalism and keep control of nuclear arms.
Mikhail Gorbachev had hoped to hold all 15 republics together in a renewed confederation, a result that the West once fervently rooted for. But Ukraine's overwhelming vote for independence last week dashed that fading hope. The task now is to build a new association of republics from the bottom up. 
 The Commonwealth of Independent States, vague though its initial formulation may be, provides welcome evidence that the three Slavic republics recognize they can't go their separate ways. But the commonwealth will last only if detailed agreements are promptly reached, and carried out, to reverse the dangerous downward economic slide and to control the armed forces.
The leaders of the three Slavic states still have many obstacles to overcome if their common struggle against chaos is to succeed.
One is the upsurge of narrow nationalism unleashed by democratization. The commonwealth's leaders have themselves played to the flag-wavers at times, which has impeded their ability to come together. Boris Yeltsin's assertiveness after he became President of Russia, for instance, intensified separatism in Ukraine. And that raised the risk of conflict between Ukrainians and Russians that could tear apart the new commonwealth -- and Ukraine along with it.
Another obstacle is a restive military. The three republics have now pledged to "insure unified control over nuclear weapons and their nonproliferation," but they didn't say how. Nor did they say how they would cut, yet control, the armed forces on their territory.
A third obstacle is the exclusion of non-Slavs from commonwealth deliberations. Although the agreement remains open to all member states of the former U.S.S.R., the belated invitation may not appeal to those initially left out.
The exclusion of Kazakhstan, with a population 40 percent Slavic, is particularly worrisome. It, along with the three commonwealth members, has long-range nuclear-tipped missiles based on its territory.
The immediate obstacle to success is economic. That the three republics have agreed not to erect trade barriers against each other is essential. But are the republics prepared to enforce contracts negotiated with businesses in another republic?
Similarly, the joint pledge of price decontrol is well intentioned. But if Russia proceeds with the price decontrol planned for next week, it will take coordinated steps to insure that desperately needed food and goods are not sucked out of Ukraine to take advantage of the suddenly higher prices in Russia.
Unless Russia, Ukraine and Byelorussia can harness nationalism to the task of opening up their economies, the new commonwealth may soon go the way of the old union.

HEADLINE: Peru's Rebels Driving Church Underground

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru

 BODY:
On a nameless street in a shantytown here, a tiny kitchen had a cozy, snug feeling, and little touches of Americana -- a Betty Crocker cookbook in the bookcase and a yellowing photograph of the occupant's parents when they ran a New York delicatessen.
But as the white-haired American priest rested in his easy chair, conversation in the kitchen revolved around topics that were far from settling: alarm whistles, escape ladders, canceled Masses, closed-door weddings, death threats, and priests executed after "people's trials." 
 "We are halfway to the Church of the Catacombs," said the 63-year-old priest, one of 438 American Roman Catholic missionaries in Peru, the largest concentration outside the United States.
The persecution of the Christians of modern-day Peru does not come from the Government, as it did in ancient Rome, but from the Shining Path, a brutal and fanatical movement that feeds on the nation's numbing poverty.
Ninety percent of Peruvians profess to be Catholics, but church leaders long believed Shining Path's leaders when they boasted that the Catholic Church would be "the revolution's dessert" -- a final dish to be consumed after the annihilation of Peru's political, military and economic authorities.
But the terrorists, increasingly confident, are skipping courses. And in a nation where foreigners account for two-thirds of the 6,200 priests and nuns, foreigners are taking the brunt of the attacks on the church. Since May, Shining Path has killed two Polish priests, an Australian nun and an Italian priest and has severely wounded a Spanish priest.
"In this crucial stage of the struggle, the clergy is using the religiosity of the people to confront the Maoist guerrilla war," Luis Arce Borja, the Shining Path's European spokesman, said in an interview with El Expreso, a Lima newspaper, in November. "All great revolutions have had to confront the most rightist clergy. And that is what is happening now."
The Shining Path opposes church social activities like schools, soup kitchens and work programs because they deaden the people's revolutionary ardor.
American churchworkers agreed to be interviewed on the condition that they not be photographed or identified by name. "Sendero is in New York, and under no circumstances can you use my name," warned the priest from New York, using the group's Spanish name. "This could be brought back here. If they decide to have a people's trial, that's the end."
The Brooklyn-born priest said he had seen the Shining Path's influence expand in his own neighborhood this year. "Sendero Luminoso is infiltrating everything -- parish organizations, confirmation classes, the Faith and Happiness schools," he said. Near his house, a church wall was marked with Sendero's telltale red paint: "Yankees out of Peru." An American nun said that two times daily, a Sendero scout sits on a hill above her church-run Faith and Happiness school, "monitoring the comings and goings."
To minimize risks to individual leaders, church groups increasingly are run by semi-secret councils, rather than by high-profile presidents. Parish programs are now called "community programs."
"We had a chapel dedication the other day, and we didn't mention who helped in the construction," the priest said. "We no longer advertise confirmation programs. It's only by word of mouth."
For personal protection, the American said he has adopted a deliberately erratic way of life.
"I never tell people in advance if I will turn up at Mass or at a parish meeting," the priest said. "My neighbors will never tell a stranger where I live.
"If strange people show up at Mass," he added, "I always develop stomach cramps and leave immediately.
"The people are suffering, they are hungry," he continued. "The people feel the Government has abandoned them. The people are saying, 'What is the alternative?' That's the scary thing."

HEADLINE: SOVIET DISARRAY;
Text of Gorbachev's Statement on a New Commonwealth

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Dec. 9

 BODY:
Following is the text of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's statement issued here today and provided by Tass, the Soviet news agency:
On Dec. 8, 1991, the leaders of Byelorussia, the Russian Federation and Ukraine signed in Minsk an agreement to found a commonwealth of independent states. 
 As the country's President, the main yardstick with which to evaluate this document is the measure to which it satisfies the interests of security of its citizens, meets the tasks of overcoming the present crisis and the preservation of statehood and furtherance of democratic reforms.
This agreement has its positive moments.
The Ukrainian leadership, which previously showed no activity in the negotiating process, has joined it.
The document stresses the need to create a single economic space, operating on coordinated principles with a single currency and finance and banking system. It expresses readiness for cooperation in the fields of science, education, culture and other spheres. It suggests a definite formula of interaction in the military-strategic field.
But this is a document of special significance. It touches very deeply on the interests of the peoples of our country, of the entire world community, and hence calls for a comprehensive political and legal evaluation.
 
Illegal and Dangerous
 In any case, it is clear to me that the agreement directly proclaims the end of the U.S.S.R. Undoubtedly, each republic has the right to withdraw from the Soviet Union, but the fate of our multinational country cannot be decided by the will of three republican leaders. This question can only be resolved through constitutional means with the participation of all sovereign states and taking into account the will of their peoples.
Illegal and dangerous is the assertion about the termination of all-union legal norms, which can only boost chaos and anarchy in society.
The speed with which the document appeared is baffling. It was not discussed either by the citizens or the Parliaments of the republics on behalf of which it was signed.
Even more significantly, it happened at a time when the republics' Parliaments are discussing the draft treaty of the union of sovereign states, drafted by the U.S.S.R. State Council.
I am deeply confident that in the present situation it is necessary for all Supreme Soviets of republics and the Supreme Soviet of the U.S.S.R. to discuss the draft treaty of the union of sovereign states and the agreement signed in Minsk. As the agreement puts forward a formula of statehood, which is in the competence of the Congress of Soviet People's Deputies, it is necessary to convene the Congress. Besides, I do not rule out holding a nationwide referendum on this question.

HEADLINE: SOVIET DISARRAY;
SOVIET ATOM ARMS WORRY EUROPEANS

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MAASTRICHT, the Netherlands, Dec. 9

 BODY:
Since it has been clear for several months that the "mighty, indivisible, indestructible" Soviet Union was a thing of the past, its formal unraveling has not come as an unsettling surprise to Western European leaders trying to decide here today how to knit their own countries more closely together.
The Soviet Union began falling to pieces immediately after President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia and other leaders of constituent Soviet republics faced down the hard-line coup against President Mikhail S. Gorbachev it August. Though the coup failed, it weakened Mr. Gorbachev, and most West European leaders now apparently believe that his power cannot be restored. 
 "I think the Soviet Union has been coming apart for a long time, hasn't it?" the British Foreign Secretary, Douglas Hurd, said today. He added that the agreement announced in Brest on Sunday to form a new commonwealth of the three Slavic republics with its capital in Minsk may have been the final blow. "I think it will be some time before we see the new pattern at all clearly," Mr. Hurd said.
Though neither the heads of government nor their foreign ministers spent much time today discussing events in the Soviet Union -- the foreign ministers discussed it over dinner, according to their spokesmen -- they are not without concern about them. They worry, as they have since last August, about who will insure the control and safety of the Soviet nuclear and conventional arsenal that belonged to Moscow.
 
Doubts About Assurances
 And they cannot yet be sure how seriously to take the assurances of Mr. Yeltsin and the leaders of Kazakhstan, Ukraine and Byelorussia that the nuclear weapons in their territories will remain under strict, joint control.
The British Prime Minister, John Major, described the nuclear question as "critical" today, but another official said: "Reassuring noises are coming out of the Soviet Union. I wouldn't say this is something where there's an urgent concern, but it's something we want to keep on top of."
Mr. Major also said he and others here would be concerned about human rights and the question of who would take responsibility for Soviet debt.
But a larger question, one overshadowed here today by the problems of how and when to agree on a single European currency and strengthen political cooperation among the 12 European Community member states that their leaders were discussing, is what they can do to channel change in the East into constructive channels.
 
Impotent in Yugoslav War
 Though they are talking about European political union, the community leaders have not yet been able to agree even on any meaningful way of stopping Yugoslavia's long decline into civil war right on their doorsteps, and they do not want to see the Soviet Union become "Yugoslavia with nukes," as the American Secretary of State, James A. Baker 3d, put it in a television interview over the weekend.
A Danish Foreign Ministry official said there was some concern among the leaders here about "total dissolution," and a British official said Mr. Major would send a representative to Kiev, Minsk and Moscow later this week to size up, among other things, what the Soviet Army planned to do about the latest developments. "Who pays them, and and is there a body that finances them?" this official asked.
Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany would like to see the community put together a logistical task force this weekend, putting soldiers, railway workers and other experts in civilian clothes to rush supplies of milk, sugar and other food supplies to cities like Moscow and Leningrad before shortages become so critical that they create social unrest, according to German officials.
But the European Community, long a bulwark against the threat of Soviet Communism, was not designed as protection against its collapse. The foreign ministers will not meet formally to discuss the subject until next Monday in Brussels, according to officials.
One thing they must not do, some of the Europeans feel, is build up such a tightly federated political and economic structure that Eastern European countries, and possibly Ukraine and even Russia one day, will have no hope of ever becoming a part of what Mr. Gorbachev used to like to call the "common European home."
 
Requests for Membership
 But asked today how the community would deal with a request from Ukraine to join its ranks as a full member, one European official pointed out that Austria had already applied, that the Scandinavian countries probably would soon, and that their applications would be dealt with first. Eastern European countries get only a limited association status and lots of advice.
A $325 million European Community package of grants to help the Soviet Union avoid economic ruin was delivered to Moscow earlier this year. Now that it appears that the country no longer exists, community officials will probably have to decide where to direct a $520 million line of credit and $1.56 billion in credits for food and humanitarian aid that they were still trying to negotiate with Moscow today. A spokesman for the community's Executive Commission in Brussels said the foreign ministers would probably channel these more through the republics.

HEADLINE: U.N. Passes Voluntary Register to Curb Arms Sales

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Dec. 9

 BODY:
At a time when the international arms trade may be starting to grow again after a sharp decline, the United Nations General Assembly voted overwhelmingly today to establish the first register of international arms sales.
The aim of the register, which won strong support in the wake of the Persian Gulf war, is to curb the international traffic in arms by publicizing transactions and identifying potential trouble spots by showing where arm stocks are increasing. 
 Although the resolution calls on all nations to provide the world organization with an annual list of all imports and exports of arms, it does not require them to do so. Nonetheless, diplomats say most countries are likely to comply with the register because of the overwhelming support it has received and particularly because of its support from Britain, the United States, France and the Soviet Union, which together account for about 70 percent of the international arms trade.
The register will initially apply only to sales of heavy arms, like tanks, armored fighting vehicles, artillery pieces, combat aircraft and attack helicopters, that can be used to seize and hold territory.
China, a major arms producer, refused to take part in today's vote, even though it participated in talks with the other four permanent members of the Security Council in Paris last summer on curbing arms sales to the Middle East. China offered no explanation for its stand. But some diplomats said the Chinese action might reflect the importance that arms sales has acquired for China as a source of foreign currency as well as resentment at the pressure to go along with the register from the United States and other Western supporters.
In today's vote, 150 countries approved the resolution establishing the register and procedures for gradually expanding its scope to cover not only heavy arms shipments but also lighter weapons, arms production and national weapon stocks. While no nation voted against, Cuba and Iraq abstained.
During the debate in committee, many developing countries complained that the register would discriminate against poorer nations, which import their arms, by requiring them to disclose their purchases while protecting richer nations with indigenous arms industries against revealing their military strength.
As a result, the resolution calls on the Secretary General to set up an expert group to report next year on ways of extending the register to include lighter arms as well as production sites and national weapon stocks. This could transform the register from a list of arms sales into one for conventional arms that includes transfers.
Purchases by developing countries account for about 75 to 80 percent of the international arms trade, which peaked at $57 billion in 1987 before declining, according to the latest report of the United States Arms Control and Disarmament Agency.
The United States earned $14 billion from selling arms overseas in 1988, the last year for which Government figures are available, accounting for 29 percent of the world market. According to the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, world arms exports fell 13 percent from $57 billion in 1987 to $49 billion in 1988, the lowest level in 10 years. But in average terms, the agency says, sales have been declining 3 percent a year since 1983.
"For the first time in history, perhaps, the favorable prospects for controlling the transfer of conventional weapons appear to outweigh the negative," Prof. Stephanie Neuman, an arms control expert at Columbia University, said in a paper for the American Association for the Advancement of Science. Professor Neuman attributes the downward trend to the increasing sophistication of weapons, deteriorating economic conditions and "the new political order."
But at a recent meeting of arms control scholars at Wisconsin University, Michael Klare of Hampshire College said Iraq's defeat in the gulf war might encourage developing countries to shift from their preference for large tank and infantry formations to a greater emphasis on aircraft, helicopters and precision-guided munitions.
