HEADLINE: Spurning Fine-Tuning;
Any Fixes Washington Might Do to Help Could Just as Well Harm, Economists Say

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
Republicans and Democrats alike are hard at work seeking ways to pump up the American economy and let the good times roll again.
That is what prominent economists used to think Government was all about. But now the economics establishment has generally lost confidence in the ability of the Government to fine-tune the economy, afraid that anything that Washington might do would be as likely to harm as help. 
 Heeding his political advisers, President Bush is nevertheless hard at work formulating an anti-recession tonic, something more effective than buying socks at the mall.
And judging from Administration testimony before Congress, the medicine is likely to blend in a little something for everyone who is feeling the pain.
Democrats and Republicans in Congress appear eager to use the occasion to mix investment incentives for dispirited businesses with some combination of savings and payroll tax breaks for the middle class. Everything from a capital-gains tax reduction to expanded retirement accounts to accelerated public works spending has its champions.
But where did these ideas come from? Why is it assumed that government can cure what ails the American economy?
It's no secret that many of the President's economists, along with much of the economics establishment, fear that economic stimulus of any kind is as likely to harm as help.
In part, the misgivings are based on the conviction that allowing Washington to renegotiate last year's deficit reduction deal is akin to inviting Imelda Marcos to window shop at Gucci. But it also reflects fundamental intellectual doubts about the value of fiscal measures in fighting economic downturns, as well as the more specific worry that any pre-election fix would undermine long-term efforts to increase savings and growth.
As recently as the early 1970's most economists thought they knew how to take the sting out of recessions. A decline in the inclination of businesses and consumers to spend, they said, could leave a gap between the total demand for goods and the economy's capacity to provide them. And while the gap would eventually close without government intervention, eventually could be a very long time indeed. What was needed to offset swings in private demand, they argued, was some combination of tax cuts and government spending, plus an increase in funds available for bank loans.
 
Keynes Followers Unfazed by Deficits
 The size, timing and the proper mix of fiscal and monetary stimulus have always been a matter of fierce debate. The intellectual heirs to the great British economist John Maynard Keynes emphasized the merits of reducing taxes and increasing government spending; the resulting budget deficits, they argued, would pose no burden to society as long as the extra demand for goods and services could be met from farms and factories that would otherwise be idled.
Followers of Milton Friedman of the University of Chicago much preferred to rely on monetary measures. They were convinced that business cycles could be smoothed away simply by requiring that the Federal Reserve keep the growth in the supply of money on an even keel. But the two camps grudgingly shared an intellectual framework of how the economy worked, as well as an implicit belief that stabilization policies could be perfected.
The last two decades on a roller coaster of recession and growth, however, have shaken public faith in economists' capacities as scientists of stability, and speeded a parallel drift within the profession. Virtually all economists would still use fiscal and monetary tools to offset Depression-magnitude swings in demand. But there is no longer anything approaching a consensus on the virtues of intervention in a crisis of current dimensions, where unemployment remains low by historic benchmarks.
The ranks of orthodox monetarists have declined. But as the non-monetarist Robert Gordon of Northwestern University notes, their core idea -- that steady-at-the-helm works best(if not always very well) -- has been filched, not abandoned. Pragmatists like Robert Hall of the Hoover Institution in California have convinced the Federal Reserve Board to change course infrequently, and to aim at a simple and easily measured target: the rate of growth of total spending in the economy. It is really the Keynesians, with their enormous investment in the concept of fine-tuning with fiscal policy, who have suffered most.
One striking challenge came from "supply-side" economists, most notably Arthur Laffer, who contended that the sheer waste and perverse incentives associated with high tax rates created opportunities to cut tax rates without cutting tax revenues. There was thus no need to think of fiscal policy as a mechanism for fine-tuning: The fiscal spigot could and should be left wide open to spur economic growth.
Supply-side economics did not work as Mr. Laffer and his disciples expected. After the big income tax cut of 1981, the budget deficit ballooned to levels unprecedented in peacetime. But neither did it confirm the Keynesian view that wide-open deficit spending would lead to uncontrolled inflation.
 
Foreign Lenders Stepped In
 Substantially increased government borrowing to finance the deficit did not "crowd out" private borrowers because foreign lenders proved ready and willing to make up the difference. Moreover, collapsing energy prices and sharply increased world competition in manufactures kept inflation to a pleasing minimum. And while few research economists were converted to the supply-siders' cause, stable (if relatively slow) growth of the Reagan years certainly undermined public confidence in the logic of fiscal fine-tuning
The boldest critique of Keynesian theory from within the economics establishment has come from Robert Barro of Harvard. When the Government cuts taxes or increases spending it borrows to cover the extra deficit. Thus in the process of cutting taxes today, Mr. Barro said, the Government is creating a future liability -- the added debt -- that will have to be financed by raising taxes tomorrow. And taxpayers are likely to respond by curtailing current spending, offsetting the direct fiscal stimulus.
Mr. Gordon of Northwestern probably speaks for most policy-oriented economists in dismissing the Barro critique as "aerie fairie" theory, hardly related to how people actually behave. But its sheer ingenuousness has made it the grist of a hundred academic journal articles and a thousand graduate school classes. Mr. Hall of the Hoover Institution argues that the Barro punchline -- that the consequences of fiscal stimulus might be both complicated and unintuitive -- "has shifted the ground" under the Keynesian monolith and made it fair game for more practical-minded critics of fine-tuning.
Gregory Mankiw of Harvard lays out a smorgasbord of these qualms. Once the need for fiscal stimulus is recognized, he notes, it may take months to pass the necessary legislation. Hence the full impact may only hit the economy after the recovery is under way and the stimulus is no longer welcome. Even if the stimulus does hit in timely fashion, public fears that it will ignite inflation may push up interest rates and slow business investment.
That should not be a significant problem if the public is convinced that the spending or tax stimulus is indeed temporary and will evaporate by the time offices and factories are running full tilt. But such convictions do not come easily to a public grown cynical about Washington: "Whenever I hear a politician say 'never again' I don't believe it," Mr. Mankiw, the Harvard economist, said.
 
Drawbacks In Tax Cut
 John Taylor, who just returned to Stanford University from President Bush's Council of Economic Advisers, points out that a credible temporary cut in payroll or income taxes would have its own drawbacks. If the increase in take-home pay is scheduled to last just a year or so, research suggests that just 20 or 30 cents out of every extra dollar will actually be spent; the rest would end up as private savings. And while there is nothing wrong with people saving more, it is no virtue in this context: most of the intended stimulus would be lost, even as the budget deficit rose.
The bang from a buck of direct government spending -- say, highway construction -- is far greater than the punch from a tax cut. But Mr. Mankiw noted that the time it took to put a workable spending plan in place increased the likelihood that the stimulus would come too late.
Some economists who might otherwise take a chance with fine-tuning offer specific objections to a fiscal fix in the current climate. Mr. Taylor, for example, believes that the nation's core economic problem remains slow growth in productivity -- a condition that is worsened, if not caused, by Americans' historically low rate of savings. And he fears that any tampering with the deal to cut the deficit in half by the mid-1990's will dim the prospects for a collective turn toward thrift. "We ought to be thinking about the long term," Mr. Taylor said.
Would it be possible to devise a fiscal package that mollifies the skeptics' most pressing concerns? Two unrepentant Keynesians, the Nobel Prize winner Robert Solow of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Francis Bator of the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, think part of the answer is a one-time increase in Federal aid to states and localities. Much of the money, they believe, would be used to restore spending on public investment projects in progress that have been delayed by the budget pinch.
That need not conflict with long- term growth objectives, Mr. Bator argues, since "we need the increase in public investment." And pressure to extend the program beyond a year should be containable because state and local government revenues will rise with the economic recovery.
Neal Soss, chief economist at the First Boston Corporation, seconds the motion for increased public spending because he doubts there is any easier way to light a fire under private spending. In this third year of the economic slowdown -- output, he notes, has barely budged since 1988 -- "businesses and consumers have become allergic to risk."
Mr. Hall of the Hoover Institution points out that the temporary nature of a tax break can cut either way. While people would probably spend little of a one-time income tax reduction because it would have little effect on their lifetime purchasing power, businesses would likely jump at a one-time chance of a tax credit on new investment they had planned to make next year or the next.
Mr. Hall (who, incidentally, is no fan of fiscal fine-tuning) thinks it would even be possible to devise a stimulus package that does not increase the national debt. One might, for example, pair a 5 percent tax credit for business investment in 1992 with a special 5 percent tax surcharge on business investment in 1993. There would presumably be no revenue loss over the two years. Moreover, the kick in 1992 would be even larger than from a simple one-time tax break because businesses would have a greater incentive to accelerate investments already in the works.
 
Also a Risk In Sitting Tight
 Could even the most carefully crafted stimulus misfire? Might public confidence -- and public spending -- fall in response to a pre-election fix? Might the last best hope for convincing Washington to keep government outlays within sight of revenues be lost? Almost anything is possible, Mr. Bator of the Kennedy School concedes. But "it would be an odd reaction," he said, one out of tune with the "empirical regularities of the past."
He argues, moreover, that there is a parallel risk in sitting tight. If the economy slips deeper into decline, the demand for relief could overwhelm an orderly effort to stabilize the economy without sacrificing long-term productivity goals. A deeper slide might not be likely, Mr. Bator says, "but do you want to take a chance?"
Official Washington plainly does not. And economists who would rather stay the course are rapidly losing their influence.

HEADLINE: Japan Leaders Are in Disarray On Troop Role

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Dec. 10

 BODY:
Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa and his five-week-old Government have been thrown into disarray by a string of embarrassing setbacks that culminated today with the sudden collapse of legislation to let Japan participate in United Nations peacekeeping operations.
Japanese officials said this evening that the peacekeeping bill, which would have authorized the first dispatch of army troops abroad since World War II, was dead. 
 Analysts said the hopes of passing a peacekeeping bill were engulfed by a tide of anxiety among Japanese that the bill would be seen as a first step on the road to rearming. The fears reached a peak in the last week with the observance of the 50th anniversary of the attack on Pearl Harbor.
 
Measure's Future Unclear
 Some officials said the peacekeeping-forces bill may be revived late next year, after parliamentary elections, but no one would predict even that for sure.
The measure's failure doomed Tokyo's hopes of using the occasion of President Bush's visit next month to proclaim its readiness to play a new international role commensurate with Japan's status as an economic superpower.
Even before the latest developments, there has been considerable criticism of Mr. Miyazawa, who has been described as aloof and equivocal in handling a range of problems. His popularity has plummeted only a month after he took office.
"It is not clear where the command post is," one commentator said this week in The Japan Economic Journal. "We cannot see what the Prime Minister's office is thinking. What does he intend? How is he carrying things out? We cannot understand either his purposes or his proposals."
Among the other setbacks for Mr. Miyazawa was the failure last week of a proposed measure in Parliament to express regret over World War II on the Pearl Harbor anniversary. The measure died in the midst of partisan squabbling, and misgivings among rightists over apologizing to the United States.
Also besetting the Prime Minister is Japan's sagging economy, which has widened the budget deficit and forced the Government to decide whether to borrow, raise taxes or both. The Parliament has been haggling over this issue for weeks.
The Prime Minister, who was forced to resign as Finance Minister in 1988, has also been hit with revived charges that his office received questionable payments from the scandal-tainted Recruit Company, which was at the heart of the financial scandals of 1988 and 1989. A package of reform bills also seems to be dead.
Finally, there has been scant progress in getting Japan to yield in its longtime ban on the import of rice. The United States has charged that the ban threatens to undermine international trade talks. American officials are worried that Mr. Bush's visit could thus be seen as accomplishing little.
The peacekeeping bill had been put together as a response to widespread criticism that Japan gave only money to the war against Iraq, and not personnel. Despite Japan's contribution of $13 billion for the war, many Americans said Tokyo should have done more.
Only a week ago, senior aides to Mr. Miyazawa were confidently predicting that the measure would be approved in the opposition-controlled upper house of Parliament. The bill had passed the lower house.
The peacekeeping measure would have authorized up to 2,000 troops to participate in United Nations operations. To win approval among uneasy lawmakers, the bill said Japanese troops would only carry small arms and only use them in self-defense.
Japanese voters had mixed feelings over the idea, supporters of the bill acknowledged. Polls showed they overwhelmingly believed that Japan had to do more than contribute money to the cause of keeping peace, and that they backed sending navy minesweepers to the Persian Gulf earlier this year.
But polls also showed they opposed sending Japanese troops abroad, even under United Nations auspices. China, South Korea and Singapore -- former victims of Japanese military aggression -- also expressed their misgivings in recent weeks. Japanese Defense officials were also nervous about sending poorly trained troops into Cambodia, their probable first mission.
The measure was approved by the lower house last month, but only after scuffling broke out as Socialists and Communists tried to prevent a vote. In the upper house, the ruling Liberal Democratic Party was optimistic because it had won the nominal support of the tiny Komeito, or Clean Government Party.
But it turned out this week that Komeito's support -- crucial in the opposition-controlled upper house -- was shaky, in part because the party is having its own problems. It is always good politics in Japan to be in favor of peace, and Komeito apparently began to worry over the last few days that its pro-peace image was being tarnished.
The bill was declared dead after a bout of complicated legal maneuvering in which it was decided that the current session of Parliament would adjourn in 11 days, leaving no time, officials said, for the bill to be debated further and passed.

HEADLINE: Buchanan, Urging New Nationalism, Joins '92 Race

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CONCORD, N.H., Dec. 10

 BODY:
Patrick J. Buchanan, the conservative commentator, entered the race for the Republican Presidential nomination today with a biting attack on foreign aid and President Bush's "globalist" passions, and with a plea for a new nationalism.
Mr. Buchanan cast his candidacy as a crusade for a party and a country forsaken by its President. He asserted that Mr. Bush had abandoned conservative precepts, lost touch with the nation and become consumed with world affairs, while Americans struggle with recession and increasing economic competition from abroad. 
 The candidate contended that the end of the cold war had heralded an era of nationalism that requires a new focus on American interests and American needs.
"It is time to end these routinized annual transfers of our national wealth to global bureaucrats who ship it off to regimes who pay us back in compound ingratitude," said Mr. Buchanan, declaring his candidacy in this capital of the state that will hold the nation's first primary of the 1992 campaign. "It is time to phase out foreign aid and start looking out for the forgotten Americans right here in the United States."
 
Economic Issues Cited
 Mr. Buchanan, who like any challenger has limited resources for a battle against a sitting President, is centering his campaign on the Feb. 18 primary here. Many analysts say New Hampshire's stricken economy could make voters particularly receptive to an anti-Bush appeal, and a recent poll for The Boston Globe suggests that Mr. Bush's support among Republicans today is not overwhelming.
Still, Mr. Buchanan, a onetime aide to Presidents Richard M. Nixon and Ronald Reagan, acknowledged to reporters that his candidacy was "a very long-shot thing."
His best hope, he said, would be a replay of 1968, when Eugene McCarthy pulled 42 percent of the vote in New Hampshire's Democratic primary, a humiliating blow to President Lyndon B. Johnson, who ultimately withdrew from the race. But Mr. Buchanan acknowledged that Mr. Bush would not easily give up the fight.
At the very least, Mr. Buchanan will make life difficult for a President who has a clear sensitivity on his right flank. Today, for example, Mr. Buchanan put the blame for the recession squarely on the White House and its 1990 budget deal with Congress, which caused Mr. Bush to renege on his pledge to foreswear new taxes.
"Why am I running?" he asked. "Because we Republicans can no longer say it is all the liberals' fault. It was not some liberal Democrat who declared, 'Read my lips no new taxes,' then broke his word to cut a seedy backroom budget deal with the big spenders on Capitol Hill."
Mr. Buchanan added: "What is the White House answer to the recession that was caused by its own breach of faith? It is to deny that we even have a recession. Well, let them come to New Hampshire."
 
An Isolationist Ideology
 Still, Mr. Buchanan's speech often seemed less focused on the troubles of New Hampshire than on the commentator's conservative ideology, which critics assert has grown increasingly isolationist.
He said the United States needed to re-examine all the alliances and institutions of the cold war, established to guard against "Communist enemies that no longer exist." He warned of new economic challenges on the world scene, posed by "the rise of a European superstate and a dynamic Asia led by Japan."
Mr. Buchanan added, "With a $4 trillion debt, with a U.S. budget chronically out of balance, should the United States be required to carry indefinitely the full burden of defending rich and prosperous allies who take America's generosity for granted as they invade our markets?"
The United States should always be ready to help in times of natural disaster, he added, but should start to reorder its priorities to reflect the concerns of the home front. Mr. Bush, he said, "is a globalist, and we are nationalists. He believes in some pax universalis; we believe in the old republic. He would put America's wealth and power at the service of some vague new world order; we will put America first."
 
Some Editorial Support
 This isolationist tone of past movements in the United States has prompted some deep misgivings among many of Mr. Buchanan's fellow conservatives. But cheering Mr. Buchanan on are the editorial pages of The Manchester Union Leader, which described him today as the "conservator of the principles of the 1980's Reagan revolution that began in New Hampshire and swept the nation."
The commentator's foreign policy views have put him in the same politically awkward position as the Democrats: he opposed the war in the Persian Gulf, which was eventually widely supported in the public opinion polls.
Mr. Buchanan said he supported cuts in both the tax on capital gains and in taxes people pay for Social Security. He said it was time for the President to call back Congress and push through a major tax cut program. "I'll tell you what I won't do," he said, alluding to a recent Presidential trip widely ridiculed as a futile gesture of economic faith, "I won't go to J. C. Penney's and buy four pairs of socks."
Mr. Buchanan is the second challenger to enter the Republican primary; State Representative David Duke of Louisiana, a former leader of the Ku Klux Klan, entered the race last week, although he said he would not compete in New Hampshire. Mr. Buchanan had little but disdain for Mr. Duke, saying he was looking forward to going head-to-head with the former Klansman in the South to determine "who's the true conservative."
Mr. Buchanan's announcement was interrupted today by a protester chanting, "Act up, fight back, fight AIDS." The protester was quickly and forcibly ushered from the hall.
After announcing his candidacy, Mr. Buchanan embarked on some sidewalk campaigning, accompanied by a small band of supporters bearing signs like "Watch out, George Bush -- Pat Buchanan doesn't brake for liberals."
Since the town was Concord, the sidewalks were crowded with politicians, journalists and lobbyists, including Ralph Nader, who was in town to lead a crusade for term limits, new campaign finance laws and other political measures. "Hey, Pat," Mr. Nader called, and the two men exchanged greetings.

HEADLINE: U.S. WEIGHS PLANS FOR FOES OF IRAQI

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10

 BODY:
The Bush Administration is reviewing military options on how the United States would respond to a coup in Iraq by senior members of the Iraqi armed forces, Administration officials said today.
The Administration has received recent intelligence reports of "serious strains" in the Iraqi leadership and wants to insure that President Bush is not caught without a plan of action, as he was during a coup attempt in Panama in October 1989, a move that preceded the invasion by United States forces two months later. 
 The military options, prepared by the Joint Chiefs of Staff over the last three weeks, would prepare the United States for a situation in which key officers in Iraq's armed forces might request support from Washington in an attempt to seize power from President Saddam Hussein.
The options are to be reveiwed on Thursday at a high-level meeting of the so-called deputies committee of key Cabinet departments, which is headed by Adm. Jonathan T. Howe, the deputy national security adviser.
 
Timing of Military Plans
 The planning comes as Mr. Bush's re-election bid is about to be begin, and it seems likely to prompt critics to suggest that Mr. Bush is contemplating a foreign venture to divert attention from his domestic political troubles, or to insultate his re-election campaign from charges that the otherwise successful American military effort in the Persian Gulf war last winter failed to dislodge Mr. Hussein from power.
Some Democrats and Republicans have been urging the President to take stronger steps to remove Mr. Hussein and to avert a new humanitarian crisis in Iraq, where United Nations sanctions have led to widespread malnutrition among the poor, a condition that Mr. Hussein appears to be exploiting.
The military options were provided by Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff and the President's top military adviser. They were reviewed by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney before being sent to the White House late last week.
One potential dispute that emerged from the military review of coup "scenarios" posed by the White House centers on the issue of whether United States ground forces would be needed to back a successful coup attempt against Baghdad's current leadership.
 
White House Preference
 The White House wants a military solution based only on air forces and naval forces, officials said, while General Powell is said to believe strongly that the removal of Mr. Hussein cannot be guaranteed under any coup scenario without committing American ground troops, a decision that would present a politically debilitating and risky condition for the White House.
A classified discussion paper from General Powell is said to point out the difficulties of confronting the four Republican Guard divisions that ring Baghdad. While United States air forces might be sufficient to assist an Iraqi military coup by destroying and tying down loyalist forces, air power alone could not deal with every contingency or guarantee a final victory over Mr. Hussein, as one official described the military argument.
The military review did not appear to be prompted by intelligence information indicating that Mr. Hussein's top officers were actually plotting against him.
"We have had intelligence information very recently that indicated some serious strains" within Mr. Hussein's inner circle, an Administration official said.
 
'Armed Conflict'
 One intelligence report, received after Mr. Hussein changed defense ministers last month, described an incident of "armed conflict" between rival security forces of the new Iraqi Defense Minister, Ali Hassan al-Majid, a cousin of Mr. Hussein, and the relative he replaced, Hussein Kamel Hassan, who is Mr. Hussein's son-in-law.
The "conflict" resulted in "injuries and some deaths and was carried out in a revenge fashion" by Mr. Hassan's forces, the official said. The official added that other intelligence reporting indicated a general disaffection with Mr. Hussein among Iraq's traditional Sunni Muslim elite, which dominate the merchant class, the army and the upper ranks of the ruling Arab Baath Socialist Party.
By undertaking this review, however, the Administration may be hoping to foster the planning of a coup by keeping Mr. Hussein's regime under tight economic sanctions and by taking intrusive steps to remove or destroy all vestiges of Iraq's nuclear, chemical and biological weapons programs, as well as laboratories and factories taking part in ballistic missile work.
The military review was conducted in response to two specific scenarios posed by the National Security Council staff, officials said. Under one scenario, Iraqi military commanders began a coup attempt that bogged down and then asked for American assistance. Under a second scenario, Iraqi military leaders signaled to Washington they were ready to depose Mr. Hussein if the United States would provide support, particularly air support, since the Iraqi Air Force remains grounded as part of the allied cease-fire conditions imposed last winter.
To be successful in the removal of Mr. Hussein, General Powell is said to have forcefully argued, United States ground troops would be necessary and warned that the consequences of failure would undermine the long term gains United States foreign policy achieved with the gulf war victory.

HEADLINE: California Proposes Cutting Aid to Poor

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 10

 BODY:
The Governor of California has proposed sweeping changes in welfare policy in the nation's most populated state that would slash grants to long-term recipients, use increased benefits as a way to encourage certain forms of behavior and limit payments to indigent families who move here from other states.
Similar proposals are on the table in several other states, but none would affect as many people, involve as much money or inspire the kind of heated debate that is likely to occur here on sensitive issues of race and class. 
 While other states are seeking to overhaul welfare policy in a legislative setting, California will go the route of the ballot initiative, the populist approach to governance here that has been growing in popularity since the success in 1978 of Proposition 13, which cut property taxes here and led to a nationwide taxpayers' revolt.
 
Wise Political Move
 Circumventing the Legislature and going directly to the public with his ideas, national experts say, is a wise political move on Mr. Wilson's part and one likely to generate widespread interest across the country in coming months.
"This is in keeping with the whole tenor of the times," said Isabel V. Sawhill, a senior fellow at the Urban Institute, a nonprofit research institute in Washington. "There is a strong feeling out there on the part of the public that too much money is going to people who don't play by middle-class rules and this is an attempt by the Governor to tap into those feelings."
Ms. Sawhill, and others of varying political disposition, predicted that the measure, which the Governor called the Taxpayers Protection Act of 1992, was likely to qualify easily for next November's ballot and fare well with voters, who are likely to turn out in large numbers in a presidential year.
Ms. Sawhill said that complex issues like welfare reform were "far too complicated to be decided by referendum," and often wind up in court for just that reason, but that voters have been left little recourse in recent years by politicians who have failed "to keep in touch with where the public is on value issues."
 
Policy of New Paternalism
 Governor Wilson's proposal includes many elements of what has become known in policy-making circles as the new paternalism, a menu of welfare changes that urge paying the poor less, asking them to do more, and persuading them to bear fewer children. Along with other broad changes in California's budget-making process, the initiative includes the following:
*Overall grant levels under Aid to Families with Dependent Children, the state's largest welfare program, would be reduced 10 percent -- from $663 a month to $597 for a mother and two children. The A.F.D.C. program here currently costs $5.6 billion a year, and the cost is split by the state and the Federal Government.
*Grants would be reduced an additional 15 percent after six months -- to $507 a month -- for any family headed by an able-bodied adult. California now has the fourth-highest A.F.D.C. payments in the nation, behind Alaska ($891), Hawaii ($666) and Vermont ($679). After the 25 percent reduction, California would drop to 14th, state officials said.
*Grants would not increase for additional children, as they do under current law.
*Families moving here from out of state, who now account for 7 percent of the 2.2 million people collecting A.F.D.C., would be limited to grants equal to those in their former state for 12 months. After that, these new residents would qualify for full California benefits.
*Teen-age mothers would be entitled to grants only if they lived with their parents or legal guardians, with the payments going directly to the older generation.
*Teen-age parents would receive an additional $50 a month if they were in school and have the same amount subtracted from their grant if they dropped out.
*Food stamp allowances for A.F.D.C. recipients would increase $20 a month. And the amount of money an individual could earn before a reduction of benefits would remain at $694 a month.
*In the future, the annual A.F.D.C. grant level would be tied to the state's financial health and be part of the budget process, which is not the case now. Grants would go up and down according to a formula that includes state tax revenues and welfare caseloads.
 
Proposal Introduced on Monday
 Governor Wilson, a moderate Republican, introduced his proposals on Monday before a friendly Chamber of Commerce audience in Glendale, Calif. Today, on a visit to a minority-owned construction company not far from Sacramento, the state's capital, he amplified his ideas and defended a program that state officials said would save $600 million a year.
Mr. Wilson said the state was "on course for a train wreck" because the cost of entitlement programs, by the year 2000, would exceed California's tax revenue. Asked if his proposals did not echo some of the rhetoric of David Duke, the former Ku Klu Klan leader who lost the Louisiana governor's race last month, Mr. Wilson said that it was easier to trade epithets than to deal with "harsh reality," but that he intended to do the latter.
Mr. Wilson's proposal comes at a time when California, like most of the nation, is reeling from recession and facing recurrent budget deficits, limited tax revenue and growing caseloads for social services. Last year, with a $14.3 billion deficit, the largest ever for a state, Mr. Wilson raised taxes here by $7 billion and, with legislative approval, cut A.F.D.C. payments by 4.4 percent. But new deficits loom and both the Republican Governor and the Democratic-controlled Legislature agree that Californians are taxed to the limit.
In recent weeks, in a variety of national and local forums, Mr. Wilson has hammered at the theme that California's financial emergency is caused by an influx of indigents and immigrants, who have a huge need for government service, and a simultaneous exodus of working taxpayers, who are fleeing smog, traffic, urban chaos and the nation's highest housing prices.
Today, advocates for the poor condemned the Governor's plan and lawmakers, in large measure, lined up in predictable partisan configurations.
Assembly Speaker Willie Brown, a San Francisco Democrat, said that the problems of California "go beyond the cost of welfare families" and that "finding a scapegoat" was easier than "finding a solution." By contrast, Senator Ken Maddy, a Fresno Republican and party leader, said the proposed cuts "very well may be necessary if we're going to survive as a state."
The political potential of the situation was perhaps best summed up by B. T. Collins, a Republican Assemblyman from suburban Sacramento who briefly served as chief of staff in Gov. Edmond G. Brown Jr. 's administration. "Boy, is this gonna sell," Mr. Collins said, pointing particularly to the provision capping grants if women have more children. "That alone assures its passage. That just drives people crazy."
That sort of popular ethos was not lost on the state's leading Democrats. Robert Forsyth, spokesman for David A. Roberti, president pro tem of the State Senate, noted that Republicans had to avoid "a subtext that is racist" in discussing welfare changes. But the Democrats had as heavy a burden, Mr. Forsyth said, in seeking balance between "their philosophical constituencies" and the "growing middle-class economic woes."

HEADLINE: Depositors' Yields Slip Even Further

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH M. FOWLER

 BODY:
The decline in yields on certificates of deposit and bank money-market accounts steadily gained momentum in the last week, according to The Bank Rate Monitor, the publication in North Palm Beach, Fla., that specializes in covering interest rates.
"The speed and the size of the current decline is intensifying," Robert K. Heady, the publisher of The Monitor, said yesterday. He said banks had been racing to bring down their cost of funds before the Federal Reserve reduced its discount rate again; however, a high-ranking Fed official suggested yesterday that the Fed's policy makers were unlikely to take urgent action on rates when they meet next week. Mr. Heady said he thought the unusually low current yields would move even lower by mid-February, possibly by another 25 or 30 basis points. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
 
 
Sees 4.5% on 6-Month C.D.'s
 He said that the nationwide average yield on six-month certificates of deposit probably would be less than 4.50 percent. New York banks have cut yields by about 14 basis points, to 4.16 percent, he said. 
 In the case of money-market accounts, the largest cuts were made by Astoria Federal Savings Bank and Bank of Tokyo Trust, which both cut yields by 26 basis points.
The Bank of Tokyo Trust was also the leader in cutting its three-month certificates of deposit by 45 basis points and its six-month certificates by 35 basis points.
For the New York commercial banks, the average yield on money market accounts was 4.18 percent, down 6 basis points. The average yields on those banks' three-month and six-month certificates were, respectively, 4.16 percent, down 14 basis points, and 4.26 percent, down 11 basis points.
 
 
Cuts by Savings Institutions
 At savings institutions in the New York area, yields were cut to 4.83 percent, down 9 basis points, for money market accounts; to 4.83 percent, down 10 basis points, for three-month certificates, and to 5.00 percent, also down 10 basis points, for six-month certificates.
The Monitor said the average yields at 20 major banks outside the New York area had been cut by 8 basis points, to 4.47 percent, on money-market accounts, and by 14 points, to 4.55 percent, for six-month certificates.
By comparison, at the Treasury Department's weekly bill auction on Monday, the three-month bill was auctioned at an average discount rate of 4.21 percent.

HEADLINE: New Mayor of Nation's Capital Finds Sober Reality Dulls Bright Promise

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10

 BODY:
In the 11 months since Sharon Pratt Kelly replaced Marion S. Barry Jr. as Mayor of the nation's capital, sober reality has dulled some of the sheen of her bright promise of change and supplanted some of her do-it-yesterday eagerness.
Mrs. Kelly -- she was Sharon Pratt Dixon until this past weekend, when she married James R. Kelly 3d, a businessman who has homes in New York and Los Angeles -- took office in early January promising to "clean house." She was eager to deal with the drug-driven crime bedeviling the city. She could hardly wait to wrestle the bloated City Hall bureaucracy she inherited from Mr. Barry, whose 12-year tenure ended with him bound for prison on a drug conviction. 
 But it is now apparent that solving the problems facing the District of Columbia, which is desperately short of money and stunned by a horrific spree of robbery and murder, is going to be no easier or more readily accomplished than solving the problems facing any other troubled American city.
For reasons beyond her control, some of the problems here have grown worse since Mrs. Kelly took office. Other problems have been worsened by her administration's mistakes.
 
No Major Erosion Yet
 There is no wholesale souring on the new Mayor, a Democrat and the first black woman elected to run one of the nation's major cities. But the expectations of many people here had soared with her ascendancy, perhaps soared too much, and now they have begun to chafe with disappointment.
Despite the disappointment, polls indicate that Mrs. Kelly has not yet suffered major, irretrievable erosion of her political base. And in recent weeks she has moved to shore up that base, aware that the sort of problems she faces has seriously weakened the political strength of some mayors, including David N. Dinkins of New York, and has led to the defeat of others, like Kathryn Whitmire of Houston.
One of the major problems here is crime. The drug-driven murder wave has intensified, claiming some 400 lives thus far this year. And increasing numbers of them are innocent bystanders, shot down for no apparent reason.
Moreover, the municipal bureaucracy remains bloated and resistant to change. Employment, housing, health and education problems have grown worse as the nation's economic recession reduces revenue, forcing a shrinkage in government social programs just as rapid expansion is needed.
A few nights ago the disappointment over the new Mayor's achievements thus far boiled over when she talked about crime and other issues with 300 members of the Citizens Association of Georgetown. Along with other white enclaves in this predominately black city, Georgetown gave Mrs. Kelly the edge she needed to pull off a suprising victory in the 1990 mayoral election.
"You have my support but you also have my anger," Clifford L. Brody, a government consultant, told the Mayor, his voice rising. "We think it can be done better."
Mrs. Kelly replied that she heard his message "loud and clear" and was moving determinedly to solve the city's problems. She spoke of her recent proposal to attack crime not just by putting more police officers on the street, but also by reaching out to troubled young people with more education and training programs.
"But we're looking at something that's going to take awhile to solve -- not forever, but awhile," she said, caution edging in where once there had been boundless optimism.
The Mayor's critics concede the money squeeze has left her with no funds to expand old government programs or institute new programs. But they contend that she has made matters worse by feuding with the City Council and by allowing her top aides to feud among themselves.
"She's fallen short by any measure, even though she's had a lot of very tough things to deal with and has made some progress here and there," said Joslyn Williams, the head of the city's Democratic Party. "A lot of people feel frozen out. They don't know where to turn."
Still, the first year of Mrs. Kelly's four-year tenure has not been without some successes. For example, she has been able to persuade Congress, which by law has the final say over most District matters, that the city merits the Federal support that was denied in the waning days of the Barry administration. Lawmakers have responded with more money, including an extra $100 million to help the city pay its debts, and an increase in the annual appropriation for services the city provides the Federal Government.
"The feeling about the city, as far as Congress is concerned, has gone from the dead of winter to a bright spring day," said Representative Thomas J. Bliley Jr. of Virginia, the ranking Republican on the House Committee on the District of Columbia, who is a former Mayor of Richmond. "Given what she's had to work with and all the problems she faced right from the beginning, I'd say she's off to as good a start as could be expected."
In an effort to shore up her political support, Mrs. Kelly has appointed one of the city's top political operators, Ted Gay, whose task is to establish contact with community groups and improve constituent services.
"Naturally, she was weak in this area," he said. "She came in as an outsider, someone who wasn't supposed to win, had no big organization. It takes time. We'll get it done."
Perhaps most importantly, Mrs. Kelly has moved forcefully to defuse the crime issue, which polls show is what most worries the average citizen.
Last month, after a particularly heinous murder in which a woman riding home on a city freeway was shot to death by a man who the police said "just wanted to kill somebody," the Mayor made a prime-time television appearance in which she announced that the city would increase police presence on the streets and reach out to troubled youngsters with special education and training programs.
Community centers will be established at which social workers will assist and advise families with crime-prone children and offer more health services for teen-agers with drug problems, as well as programs to curb teen-age pregnancy.
Curfews will be imposed in neighborhoods that have an unusual crime wave, and the age at which juveniles can be prosecuted as adults for serious crimes will be lowered a year, to 14, with bail provisions tightened.
The number of homicide investigators will be doubled, to 110. Additional officers will patrol the city by foot, with the number doubling in public housing projects, where much of the city's worst crime occurs.
Mrs. Kelly estimated the cost of her anti-crime plan at $20 million. She proposed paying for it by taking money from other programs and by seeking grants from the Federal Government and private foundations.
Given time and resources, the Mayor says, she will make good on her promise to clean house.
"But I don't have any instant solutions to our problems," she said in an interview. "What I offer now is hope. We can eventually get the job done."

HEADLINE: Poor Find Going Broke Is Too Costly

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MORGANTON, N.C.

 BODY:
Almost a million Americans went bankrupt last year, but others were not so lucky.
Many Americans are too poor to go bankrupt. 
 Unable to afford court costs and lawyers' fees that can total $1,000 or more, many poor people lose possessions that a bankruptcy filing could save, and find themselves subject to unnerving or even illegal pressure from collection agencies. They also stay buried under their financial misfortunes, unable to enjoy the rehabilitated credit histories that bankruptcy affords the more privileged.
"There are probably a million people in the country who would like to file for bankruptcy, but can't afford it," said Gary Klein of the National Consumer Law Center, which advises lawyers on consumer cases.
 
Law's Uneven Application
 As this recession, like others, has led to record bankruptcy filings, most attention has focused on the legal maneuvers of troubled titans like Donald J. Trump and Drexel Burnham Lambert.
But while bankruptcy laws are also supposed to more modest earners who fall on hard times, allowing them, too, to reorganize or cancel their debts, the system is not working for people like Bob and Amy Davis of Morganton.
In this small town in a low-wage valley of furniture factories, poultry farms and textile mills, the Davises have been virtually without work since last summer, when Mr. Davis's attempt to open an auto repair shop collapsed under the weight of the recession.
With three young children suffering from a rare genetic disease called Albright's syndrome, the Davises owe more than $15,000 in medical bills. Creditors have repossessed their car, the bicycle they gave their son last year for Christmas and the bed they gave their daughter.
The Davises finally sought the help of a bankruptcy lawyer, who tallied their debts on a piece of adding machine tape that stretched four feet. They totaled $26,073.26.
 
Legal Fees Are Too High
 Lawyers say that filing for bankruptcy could erase most of that debt. But when the Davises learned it would cost about $600 in legal fees, plus $120 in court costs, to declare themselves officially broke, they found it a luxury they could not afford.
"The laws are really strange," Mr. Davis said. "If we had the money to file, we'd just pay the bills."
Unable to find work as a mechanic, Mr. Davis now gets occasional jobs in one of the few businesses in this area that seem to be booming: he works as a "repo man," taking back cars from debtors like himself.
Poor people seeking bankruptcy protection face at least three problems.
Some just do not have the income to pay their debts even if their obligations were reduced under a bankruptcy proceeding. Others do have the income that might save their cars, appliances or sometimes even their homes, but they cannot afford the legal fees, which range from $400 to $1,500 and sometimes must be paid in advance.
Added to that is a third financial problem: debtors must pay a $120 filing fee, since bankruptcy courts refuse to waive fees for the indigent, as other courts will. A 1973 ruling by the United States Supreme Court upheld the bankruptcy fee, which was then $50, declaring that there is no constitutional right to bankruptcy.
In an angry dissent, Justice Thurgood Marshall termed the ruling "disgraceful" and said, "No one who has had close contact with poor people can fail to understand how close to the margin of survival many of them are."
 
It's Expensive to Be Poor
 Some advocates argue that the problems poor people face in getting bankruptcy protection are just part of a larger pattern of credit inequities that make it expensive to be poor. Unable to get conventional financing, for instance, many poor people buy televisions or appliances on weekly payment plans that drive up their costs dramatically.
"It tends to create a cycle of poverty," Mr. Klein said.
In the year ending June 30, there were 811,206 personal bankruptcy cases filed in the United States, a 23 percent increase over the previous year and a record.
Of those, 621,324 were under Chapter 7 of the bankruptcy code, typically used by the poorest debtors. This requires them to sell off their property to pay their creditors, while, in exchange, the court cancels the debt that remains. Under this proceeding, debtors are allowed to keep a certain amount of property, which varies by state but averages about $12,000.
In the case of the Davises, who have few possessions to sell, lawyers say the court would simply cancel most of their debts. "Medical bills -- boom -- gone," said John Vail, who runs the nearby Catawba Valley Legal Services office.
The remainder of the nation's personal bankruptcies were under Chapter 13, which allows debtors to retain more of their possessions, often including their homes, in exchange for making reduced but steady payments.
 
A Matter of Triage
 Only about half the nation's Legal Services offices handle bankruptcies, citing a shortage of lawyers. Mr. Vail, who takes bankruptcy cases only when doing so can save a home, said he turns away as many families as he helps.
"It's triage," he said, adding that there are "a lot of folks we don't do anything for."
Some scholars have urged that bankruptcy be made an administrative procedure, dispensing with the need for lawyers. Under current law, people are allowed to represent themselves, but the proceeding is a technical one that even lawyers sometimes find confusing.
Among bankruptcy's intangible but important benefits is the protection from harassment that it promises. The law bars collection agencies from soliciting from those who have declared bankruptcy.
When a collection agency called Sue Bottiggi, of North Andover, Mass., it threatened to take not just her possessions but her children.
Ms. Bottiggi's husband left the family in late 1989, and her 11-year-old daugther was subsequently hospitalized with emotional problems. But when Ms. Bottiggi told a collection agent that she could not afford to pay off a $1,600 Visa bill, she said, the agent calmly, illegally and falsely told her that she would be taken to court, where a judge would probably put her children in foster care.
Eventually, she told her divorce lawyer of the calls. Threatened with a suit, the collection agency agreed to pay Ms. Bottiggi $10,000 and the bank erased her debt.
 
Pressure From a Collector
 The Davises have been relying on the $407 monthly disability checks that two of their children receive, plus $107 a month in food stamps. In addition to treating the children's Albright's syndrome, a hormone problem that has left them with learning disabilities, Mr. Davis ran up his own medical bills with a heart attack and lymph node surgery.
Before the family changed to an unlisted telephone number, Mr. Davis said, one collector called and "said he didn't care if he harassed me enough to give me another heart attack, he was going to get his money."
Mr. Davis now works the other side of the collection line, earning $50 for each car he repossesses. He said several debtors tried to stop him with fists, and one drew a gun. "There's quite a few of them I do feel terrible for," he said, "but if I don't do it somebody's going to."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The recession has led to record bankruptcy filings, but Bob and Amy Davis of Morganton, N.C., found that like many who are struggling financially, they were unable to afford the court costs and lawyer's fees. With them in their trailer home were their children, from left, Jonathan, D. J. and Valerie. (Duane Hall for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Panel Steps Up Census Dispute With Bush Official

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10

 BODY:
The tug of war over politically volatile census data erupted into an angry confrontation today as a House subcommittee chairman said Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher had "put himself outside the law" by refusing to appear and turn over the full set of alternative census counts subpoenaed by the panel.
Although Mr. Mosbacher's aides appeared before the subcommittee today and agreed to turn over half of the adjusted counts, the chairman, Tom Sawyer, Democrat of Ohio, said, "No Cabinet official has ever failed to appear before the Legislature when withholding subpoenaed documents." 
 Alternately pale and flushed with anger, Mr. Sawyer, who heads the House Census and Population subcommittee, told Mr. Mosbacher's aides that he would "take under advisement" whether the partial data they offered would be acceptable, or whether he would seek to have Mr. Mosbacher held in contempt of Congress.
If Mr. Sawyer chose to take that course and won approval from a majority of the full House Post Office and Civil Service Committee, his fellow Congressional Democrats would be faced with the ticklish but enticing prospect of taking an obscure dispute on the census and using it to embarrass a chief political adviser of President Bush. The President named Mr. Mosbacher last week as general chairman of his 1992 re-election campaign.
After the hearing, the Democratic Party chairman, Ronald H. Brown, issued a statement accusing Mr. Mosbacher of "hiding" and saying his "contempt of Congress is surpassed only by his contempt for the standards of accuracy and fairness in the first place."
But at the Commerce Department, aides argued that the Department had complied with the subpoena by providing half the available national data to the committee. In mid-November, before the subpoena for the full set of data was voted, Mr. Sawyer had said half the data would be acceptable.
"We felt we are fully in compliance," said Michael R. Darby, the Department's under secretary for economic affairs. "This is not a reasonable thing that's going on here." Commerce aides said the subpoena voted by the committee did not specifically require Mr. Mosbacher to appear today.
At issue are computer tapes with the adjusted population counts, a second full set of data compiled by taking the original count, comparing it with the results of a later survey of 171,000 households and using statistical models to adjust the final counts to compensate for an estimated census undercount of 3 million to 5 million people.
In July, Mr. Mosbacher, whose statistical advisers disagreed over which data to approve as the official 1990 figures, ruled that the original census enumeration would be designated as the official numbers, and that the alternative, adjusted figures, would be used for analysis and possible adjustment of subsequent population estimates.
Mr. Sawyer has said he is seeking the adjusted counts for scientific study on ways to improve the census process before the year 2000, but the political subtext of the request was clear. Although the official, unadjusted census data has already been used to allocate Congressional seats among the states, state legislatures are free to bypass the official numbers and use the adjusted figures, if they can get them, to draw in-state legislative maps.

HEADLINE: Trade Deficit Rose in Quarter

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10

 BODY:
The nation's foreign trade deficit, which includes services and investments as well as goods, climbed to $10.5 billion in the July-September quarter, the Government said today.
The deficit in the current account, the broadest measure of the nation's performance with the rest of the world, followed rare back-to-back quarters of surplus. In the first two quarters, the perennial merchandise trade deficits were offset by contributions made by the allies to pay for the Persian Gulf war. 
 The allies' contributions fell by 60 percent in the third quarter to $4.6 billion, however, and were not enough to offset a 33 percent increase in the merchandise trade deficit to $20.5 billion.
The current account measures not only merchandise but also imports and exports of services and investment between the United States and other countries.
Many analysts predicting that this year's current account deficit could dip to $20 billion or less, as the war payments and lower imports resulting from the recession create a big improvement over last year's $92.12 billion deficit.
But analysts said the big jump in the third-quarter deficit was an ominous sign of things to come as the war payments stop and as demand for United States exports slows because of economic sluggishness abroad.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Mozart's Money Misunderstanding

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
POOR Mozart. Everybody who saw the movie knows genius went unrewarded, that the composer of "Don Giovanni" and "The Magic Flute" lived hand to mouth and died a pauper. In fact, say William Baumol, an economist at New York University, and Hilda Baumol, an economics consultant in New York, everybody got it wrong.
In a paper written for the Mozart Bicentennial Symposium at the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars in Washington, the husband-wife team calculates that Mozart's income in the last decade of his life was thoroughly middle class by 1990's standards -- a remarkable achievement for a time in which most wage earners lived at the raw edge of subsistence. 
 Mozart, moreover, was not alone in his good fortune. His was a golden era for composers in German-speaking Europe , the Baumols say, one in which a serendipitous convergence of factors favored the flowering of musical culture. They believe that the fragmentation of central European states along with changes in the technology of music virtually assured that economic growth would generate financial windfalls for composers.
First, the question of how much Mozart made and what it was worth. According to Volkmar Braunbehrens, a biographer of Mozart, the great composer's annual income during his Vienna years (1781-91) fluctuated between 800 and 3,800 Austrian florins. But these numbers omit much of his earnings from teaching, performance and publication. The Baumols figure Mozart's total take averaged 3,000-4,000 florins a year during the period.
Translating Mozart's 1780's income in florins into 1990's dollars is a matter of educated guess work because data on 18th-century prices and consumption habits are sparse. Moreover, no matter how carefully the index is constructed, comparisons across centuries have limited meaning because the goods available have changed so radically: there is, for example, no way to figure the value in florins of the few dollars' worth of antibiotics that might have saved Mozart from his fatal bout of typhoid fever.
The Baumols plow ahead, however, with striking results. They use the long-running Phelps Brown-Hopkins index for the cost of living in Britain to compare 1786 British pounds with 1989 pounds. Then they convert pounds to florins on the 18th-century end, and pounds to dollars on the other.
It seems that the 1786 florin could buy roughly as much as $10 in 1989. Thus 3,000-4,000 florins were worth $30,000-40,000 -- less than Madonna makes from a single concert, but not a bad deal for a serious artist in his 30's. The figure looks even better when one remembers that the purchasing power of the average wage in Mozart's Vienna was, at very most, one-seventh the average in America today. Mozart's income was thus enough to qualify him for Vienna's upper middle class.
The Baumols believe it was no accident that the place and time that nurtured Mozart also brought forth the likes of Beethoven, Schubert, Hayden and Gluck. Rarely, they say, has the economics of musical composition been so fortuitous.
The existence of 1,800 separate German monarchies meant that 1,800 royal courts could covet musical performance, both as a means of conspicu ous consumption and a way to relieve boredom. Moreover, by the conventions of the time, the only good music was new music -- nobody wanted to hear that dreary old stuff from Bach and Handel if they could afford something original.
This rich market for composition was made yet richer, the Baumols contend, by changes in popular taste and in the technology of musical instruments. The new "galant" style was far easier to play than the traditional contrapuntal style, opening performance to amateurs and reducing the cost of professional productions. And the invention of the fortepiano, an instrument as loud as the harpsichord yet as subtle as the clavichord, made it possible to play the new music for much larger groups. By no coincidence this was the era in which concert hall music, paid for by subscription, became a bourgeois pastime.
This cheery history still leaves the matter of Mozart's grim burial to explain. The Baumols, ever resourceful, think that the story of Mozart's consignment to a pauper's grave is based on a misunderstanding.
It seems that Emperor Joseph II of Austria thought that burial pomp had no place in the rational modern world. And for a while, Viennese society humored him: everyone but the aristocracy ended up in mass graves, where they were dumped without ceremony after church services. Later, the Baumols report, the bones were dug up and reburied in private ossuaries.

HEADLINE: SOVIET DISARRAY;
Chaos Looms Over Soviets, Gates Says

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Dec. 10

 BODY:
Robert M. Gates, the Director of Central Intelligence, warned today that the fragmented Soviet Union faces the most severe instability this winter since the civil war that followed the Bolshevik seizure of power in 1917, including the possibility of a reversion to authoritarian rule in some regions.
Describing the volatile political situation as "dangerously unstable," he cited many internal crises, including the collapse of central authority, continued decay and disintegration of the Soviet Army, uncertainty over the control of the Soviet arsenal of 30,000 nuclear weapons and the potential for conflict between various republics in the next year or two if aggressive, xenophobic regimes emerge from the current political turmoil and economic privation. 
 Mr. Gates's testimony before a House subcommittee, in part a distillation of intelligence assessments recently prepared for President Bush, underscored the delicate and confusing position the Administration faces as it struggles to adjust American policy to fit a moving target.
The Administration said on Monday that it was ready to work with the new commonwealth of Russia, Ukraine and Byelorussia, which was formed on Sunday, but made no move to formally recognize it or to break ties to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, at least for the moment. No policy changes were announced today, as officials continued to wait for events to unfold.
 
A Grim View
 In the most comprehensive Administration analysis of the current Soviet crisis, Mr. Gates told the Defense Policy Panel of the House Armed Services Committee:
"The economy is in a free fall with no prospects for reversal in sight. Severe economic conditions, including substantial shortages of food and fuel in some areas, the disintegration of the armed forces and ongoing ethnic conflict will combine this winter to produce the most significant disorder in the former U.S.S.R. since the Bolsheviks consolidated power."
During grueling confirmation hearings last fall, Mr. Gates was questioned extensively about his long-held view that the prospects for a peaceful transition to democracy in the Soviet Union were not good, and his grim assessment today was consistent with that view. But he also noted that the disintegration could in some ways prove beneficial for the United States and the West.
None of the splintering republics, he said, "either individually or collectively, has the desire or ability to pose as great a threat to U.S. security as did the U.S.S.R. for so many decades."
"Indeed," he said, "most republics of the former U.S.S.R. are trying to reduce their defense burdens, join Western economic and security structures and forge cooperative relationships with the United States."
President Bush sought today to assure the American public that the United States was responding adequately to the volatile situation.
"I'm proud of the way we've handled the evolution in the Soviet Union, and right today it is extraordinarily complicated," he said in a speech in Chicago, without elaborating.
 
Remarks by Strauss
 Robert S. Strauss, the American Ambassador to Moscow, was at times more upbeat, at times more pessimistic than Mr. Gates in less formal remarks made in Washington today.
In a breakfast meeting with the American Committee on U.S.-Soviet Relations, Mr. Strauss praised the fledgling commonwealth of Soviet republics for embracing principles the United States finds "positive," but expressed doubts over whether it had the popular support necessary to survive.
"This new commonwealth that we hear about, God only knows where it's going to end up," he said.
Even more worrisome, Mr. Strauss noted, was what he called the possibility that disgruntled remnants of the Soviet military might stage a coup. Calling the military a "wild card," he said, "We haven't heard a word from the army over there, and there are millions of men that are terribly unhappy and frustrated and hungry and homeless and families are disturbed." He called the situation "made to order for any of several first-rate demagogues they have."
Mr. Gates, while praising Boris N. Yeltsin, the Russian President, for his articulation of "bold economic reforms," added, "It remains to be seen whether he can carry them out."
 
Uncertain About Gorbachev
 In the closed session that followed his opening statement, Mr. Gates was careful not to rule out a future role for Mr. Gorbachev or to criticize Mr. Yeltsin, people who attended the briefing said.
"His prognostication for Gorbachev's success in pulling something out of this was very low," an American official said. "But when people tried to press him questions about Gorbachev, I honestly don't think either he or the agency knows."
Despite their close working relationship via telephone during the Persian Gulf crisis and during other Soviet political developments, Mr. Bush has not tried to speak with Mr. Gorbachev since the republics of Russia, Ukraine and Byelorussia announced their confederation on Sunday, Marlin Fitzwater, the White House spokesman, said today.
Nor has Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d spoken to his Soviet counterpart, Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, or to any of the foreign ministers of the republics, Margaret D. Tutwiler, the State Department spokeswoman, said.
Still, she added, Mr. Baker, who is scheduled to leave for Moscow on Saturday night, will meet with Mr. Shevardnadze on Sunday night and with President Gorbachev on Monday.
 
'Immediate' Nuclear Concern
 Mr. Gates told the lawmakers that although the Soviet military threat had dramatically diminished and that military "readiness is at its lowest level in decades," of "immediate concern" was the danger that the Soviets will not be capable of maintaining safeguards as they reduce or dismantle much of their nuclear arsenal. Until now, he noted, the Defense Ministry and General Staff had guaranteed safeguards through an elaborate system of central control.
"But the center is evaporating before our eyes," he said in the starkest portrayal of the Administration's concern about control of Soviet nuclear weapons. "Those who designed the control system never anticipated this."
Even extraordinary physical security measures, elaborate codes and fail-safe methods "become ineffective if the guards or their commanders are suborned, corrupted or simply disappear."
 
Worry Over Technology
 Mr. Gates also expressed concern that the former Soviet Union could emerge as a major new source of nuclear and other weapons technology for developing countries in exchange for hard currency. He said that such technology could come particularly from republic and local governments with high concentrations of military equipment and little else that was marketable.
"Even if republic governments retain tight control over their arsenals, economic conditions will tempt them to sell weapons to the highest hard-currency bidder," he said.
He also speculated that among the tens of thousands of scientists, engineers and medical doctors emigrating annually from the Soviet Union, some may find a market for their expertise in countries in the developing world that are striving to acquire new weaponry.
As for the internal political situation, Mr. Gates expressed concern that economic reform would lead to inflation and unemployment that could overwhelm democratic forces in the Soviet republics.
"The possibility cannot be ruled out that such circumstances could produce a return to authoritarian government -- whether led by reformers desperate to feed the people and stave off an explosion, or by nationalists driven by a xenophobic, atavistic vision of Russia," he said.
 
Trying to Keep Pace
 Events were moving so quickly that Mr. Gates said he had drafted his remarks -- his first public statement on the Soviet Union since assuming the nation's top intelligence post last month -- on Saturday thinking that it was "bold and forward-leaning." But he added that he had to make substantial changes on Monday to reflect the most recent events.
Underscoring the uncertainty, he has short-circuited the lengthy interagency analysis process and ordered his analysts to draft 10 brief assessments of the Soviet Union this month.
The classified reports range from food and fuel needs and ethnic conflict to the disintegration of the armed forces and the strategic threat. While some have already been delivered to the White House, intelligence officials said that others would have to be substantially rewritten to reflect the quick pace of events.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Robert M. Gates, the Director of Central Intelligence, who described the volatile political situation in the Soviet Union as being "dangerously unstable." (Associated Press)

Chronology: "Cracks in the Union"
 
AUGUST
 19 -- The day before President Mikhail S. Gorbachev planned to sign a union treaty intended to keep several republics together, hard-liners move to overthrow him.
 21 -- The coup fails and Mr. Gorbachev returns to Moscow.
 24 -- Mr. Gorbachev resigns as Communist Party chief and urges that the party be disbanded.
 27 -- Mr. Gorbachev appleals to the republics to preserve military and economic union.
 29 -- Soviet lawmakers suspend teh Communist Party's activities nationwide and freeze its bank accounts because of the party's role in the failed coup. Russia and Ukraine bypass the Kremlin to form a military and economic alliance.
 
SEPTEMBER
 2 -- The Congress of People's Deputies approves a plan to reduce the Kremlin's authority in the Soviet Union but retain a loose federation of states.
 5 -- Soviet lawmakers approve an interim Government to usher in a confederation of sovereign states.
 6 -- The Soviet Union recognizes the independence of Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia.
 12 -- Officials of the Baltic nations and the 12 remaining Soviet republics agree to maintain a collective defense framework and a single control over the Soviet nuclear arsenal.
 
OCTOBER
 1 -- The 12 Soviet republics agree to an economic union.
 17 -- Ukraine refuses to join the economic union.
 18 -- Mr. Gorbachev and Presidents of eight Soviet republics sign a treaty to create an economic union.
 
NOVEMBER
 4 -- Ukraine agrees to join the economic union.
 16 -- Boris N. Yeltsin, the President of the Russian republic, takes control over the Soviet money supply and trade in oil, gold, diamonds and foreign currency.
 25 -- Seven republics fail to endorse the union treaty but promise to send it ot their legislatures.
 
DECEMBER
 1 -- Ukraine voters approve a referendum declaring independence.
 4 -- The Supreme Soviet endorses the union treaty. Seven republics say they will sign.
 8 -- Russia, Ukraine and Byelorussia form a "commonwealth" and declare Mr. Gorbachev's Government dead.
 9 -- Mr. Gorbachev disputes the three republics' right to create a new commonwealth. He urges that the Congress of People's Deputies convene to take up the matter.
 10 -- The Parliaments of Ukraine and Byelorussia vote to ratify the commonwealth agreement. (Source: Associated Press)

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Small Shops Move to Hire Top Directors

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT

 BODY:
TWO smaller New York agencies known for their originality are seeking to break out of the pack by hiring two executives with similar reputations as creative directors.
One is Bergelt Litchfield Inc., the home of humorous radio commercials that urge commuters to ride the Long Island Rail Road by dramatizing the drudgery of driving. Bergelt has hired Cary Lemkowitz, formerly of Young & Rubicam New York, as its president and executive creative director. 
 The other is Frankfurt Gips Balkind Advertising, whose witty advertising for the New York Restaurant Group includes a television spot in which professional waiters mangle famous lines from plays and movies to demonstrate that "no one's ever discovered a great actor at Smith & Wollensky. Only great steak."
Frankfurt has hired Marty Cooke of Chiat/Day/Mojo Inc. as its executive vice president and creative director.
The appointments are the latest in what has been an almost frantic round of hirings at agencies searching for top creative talent. Among the familiar names changing jobs: Gordon Bowen and Parry Merkley, who left Ogilvy & Mather New York for, respectively, McCann-Erickson New York and Doremus & Company; Nina DiSesa, who left McCann for J. Walter Thompson Chicago, and Eric Weber, who left Y. & R. New York for Foote, Cone & Belding in Chicago.
The reason for the rondelay is the continuing advertising industry recession. Agencies are increasingly eager to land the key creative people who they fervently hope will produce campaigns that sell products and attract clients.
"Creativity is the critical issue," Jane Cavalier, Frankfurt's president, said yesterday.
Since September, when Mr. Lemkowitz left Y. & R. New York, where he had been an executive vice president and creative director, there has been intense speculation over his next stop. He earned his reputation there for campaigns like Metropolitan Life's "Get Met, It Pays" advertising, featuring the "Peanuts" characters, and Citizen Watch's "Citizen, Citizen, Citizen" commercials, but, he said, "it was time to turn the page."
Mr. Lemkowitz, who is 43 years old, characterized his new post as "an opportunity to focus on creativity and be involved with all the clients."
In keeping with what he called a desire to "be entrepreneurial," he is being made a principal in Bergelt, which has about 40 employees and around $35 million in billings from clients that also include Villeroy & Boch and the Association of American Railroads.
Mr. Lemkowitz, whose appointment takes effect immediately, succeeds Dick Raboy, the president and creative director. David H. Venghaus, Bergelt's chairman, described it as "an amicable separation," adding that he had been "looking to bring in the next wave of management."
A primary reason, he continued, was a belief that Bergelt, unlike shops like Deutsch Inc., Kirshenbaum & Bond and Omon, "is not getting into some of the presentations I think we should be."
Signing Mr. Lemkowitz "is like hiring a name brand," he added.
At Frankfurt, the decision to hire Mr. Cooke, 39, stemmed from a desire to "position ourselves as the great creative force that's missing in New York right now," Ms. Cavalier, the president, said. Effective on Jan. 6, she added, he will replace Frankfurt's acting creative directors, Bryan Buckley and Frank Todaro, who will continue as consultants.
Mr. Buckley and Mr. Todaro were top creative executives at Buckley DeCerchio Cavalier, which was merged into Frankfurt in August to form a shop with about 35 employees and around $49 million in billings from clients that also include Giant Carpet and the Comedy Central cable television network.
"For me, this is like a start-up without all the angst of going through a start-up," Mr. Cooke said yesterday in an interview from Toronto, where for 14 months he has served as creative director of Chiat's Canadian operations.
Among the campaigns he has worked on, at Chiat and at Scali, McCabe, Sloves, are Nynex's pun-filled "human cartoons" telephone directory ads and Reebok's surrealistic "U.B.U." ads.
