HEADLINE: President Mingles With the People In Chicago as Economy Is an Issue

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Dec. 10

 BODY:
President Bush chose a trip to the middle of America today to make the oft-debated political point that he is, too, in touch with the average person.
In trips to the Chicago Board of Trade and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, Mr. Bush waded happily through mobs of commodities and financial futures brokers on the frenzied trading floors, perhaps the nation's most vivid examples of robust capitalism. Later, speaking to the Illinois Farm Bureau Federation, he waxed enthusiastic about the moral and social values of rural America. 
 In between, the President ducked into the Billy Goat Tavern, a seedy downtown bar favored by reporters and construction workers, for a cheeseburger-and-Coke lunch with five ordinary people assembled by the White House's image consultant, Sig Rogich.
 
Choice of Tavern
 Marlin Fitzwater, the President's spokesman, said the White House chose the Billy Goat, a hamburger-and-a-beer joint tucked gloomily beneath Michigan Avenue, "because we needed a place to go to lunch," and not expressly for political reasons.
Mr. Bush ate his cheeseburger and potato chips off a wax-paper place setting. He was overheard discussing the economy, unemployment, Pearl Harbor, the Soviet Union and Chicago real estate with the three men and two women who were his guests, but only snippets of the chat were audible to nearby reporters.
One of two sheet-metal workers who had lunch with Mr. Bush, Jim Mancini, later told reporters that Mr. Bush "seemed like he was very concerned in trying to find a way" to revive the nation's slumbering economy, but was "kind of confused" as to how to proceed.
Mr. Bush spent much of the day working hard to persuade audiences that he would "do my level best," as he said at one point, to shake the economy out of its slump. But like Mr. Mancini, many who heard him seemed to have a mixed response.
As Mr. Bush entered a private meeting on the nation's economy with some of the city's top leaders at the Board of Trade, he said he was "not happy, nor is anybody, with the state of the economy," adding that it needed the "kick" of a legislative package of stimulants that he is now putting together.
He made the point more emphatically later in a speech at the mercantile exchange, where he blamed Congress for many of the economy's current problems.
"I've asked Congress for three years to pass a series of growth initiatives -- job-creating initiatives," he said. "And the economy has turned sluggish. People want action. And I want action -- action to help people, action to make things better now and in the future."
But Mr. Bush offered no hint today of what measures he might favor to improve the economic climate beyond a litany of ideas -- including banking deregulation, tax-free savings accounts for first-time homebuyers and a cut in the tax on capital gains -- that he has previously proposed and has often berated Congress for not addressing.
 
Economy Is Called 'Awful'
 One executive who attended another private session on the economy with Mr. Bush, this one at the Mercantile Exchange, Louis A. Holland, said that bankers and others told the President that the economy was "awful."
"We really didn't get any strong feeling from him as to what would be proposed, so I think it's going to be more of the same," said Mr. Holland, a managing partner of the investment firm Holland Capital Management. He nevertheless called the session a "net positive," saying: "You can solve the problem if you recognize it, and I think the light has finally come on."
Roger Carlson, a mercantile exchange trader who listened to Mr. Bush's speech, was more skeptical. "I'll wait till January 1992 to see what he comes out with," he said later.
The President also sought today to throw cold water on the announcement of a rival Republican, the political commentator Patrick J. Buchanan, that he will run against Mr. Bush in the New Hampshire primary. Mr. Buchanan has frequently attacked Mr. Bush's support of free trade and his internationalist viewpoint.
Today Mr. Bush warned that the nation must not retreat from its economic troubles into "some isolationist sphere, listening to the siren call of 'America first.' "
"I learned that lesson as a young kid, just at the beginning of World War II," he said, "and I don't want to see this country go back to America first' and protection. That will shrink markets and throw people out of work. And we need to stand together against that call form the left and against the call from the right, to stay within ourselves. We owe the world leadership, and they're going to get it from this President."
The visual highlight of the President's Chicago visit was easily his trip to the mercantile exchange floor, an acre-sized room dominated by four huge "pits" that deal in agricultural commodities and financial instruments. The President took about 20 minutes to cross the floor, parting a literal sea of traders in bright red, blue and orange coats who cheered "U.S.A., U.S.A." when they were not clamoring to buy and sell.
A vice president and chief spokesman for the exchange, Andrew Yemma, said the traders produce a "report card" on Mr. Bush's handling of the economy and world events every day, pushing the price of commodities and financial instruments up or down based on their reading of global events.
The exchange would amass a record volume of trades this year, he said, eclipsing the old record of 102 million set in 1989. In no small part, he said, that reflects fears about the economy, because the exchange is the forum where investors seek to hedge against the risks of sudden drops in the values of their holdings.

HEADLINE: Study Shows Improvement In Service On Subways

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
The on-time performance of New York City's subway during the morning rush hours showed "significant improvement" between 1988 and 1990, according to a report released yesterday.
Eighty-five percent of all trains between 7 and 9 A.M. ran on time last year, the study, by the Inspector General of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, determined. In 1988, only 76 percent of the trains were on time during the same hours, a previous study by the Inspector General found. 
 Trains are considered on time if they are within five minutes of their schedule, under definitions of the Transit Authority, an M.T.A. subsidiary, which operates the city's subways and buses.
The report found that only 5 percent of all trains were late by more than 10 minutes last year, compared with 9 percent in 1988. The proportion of trains running ahead of schedule also showed a marked improvement, the report said. In 1990, 26 percent of the morning rush-hour trains were early, compared with 12 percent in 1988.
The Inspector General, John S. Pritchard 3d, cited a number of reasons for the improved performance. Billions of dollars have been spent on the subway system over the last decade, he said, for new and rebuilt cars, new tracks and other equipment. In all, the M.T.A. has spent $16 billion since 1981 to upgrade the city subway and the Long Island and Metro-North commuter railroads.
Mr. Pritchard also credited other changes with affecting the quality of service, including a decline in ridership because of the recession, which reduced overcrowding on some lines, and the creation of skip-stop service on two subway lines, the J and Z and the 1 and 9.
The report was released just as the M.T.A., Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and the State Legislature were considering how to avoid a large increase in the subway and bus fare, to $1.40 from the current $1.15, on Jan. 1. The Transit Authority proposed the increase last month, and the M.T.A. board is scheduled to vote on it on Dec. 20.
Mr. Pritchard said the timing of the report's release was coincidental. His researchers have been working on the study for some time, he said, and he wanted to produce it before the end of the year.
"We're an independent agency," he said in an interview. "We're not about to try to curry favor with the M.T.A. and the T.A."
But some do connect the report's findings with the political battle over the subway's financial future. The Straphangers' Campaign, a riders' group, said that while it had some quarrels with specifics of the report, the overall significance was to demonstrate the value of spending to upgrade the subway.
The M.T.A.'s second five-year rebuilding plan will end on Jan. 1, and transit officials have proposed a third five-year plan, which will cost $10.6 billion. The proposal is stalled in the Legislature.
The report's most significant lesson, said Gene Russianoff, staff attorney for the Straphangers' Campaign, "is that you get better subway cars and fewer breakdowns if you spend money to buy new subway cars or fix old ones."
"If the Governor doesn't exercise some leadership soon," Mr. Russianoff said, "the next phase of the rebuilding effort isn't looking so good."
The study showed that some lines -- including the J, G, L and N trains, and the 1 and 3 trains -- had on-time records of at least 90 percent last year. The worst lines were the E and F, which had on-time rates of 77 percent.
Mr. Pritchard noted that his objective measures may not be in line with commuters' subjective experience. Nonetheless, he said, "This segment of the subway's performance is important. Improvements have been made in the system, and that to us is very encouraging."

HEADLINE: Unlikely Bedfellows Put New Spin on Trenton Tax Debate

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Dec. 10

 BODY:
Like a troupe of dismayed and disillusioned Aladdins, Trenton Republicans and their allies in business, who wished for a rollback of the new taxes imposed by the Democrats last year, are trying desperately to coax the genie back into the magic lamp. Their wish may suddenly be granted, and they don't like it a bit.
To make matters more puzzling, the people trying to grant the Republicans' wish are the Democrats, the very ones who imposed the $2.8 billion increase in the first place.
All this came into sharp if confusing focus Monday, when the Democrats began committee hearings on a package of bills that would repeal every penny of the increase they passed last year with such fervor that the critical vote was cast by an ailing Democratic Senator who checked out of a hospital so he could be present. 
 On Monday that same Senator, 72-year-old Walter Rand of Camden, a senior member of the Senate Appropriations Committee, made it clear that he was ready to repeal the entire increase and let the Republicans do what they want to replace the revenue it generates.
 
No Republicans at Hearing
 In a sense, Mr. Rand played to an empty hall: no Republicans showed up for the committee hearing, and they boycotted a full session of the Assembly at which the Democrats planned to introduce the same tax repeal package.
And business representatives, who last year paraded to the witness stand to oppose the tax increase, got in line to on Monday oppose its repeal. They argued that repealing the taxes would send the state even further into an economic tailspin.
The Democrats' reasoning in moving to repeal the very taxes they imposed just 18 months ago is largely political but partly governmental.
"It's not sour grapes," insists Senator Laurence S. Weiss of Woodbridge, the chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee. He was both a point man in writing and shepherding through the tax-increase legislation last year and a leading proponent of repealing it this year. "The voters have sent a message," he said, "and we heard it loud and clear, nobody more than I did." Mr. Weiss was defeated in his bid for re-election after 14 years in the Senate, with 11 years as appropriations chairman.
Mr. Weiss and other Democrats concede that they simply cannot get the message across on their own that the taxes were necessary and that cutting them would mean unnacceptable reductions in state employment, programs and services.
So the Democrats reason that if they remove the taxes, the Republicans, who are to take control of the Legislature next year with overwhelming majorities in both houses, will have to enact new taxes to replace most of them. The Republicans have pledged only to reduce the sales tax by a penny, which would eliminate only $590 million of the $2.8 billion increase.
The Democrats also reason that many Republicans who took no-tax pledges during the campaign will not vote to raise taxes in any case. So if the Republicans do have to restore some revenue, they will need Democratic help. That would give the Democrats some leverage, though they will be outnumbered, 58 to 22 in the Assembly and 27 to 13 in the Senate.
The Republicans are not saying so, but they basically agree with that line of reasoning. They campaigned relentlessly and unequivocally against the entire tax package. But now that they are preparing to take control of the Legislature, such Republican leaders as Garabed (Chuck) Haytaian, who is to become the Assembly Speaker in January, maintain that they never promised to roll back all the taxes, just the one-cent sales tax increase. That suggests, of course, that the Republicans are willing to allow the remaining $2.3 billion to stand.
But as the inconsistency of their new position began to dawn, the Republicans changed their tactic. Mr. Haytaian now says, "Go ahead, make my day." Nonetheless, the Republicans refused even to show up when the Democrats forged ahead on Monday with their proposals to repeal all the taxes.
John Budzash, a co-founder of Hands Across New Jersey, the tax protest group that was instrumental in creating the public outcry that led to the Democratic rout, said at the hearing that the Republicans were "cowards for not showing up" to debate the issue after winning election "on the coattails of the tax revolt."
Mr. Budzash, once an ally of the Republicans, parted company with both them and Hands Across New Jersey when the Republicans reneged on a promise to support legislation to allow citizen lawmaking through initiative and referendum.
But the politicians were not the only ones doing turnabouts. James Morford of the New Jersey Chamber of Commerce and Bruce Coe of the New Jersey Business and Industry Association -- both groups that opposed the increases originally -- implored the committee on Monday not to roll back the taxes. Doing so, they asserted, would send shock waves of uncertainty through the business community.
That is no doubt true; business abhors uncertainty, even with a Republican majority in control of the Legislature.
But there was another factor at work, the possibility that if the taxes were repealed and had to be replaced, it would be business and industry, which largely escaped new taxes in the last increase, that would take the heaviest hit.
Indeed, New Jersey Citizen Action, a coalition representing labor unions, church groups, consumers and civil rights groups, said in written testimony filed with the committee that "the time has come for corporations" that are "not paying their fair share to pay up."
Business and industry interests would just as soon not face that kind of sentiment if a new round of taxing takes place next year.

HEADLINE: Fed Official Optimistic On Growth

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

 BODY:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 --
The economy is not so weak as is popularly believed, and a resumption of solid growth is very likely by mid-1992, the second-ranking Federal Reserve Board official said today, despite what he called a "pervasive sourness" among both business people and consumers.
Asked when expansion would again reach a fairly normal 2 1/2 percent to 3 percent pace, David W. Mullins Jr., the Fed's vice chairman, declared, "It looks promising that we could be back on that path sometime next year -- late spring, early summer." He added, "It looks promising, certainly by midyear we should be back squarely in the positive growth category." 
 The comments by Mr. Mullins, who attracted a standing-room audience and three dozen reporters to a luncheon of the National Economists Club at the Library of Congress, appeared to undermine the bond market, where prices fell and interest rates rose during the afternoon. [Page D14.]
 
Tenor of Comments
 Many analysts and market participants have been expecting the Fed to cut rates further to aid a faltering recovery, and Mr. Mullins did not directly or even indirectly rule this out. But the tenor of his comments was that there would be little urgency to cut rates when the Federal Open Market Committee meets next week to set a monetary course into early February.
He said he saw no evidence of cumulative deterioration in the economy -- a new downturn -- that might require such action, and Mr. Mullins argued at another point that a "substantial amount" of the monetary stimulus the Fed had already supplied had yet to emerge from the pipeline.
The full effect of lower rates will not be felt until early in the new year, Mr. Mullins said. A former Treasury official, he joined the Fed last year and became vice chairman in July.
 
Some 'Flat Quarters'
 At the same time, Mr. Mullins said he did not expect an immediate resumption of growth, suggesting there might well be "a couple of flat quarters" before it reappeared.
Over all, the vice chairman's view appeared not dissimilar to those of Michael J. Boskin, the President's chief economic adviser, and Robert Reischauer, the head of the Congressional Budget Office.
Mr. Reischauer told the House Budget Committee today, "We expect growth to be anemic at best through the spring."
In beginning his presentation, Mr. Mullins tried to account for pessimism that seemed worse than warranted by available statistics, which show that while the recovery has "flattened," the economy is probably not sliding backward.
One reason, the Fed official ventured, is that many of today's consumers and businesses have never experienced recession, since none has occurred between 1982 and 1990. Compared with double-digit inflation and unemployment in the late 1970's and early 1980's, Mr. Mullins contended, "There doesn't seem to be all that much to be pessimistic about" today.
 
'Insatiable' Media Appetite
 Mr. Mullins also cited political opportunism, a seemingly "insatiable" media appetite for negative stories, immobilized fiscal policy and heightened public vulnerability to bad news when growth is slow and the wealth of many, including homeowners, is shrinking.
But he said the more fundamental obstacle to renewed economic growth was the lingering effects of the excesses of the 1980's, particularly the overreliance on debt and leverage. The correction of these imbalances, a process that cannot be evaded or short-circuited, is made more difficult because they all involve financial institutions, many of which have become reluctant lenders, Mr. Mullins said.
The Fed official took a relatively sanguine view of inflation, saying he saw no evidence that upward price pressure was building and that he found it hard to imagine sustained high inflation in view of modest recent growth in money and credit. But Mr. Mullins also indicated that the Fed had not forgotten its commitment to bring inflation down further, with today's circumstances offering a rare opportunity to take "a bite" out of inflation for the longer term.

HEADLINE: Senate Delays Tax Decision After Narrow House Vote

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Dec. 10

 BODY:
A scheduled Senate vote to consider repeal of Connecticut's three-month-old tax on wages was scrubbed today, with opponents and supporters asking for another 24 hours to regroup and rethink their strategies after the vote in the House of Representatives on Monday night.
The vote in the House to repeal the wage tax was 86 to 63, well short of the 101 votes that would be needed to override Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s certain veto. Repeal leaders had said before the House debate that they were within five or six votes of the 101-vote threshold, which marks the two-thirds majority in the 151-member chamber. 
 Lawmakers said that in the wake of the House vote, Senators on both sides of the issue had filed amendments, some intended to make the bill more palatable in the other chamber, and some intended to substitute legislation that would simply use the repeal bill as a vehicle for less drastic change, like an amendment to the income tax on the books. If the Senate amends the plan, the House would have to debate and vote again, perhaps late Wednesday or Thursday.
"There's a wider range of options now," said Senator William H. Nickerson, a Republican from Greenwich who opposes the repeal. "It's like the engine that drives it is not as strong," he said, referring to the bill passed by the House. "There's a desire to use it to go in other directions."
Lawmakers convened last month to consider overturning the new wage tax, which has evoked anger from one end of the state to other, culminating last month in a rally at the Capitol that drew more than 40,000 protesters.
 
Budget Gaps Predicted

 The bill passed by the House on Monday would eliminate the wage tax, set at a flat rate of 4.5 percent, and make up the $1 billion in lost revenue by cutting spending and by raising other taxes, notably the sales tax, which would rise from 6 percent to 8.25 percent. The changes would affect the $7.6 billion budget for the year that ends June 30.
In the House debate, the bill was attacked by critics both for the types of cuts -- in particular a $50 million reduction in the state's contribution to the general assistance welfare system -- and for the economic assumptions behind the plan.
The legislature's Office of Fiscal Analysis issued a report just before the debate began, saying that weak tax collections because of the recession could result in a budget gap of up to $1.25 billion in the year that begins July 1 if the bill becomes law. Even the current budget, with the income tax in place, might face a gap of up to $770 million, the report said.
The co-chairman of the Legislature's Appropriations Committee, Senator Joseph H. Harper Jr., said that amendments would probably be offered in the Senate to break out parts of the bill, especially on spending cuts, and vote on them separately.
Mr. Harper said that if enough Senators concluded that the House was incapable of mustering the additional votes needed to override Mr. Weicker's veto, momentum would grow to forge some package that might survive, either because Mr. Weicker would not veto it, or because two-thirds of the House could support it.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Top Position Is Filled At Burson-Marsteller

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
The past few years have been difficult ones for the public relations business, as corporate clients have tightened budgets. But Larry E. Snoddon, who was named yesterday as the new president and chief executive of Burson-Marsteller, has enjoyed rapid growth as head of the firm's European business since 1987. Since then, Burson-Marsteller's European business has nearly tripled to $70 million a year in fee income, the equivalent of revenues.
The European business has expanded not only by advising American and European corporations gearing up for the 1992 single European market, but also with more unusual projects like advising the Polish Government on privatization issues and working with the German Ministry of Economics to develop educational programs for the nation's new citizens from eastern Germany. "We're basically trying to tell them what it's like to live in a free-enterprise system," Mr. Snoddon, (pronounced Snow-Don), said. 
 Mr. Snoddon, who is 46 years old, will succeed James H. Dowling, who moves up to chairman. Harold Burson will assume the new title of founder chairman. The changes are effective Jan. 1.
In the chairman's post, Mr. Dowling, 60 years old, will be "deeply involved with client development," said Mr. Snoddon, who as chief executive will be in charge of managing the firm.
Burson-Marsteller, the second-largest international public relations firm, after Shandwick P.L.C., is having a fairly strong year despite the recession. Mr. Snoddon estimates that Burson-Marsteller's fee income will increase this year to about $220 million, up from about $210 million in 1990. Both Shandwick, whose share price dropped sharply in London yesterday after it announced that 1991 would be disappointing, and Hill & Knowlton, the third-largest firm, are expected to post lower fee income this year. Burson-Marsteller, with more than 2,000 employees in 29 countries, is a subsidiary of Young & Rubicam Inc.
Mr. Snoddon, who joined the firm in 1972 after working for the General Motors Corporation and the American Express Company, says public relations firms must become increasingly sophisticated, with specialists in a variety of disciplines. He cited as an example the firm's winning of an account this week for the Beef Industry Council, the producers' trade group. Burson-Marsteller specialists on government policy from Washington, health-care experts and others helped garner the account, worth roughly $1 million a year in fees.
"That multi-disciplinary approach is the direction things are headed, and it was also a good-sized account in this day and age," Mr. Snoddon said.

HEADLINE: Hard Times Present Hard Choices

BYLINE: By J. PEDER ZANE

 BODY:
For charities around the New York region, the current hard times mean more than rising caseloads. They mean hard choices -- choices that in some cases include cutting off funds to programs whose value has been proved, simply because the money is not available or is needed more desperately elsewhere.
When officials at the Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service contemplate such cuts, they think of two women who almost lost their children to foster care: a 30-year-old with AIDS who faced frequent hospital stays, and a 27-year-old mother of three who was winning her battle with drugs, but who was kept away from home by her daily counseling sessions. 
 They were able to keep their families intact because the bureau used city funds to provide them with homemakers who could feed, clothe and supervise their children when they were away.
But many other families will not be as lucky. In response to the city's fiscal crisis, the Human Resources Administration cut funding for the homemaker program by $232,000 this year, to $1.68 million.
"In human terms, it means that 35 to 50 more children are now at great risk of ending up in foster care," said Gen Wiltshire, director of the bureau's homemaker program. "Money-wise, everybody also loses in the long run because it costs at least $14,000 a year to keep a child in foster care while it's about $4,200 a year to provide a child with a homemaker."
Ms. Wiltshire's warning is being echoed at nonprofit agencies throughout the city that are being called on to provide greater services because of the recession while being furnished with less money from governments that are cutting back. They are scaling back or eliminating programs that teach youngsters about drugs, that keep the elderly out of nursing homes and that help the homeless renovate abandoned buildings.
Formerly these agencies relied primarily on private donations to aid services to the sick and poor. But in the last three decades, as government began assuming broad responsibility for helping these people, it provided funding that allowed nonprofit groups to expand their services.
However, this reliance on government has in fact made private donations even more important to nonprofit organizations, including the seven charities supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. "The government gives us a specific, generally slightly inadequate, amount of money to provide a specific service," said Msgr. Timothy McDonnell, the chief operating officer of Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York. "The donations from the Neediest Cases are generally unrestricted so we can use them to make up deficits, provide emergency services or anywhere else there is a great need."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up in Quiet Trading On Talk About Gorbachev

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar closed higher in quiet trading yesterday, helped by rumors -- later denied -- that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev was going to resign soon.
"There was a short-covering rally and apprehension about" the Soviet Union, said Matthew Robertson, vice president at Banque Nationale de Paris in New York. Nonetheless, market sentiment remained bearish toward the dollar, because of economic weakness in the United States, traders said. 
 The dollar closed at 1.5820 German marks, up from Monday's finish of 1.5715. Against the Japanese yen, it closed at 128.80, up from Monday's 128.27.
Whatever the final outcome in the Soviet Union, traders are concerned about the potential for chaos. Most players are betting that the dollar will fall in the near term, so a catastrophe in the Soviet Union would mean a significant rally for the currency, Mr. Robertson said.
The mark suffers from unrest in the Soviet Union because of Germany's close geographical and economic ties to the region.
The market was also carefully watching the European summit meeting in Maastricht, the Netherlands. European Community leaders agreed on a common foreign and military policy today.
Community leaders also agreed on a joint military policy and reached the outlines of a deal with Britain on social affairs that could clear the way for a political and monetary union treaty.
But several issues remained unresolved, and officials said talks were likely to continue late into the night.
A successful conclusion to the summit meeting would push European currencies slightly higher, traders said.
They said the marked weakness of the American economy would be likely to pull the dollar back down in coming sessions. That sense of weakness was reinforced by President Bush's statement that he is not happy with the economy's condition.
Frank Pusateri, vice president at First National Bank of Boston, predicted that the dollar would trade in ranges of 1.5650 to 1.5800 marks and 128 to 129 yen tomorrow.
In other trading, the British pound closed at $1.8060, down from $1.8110.
The dollar ended at 1.3970 Swiss francs, up from 1.3935 at Monday's close, and at 5.4055 French francs, up from 5.3690.
The United States currency ended at 1.1370 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1360 on Monday.
